webTitle: Charlton capture Kitson for the run-in

fields.headline: Charlton capture Kitson for the run-in
fields.trailText: West Ham's Paul Kitson has joined Charlton on loan for the rest of the season and may make his debut when Grimsby visit the Valley this evening.
fields.body:
West Ham's Paul Kitson has joined Charlton on loan for the rest of the season and may make his debut when Grimsby visit the Valley this evening.

Kitson, who moved from Newcastle to West Ham for £2.3m in 1997, has struggled to make a first-team impact this season because of injury.

Everton have rejected Sunderland's £1m bid for Don Hutchison with a further £1m linked to games. "We believe £3m is a sensible figure and he will not be leaving this club for anything less than that," a Goodison spokesman said.

Millwall have signed the Wycombe right-back Matt Lawrence for £200,000. Leicester are looking to buy Nottingham Forest's Andy Johnson as his manager David Platt has been told to sell before increasing an offer for Manchester City's Tony Vaughan after having a bid, of around £300,000 turned down.

Emile Heskey and five other senior contenders will lend a heavyweight presence to England's attempt to reach the Under-21 European championship finals via the play-off with Yugoslavia in Barcelona next Wednesday. The £11m Liverpool striker, fresh from an impressive senior debut, spearheads a strong junior squad.

Kieron Dyer and Rio Ferdinand, who played alongside Heskey against Argentina at Wembley last month, are joined in Howard Wilkinson's 23-strong party for Barcelona by Steven Gerrard, Gareth Barry and Richard Wright, who have also been in Keegan squads.

But the chances of Joe Cole leaping into the Euro 2000 frame are likely to be reduced further. After being given only 45 minutes for the Under-21s against Argentina at Craven Cottage, the West Ham teenager is again likely to start on the bench in Barcelona.

webTitle: Court appearance rules Australian out of Bolton's promotion charge

fields.headline: Court appearance rules Australian out of Bolton's promotion charge
fields.trailText: Con Boutsianis, the Australian midfielder who joined Bolton on loan from Perth Glory last week, seems likely to miss out on his new club's run-in to the season as he will be required in a Melbourne court to answer two charges of armed robbery and two more of false imprisonment.
fields.body:
Con Boutsianis, the Australian midfielder who joined Bolton on loan from Perth Glory last week, seems likely to miss out on his new club's run-in to the season as he will be required in a Melbourne court to answer two charges of armed robbery and two more of false imprisonment.

Boutsianis, 28, training with ninth-placed Bolton but who has yet to play as he is awaiting international clearance, was summoned for trial on May 15, two days after the play-offs start and five days before the FA Cup final. Bolton face Aston Villa in the FA Cup semi-final on Sunday week, with the final taking place on May 20.

Sam Allardyce, Bolton's manager, said: "If there is something, it's a problem. As far as I know, he says he has no case to answer."

The armed robbery charges had been discharged against Boutsianis during December, 1998, but were later resurrected by Victoria's Office of Public Prosecutions, which overturned a preliminary hearing decision not to send the player and his co-defendant for trial because of lack of evidence.

The charges relate to a raid on the head office of a restaurant chain in January 1998. Boutsianis was arrested last April and pleaded not guilty. It had been alleged that he was the getaway driver.

Ajax yesterday sacked their coach Jan Wouters and asked the youth coach Hans Westerhof to take over until the end of the season. "Jan Wouters has understood the decision, bearing in mind the sporting results," the club said in a statement. Ajax, who celebrated their centenary last weekend, slipped to fifth last Sunday after a 1-0 defeat by visiting Twente Enschede.

Not to be outdone Salernitana also fired their coach, Gigi Cagni, but replaced him with his predecessor Adriano Cadregari, despite the team sitting only four points from a Serie B promotion place.

Cagni took over five games into this season. "I got 35 points from 22 games and took the side from fourth from bottom of the table to the edge of Serie A," he said. "That is what the numbers say, but the numbers don't explain my dismissal."

Australia's coach Frank Farina has disregarded the concerns of several English clubs and named his strongest squad to face the Czech Republic in Teplice next Wednesday. "It's the teams looking at promotion or relegation, that's where the problems are coming from," Farina said.

Full squad : Bosnich (Man Utd), Muscat (Wolves), Moore (Rangers), Okon (Fiorentina, capt), Popovic (Sanfrecce Hiroshima), Skoko (Racing Genk), Johnson (Watford), Lazaridis (Birmingham), Viduka (Celtic), Kewell (Leeds), Agostino (1860 Munich), Van Blerk (West Brom), Foster (Crystal Palace), Corica (Sanfrecce Hiroshima), Murphy (Sheff Utd), Tiatto (Man City), Casserly (Northern Spirit), Kalac (Roda).

fields.headline: Brown sticks to trusted formula
fields.trailText: Faced with the prospect of playing the world champions, Craig Brown decided yesterday not to stray far from the squad that beat England at Wembley in November.
fields.body:
Faced with the prospect of playing the world champions, Craig Brown decided yesterday not to stray far from the squad that beat England at Wembley in November.

Seven of the players likely to start the friendly at Hampden Park are thirty-somethings. Even the stripling, Rangers' Barry Ferguson, is knocking on 23.

"There's no need for wholesale experiments," Brown said. "We have lost only one of our last six games - against England at Hampden - so we ended our European qualifiers strongly. Anyway, is there someone else I could have picked?"

Many believe he should have selected the newest phenomenon, Hibernian's teenager Kenny Miller, who has scored against Rangers and Celtic recently and whom many sound judges reckon could turn out to be a more influential player than Mark Burchill, who was given a chance at the same age.

Brown disagrees. "He has made only 13 starts this season and, remember, he was also on loan to Stenhousemuir. His time will come but at best he would have been on the bench and it is better to give him an Under-21 game. Remember Burchill played 17 minutes at Wembley and did not deserve to be left out."

Perhaps a bigger worry for Brown is that his four strikers have played only 71 games this season for a total of 12 goals.

Scotland (v France, Hampden Park, March 29): Douglas (Dundee), Gould (Celtic), Sullivan (Wimbledon); Boyd (Celtic), Dailly (Blackburn), Elliott (Leicester), Hendry (Coventry), O'Neil (Wolfsburg), Ritchie (Hearts), Weir (Everton), Burley (Derby), Cameron (Hearts), Davidson (Blackburn), Ferguson (Rangers), Hutchison (Everton), Johnston (Sunderland), McNamara (Celtic), Burchill (Celtic), Dodds (Rangers), Gallacher (Newcastle), McCann (Rangers).

webTitle: Sedgley strikes to help satisfy Wolves' promotion hunger

fields.headline: Sedgley strikes to help satisfy Wolves' promotion hunger
fields.trailText: Wolves 2 - 2 Crewe
fields.body:
Wolverhampton Wanderers maintained their quest for a play-off place last night with a victory that did Crewe Alexandra's hopes of First Division survival few favours.

Yet, with both teams needing the points for different reasons, this was a curiously subdued affair: perhaps the finishing-straight jitters are already taking hold with eight games to play.

That cautious approach was reflected by the Wolves line-up, although their manager Colin Lee will doubtless claim the end justified the means.

The final play-off place could yet be determined by goal difference and Wolves need to improve theirs. But Lee opted to replace his suspended striker Ade Akinbiyi with a midfielder in Neil Emblen.

And given the territorial superiority Wolves enjoyed in the first period, how they could have done with Akinbiyi or even Haavard Flo, who was left on the bench after suffering a dead leg against Swindon on Saturday.

Chances were created and wasted and Wolves had to rely on Emblen's partner in the Old Gold engine room, Steve Sedgley, to provide the solitary goal of the half.

He did so in the 13th minute courtesy of a convoluted free-kick routine that looked as though it had been choreographed by Torvill and Dean and a fortunate deflection.

Scott Taylor and Emblen looked as though they had wasted the opportunity on the edge of the penalty area when they almost fell over each other's feet. But Sedgley restored order with a left-foot shot that was deflected past Jason Kearton.

Wolves' other chances of the half were more straightforward: Michael Branch was thwarted by a tackle from David Walton, an Emblen header hit the crossbar and Kearton saved comfortably from two headers following corners.

But the crispest manoeuvre of the period belonged to the visitors. In their solitary sortie into the penalty area, Colin Cramb's first-time left-foot shot from Mark Rivers's cross resulted in the admirably alert Michael Oakes diving to his right for a one-handed save.

With Wolves pitching camp in the visiting half immediately after the restart, it was as though the two periods were seamless. Their endeavours finally paid off in the 68th minute, however, when Scott Taylor latched on to a through ball from Carl Robinson and settled matters with a right-foot shot past Kearton.

 Marlon Harewood made it two goals in two games for Nottingham Forest, but Chris Beech soon equalised for Huddersfield and Chris Holland secured the points which kept them in sixth place, two points ahead of Wolves.

webTitle: Jobson to the rescue for stumbling City

fields.headline: Jobson to the rescue for stumbling City
fields.trailText: Stocckport 2 - 2 Man City
fields.body:
The fragile nature of Manchester City's promotion challenge was further exposed last night when they were held to a draw by Stockport County, a team who have now not won for 15 matches, equalling an invidious club record.

Joe Royle's team had themselves gone seven matches without a victory and his hopes that City had emerged from a lull after their draw against top of the table Charlton Athletic last Sunday were immediately proved premature. With a little more composure, and a goalkeeper less talented than City's Nick Weaver, Stockport could, and perhaps should, have won.

Having not seen their team win since Boxing Day, County supporters were hoping this high-tension clash might finally proffer some much-needed inspiration. But there was not even time for perspiration before City were ahead.

Mark Kennedy's surge down the left saw County's defence horribly stretched and it seemed Robert Taylor's pow erful header might have the beating of Carlo Nash before Jamie Pollock intervened to make absolutely sure.

County's collective deflation was obvious, what bit of confidence they possessed before the kick-off leaking into the night sky. City strutted; City paraded. Expectations of another goal and a comfortable win were abundant.

But this was a derby and gradually Stockport regrouped, revved themselves up and began to press hard and long as City's initial composure frayed at the edges.

Stockport were beginning to believe in themselves and a brilliant through ball by Karim Fradin saw them equalise. City's defence had pushed up hard and Fradin's perceptive pass sent in Ian Moore with only Weaver to beat, which he did with ease.

Stockport were transformed although it took a fine save by Nash to deny Pollock before Mike Flynn bundled in a Gibb corner just before half-time as the home side completely turned the first half around.

On the hour City pulled off midfielder Ian Bishop and replaced him with the striker Paul Dickov in a desperate attempt to re-vitalise themselves, this after both Connelly and Moore might have put Stockport further ahead.

Dickov's arrival had no immediate effect except to underline the feverish nature of City's response. But an injury to Stockport central defender James Gannon proved just a little too much for the home side to bear with Richard Jobson heading the equaliser from Edgehill's right wing cross ten minutes from time.

fields.headline: Burnley take Branch line
fields.trailText: Blackpool 1 - 1 Burnley
fields.body:
Blackpool's anticipated resurgence under Steve McMahon was again put on hold last night when the Burnley full-back Graham Branch's 72nd-minute equaliser cancelled out Wayne Gill's fourth goal in as many games.

The result was a bitter disappointment for Blackpool who desperately needed three points to haul them away from the foot of the table.

Not surprisingly for a team under the direction of McMahon, Blackpool displayed an early resolve that suggested they had the stomach for the fight that looms between now and the end of the season. Not that the Bloomfield Road faithful have any doubts about McMahon's powers of salvation. His appointment in January, accompanied by the news that the crumbling old stadium is to be redeveloped, has engendered an unlikely sense of optimism on this part of the Fylde coast.

McMahon has wheeled and dealed with admirable prudence to rebuild his team with a collection of loan signings and free transfers, combining old heads like Mike Newell, Kevin Richardson and Gary Ablett with younger talent.

The Clarets' wing-back Glen Little enjoyed the freedom of the right flank and was unfortunate to see his low 16th-minute cross evade the runs of strikers Andy Payton and Andy Cooke. Surprisingly it was Payton, the division's 22-goal leading scorer, who missed the best chance of the first half, firing a snap shot that produced a point blank save from Phil Barnes.

Three minutes after the break Newell, whose tireless running has not been curtailed by advancing years, found space to send in a left wing cross towards the head of Jason Thomas. Thomas's knock-down was skilfully gathered by the midfielder Gill who advanced five yards before calmly tucking the ball past Phil Crichton.

Inspired by the substitute Ian Wright, Burnley equalised. Typically the goal came from a Little cross that worked its way across the edge of the box to Branch whose first-time shot gave Barnes no chance.

webTitle: United make most of Spanish stroll

fields.headline: United make most of Spanish stroll
fields.standfirst:
Valencia join top-of-the-table holders in the quarter-finals
Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: Manchester United's place in the quarter-finals of the Champions League as winners of their group was never in serious doubt here last night. While Valencia produced enough attacking flair to give Sir Alex Ferguson's defenders a decent workout, and hit a post in the first half, the possibility of United losing by a big enough margin to be forced into second place was always remote.
fields.byline: David Lacey at the Mestalla stadium
fields.body:
Manchester United's place in the quarter-finals of the Champions League as winners of their group was never in serious doubt here last night. While Valencia produced enough attacking flair to give Sir Alex Ferguson's defenders a decent workout, and hit a post in the first half, the possibility of United losing by a big enough margin to be forced into second place was always remote.

With Valencia needing just a point to qualify and Manchester United one to ensure finishing top of the group the game was unlikely to suffer from over-ambition by either side. Whatever Ferguson's fears might have been about Spanish kamikaze tactics Hector Cuper, Valencia's Argentine coach, had made it clear his team would not be committing suicide in search of the three-goal victory they required to go above United.

With David Beckham suspended for this match and Ryan Giggs back home protecting a vulnerable hamstring United did not want to find themselves in the position of having to chase the game to win the group. And staying top was important if the likes of Bayern Munich, Barcelona and maybe Chelsea were to be avoided in Friday's quarter-final draw.

Ferguson, however, still decided to rest his first-choice strikers, Dwight Yorke and Andy Cole, which meant starting with Teddy Sheringham and Ole Gunnar Solskjaer. At least a degree of continuity was preserved since on United's previous visit to Spain Sheringham and Solskjaer had scored the late goals in Barcelona to bring the European Cup back to Old Trafford.

Not that the United attack exactly snapped into immediate action. They were always likely to keep the game at a moderate tempo if they could and from the start there was a tendency to leisurely string passes together like men building a rope bridge on their day off.

With Valencia it was rather different. Unbeaten at home in European competitions for 7 years it clearly never occurred to them that they might lose now.

So Mark Bosnich found himself busy more or less straight away as Claudio Lopez, Angulo and Gerard infiltrated space between United's midfield and defence. Within seven minutes a header from Gerard and a 25-yard drive from Kily Gonzalez had drawn sharp saves from the United goalkeeper.

Manchester United did not think of scoring until the quarter-hour, just after a shot from Sanchez had been deflected past their near post. An excellent centre by Quinton Fortune, Giggs's replacement on the left wing, found Sheringham unmarked at the far post. His header was true but blocked by Canizares.

After that United's football became more lively. Paul Scholes set up Sheringham for the low cross from the right which Solskjaer met at full stretch, Canizares saving the Norwegian's shot near the right-hand post.

Eleven minutes before half-time Jocelyn Angloma, Valencia's French right-back, did rather better. His swerving shot from 25 yards beat Bosnich and was worthy of a goal. Instead the ball rebounded from the far post.

The longer the game progressed the more Angulo emerged as the prime creative force for Valencia. And had Lopez, winning a race with Bosnich for a ball rolling across the penalty area, not pulled out as the goalkeeper lunged for it United might have fallen behind.

The pattern was much as before. While the contest never became a mere sparring match neither did it become, in the football sense, a matter of life and death. Yet Valencia continued to find the thought of beating the European champions sufficiently attractive to press home their attacks with some vigour and shortly before the hour, following Lopez's corner, Angloma headed into Bosnich's hands from close range.

With Solskjaer giving way to Jordi Cruyff, United played the last 25 minutes of the game content to leave Sheringham largely on his own up front.

Valencia then introduced the Romanian striker Adrian Ilie, although by now it was clear that both teams had got what they wanted.

 Two goals in the last three minutes earned Bordeaux a 3-3 draw in Fiorentina in the other match in Group B, but the result was rendered irrelevant by Valencia's draw. Enrico Chiesa, Gabriel Batistuta and Rui Costa scored three goals in 17 second-half minutes for Fiorentina.

Valencia: Canizares; Angloma, Djukic, Pellegrino, Carboni; Angulo, Farinos, Gerard, Kily Gonzalez; C Lopez, Sanchez (Ilie, 71min)].

Manchester United: Bosnich; G Neville, Stam, Berg, Irwin; Scholes, Keane, Butt, Fortune; Sheringham, Solskjaer (Cruyff, 68).

Referee: L Michel (Slovakia).

With David Beckham suspended for this match and Ryan Giggs back home protecting a vulnerable hamstring United did not want to find themselves in the position of having to chase the game to win the group. And staying top was important if the likes of Bayern Munich, Barcelona and maybe Chelsea were to be avoided in Friday's quarter-final draw. Ferguson, however, still decided to rest his first-choice strikers, Dwight Yorke and Andy Cole, which meant starting with Teddy Sheringham and Ole Gunnar Solskjaer. At least a degree of continuity was preserved since on United's previous visit to Spain Sheringham and Solskjaer had scored the late goals in Barcelona to bring the European Cup back to Old Trafford. Not that the United attack exactly snapped into immediate action. They were always likely to keep the game at a moderate tempo if they could and from the start there was a tendency to leisurely string passes together like men building a rope bridge on their day off. With Valencia it was rather different. Unbeaten at home in European competitions for 7 years it clearly never occurred to them that they might lose now. So Mark Bosnich found himself busy more or less straight away as Claudio Lopez, Angulo and Gerard infiltrated space between United's midfield and defence. Within seven minutes a header from Gerard and a 25-yard drive from Kily Gonzalez had drawn sharp saves from the United goalkeeper. Manchester United did not think of scoring until the quarter-hour, just after a shot from Sanchez had been deflected past their near post. An excellent centre by Quinton Fortune, Giggs's replacement on the left wing, found Sheringham unmarked at the far post. His header was true but blocked by Canizares. After that United's football became more lively. Paul Scholes set up Sheringham for the low cross from the right which Solskjaer met at full stretch, Canizares saving the Norwegian's shot near the right-hand post. Eleven minutes before half-time Jocelyn Angloma, Valencia's French right-back, did rather better. His swerving shot from 25 yards beat Bosnich and was worthy of a goal. Instead the ball rebounded from the far post. The longer the game progressed the more Angulo emerged as the prime creative force for Valencia. And had Lopez, winning a race with Bosnich for a ball rolling across the penalty area, not pulled out as the goalkeeper lunged for it United might have fallen behind. The pattern was much as before. While the contest never became a mere sparring match neither did it become, in the football sense, a matter of life and death. Yet Valencia continued to find the thought of beating the European champions sufficiently attractive to press home their attacks with some vigour and shortly before the hour, following Lopez's corner, Angloma headed into Bosnich's hands from close range. With Solskjaer giving way to Jordi Cruyff, United played the last 25 minutes of the game content to leave Sheringham largely on his own up front. Valencia then introduced the Romanian striker Adrian Ilie, although by now it was clear that both teams had got what they wanted.  Two goals in the last three minutes earned Bordeaux a 3-3 draw in Fiorentina in the other match in Group B, but the result was rendered irrelevant by Valencia's draw. Enrico Chiesa, Gabriel Batistuta and Rui Costa scored three goals in 17 second-half minutes for Fiorentina. Manchester United: Bosnich; G Neville, Stam, Berg, Irwin; Scholes, Keane, Butt, Fortune; Sheringham, Solskjaer (Cruyff, 68). Referee: L Michel (Slovakia).

webTitle: Wise doubtful for game Lazio must win

fields.headline: Wise doubtful for game Lazio must win
fields.trailText: The little man who has played such a big part in Chelsea's European success this season could miss tonight's final second-phase game after picking up an injury in training.
fields.body:
The little man who has played such a big part in Chelsea's European success this season could miss tonight's final second-phase game after picking up an injury in training.

Dennis Wise, the captain and midfield hub, collided with Roberto di Matteo and hobbled off with a leg injury. Gianluca Vialli will make a late decision today on whether to play the England midfielder.

As Chelsea have qualified for the quarter-finals, his absence would not be catastrophic, with Jody Morris and Di Matteo more than capable deputies. But the Fulham Road club want to make sure they pick up the point they need to top the group and so avoid heavyweights such as Barcelona and Bayern Munich in Friday's quarter-final draw.

That could prove crucial to their chances of eventually winning this tournament. It is only as holders that Chelsea look likely to qualify for the Champions League next season, for they are unlikely to qualify via the Premiership.

For Lazio a draw or defeat would knock them out of the tournament. And they will be without their injured captain Alessandro Nesta.

But despite all the energy that has gone into taking Chelsea this far, Vialli insisted yesterday that winning the Premiership remains his eventual priority. And to that end he was ambivalent about stepping on to the Champions League treadmill again.

"I want to play in the Champions League but you've got more chance of concentrating on the Premier League if you're in the Uefa Cup. The domestic league will always be the most exciting thing to win for English supporters. They want to take the mickey out of Tottenham fans - Barcelona fans are a bit far away to do that."

fields.headline: Chelsea 1 - 2 Lazio
fields.trailText:
Chelsea: De Goey, Ferrer, Desailly, Leboeuf, Babayaro, Petrescu, Di Matteo, Deschamps, Poyet, Flo, Zola.
Substitutes: Cudicini, Hogh, Sutton, Ambrosetti, Morris, Thome, Harley.
fields.body:
Chelsea: De Goey, Ferrer, Desailly, Leboeuf, Babayaro, Petrescu, Di Matteo, Deschamps, Poyet, Flo, Zola.
Substitutes: Cudicini, Hogh, Sutton, Ambrosetti, Morris, Thome, Harley.

Lazio: Marchegiani, Negro, Couto, Mihajlovic, Pancaro, Stankovic, Veron, Simeone, Almeyda, Nedved, Inzaghi.
Substitutes: Ballotta, Sensini, Conceicao, Boksic, Salas, Mancini, Gottardi.

Referee: Vitor Manuel Melo Pereira (Portugal)

No British players in the starting eleven for Chelsea - skipper Dennis Wise injured in a training ground collision with Di Matteo yesterday. A draw may not be enough for Lazio tonight, so the game should be an open, attacking affair.

1 min Lazio kick off with Inzaghi leading the line and Salas warming the bench. Early tussles for midfield superiority - where the home side will miss their influential skipper.
3 Inzaghi played through by Nedved and De Goey blocks well with his knees from 15 yards. Leboeuf collects the ricochet and clears.
6 Juan Veron collects on the right and with everyone in blue waiting for the through ball to Inzaghi, the Argentine drives a low, testing shot that De Goey does well to palm wide of his left-hand post. Mihajlovic takes the corner from the right, but the delivery is uncharacteristically poor and Chelsea are able to clear.
8 Lazio are enjoying having a dig at De Goey tonight. Nedved from 25 yards in a central position, hits it well but De Goey is always behind it. The Dutch keeper will have to have his wits about him during these opening moments.
9 Zola tries a repeat of last week as a ball aimed at Flo is headed out by Couto, but only as far as the diminutive Italian on the edge of the area. He waits patiently for the ball to come down and his volley is sweet. Marchegiani manages to divert the shot wide of his left-hand post.
14 Chelsea have carved out a couple of good chances, but Lazio are the ones with the urgency tonight, attacking down both flanks. Stankovic, sneaking unnoticed into the six-yard box, latches onto a Pancaro cross from the right. His header clears De Goey's crossbar, but only just.
16 Petrescu on the right by the half-way line, spots Poyet's run into the Lazio area. His lofted pass is an invitation to head goalwards, and Poyet obliges, but the effort is weak and straight at Marchegiani.
22 This game is descending towards a real physical battle, which is a shame considering the talent on display on both sides. Flo and Almeyda have shared a few spats and Leboeuf has just mentioned something inflammatory to Pancaro.
26 Corner to Lazio. Mihajlovic delivers from the right and Stankovic manages to head the cross back from the far post for Simeone, but the ball had just crossed the line. Goal kick.
28 A free kick for Lazio from 30 yards on the centre-left. The six-man Chelsea wall have the dubious honour of facing one of the hardest strikers of the ball in world football. Mihajlovic takes and De Goey gets his body behind the dipping shot, which is just as well as it bounces back off his chest and Babayaro hoofs it away from Inzaghi. Lots of Lazio pressure in the last ten minutes.
32 Good interplay from Chelsea as Petrescu wins a corner from the right. Flo meets Zola's centre with a well directed header to Marchegiani's left-hand post. The keeper blocks well and in the resulting melee, Leboeuf, Couto and Simeone exchange words and shoves.
33 The football restarts after a brief hiatus during which Leboeuf and Couto were booked for their trouble.
37 Simeone, Veron, Nedved and Inzaghi all exchange tight passes in between Chelsea midfielders and defenders before Nedved's cross is misdirected to De Goey. Chelsea are having trouble putting their foot on the ball against this classy Italian outfit.
40 Zola, having intercepted a pass from Almeyda, plays Di Matteo through the middle. The Italian midfielder shapes to hit with his left, then cuts back onto the right and gently scoops the ball into Marchegiani's hands from 20 yards.
42 Best chance yet for Lazio to break the deadlock as Nedved finds some space on the right and crosses well into the centre of the Chelsea area where Inzaghi waits at the penalty spot. The Chelsea defence haven't picked him up and the header is powerful but the direction woeful. A real let-off for the home side.
44 GOAL Chelsea 1 - 0 Lazio Chelsea send Stamford Bridge into delirium. Poyet picks up the ball on the break in the centre circle after a great tackle by Deschamps to win possession.After two touches Gus drives a rising, swerving shot from 25 yards that clips the shirt of Negro on its way to the bottom corner.
45 Half time comes with the Bridge still singing Poyet's praises.

45 Lazio substitution: Boksic for Stankovic.
45 Chelsea restart and will brace themselves for an onslaught from the Italian side. Nedved starts brightly by pushing up with the ball from midfield. his shot is a disappointment, well wide on the right.
47 Boksic's first touch tonight is to lift the ball over an advancing De Goey, but agonisingly wide of the left upright.
49 Zola toys with Mihajlovic on the right-hand side of the Lazio area and eventually delivers a cross but Negro manages to clear as Poyet waited at the far post. Chelsea may find the best form of defence is attack.
50 Nedved collects a deep cross at the left-hand post with a great first touch to bring the ball down. His second touch is to crash the ball into the advertising hoardings, much to the relief of De Goey.
52 Chelsea are keeping possession well in the Lazio half, frustrating the visitors as they seek to redress the balance. Marchegiani finally gets to touch the ball after a mishit Babayaro cross.
54 GOAL Chelsea 1 - 1 Lazio Nedved, played out wide on the left of the Chelsea area, looks on a hiding to nothing as the angle narrows to De Goey's goal. Instead of the shot comes the cross and Inzaghi manages to hold off Desailly to score what could be a vital goal for the visitors.
57 Flo is booked for rubbing his head too forcefully on Simeone's boot.
59 Flo from the right delivers an innocuous floating cross headed clear by Pancaro. Di Matteo cannot resist the seductive bounce of the ball and drives his volley straight at the centre of goal, where Marchegiani waits and collects.
61 Chelsea substitution: Hogh for Leboeuf. A sensible move seeing as the volatile Frenchman is on a yellow.
63 Nedved his trying to hit everything behind the Chelsea goal. This time he opts for height as his half-volley soars over De Goey and into the upper stand.
65 Babayaro penalised for use of the arm. Free kick from the right and Mihajlovic is standing over it.
66 GOAL Chelsea 1 - 2 Lazio The two-man Chelsea wall can only watch the shot as it flies over their heads and then hear the groan milliseconds later as Mihajlovic's rocket distorts the side netting from the inside of De Goey's goal.
67 Lazio substitution: Salas for Inzaghi.
70 Deschamps lofted cross finds Petrescu on the right of the Lazio area. Marchegiani does everything right, narrowing the angle before making the save. The resulting corner is cleared.
73 A corner to Lazio. Another Mihajlovic special delivery causes pandemonium in the Chelsea area. Babayaro is happy to drive the ball upfield.
75 Chelsea substitution: Morris for Babayaro; Harley for Di Matteo. Some Englishmen are on the pitch - they think it's all over...
76 A long clearance from De Goey is missed by Mihajlovic and Poyet controls with his thigh and strikes a volley well over the bar from 20 yards. Chelsea's first attacking move for a while.
80 Zola impeded on the left in full flight by Couto, who must have his heart in his mouth as he's already on a yellow. The referee shows restraint and simply awards the free kick. The delivery is poor and Marchegiani can take his time over the goal kick.
82 The ball breaks for Zola and for a second he has a clear sight of goal. All too soon Pancaro blocks the way and the move breaks down. It's going to take something special from Chelsea if they are to draw this match and win this group.
83 Sent off: Couto (second bookable offence). A nasty tackle on Flo leaves the ref no option but to dismiss the Lazio defender.
84 Zola, Flo and finally Morris lay siege to the Lazio goal as the visitors' undermanned defence is creaking. Morris' header is powerful but straight at Marchegiani.
87 Harley centres to Poyet, who flicks on to Petrescu on the right. The Romanian runs through on goal and his shot slides under Marchegiani, but Negro is there to clear off the line.
88 Lazio substitution: Gottardi for Salas. The Chilean is unamused with his truncated appearance, stripping off his shirt and tossing it on the ground as he leaves the playing area. The referee books him for ambling off.
90 Three more minutes for Chelsea to get the goal that will earn them the seeding for Friday's draw.
92 Cross after cross bombards the Lazio area, but the quality in the pass is lacking. Lazio break and Veron carves a chance out of nothing, but his shot is scuffed and nowhere near the goal.
93 Full time: Chelsea 1 - 2 Lazio.

fields.headline: Snub for reform campaigners
fields.standfirst: £400m VAT bill still stands
fields.trailText: Charities last night expressed severe disappointment about a budget that offered incentives to boost donations but did little to tackle their biggest problem: a £400m annual VAT bill.
fields.body:
Charities last night expressed severe disappointment about a budget that offered incentives to boost donations but did little to tackle their biggest problem: a £400m annual VAT bill.

Gordon Brown extended tax relief for gifts to cover a wider range of shares and allowed non-residents to make tax-free donations.

He also extended VAT exemption to more fund-raising events and broadened the VAT zero rate for the sale or hire of donated goods.

Oxfam said the changes would "help us raise a lot more money". But other groups said the help was fatally undermined by not properly tackling the growing VAT problem. The Charity Tax Reform Group, which has represented 350 leading charities in talks with the chancellor, said Mr Brown had concentrated on piecemeal reform.

"We are very happy with the changes to payroll giving and gift aid but we are left with the fundamental problem of VAT which we have been campaigning to change since the 1980s," said Alison Cornell, the group's spokeswoman.

VAT is paid when charities spend money, for example, on a minibus for the elderly. Because there is no charge to the users, the VAT element cannot be passed on or recovered.

Similarly, the maintenance of residential buildings incurs significant VAT bills. Help the Aged pays £500,000 a year in this kind of tax.

Mr Brown said all voluntary organisations and charities would benefit from the tax reforms announced last autumn. From April 6, for every pound a taxpayer gives to charity the government will add 28p.

fields.headline: No man's land
fields.standfirst: John Prescott's targets for new homes in the south-east are inadequate and underfunded, says  John Perry
fields.trailText: John Prescott's targets for new homes in the south-east are inadequate and underfunded, says John Perry.
fields.body:
It may have been a deft political move by John Prescott to pitch his target for housing in the south-east halfway between what planners think there is space for and what (different) planners think is needed, but will it work?

The crucial test is not whether fewer acres of countryside will be concreted over, but whether people will be able to find a decent home at a price they can afford.

The deputy prime minister's dilemma is understandable. The media and the countryside lobby have succeeded in giving the impression that the million-plus homes that the government's own adviser said are needed was an exceptional figure, rather than a continuation of existing trends and rates of development.

Furthermore, the impression is created that most of the new households are people moving from elsewhere, such as the declining north, and policy changes would alter the figures. A further misconception is that the green belt is about to be lost and the countryside destroyed.

There is some truth - but not much - in these points, yet they have dominated the debate. What has been missing is serious concern that east of a line between South-ampton and Peterborough, housing demand has reached boiling point, and that not much is being done about it.

Take some facts about the situation in London alone. The average house price is £155,000 and has gone up 16% in one year. A household without savings would need to earn £50,000 to get a mortgage on such a property. Partly as a consequence, 187,000 are on waiting lists for social housing. There are nearly 40,000 families in temporary accommodation awaiting permanent homes. The latest reported homelessness figures were the highest since 1995. Of all the country's severely overcrowded families, 42% live in London.

As demand rises, supply falls. New lettings by London councils and housing associations are down 17% compared with two years ago. Over the next five years, about 20,000 new rented homes will be built - very welcome, but probably no more than a third of what is needed.

How does all this relate to Prescott's targets? The first point is that if the targets are set too low, too few houses will be built. Experience in the last decade has shown that nationally, supply of private housing has more or less kept up with projected demand. The shortfall has occurred in rented housing. Constraining supply is always likely to have the same outcome, the better off will meet their needs, however high the price, whilst the worse off endure overcrowding, poor conditions, insecure accommodation or all three.

This could be tackled if there were targets for affordable housing, within the overall figure. The government has gone a step towards this by insisting on higher densities and smaller homes but has not grasped the nettle of setting targets for rented or low-cost market housing.

This task is delegated to local authority development plans. But the government also missed the chance to toughen up the planning system to deliver more affordable housing. It could have called for specific targets at regional and local level, ensured housing mix on the smaller brownfield sites it wants to see developed, and prevented low-cost homes from being sold on at inflated prices. In issuing new planning guidance which omitted these points, it ignored the work of its own urban taskforce.

Of course, although planning reforms and targets for affordable housing are key requirements, even more important is that money is available to build the new homes. To some extent the planning system provides the cash too, in the cross-subsidy for affordable housing which is forced out of developers. fields.headline: Man with a commission
fields.standfirst: If you're about to head the body that is charged with  improving race relations, where do you start?  Gurbux Singh says that his first priority is to make  it a centre of excellence. Then, reports Alan  Travis, he will target local and national  government and the private sector
fields.trailText: If you're about to head the body that is charged with improving race relations, where do you start? Gurbux Singh says that his first priority is to make it a centre of excellence. Then, reports Alan Travis, he will target local and national government and the private sector.
fields.body:
Two months before Gurbux Singh even takes over the top job at the Commission for Racial Equality, he already finds himself having to sort out one of the more difficult episodes in the history of an organisation that has been the target of constant political sniping since it was set up in 1977.

But he is determined that the collapse of the global cultural diversity congress which was due to take place in Cardiff this month will not deflect the CRE from taking advantage of perhaps the most favourable political environment for work on race equality that has been seen for more than 20 years. It is not going to be easy, as the company which organised the Cardiff congress has gone into liquidation with a significant slice of the senior high command of the CRE on its board, amid official allegations of inadequate financial and management control.

Mr Singh, who has a strong reputation in local government as the modernising chief executive of Haringey council, has been asked by the home secretary, Jack Straw, to carry out an official inquiry into the collapse of the company: "I want this review to be carried out properly, rigorously and it has got to be thorough. If it is seen to be a whitewash, if I can use that language, then there will be a fair degree of criticism and I am not in the business of cover-ups. It will be a fair and balanced investigation. It will try to establish the facts and I will need to make some form of assessment as to whether there is any culpability on anybody's part.

"I want this thing dealt with and out of the way because I do not want it to be a deflection from the proper business of the CRE," says Singh, adding that his inquiry report will be on Jack Straw's desk by the end of May.

Having done one of the toughest jobs in local government seems to be a key qualification for a new chair of the CRE. His predecessor, Sir Herman Ouseley, had run the Inner London Education Authority and Lambeth council before he took up the job. Gurbux Singh has spent 11 years helping to turn round the particularly intractable problems of a London borough that includes the Broadwater Farm estate and has pockets of 70% young black unemployment.

A Sikh born in the Punjab, India, whose family came to Britain in the 1950s when he was six, Singh grew up in Wolverhampton and took a degree at Sussex university. He is still a season ticket holder at Molyneux. He spent an early part of his career working at the community relations commission - which turned into the CRE - concentrating mainly on housing and local government, tackling building soc iety and estate agents who charged black and Asian people more expensive mortgages or adopted "red lining" practices which stopped them moving into white areas.

Walking into the CRE's Victoria offices in London with Mr Singh it is immediately obvious that he is remembered from those days with genuine affection by the staff.

But what of the future of the CRE? "I believe this is the right time to be the chairman of the CRE. The political environment is right. I am not a card-carrying member of any political party but there is both leadership and commitment by this government to race equality... I support the prime minister's view that we need a modern Britain which is inclusive and which is based on justice and fairness. If you believe in modern political institutions and modern public services you cannot modernise unless you look at the whole question of race and the composition of your communities."

The post-Lawrence inquiry race relations (amendment) bill, now going through parliament, represents the first quantum leap forward in race equality legislation since the law setting up the CRE was passed in 1976. It does not include outlawing religious discrimination [see article opposite], but Mr Singh believes that the government will have to tackle that question sooner or later.

The bill's provisions, making institutional racism illegal and placing a new legal duty on public bodies to promote equality, mean the CRE will have an even more important role. Mr Singh believes that will include ensuring ministers and senior civil servants see race equality as a mainstream component of the programme to modernise Britain. That includes not only Whitehall permanent secretaries but also local government, the health service and the police.

"The questions are what is the national framework around race equality and how do ministers and senior officials begin to put into place an equalities framework. Take the simple example of school exclusions and the educational under-achievement of Afro-Caribbean boys. To what extent is the Department for Education and Employment doing something meaningful about that? The CRE needs to enter into a dialogue with them about that. What is the DfEE doing about young blacks and unemployment? You know that 70% of kids in Tottenham who are Afro-Caribbean between the ages of 17 and 24 have never worked."

Mr Singh says he believes the race equality debate in the private sector has moved significantly: "But we are at the stage where there is a lot of positive declarations by captains - and others - of industry. What we are not doing anything about is actual delivery. You know - actual change on the ground, so that the employment profile of these organisations begins to reflect the communities in which they operate."

He cites a recent TUC report showing that, while white unemployment rate is coming down, among the black communities it is going up and the level of joblessness among black and Asian people is twice the white unemployment rate. In the three major conurbations where the black communities are settled, Manchester, the West Midlands and London, the average minority ethnic unemployment rate is around 20%. "So the private sector clearly has a very important role to play." But also conscious of the political attacks that the CRE has repeatedly faced during its lifetime, Mr Singh has another important priority: "The one thing I want is for the CRE to be a centre of excellence that has legitimacy in the public eye. That the public actually believe the CRE is an important institution doing a valuable and meaningful job."

He believes the recent Guardian/ICM survey showing that for the first time a majority of the British public regard racism as unacceptable was particularly encouraging and a good basis from which to build.

What of his own record? Well, at Haringey some 48% of the workforce is drawn from black and minority communities, including the Irish: "But the vast majority are located at the bottom end of the system. At the top end, while we have made some progress around gender in terms of senior positions, there is this glass ceiling. Minority ethnic communities have not broken through at assistant director or director level. We want to address that. We did it by setting targets, and these are targets and not quotas, and we said if everything goes well we expect this to happen. Once you have any sort of target system it helps to focus minds," said Mr Singh.

"We made very positive and encouraging noises in the adverts we put out and we made it known that this was an open and accessible organisation where minority ethnic communities were welcome. It's funny, you go to some authorities and they will be seen institutionally as white, male and not terribly accessible. In spite of Haringey's difficulties it is not like that."

webTitle: Hague and Blair clash over tax

fields.headline: Hague and Blair clash over tax
fields.trailText: After Gordon Brown favoured prudent spending priorities to profligate tax cuts in his fourth Budget, the measures dominated prime minister's question time in the Commons today.
fields.body:
After Gordon Brown favoured prudent spending priorities to profligate tax cuts in his fourth Budget, the measures dominated prime minister's question time in the Commons today.

The Tory leader, William Hague, provoked Labour anger by claiming taxes on businesses are to rise by £30bn over the lifetime of this parliament. He repeatedly challenged Mr Blair over the true cost of Mr Brown's policies.

In testy exchanges, Tony Blair hit back, insisting the Government had sorted out the public finances, and strengthened the economy. He attacked the Tory tax record, saying the Conservative way was "tax rises, public service cuts and boom and bust".

The prime minister said: "We have cut the rate of corporation tax - and corporation taxes and small business taxes are now at their lowest level ever." Mr Hague said this was an example of "why nobody believes anything you say about taxes".

Mr Hague drew the prime minister's attention to concerns raised by the accountancy firm, Pricewaterhouse Coopers, and claimed the total net increase in taxes in the coming month was £365m. Mr Blair responded by claiming the tax burden was now falling under Labour.

Mr Blair was also challenged by Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy over the 75p rise in the basic state pension. "That is not all pensioners are getting," Mr Blair insisted.

While Budget issues dominated the 30-minute session, the issue of asylum seekers also prompted heated exchanges. The Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman Simon Hughes urged Home Office ministers not to "encourage some of the press to pander to the twin evils of racism and prejudice".

The prime minister outlined the government's strategy to speed up asylum claims and declared: "I reject entirely the argument that these measures are in any shape or form whipping up prejudice - they are in fact the best way of preventing it."

fields.headline: Priority No1: the NHS
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown yesterday threw a £2bn lifeline to the ailing NHS as part of a huge four-year boost to health spending designed to allay public concern over Labour's most vulnerable area in the run-up to the next election.
fields.byline: Larry Elliott, Michael White and John Carvel
fields.body:
Gordon Brown yesterday threw a £2bn lifeline to the ailing NHS as part of a huge four-year boost to health spending designed to allay public concern over Labour's most vulnerable area in the run-up to the next election.

After a winter of crisis in Britain's hospitals, Mr Brown opened his brimming war chest to bring forward part of his planned summer spending round. He pledged a 35% real increase in funds for the NHS by 2004, the biggest sustained increase in its 52-year history.

The first fruits of the chancellor's surprise announcement - the centrepiece of his fourth Budget - will be a sustained drive to recruit 10,000 more nurses and better intensive care, but Mr Brown emphasised that the extra cash would have to be matched by reform and modernisation of the NHS.

To underline Labour's determination to recapture public confidence after sustained criticism of poor services and long waiting lists, Tony Blair will be taking personal responsibility for the NHS. The prime minister will make a Commons statement on health today explaining how he and the health secretary, Alan Milburn, will spearhead the public debate about the future of the NHS and ensure the government gets the best value for Mr Brown's billions.

Last night the prime minister met healthcare professionals and told them that today he would be setting out plans to publish more tables highlighting the vastly different costs of operations from region to region, outlining increased powers for nurses and a further tranche of cash for preventive and primary care.

The chancellor said the 6.1% a year real increase in spending was the reward for his disciplined handling of the economy, which he expects to grow robustly over the next three years despite the impact of the strong pound on manufacturing. With the economy in its ninth year of sustained growth, Mr Brown said he would have a budget surplus of £12bn this year, £15bn better than he expected a year ago. Next year, even after the extra spending, the surplus will still be £6bn, leaving plenty of scope for pre-election tax cuts or further spending increases.

"We have been prudent for a purpose. New money we can provide because we have made our choice: a Budget that unites the whole country, a Budget for all our people," Mr Brown said.

Treasury officials strongly denied that the chancellor had been panicked into a spending spree, although many at Westminster believed that the move reflected the direct intervention of the prime minister to twist Mr Brown's arm.

While health was the most eye-catching announcement in the Budget, there was also an extra £1bn for education, to allow David Blunkett to hand up to £9,000 for primary schools and up to £50,000 to secondary schools.

More money for transport and combating crime mopped up the rest of Mr Brown's £4bn boost to public spending, which dwarfed tax cuts of just over £1bn.

The British Medical Association, often critical of Mr Blair, led a chorus of delight from within the NHS. "We are delighted that the government has responded so quickly to our call for a fundamental review of health service funding. We see this as a first major step to putting the health service on a firm, long-term basis," said its chairman, Ian Bogle.

Government sources said the increases would take health spending from £49.3bn to £68.7bn by 2004, equivalent to 7.6% of GDP and within touching distance of the European average of 8%.

Despite Conservative scepticism about Mr Brown's figures, the sheer scale of the chancellor's commitment to "a publicly funded NHS, true to the original principles of its founders" took MPs on all sides by surprise.

Cash spending will rise by 50% from £1,850 a household to over £2,800 by 2004. One Whitehall official said: "This is a step change in the money available. Now we need a step change in the results we get from it."

Some of the new money has been earmarked to wipe out £600m of accumulated NHS debts.

With the four-year programme for increased health spending already agreed, the education department was set to become the big beneficiary of the chancellor's comprehensive review of other Whitehall spending.

"Education will be the big selling point in the summer. So David is smiling. I can't see how this can do anything but help," one of Mr Blunkett's ministerial colleagues said last night.

Education spending had been set to increase by £3.5bn over the coming financial year and yesterday's Budget raised this to £4.5bn. Health spending had been due to rise by only £2.9bn, but overtook education as a result of the chancellor's statement to get an increase of £4.9bn.

However, education ministers said last night that they were not losing out because their increase over this year's budget was 8.5%, while health got 7.9%.

The eventual outcome would depend on the comprehensive spending review, but gains made by the health department would strengthen arguments for spending more on education.

webTitle: Mr Brown's healthy brew: But the pound remains a cause for

fields.headline: Mr Brown's healthy brew: But the pound remains a cause for
fields.standfirst: Leading article
fields.trailText: Leading article
fields.body:
Gordon Brown's fourth Budget contains a broadside of measures to appease Labour heartlands, mollify Middle England and stimulate small businesses ahead of a general election next year. The chancellor has again pulled off the political conjuring trick we are now getting used to. He is planning an almost unprecedented 6.1% annual increase in health spending - above the rate of inflation - for the next four years (plus an extra £ 1billion for schools) while simultaneously tightening the fiscal stance (the balance between borrowing, spending and taxation) quite substantially by over 1% of of gross domestic product. He is sitting on Fort Knox in the form of a £12 billion budget surplus - one of the biggest in history - but in practice he has had to put Scrooge's cap on because his largesse has been constrained by the need not to upset the City by spending too much at a time when the economy is in danger of overheating.

On the first of the two tests on which we said this budget should be assessed - the need to boost spending substantially on health and education - he has come out with flying colours. But on the second _measures to bring down the over-strong pound - the jury is still out. The Treasury argues that it has already hugely tightened fiscal policy in recent years in the hope that this would take the pressure off the pound, but that has not worked. The problem, it believes, is the weak euro, not the strong pound, and when the EU economy awakens from its slumbers, as it is now showing signs of doing, the problem will sort itself out. Maybe. But until it does, the Treasury's prediction of a near 6% rise in export volume this year (compared with 2.5% last year) looks like wishful thinking.

But even within his fiscal constraints Mr Brown has money to scatter around, thanks to lower debt interest payments, higher tax receipts and reduced outlays on social security. Small and medium-sized businesses will welcome his £225 million reduction in capital gains tax liabilities on business assets and a sheaf of other measures, including £280 million for a new all-employee share plan. He also promises to look at the problems of dot.com companies, worried about tax liabilities arising from share options on which their early success depends. Middle England will be relieved that the problems of the health service are to be tackled (after the neglect of Labour's first two years) even if they are not yet convinced that Mr Blair's target of matching European generosity is on the horizon.

This was a Budget in which Labour threw itself as never before behind nurturing entrepreneurs, while also giving help to the poor - especially pensioners. Their increases, while hardly dramatic, are more generous than they look because they have been craftily targeted to help the really needy. Only a year ago, education was due to get more than health in this latest budget - an extra £3.5 billion compared to health's £2.9 billion. But since then the health service has been hit by flu and a winter crisis. Public support for Labour's handling of health steadily bled away in its first two years, but this last winter created a critical haemorrhage. Hence the prime minister's decision to intervene. He will speak more fully in the Commons today of Labour's new programme for the NHS, but the key injection - cash - was dealt with by the chancellor yesterday. Instead of an extra £2.9 billion, the health service will receive £4.9 billion for the financial year that starts in 10 days time - a 7.4% increase. This will be the first of four increases through to April 2004, averaging 6.1%. The health service has seen nothing like it. Its increases have averaged only 3.3% since its foundation and the last Conservative government averaged only 2.9%. True, the Tories pushed up spending by 9% in 1991 to save their `internal market'', but no government has achieved such a sustained level of investment. It is a health managers' dream, an opportunity to look and plan for the medium term rather than merely tomorrow. A health budget which was £45.1billion only last year, will rise to £68.7billion by April 2004 - a 50% increase in cash terms and a 35% increase in real terms. Sceptics will say that not even this huge investment will lift British health spending to the European average, as Mr Blair promised in January on the David Frost programme. They would be right, in that it is due to lift spending (both public and private) to 7.6% of GDP. But that is only 0.4% short of the crude European average.

Although education has only received pounds 1bn extra compared to health's £2 billion on this April's planned increases, education still achieved a higher proportionate rise: some 8%. There is no doubt that health is in a much sorrier state than education, so honour would be achieved by health receiving the bigger cash injection with education maintaining a higher proportionate rise. Headteachers were delighted not just with the extra funds but the method of distribution direct to the school. What was particularly welcome was the freedom for the schools to chose how the extra was spent: on books, technology or staff.

There was much less excitement on the anti-poverty front, where the two previous budgets introduced the best deal for the poor for a generation. But earlier announcements were consolidated, with the New Deal's welfare-to-work programmes extended to long-term unemployed, older workers and lone parents. By the end of the next financial year 1 million children will have been lifted out of poverty and there are already plans to lift another million over three years through an integrated child credit. If that is achieved, the government will be on target to cut child poverty in half by 2010 - a new halfway house before the ultimate goal of complete abolition by 2020. One welcome new trend was the chancellor's readiness to point to the redistribution that Labour is achieving. Civic society is being renewed.

Mr Brown, in sum, may have `given away' about as much as he could without frightening the City. Many people will still be understandably bemused as to why a chancellor sporting a record budget surplus, with more expected in coming years, cannot do even more to rectify the glaring deficiencies in health, education and transport. But within his self-imposed constraints, the chancellor has done himself proud.

fields.headline: Priority No 1: the NHS
fields.standfirst:
• Brown's immediate £2bn injection   • 10,000 extra
           nurses  • Blair takes personal responsibility for health service
fields.trailText:
Gordon Brown yesterday threw a £2bn lifeline to the ailing NHS yesterday as part of a huge
           four-year boost to health spending designed to allay public concern over Labour's most vulnerable area
           in the run-up to the next election.
fields.byline: Larry Elliott, Michael White, John Carvel and Mark Atkinson
fields.body:
Gordon Brown yesterday threw a £2bn lifeline to the ailing NHS yesterday as part of a huge four-year boost to health spending designed to allay public concern over Labour's most vulnerable area in the run-up to the next election.

After a winter of crisis in Britain's hospitals, Mr Brown opened his brimming war chest to bring forward part of his planned summer spending round. He pledged a 35% real increase in funds for the NHS by 2004, the biggest sustained increase in its 52-year history.

The first fruits of the chancellor's surprise announcement - the centrepiece of his fourth Budget - will be a sustained drive to recruit 10,000 more nurses and better intensive care, but Mr Brown emphasised that the extra cash would have to be matched by reform and modernisation of the NHS.

To underline Labour's determination to recapture public confidence after sustained criticism of poor services and long waiting lists, Tony Blair will be taking personal responsibility for the NHS. The prime minister will make a Commons statement on health today explaining how he and the health secretary, Alan Milburn, will spearhead the public debate about the future of the NHS and ensure the government gets the best value for Mr Brown's billions.

Last night the prime minister met healthcare professionals and told them that today he would be setting out plans to publish more tables highlighting the vastly different costs of operations from region to region, outlining increased powers for nurses and a further tranche of cash for preventive and primary care.

The chancellor said the 6.1% a year real increase in spending was the reward for his disciplined handling of the economy, which he expects to grow robustly over the next three years despite the impact of the strong pound on manufacturing. With the economy in its ninth year of sustained growth, Mr Brown said he would have a budget surplus of £12bn this year, £15bn better than he expected a year ago. Next year, even after the extra spending, the surplus will still be £6bn, leaving plenty of scope for pre-election tax cuts or further spending increases.

`We have been prudent for a purpose. New money we can provide because we have made our choice: a Budget that unites the whole country, a Budget for all our people,' Mr Brown said.

Treasury officials strongly denied that the chancellor had been panicked into a spending spree, although many at Westminster believed that the move reflected the direct intervention of the prime minister to twist Mr Brown's arm.

While health was the most eye-catching announcement in the Budget , there was also an extra pounds 1bn for education, to allow David Blunkett to hand up to £9,000 for primary schools and up to £50,000 to secondary schools.

More money for transport and combating crime mopped up the rest of Mr Brown's £4bn boost to public spending, which dwarfed tax cuts of just over £1bn.

The British Medical Association, often critical of Mr Blair, led a chorus of delight from within the NHS. 'We are delighted that the government has responded so quickly to our call for a fundamental review of health service funding. We see this as a first major step to putting the health service on a firm, long-term basis,' said its chairman, Ian Bogle.

Government sources said the increases would take health spending from £49.3bn to pounds 68.7bn by 2004, equivalent to 7.6% of GDP and within touching distance of the Euro pean average of 8%. Despite Tory scepticism about Mr Brown's figures, the scale of the chancellor's commitment to 'a publicly funded NHS, true to the original principles of its founders' took MPs on all sides by surprise.

With the four-year programme for increased health spending already agreed, the education department was set to become the big beneficiary of the chancellor's comprehensive review of other Whitehall spending.

'Education will be the big selling point in the summer. So David is smiling. I can't see how this can do anything but help,' one of Mr Blunkett's ministerial colleagues said last night.

In his Budget speech, the chancellor underlined his ambition to generate a vigorous US-style business culture by unveiling a package of measures to stimulate enterprise, cushioned by fresh steps to eradicate poverty and low pay. Describing the choice between enterprise and fairness as false, the chancellor offered tax breaks to encourage entrepreneurs to create wealth, and extra money for pensioners and 'hard-working families'.

Mr Brown announced a shake-up of capital gains tax, under which all business investment held for four years would be rewarded with a 10% rate a new all-employee share ownership scheme permanent 40% investment allowances for small companies and a regional network of venture capital funds worth pounds 1bn. He said these measures would make Britain the place 'for companies to start, to invest, to grow and expand'.

Stressing his determination to tear down the barriers to full employment, Mr Brown said the working families tax credit to top up the incomes of the lowest paid would be increased to guarantee an income of £214 a week.

The Budget was welcomed by unions and business, but there was concern at the lack of impact it would have on the high value of sterling. John Edmonds, general secretary of the GMB union, praised the public spending plans but said: 'The tax measures will not bring down the pound and that is the most serious problem for the economy.'

Ruth Lea, of the Institute of Directors, said: 'Mr Brown gave a good performance, but fell slightly short of getting full marks. We liked his enthusiasm for enterprise and it is still a surprise to realise you are listening to a Labour chancellor.'

fields.headline: US puts up interest rates
fields.standfirst: Greenspan warns of further hikes as economy fails to simmer down
fields.trailText: The US central bank increased the cost of borrowing for the fifth time in nine months yesterday in an attempt to slow down the record-breaking US economy.
fields.body:
The US central bank increased the cost of borrowing for the fifth time in nine months yesterday in an attempt to slow down the record-breaking US economy.

Yesterday's decision by the Federal Reserve Bank to lift the benchmark Fed Funds rate by 25 basis points to 6 per cent brings the cost of borrowing to its highest level for five years.

Announcing the decision, the bank suggested that it could continue to increase rates because it fears higher inflation. Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, said that with economic conditions showing no signs of slowing down he was still concerned that demand was outstripping supply.

The Fed also decided unanimously to increase the discount rate by 25 basis points to 5.5 per cent, which several analysts took as a sign of greater-than-expected concern among its board members.

Investors had expected a further increase in the main overnight bank lending rate, however, and the markets showed little immediate reaction to the news yesterday.

The Fed was expected to increase rates because of continuing signs of growth in the US economy. Official figures released just before yesterday's announcement revealed a sharp increase in the US trade deficit to a record $28bn in January.

This 14 per cent increase, well above expectations, reflected stronger demand for imports and higher oil prices in the period.

The Fed is likely to have taken such signs of increased spending by US consumers in spite of higher oil prices as a reminder of inflationary risks.

High Frequency, an economic research group, said that the deficit implied further increases in gross domestic product to around 7.8 per cent from just under 7 in the last quarter.

Such forecasts explain why many analysts expect at least one more rate increase before the end of the year. Several expect as many as three more if the economy continues to show little sign of slowing down.

Few believe the Fed will raise rates by more than 25 basis points at a time, however. Ian Shepherdson at High Frequency echoed others in pointing out the lack of political support for larger increases during an election year.

The Dow continued to trade up more than 100 points, or about 1 per cent, after the announcement. The market had been buoyed by a positive court ruling for tobacco companies and strong earnings results from financial services companies earlier in the day.

Fears over further rate increases had already helped push the Nasdaq down more than 10 per cent from its March high in recent days, however.

webTitle: Three new suspects questioned over Lawrence killing

fields.headline: Three new suspects questioned over Lawrence killing
fields.trailText: Three men were today being questioned by police after they were arrested in connection with the racist murder of the black teenager Stephen Lawrence.
fields.body:
Three men were today being questioned by police after they were arrested in connection with the racist murder of the black teenager Stephen Lawrence.

The first two arrests came last night just before Stephen's parents and deputy assistant commissioner John Grieve, the officer in charge of the case, made a witness appeal on the BBC's Crimewatch programme.

One, a 24-year-old man, was arrested in Glasgow last night in a joint operation between the Metropolitan police and the Scottish crime squad. A second man was arrested in London and, today, a third man was taken into custody.

The three, not thought to be among the five original suspects in the case, are being questioned in London about the fatal stabbing of the 18-year-old by a gang of white youths at a bus stop in Eltham, southeast London, in April 1993.

Although Scotland Yard says that none of the arrests came from the Crimewatch appeal, Mr Grieve said that the 70 calls received by the programme related to people police were "very, very interested in and have been appealing about".

Mr Grieve said that new technology had given a fresh boost to the inquiry. "We have got new witnesses. We have got new ways of analysing the massive amount of witness statements we have already collected," he added.

"There are new developments in scientific evidence which are nothing short of miraculous in finding conclusive evidence," he said. New tests will be carried out on a knife and a coat which were found close to the murder scene and the police are "very close" to identifying a potentially vital witness who is thought to have been at the scene of the murder, Mr Grieve added. Stephen's parents, Neville and Doreen Lawrence, who appeared on the programme, urged the mothers and girlfriends of any of the youths involved in the killing to come forward. "The boys would have fully confessed to them," said Mrs Lawrence. "There is one particular girl who I understand had heard from one of them about the death of Stephen and I would like to appeal to her and other mothers and young women, wives, girlfriends - anybody who would know anything to come forward and phone in." No one has been convicted for the killing but five men have at various times been arrested. The current investigation team is the eighth set up to investigate the murder and has been running for 13 months.

Stephen's parents are still pressing ahead with a compensation claim against the police officers involved in the bungled murder investigation.

 Police today arrested 62 people in a series of raids targeting known racists across London. Scotland Yard detectives detained people on suspicion of offences ranging from racially aggravated criminal damage, harassment, grievous bodily harm and threats to kill. Detective chief superintendent John Godsave, who headed today's operation, said the figure was expected to rise to at least 80 by the end of the day. Mr Godsave denied that the arrests were linked to any far-right racist group or the arrests of new suspects in the Stephen Lawrence murder. "There is nothing to suggest these people are overtly political or the individuals involved are known to each other," he added.

webTitle: Blair tells NHS to get back on its feet

fields.headline: Blair tells NHS to get back on its feet
fields.trailText: Prime minister Tony Blair today challenged the NHS to reform itself after chancellor Gordon Brown opened up his war chest for Britain's ailing health system.
fields.body:
Prime minister Tony Blair today challenged the NHS to reform itself after chancellor Gordon Brown opened up his war chest for Britain's ailing health system.

Mr Blair told the Commons that, after Mr Brown's largesse, the NHS had to embrace modernisation. "A step-change in resources must mean a step-change in reform," he said. "I say to the hardworking and dedicated staff in the NHS ... make sure the NHS confronts the hard necessities of reform to improve the value we get for the money we spend."

Staking his personal reputation on reform of the NHS, Mr Blair is to chair a committee that will develop an action plan for the health service. The prime minister said that in July the government would publish a detailed four-year action plan for the NHS - what he called the "timetable for delivery".

Labour's determination to put the NHS in order comes in the wake of several damning reports. They criticised the shortage of beds and the transmission of infectious diseases within hospitals. In the latest blow to the health service, an independent inquiry today accused Labour of politicising the health service by appointing its own supporters to NHS boards and to run hospitals.

Right on cue, health secretary Alan Milburn announced he would be considering fundamental changes to the NHS appointment process to ensure greater local accountability for NHS board members.

Responding to a report published by Dame Rennie Fritchie, the commissioner for public appointments, Mr Milburn said he would consider putting responsibility for appointing non-executive trust board members into the hands of local health authorities. That would take over 2,000 non-executive appointments out of the hands of ministers and give them to local health organisations.

In his speech, Mr Blair set out five challenges for the NHS - including for all parts of the NHS to work together to end the bed shortage, reduce unnecessary hospital admissions and provide the right level of beds and services for each level of care. Too often, he said, the pressure for change had been made "doubly painful by the pressure of scarcity".

But Mr Blair would have no truck with those who argued for a privatisation of the health service. He told the Commons: "I do not, I will not, yield to those who believe the NHS has had its day. It has not. A modernised NHS, not private medical insurance, is the future."

Responding for the Tories, William Hague said the Conservatives welcomed the additional funding for the health service, but the government's "need to relaunch policies on the NHS was a clear demonstration they have failed thus far".

In yesterday's Budget, Mr Brown pledged a real 35% increase in funds for the NHS by 2002, the biggest sustained increase in service's history. There will be a drive to recruit 10,000 more nurses and better intensive care.

But the chancellor emphasised that the extra cash would have to be matched by reform and modernisation. The government has been stung by criticism of the NHS which reached a frenzy in the tabloid press at Christmas when a flu epidemic led to an acute shortage of beds.

Mr Blair told the Commons that, after Mr Brown's largesse, the NHS had to embrace modernisation. "A step-change in resources must mean a step-change in reform," he said. "I say to the hardworking and dedicated staff in the NHS ... make sure the NHS confronts the hard necessities of reform to improve the value we get for the money we spend." Staking his personal reputation on reform of the NHS, Mr Blair is to chair a committee that will develop an action plan for the health service. The prime minister said that in July the government would publish a detailed four-year action plan for the NHS - what he called the "timetable for delivery". Labour's determination to put the NHS in order comes in the wake of several damning reports. They criticised the shortage of beds and the transmission of infectious diseases within hospitals.
