fields.headline: Hope at last
fields.standfirst: Three new arrests in the Stephen Lawrence murder inquiry are a crucial step forward, writes Gary Younge
fields.trailText: At last. Almost seven years after the racist murder of Stephen Lawrence comes concrete proof, rather than promises, programmes and policies, that the police have been taking the case seriously. Two arrests, announced yesterday and described by those close to the investigation as "significant", are a major breakthrough. The fact that it has taken so long is cause for concern; the fact that it has happened at all is cause for celebration.
fields.body:
At last. Almost seven years after the racist murder of Stephen Lawrence comes concrete proof, rather than promises, programmes and policies, that the police have been taking the case seriously. Two arrests, announced yesterday and described by those close to the investigation as "significant", are a major breakthrough. The fact that it has taken so long is cause for concern; the fact that it has happened at all is cause for celebration.

First and foremost the arrests represent a great potential victory for the Lawrences. For all the column inches dedicated to describing them as a "dignified", "upstanding" family, a crucial fact has often been forgotten - they lost a son and their ability to fully grieve that loss has been impaired by the inability of the police to bring his killers to justice.

Stephen's death did not become a national issue by accident; it emerged as a landmark on the nation's political and racial landscape as a result of their tireless campaigning in the face of political stonewalling under the Tories and the obfuscation and wilful negligence of the police. Their persistence has been laudable but their patience has been cruelly tested by the incompetence, racism and corruption within the Metropolitan police force.

Yesterday's arrests are also a crucial step forward for the Metropolitan police themselves. For all the internal discontent voiced about changes implemented as a result of the Macpherson report into the Stephen Lawrence murder inquiry; for all their attempts to transform the style, and substance, of their work, it is breakthroughs of this nature that they need. Some hard evidence that they have the will and the competence to see that justice is done.

The Lawrence family can be excused for treating this latest development with healthy scepticism. They have been let down by the police and the criminal justice system far too often to trust anything other than a hard conviction of the murderers of their son. But for the first time in a long while there is, at least, hope. At last.

fields.trailText: LIGHTS, CAMERA, OFFSIDE!
fields.body:
LIGHTS, CAMERA, OFFSIDE!

[Lights go up on Robson Green in Arsenal's number 6 shirt. He is holding a big bottle of booze. Yellow liquid is dribbling out of his shorts. Denise van Outen is looking on sympathetically]

Robson: Can't you see I'm washed up as a professional footballer? If I can't kick this terrible boozing [takes swig from bottle] I may never lead my beloved Arsenal to double success!

Denise: Ooh, innit terrible.

[Cut to blurry close-up of 12-step program]

Hot gossip from the world of celluloid entertainment (not a reference to staring at Vanessa Feltz's thighs, by the way): Tony Adams' heart-rending autobiography, Addicted, could make it to the silver screen. Reports this morning suggest that Adams has actually sold the rights to his tale of his battle against drink to Hollywood types. The Fiver is reliably informed that no deal has yet taken place, but that doesn't mean it's not going to happen.

"I've always seen it as a very cinematic story," Addicted's 'co'-author Ian Ridley told the Fiver today from his plush Bel Air beachside apartment (we think). "It's very graphic, very realistic, and very redemptive," he went on - presumably referring to the bed-wetting scenes. "Tony has been approached by several film companies, but he doesn't want to do anything until he's retired from the game." Expect Addicted in a cinema near you by Christmas.

A PUBLIC ANNOUNCEMENT MADE BY A COMPANY WITH A VIEW TO PROMOTING THEIR GOODS AND SERVICES

Economist.com - Forthright opinion and lively analysis of global politics and business, plus handy summaries of the week's news. www.economist.com

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NOW WE'RE PRESSURE COOKING

It's been coming for a while now. And today it finally happened. Yes, the simmering lid which has been precariously clattering on the rim of Alex Ferguson's head for nearly 20 years finally blew off thanks to a powerful jet of steaming invective. You see, Fergie has found out that people are irrationally jealous of Manchester United. That's what he's heard, anyway.

"You have to put all the criticism of this club down to jealousy," an enlightened Fergie told club magazine Pravda. "The nation was warming towards us in the build-up to last season's Big Cup final," stated a man clearly suffering from fevered delusions, "but the warmth was only ever going to be temporary. It's the British culture of being quick to put down the people at the top and we're a soft target." Ah, he's sounding better already.

"We're getting criticised for protesting yet we're in a society now where everyone is more confrontational," Fergie observed without any hint of irony. "The statistics show that Manchester United are one of the best behaved teams in the country in spite of all the high-pressure games that we play in," he concluded with that irritating splutter of disbelief. Would Lord Ferg be referring to a recent study of over 5,000 Premiership games which proved that 87% of refereeing decisions in Man Utd matches go the way of the Red Devils? We'll take that fountain of fresh mist as a no, then.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"Coaches are like fish; after a while they pick up a bad smell" - Giovanni Trapattoni, who admits he expects to leave Fiorentina at the end of the season, tries to sound brooding and mysterious like Cantona but doesn't quite manage it.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TWIT TWOO

So, Peter Shreeves eh? Affable fella, shiny bald patch, but not exactly the figure Sheffield Wednesday fans have in mind when looking for a messiah. Shreeves, however, is fully aware that he is only a short term solution for the club, and has no problem with that whatsoever. As he said today: "I have to help Wednesday get the points and if I achieve that I would, like everyone else want to stay employed." Er...

Wednesday chairman Howard Culley was quickly on hand to spin away poor deluded Mr Shreeves' remarks. "I am not ruling out Peter," he said oh-so-diplomatically, "but as far as I'm concerned this is an open field." Yes, that's right.

Howard Wilkinson remains the combine harvester in this particular field. The current England Under-21 boss is apparently keen to get back into club management this summer and the Wednesday board are said to be equally prepared to buy him out of his contract with the FA.

But, according to today's reports, just behind Wilko (consider him a mobile grain repository) is his Under-21 predecessor Peter Taylor. Taylor was dumped by the FA last year despite winning all his games, and has since done rather well at Gillingham - steering them into a second division play-off spot. Uncertainty remains over whether Taylor can step up to the big time however. One plan to assess his skills would see Taylor's Gills side pitted against Wednesday in a knock-out cup competition. Then we'd really see what he's made of.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Manchester United have sent scouts to Argentina to size up a possible £15m move for River Plate playmaker Pablo Aimar. The 20-year-old, who fits Lord Imperial Ferg's criteria for a midfielder by both making and scoring goals, is expected to move to Europe in the summer. "Aimar is certain to go to Europe but only for a lot of money" a River spokesman said.

Spurs midfielder Allan Nielsen looks set to move across the capital and join First Division Fulham. He will link up with fellow Danish international Bjarne Goldbaek.

Manchester City aim to complete the £500,000 signing of Derby defender Spencer Prior.

Real Madrid are ready to tempt Roma and Italy star Francesco Totti to move to Spain with a five-year £60,000-a-week deal. Any move for the apparently unsettled playmaker will however be over the dead body of Roma president Franco Sensi. "The player will not move because he is like a son to me", he said.

Rangers are chasing Sparta Prague striker Vratislav Lokvenc.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

A total of 20,000 tickets for the Big Cup final will go on sale to the general public from Friday. A new website - www.clubfinals.uefa.com - will enable supporters to buy tickets via the internet for the match on May 24 in the Stade de France.

Joe Cole has signed a lucrative two-year extension to his contract which ties him to West Ham until 2004.

Watford's Des Lyttle has joined West Brom on loan until the end of the season.

Parma striker Hernan Crespo has extended his contract with the Serie A side until June 2005. The deal ends speculation linking the Argentinian with Juventus.

Blackburn have signed a £1.75m kit deal with Italian firm Kappa.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: The Big Match - Live! (7.30pm)
Chelsea v Lazio. Will littledenniswise score a goal and then get in a fight while he's sitting injured on the sidelines? We reckon.

The Big Match (11.35pm)
No matter how hard you give out with the gravitas, Mr Venison, we can't stop thinking about your old suit and hair combinations. Nice try though.

Sky Sports 1: Futbol Mundial (7pm, 12.15am)
Crisp passing with a non-British flavour.

Soccer Special (7.30pm)
Jeff Stelling - now officially better than Des Lynam.

Sky Sports 3: Brian Moore Interviews (11pm)
Watch Brian glaze over as Jimmy Sirrel explains how he became manager of Brentford and then Notts County and then Sheffield United and then Notts County again and then Notts County again again.

ONsport1: Rosenborg v Real Madrid - Live (7.30pm)
Watch Steve McManaman come on for three minutes at the end and not touch the ball.

Chelsea v Lazio (9.55pm)
Watch this again but do please realise that your life is going nowhere.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football (7pm)
"I've never sat in a commentary position so bad," said Alan Green last night for the second time in a fortnight, before going on to diss the Nou Camp.

David Mellor (10pm)
Listen as jets of hot air whistle through that ridiculous gap in his teeth.

Marseille v Feyenoord. You can just about pick this up in France and Holland.

Alvin Martin's Big Cup Phone In (10pm)
Alvin Martin? He'd better sing I Feel Like Buddy Holly, we love that one.

webTitle: Kashmir violence beyond power of peacemaker Clinton

fields.headline: Kashmir violence beyond power of peacemaker Clinton
fields.standfirst: The US president's visit has only underlined the bitterness between India and Pakistan, and he has instead settled for fulfilling a lifetime's wish by seeing the Taj Mahal. Luke Harding reports from New Delhi
fields.trailText: The US president's visit has only underlined the bitterness between India and Pakistan, and he has instead settled for fulfilling a lifetime's wish by seeing the Taj Mahal. Luke Harding reports from New Delhi.
fields.body:
Bill Clinton yesterday made an urgent plea for India and Pakistan to resume their dialogue over Kashmir, as Indian forces waged an all-out gun battle with two militants holed up in a burning army building.

In an address to the Indian parliament, Mr Clinton ruled out mediating in the Kashmir conflict. "Only India and Pakistan" could work out their difficulties, he said, adding: "I can think of no enduring solution to this problem that can be achieved in any other way." He said he would take the same argument to General Musharraf, Pakistan's military ruler, during their brief meeting on Saturday at the end of the US president's visit.

His remarks came two days after unidentified gunmen had massacred 35 unarmed Sikhs in a Kashmiri village, and in the shadow of a fresh battle in Srinagar, Kashmir's summer capital, between Indian troops and separatists whom India claims are backed by Pakistan.

The gunmen stormed the army base on Tuesday night. After paramilitary troops had failed to dislodge them, the troops bombarded their own building for 24 hours using mortars and machine guns, and finally planted explosives on the roof. Two charred corpses were recovered.

India claimed the attack was another attempt to drag the United States into the conflict, and, in an interview with ABC yesterday, Mr Clinton went so far as to claim "elements within the Pakistani government supported those engaged in violence in Kashmir". Pakistan, meanwhile, blamed Monday's Sikh massacre on Indian security forces seeking to discredit the separatists.

In the first address by a US leader to India's parliament since 1978, Mr Clinton described India and the US as "natural allies" but renewed his call for India to sign up to a ban nuclear proliferation. "Most of the world is moving towards the elimination of nuclear weapons. That goal is not achieved if any country in any region moves in the other direction," he declared.

Responding in Hindi, the prime minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee, said that India had a minimum nuclear deterrent based on a realistic security assessment; its relationship with its neighbours had been "eroded", he added.

After meeting Sonia Gandhi, the leader of India's fading Congress Party, Mr Clinton took time off to pay a visit to India's most famous tourist attraction, the Taj Mahal at Agra. Walking hand-in-hand with his daughter, Chelsea, he posed in front of the manicured gardens of the Mughal mausoleum, declaring: 'I've wanted to come here all my life. Asked if he was awed by the sight, he replied: "How could you not be?"

Appalled by the fact that the 17th century monument was turning black, environmentalists and the government have recently moved to save the Taj, by banning traffic from the surrounding area and banishing heavy industry. Mr Clinton yesterday announced $200m in grants for clean energy projects in India, as well as the easing of sanctions on energy co-operation imposed after India's 1998 nuclear test.

The US president, who bought several silk carpets on his credit card from a hotel emporium hours after arriving in Delhi, last night travelled to Jaipur for more sight-seeing. He will today tour a tiger reserve that once served as the private hunting grounds of the local maharajas, as well as the Amber Fort.

webTitle: Two new awards for the Guardian

fields.headline: Two new awards for the Guardian
fields.trailText: The Guardian's Nick Davies was named reporter of the year and the newspaper's internet news service, News Unlimited, the online service of the year at the British Press Awards last night.
fields.body:
The Guardian's Nick Davies was named reporter of the year and the newspaper's internet news service, News Unlimited, the online service of the year at the British Press Awards last night.

webTitle: We are all aliens, say Nasa

fields.headline: We are all aliens, say Nasa
fields.trailText: Weird gases from outer space arrived on Earth during a dinosaur-killing asteroid strike 65 million years ago, and survive in molecular cages called buckyballs, researchers reported on Tuesday. Buckyballs probably drifted into the solar system early on, bringing carbon and other material from far away. "Most of the carbon in our bodies came from outside the solar system," said Ted Bunch of Nasa's Ames Research Centre in California.
fields.body:
Weird gases from outer space arrived on Earth during a dinosaur-killing asteroid strike 65 million years ago, and survive in molecular cages called buckyballs, researchers reported on Tuesday.

Buckyballs probably drifted into the solar system early on, bringing carbon and other material from far away.

"Most of the carbon in our bodies came from outside the solar system," said Ted Bunch of Nasa's Ames Research Centre in California. "We're all aliens."

Buckyballs, lacy-looking molecules made up of carbon atoms, are also known as fullerenes and are named in honour of Buckminster Fuller because they are shaped like the geodesic dome he invented.

They can form on Earth but also are born outside our solar system, in hot areas of the universe such as the gas envelopes around embryonic stars. The buckyballs in question came in on the killer asteroid.

The gas-carrying buckyballs were found in various parts of the globe, from North America to New Zealand to Denmark, in a layer of sediment laid down after an ancient asteroid impact.

"The buckyballs containing the gases arrived on Earth about 65 million years ago during an asteroid impact that scientists theorise ended the age of the dinosaurs," said Bunch.

The impact of the big space rock may have killed the dinosaurs and most earthly life with its globe-girdling dust cloud, but the sturdy little buckyballs survived with their gaseous cargo intact, Bunch and his colleagues reported in the March 28 edition of the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.

The article was available to subscribers on the Internet on Tuesday.

Inside the buckyballs was a strange type of cosmic helium, along with other gases, Bunch said in a telephone interview.

Helium created on Earth usually has four sub-atomic particles in its nucleus, while cosmic helium generally has only three, the scientists said.

"They're enriched helium 3," Bunch said. "We know by the helium signature that it was formed probably outside the solar system... they've trapped them inside (the buckyballs) at the site of formation."

This weird helium shows, as no other evidence has, that buckyballs can transport extraterrestrial gases without letting them escape on the way. Future research may focus on other gases that might have come to Earth in this fashion.

This research also supports the theory that gases that make up Earth's atmosphere and organic compounds came to Earth's surface during the so-called age of bombardment, some 3.8 billion to 4.5 billion years ago, when "asteroids were running wild in their orbits," as Bunch put it.

This was the period when the Moon's craters were gouged out by asteroids, comets and meteors, which also slammed into Earth, Mars and other celestial bodies.

fields.headline: American Mom
fields.trailText: Little League baseball is a rite of passage for every red-blooded American boy. Come Saturday morning, you will find thousands of them batting, pitching and running around baseball diamonds dotted across the continent. You will also, unfortunately, find their parents in the stands, swearing and foaming at the mouth when little Johnny strikes out. Sometimes it gets violent, as in Greensville, North Carolina recently, when a mother was charged with punching the referee of her child's game.
fields.body:
Little League baseball is a rite of passage for every red-blooded American boy. Come Saturday morning, you will find thousands of them batting, pitching and running around baseball diamonds dotted across the continent. You will also, unfortunately, find their parents in the stands, swearing and foaming at the mouth when little Johnny strikes out. Sometimes it gets violent, as in Greensville, North Carolina recently, when a mother was charged with punching the referee of her child's game.

In a culture obsessed with winning, the problem of abusive parents at the little league ballpark has hit a new high. Except in Florida. This month 2,000 parents in the city of Jupiter signed contracts promising to behave or have little Johnny thrown off the team.

They also had to watch a 19-minute video about sportsmanship and ethics in competition. If they break the pledge, they are allowed one chance to rehabilitate themselves. After that, mom, dad and Johnny are banned.

The video and ethics contract is the brainchild of Fred Engh, president of the National Alliance for Youth Sports, based in West Palm Beach, Florida. Engh says studies have shown 70% of American children who participate in sports quit by 13 because of unpleasant experiences, often involving adults humiliating them over poor performance.

"In America the mantra is, win at any cost. Parents cannot stand a child that does not succeed, and when they fail, the parents become so emotional, they lose perspective and become verbally or physically abusive. I see sports as the greatest gift you can give your child. It teaches teamwork, discipline, and social skills. And at 3 or 5 or 8, it is supposed to be fun. Unfortunately many parents don't see it that way. They encourage their children to cheat, anything to win. That is why we had to do something."

The parents of children in the Jupiter league were the first in the US to attend the ethics class and sign the contract. Since then, Engh says he has been inundated with calls from coaches across America desperate to implement identical contracts.

"I am hearing now just how bad it has become when parents can't get their egos out of their kids' games. Hopefully more leagues will insist parents sign these contracts, and their children can go back to being kids again."

fields.headline: Let the birthday battle commence
fields.trailText: My part-time daughter, Gloria, is 12 years old on Friday. The build-up to this occasion has been marked by such concerted backstairs manoeuvring, spin-doctoring and whisper-campaigning that the Millbank media goon squad looks idle by comparison.
fields.body:
My part-time daughter, Gloria, is 12 years old on Friday. The build-up to this occasion has been marked by such concerted backstairs manoeuvring, spin-doctoring and whisper-campaigning that the Millbank media goon squad looks idle by comparison. One day, some avenging god of post-modern families will strike down part-time parents who behave the way that I have recently. On giant Farley's rusks the wages of my sins shall be engraved: "Do not go the way of Fallen Father Joseph Stone, a path of plotting, conniving and outrageous indulgence."

OK. I confess. But I am not ashamed. The battle for birthday honours was joined two Sundays ago. Gloria, Jed and Billy returned from their "other home" in their customary moods: sniffy, silent and over-stimulated respectively. As I was stonewalled by Jed and talked into a torpor by Billy, Gloria went upstairs to be made civil again by champion stepmum, Angie, and half-sister, Estelle. Then Angie and I rendezvoused in the bathroom to swap notes.

"This is going to annoy you," Angie warned.

"Oooh, goodie!"

"Dilys is getting her a kitten for her birthday."

"For fuck's sake."

"And Chris is getting her a laptop."

"That man is a pillock."

We said nothing for minute. How could we match that? The cistern gurgled. A tap dripped. Then I weakly offered: "What about a puppy?"

Angie thought not: "Too obvious. And you'll end up being the one who takes it walkies."

"All right. An iMac, then? They don't even need feeding."

"We can't afford an iMac."

"True. So how about we get you pregnant?"

"Honestly!"

"Well, Gloria would love that. And she can go back to Chez Pillock and tell them all about it. That'd really piss them off."

Angie conceded that this did hold some appeal. But intercourse is one thing, conception something else, and Angie's menstrual calendar made the timing tricky. To have stood the slightest chance we'd have had to have gone at it there and then: feasible in theory, but lino can be awfully cold.

We pondered our plight again a few days later on reverting to a family of three. There had, we reflected, been low-level shenanigans at Chez Pillock for some time. It is our year to have Gloria on her birthday, but that hadn't stopped Dilys trying to backslide on the deal. She had floated a proposal to split the day in two, with Gloria waking up in our house but returning to Chez Pillock after school - all this subtlely conveyed via Gloria, naturally.

"An interesting suggestion," I'd responded, innocently. "And what would happen on the Friday evening?"

"Oh, I don't know," Gloria had evaded, airily Dilys-like. "Maybe I could go out to the pictures; maybe have some friends for a sleep-over."

"Nice idea," I'd agreed, pleasantly, boiling with rage on the inside.

"Trouble is, Angie and I have already made plans for your birthday night. Deadly secret ones, of course."

No such plans existed. Gloomily I re-lived the exchange to Angie. Typically, she became inspired. "We've got to top a kitten and a laptop. So give her the day off school. Take her to some shops. Buy her anything she wants."

"Anything?"

"Oh, why not? Flashy frocks. Nail varnish. Unsuitable shoes. All the things Dilys doesn't approve of."

I especially liked that last part. So the next time Gloria was with me I put the idea to her. And I threw in pizza and ice cream. Oh, and how about a visit to the cinema later on? To see the lovely Leo in The Beach?

"But that's a '15'!" Gloria exclaimed.

"Oh, I'll sneak you in. And why not invite some friends? They can sleep over if they want."

Of course, I don't much care for Leo and, nor does Gloria. But that isn't the point. The point is for Gloria to feel grown-up and me to put one over on Dilys and Chris The Pillock. They may prevail as providers of cute pets and portable computers, but when it comes to fostering improper behaviour, I'm the boss.

"Just think what they'll be like on Saturday morning," Angie mused. Oh yes: half a dozen girls in early adolescence staggering down for breakfast after a late night of giggling, shrieking and trying on each others' clothes. And just think of me on Saturday lunchtime dropping off Gloria on Chez Pillock's doorstep, all red-eyed and ratty in that certain way that so reminds me of her mother. Happy weekend Chris and Dilys! Happy birthday Gloria!

fields.headline: Don't wait up
fields.standfirst: What happens when your baby flies the nest into the nocturnal life of the teenager?  Sam Jordison hears how to survive the after-hours world of sex, fights and drinking
fields.trailText: What happens when your baby flies the nest into the nocturnal life of the teenager? Sam Jordison hears how to survive the after-hours world of sex, fights and drinking.
fields.body:
The night on the town is a modern-day rite of passage. As children grow up, they go out. They get drunk, they have fights, they have sex. They do foolish things they may regret, but from which they will also learn.

They leave you and their homework. The smell of sick in the bathroom may be the closest contact you get with them for weeks. They leave the security of the home for an unknown night world of hidden dangers and grasping strangers.

They spurn your offers of a lift home and, particularly if they are boys, may even turn down the comparative safety of a taxi. According to statistics in the British crime survey, males under the age of 24 are more than twice as likely to be the victims of violent crime as women, but they are generally more blasé about problems on the street.

Antony Ionnu, 17, never uses cabs. He says: "The prices are ridiculous, far out of the range of the average male teenager who has to buy beer as well." And why should they worry about cabs? Most don't regard getting home as an issue, as long as they're with other people. "It's just not a hassle," says 14-year-old Bernard Taylor. Neither of them, or any of their friends, have ever been hurt.

Eloise Millar, now 23, looking back on her own teenage nights on the town, thinks it's because girls have more to worry about: "Boys tend to get into fights or get hassled for money and girls get hassled for sex."

Eloise has had her fair share of run-ins with suspect men: "I've had loads of flashers on the way home from clubs and men who get their willies out on buses." She is able to laugh these incidents off; none was very serious and she was with friends.

That is not to say that getting home in the dead of night when drunk or even just tired is easy. Most public transport shuts down well before the clubs do. London at least has night buses, but they are notoriously infrequent and unpleasant. Everyone who uses them seems to have witnessed at least one scene of vomiting, violence, drug abuse or worse.

Rachel Smith, 15, had a stomach-turning experience at 4am one morning on the 134 to Muswell Hill in north London. "I was really tired and just wanted to go home when two guys got on. They'd obviously been drinking loads and started talking to some French girls behind me. The girls couldn't understand them, but they kept on all the same. I tried to explain and make them leave the girls alone, but they turned on me and started getting really aggressive. Then my friend's boyfriend threw a bottle of water on them. One guy tried to jump on him, but because he was really drunk he was just sick all over the place, including on my friend and her boyfriend. It was disgusting."

Rachel and her friends jumped off when the bus stopped, and the doors closed in time to shut the vomiters on board. She recounts another occasion when she was approached by a man in Leicester Square who put his arm around her. She screamed, her friend jumped in front of him and the others made him run off.

Rachel is fairly nonchalent about it. She says she has been in several similar situations, but it hasn't put her off, she explains: "We normally only go out in big groups. We stick together and make sure we're all right."

And there does seem to be some safety in numbers. The death last year of 17-year-old Ashleigh Robinson, is a frightening example of what can happen when friends are unable to take care of each other. Ashleigh was with a group who were returning home from a club in Guildford by hired coach. She became separated from her friends because she was thrown out of the club. While waiting outside in the cold she was picked up by a passer-by and found dead the next morning.

Hearing stories like this, parents are bound to worry. Keren Smedley has had many arguments with her three children. "My anxiety is often irrational, but I can't help it," she says. "And things do go wrong. While kids say it can't happen to me, parents say it can. I've never wanted to feel, 'if only I had . . .' If I don't know where they are I will chase it up. There's a chance they could be lying in a ditch. If I chase it up, they won't be there as long."

But perhaps we should give young people a little more credit. If they are allowed to, they really can look after each other. Ashleigh's friends had no idea where she was because no one told them she had been forced to leave. When it became apparent that she was not there, they raised the alarm, insisted on seeing CCTV footage from cameras outside the club and, when they did not show that Ashleigh was safe, they called the police. They were too late. Had the bouncers from the club notified Ashleigh's friends of her ejection they would have been able to look after her.

Nights on the town are not without dangers but nor are most teenagers without sense. In a big group, one or two generally stay sober and, increasingly, carry mobile phones so they can make contact if the worst comes to the worst. The bright lights and bad people do not faze them.

"There's loads of weird people out there," according to 14-year-old Amy Burrows, but she and her friends stick together, sleeping over at each other's houses so that no one has to go home alone. What unwanted attention they have received, they have been able to cope with as a group.

"We have been approached by old blokes saying dirty stuff," says Amy "but we've been together. You just ignore them. I really can't remember anything too bad happening. We were even followed by two people once, but my friends got lairy and argued with them till they went away. On New Year's Eve two blokes did get nasty and chased us, but we ran into a shop."

Parental anxiety, while understandable, can become a bigger problem than anything that happens in town. Selina Papa's most enduringly bad memory of years of going out in London was all down to her parents. "It was my first big night out, I'd drunk one too many Hooches, and was waiting for a certain guy to catch my eye when the crowds parted to reveal mum and dad bearing down on me. They were so anxious to get me home they forgot I told them to wait for me at the bus stop 100 yards down the road. It was incredibly humiliating."

Young people's advice on avoiding danger

 Do not go out alone. There is safety in numbers.

 Make sure you have financial back-up in case you are forced to get a cab.

 Carry a mobile phone.

 Make sure some take the responsibility of not getting as wasted as the others so they can help navigate home.

 Stay over at people's houses so that you don't have to get home seperately.

 Be prepared to phone your parents in the worst-case scenario. Much as they may hate to be woken up, they would prefer it to a call from the hospital.

On New Year's Eve two blokes did get nasty and chased us, but we ran into a shop." Parental anxiety, while understandable, can become a bigger problem than anything that happens in town. Selina Papa's most enduringly bad memory of years of going out in London was all down to her parents. "It was my first big night out, I'd drunk one too many Hooches, and was waiting for a certain guy to catch my eye when the crowds parted to reveal mum and dad bearing down on me. They were so anxious to get me home they forgot I told them to wait for me at the bus stop 100 yards down the road. It was incredibly humiliating." Young people's advice on avoiding danger  Do not go out alone. There is safety in numbers.  Make sure you have financial back-up in case you are forced to get a cab.  Carry a mobile phone.  Make sure some take the responsibility of not getting as wasted as the others so they can help navigate home.  Stay over at people's houses so that you don't have to get home seperately.  Be prepared to phone your parents in the worst-case scenario. Much as they may hate to be woken up, they would prefer it to a call from the hospital.

fields.headline: If you knew Lucy
fields.standfirst:
Tucked away at 32 in last week's poll of the nation's favourite authors - ahead of Sebastian Faulks, George Orwell, PG Wodehouse and William Shakespeare - lay one Lucy Daniels. So who is she? John Crace finds out
Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: Tucked away at 32 in last week's poll of the nation's favourite authors - ahead of Sebastian Faulks, George Orwell, PG Wodehouse and William Shakespeare - lay one Lucy Daniels. So who is she? John Crace finds out.
fields.body:
Unless you have a daughter under the age of 12, the chances are that the name Lucy Daniels doesn't mean that much to you. But Lucy Daniels is a publishing phenomenon. Since her first book, Kittens in the Kitchen, was published in March 1994, she has gone on to write nearly 100 more. Visit amazon.com and you will find more than 200 listings for titles in various editions, including audio cassettes, and earlier this year she celebrated five million UK sales.

Now take JK Rowling. Her combined UK sales are just 1.7m, excluding internet and book club orders. So how come JK feels like an old mate and Lucy is a total nobody? The simple answer is that she is a nobody. She doesn't exist. She is a brand, not a person.

The Lucy Daniels story begins with two men: Ben Baglio, an American children's book packager, and Rod Ritchie, managing director of Hodder prior to its merger with Headline. Baglio moved to the UK in the early 90s and had moderate successes with Mystery Club, a kid's crime series, and Mystery Kids, a Grange Hill-type series, both of which have since been dumped by Hodder. But with Lucy Daniels he struck gold.

"Vets and animals were becoming extremely popular on TV," says Baglio, "and I had the idea of this idealised setting that harked back to those non-existent golden days when everyone knew each other, but nobody pried. I also had in mind a middle-American view of England as thatched cottages, but without the caricature, as I thought this might attract US sales."

The idea that emerged was Animal Ark, featuring Mandy Hope, the daughter of two vets, who goes round solving crimes and injustices against unsuspecting members of the animal kingdom. But books don't write themselves, so Baglio and Ritchie turned to Lesley Hadcroft of Laurence Pollinger, one of the best-known agents for children's books, to tap into her stable of authors.

"Ben appeared with a brief that ran to a couple of sides of A4 and an advance of £1,200 per book," says Hadcroft. "Together we commissioned the first six titles."

The list of Animal Ark authors reads like a Who's Who of children's fiction. Sue Welford, a Whitbread prize nominee, Jenny Oldfield and Helen Magee, all of whom are names in their own right, have done a turn as Lucy Daniels. In Jenny Oldfield's case, she has done dozens of turns, and the reason is simple: money. A three-to-four-week spell spent writing a 25,000-word Animal Ark manuscript can net the author over £20,000 in royalties and foreign rights.

The name Lucy Daniels was chosen extremely carefully. "We wanted the author to be a woman, so we took the name Lucy from one of the editors at Hodder," says Baglio. "The name Daniels was used to position ourselves next to Colin Dann, author of The Animals of Farthing Wood, on the bookshelves."

Initially, the strategy backfired as sales were disappointing. "Our original jackets featured Mandy and a furry animal," says Baglio. "We decided to dispense with Mandy and make the animals much larger. We got in the artist who drew the cat on the Go-Kat packaging and he created some brilliant images."

Since then there has been no looking back. In addition to Animal Ark, there are now Animal Ark Pets, the stories of some of the original animals when they were small, Animal Ark Hauntings, ghost stories with positive messages, Little Animal Ark, for younger readers, Perfect Ponies and Nine Lives. The possibilities are literally endless because for every new idea there will always be an author out there somewhere.

The Lucy Daniels books are not bad books; many are surprisingly - or not so surprisingly, once you know the real author - well written. But the real success story lies in the sheer volume of titles. At one book a year, JK is positively idle compared with Lucy. Which is why, within the trade, there is a grudging admission that Hodder Headline may have cracked the holy grail of children's publishing with Lucy Daniels. Enid Blyton tends to be sneered at by almost everyone these days, but in more honest moments every publisher would sell his or her soul to have a non-stop production line of best-selling titles. The only difference between Daniels and Blyton is that one is real and one is not.

Not that all those children who write regularly to Lucy and receive a copy of her newsletter know that. "Lucy is real to many of our readers and we don't want to upset them," said a rather anxious woman at Hodder.

If you think Lucy Daniels is the last word in cynical marketing hype, consider this. Have you ever wondered why JK Rowling wasn't called Joanna on the jacket? An authorial diktat? No. The marketing department at Bloomsbury thought boy readers would be put off by a woman's name.

fields.headline: Jam tomorrow
fields.standfirst: The chancellor announced a small increase in benefits for new mothers yesterday. But parents hoping for extra maternity pay or help with childcare will be disappointed.  Anne Perkins  reports on another opportunity missed
fields.trailText: The chancellor announced a small increase in benefits for new mothers yesterday. But parents hoping for extra maternity pay or help with childcare will be disappointed. Anne Perkins reports on another opportunity missed
fields.body:
There was gloom last night among analysts and campaigners who'd been led to expect a "budget bonanza for babies". On a dozen measures ranging from real income to educational attainment, from rates of maternity pay to the quality and affordability of childcare, Britain bumps along behind not only Scandinavia and other prosperous northern European countries, but also the struggling economies of Portugal and Greece.

The chancellor Gordon Brown, as he reminded us again yesterday, doesn't like the figures about childhood poverty that keep leaving their grubby prints on his glistening economic record. He's committed to erasing forever the headline "Britain bottom of the table for child well-being" (last week's, but it could have been written at any time in the past 20 years). But yesterday's budget is unlikely to help much.

Ruth Lister, professor of social policy at Loughborough University, pointed out that budgets are about priorities, and family poverty was clearly not as high as had been hoped: "So much more could have been done if we weren't spending £3bn on cutting the basic rate of tax."

Having a baby in Britain continues to be like playing one of those Victorian games of snakes and ladders. Every throw of the dice takes you to another lesson in morality. For one family in six, it means stepping off the ladder marked "job and security" and into the jaws of the snake marked "baby and poverty" - less income, more outgoings, and an uncertain future at work.

As last week's headlines confirmed, there is still much more to be done before we reach a place where parents can make real choices about how to balance caring and working, where, for example, benefits will allow a mother to take a year off with her baby and still go back to her old job, where both parents are entitled to paid leave in the early years and can work sensible hours later on, and where affordable, good quality childcare is not an issue because it's there.

Yesterday barely took us within shouting distance of Scandinavia. Buried in the dense Treasury-speak there was an announcement of extra cash for the first six months after the birth of a baby - but only for those new mothers on Working Families Tax Credit. The change was welcomed by Harriet Harman, who's still a frequent visitor to the chancellor's spacious office. There was a promise of a review of arrangements for maternity pay and leave, and family-friendly working policies, and an extra £100 on the means tested maternity grant - raising it to £300. (The Maternity Alliance says it needs to be at least twice that). Finally a new Children's Tax Credit is to be introduced to replace the Married Man's Allowance - something long campaigned for - but sadly a year's gap has been left between the abolition of one and the start of the other.

The trade secretary Stephen Byers will now have to try to find a balance between demands from women, who would like to be able to afford to stay home longer and return part time, and business which has flatly rejected paid parental leave and still appears cool about reforming work practices.

There was more enthusiasm for the extra investment in the New Deal for Lone Parents (underfunded compared with all the other New Deals) which will at last boost training opportunities and help to get women into jobs that will last, at rates of pay that make working viable. And there was a shoal of small increases in benefits which will help the least well off.

To most chancellors, we are all economic units. Gordon Brown is no different. His policies, endorsed by research summarised in a Treasury paper last autumn, are about making us more efficient. The research, which the chancellor referred to again yesterday, confirmed the poverty spiral: children born and raised in poverty are much more likely themselves to be poor, to be convicted of a criminal offence, or to become a teenage mother. Having children can condemn women to poverty in old age: the longer they are out of the job market, the harder it is to get back in; lacking the opportunity to stay in the job market, they miss out on access to pension supplements and in old age have only the basic state pension to rely on. And the poor tend also to live in areas with worse schools, an over-stretched health service and to experience worse housing.

So the answer is to make it worthwhile, feasible and not too complicated to get back to work, which in turn means children will be better provided for in a better and more positive environment. That is at the heart of the latest big idea: the Integrated Child Credit. This consolidation of all benefits and tax allowances for children, providing a fixed and predictable income bridging the difficult transfer from benefit to work, was announced in the pre-budget report in the autumn. There was fevered speculation that it would be fleshed out yesterday. Instead it was dismissed in a couple of lines with a promise that it would be introduced in the next three years.

This suggests that no way has been found round the problem of trying to decide how to calculate it. Should it be based on combined family income or calculated on the income of the highest earner? The former provides better targeting at low-income families but would spell the end of independent taxation.

It was another bad day for universal benefits, the glue, many people still believe, of a cohesive society. With only a small increase in Child Benefit, there are indications that the Treasury is ready to allow it to wither in favour of the more targeted Integrated Child Credit.

"There are some good things," said Mary-Ann Stephenson, director of the Fawcett Society, who spent the afternoon with the Women's Budget Group. "At least there weren't more tax cuts and there was a massive boost for health and education, which have a powerful impact on the lives of women and children."

No one doubts Gordon Brown's determination to tackle poverty. He is not shy of using the tax and benefits system for social as well as economic ends. But it seems right now he is not ready with the next step. That much more time then, to pursuade him of what it should be.

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The question: Your child has chickenpox. Should you be allowed to send her to nursery school?
fields.trailText: The question: Your child has chickenpox. Should you be allowed to send her to nursery school?
fields.body:
Roy Macgregor General Practitioner, Kentish Town Health Centre, London.

In the US it's not uncommon to have chickenpox parties, and I'm all in favour of children passing it on to other children - it is best for them to have it while they're young, there's more chance of complications if you get it as an adult. There is a significant risk of damage to the baby if a mother-to-be contracts chickenpox in early pregnancy - so if all girls got it as children, that wouldn't be a problem. But a word of warning: there are other conditions that look like chickenpox, and if we encouraged parents to send their children to nursery we would risk children going in with something different.

Caronline Dowdell Mother of a five-year-old and a one-year-old child.

My children haven't had chickenpox, but I can't say it's something I'd actively want - no one wants their child to get ill, it's really distressing. I certainly wouldn't go running around to someone else's house if their child had it, and if my own did have it I wouldn't send them out looking all spotty. When I was pregnant one of my nieces had it, and I was worried about whether it could have caused me any problems - fortunately it didn't, but if you let your children with chickenpox go to nursery you might infect another mother who's pregnant, which could be dangerous.

Judy McRae Chair of the Royal College of Nursing school nurses forum.

We follow the advice of the Department of Health, which says that children should stay away from school for five days from the onset of the rash. But there are two provisos - if there are pregnant women, or children with, for example, leukaemia who are at particular risk, parents should be more careful about keeping their children out of the way. Even after five days, if the child still needs calamine lotion because of itching, the nursery may not be willing to have him back - giving medication to schoolchildren is voluntary and can be controversial.

Ruth Evans Mother of three-and-a-half-year-old Polly.

Yes, providing she's well enough. Polly was perfectly well when she had it recently, but her nursery wouldn't accept her. She was bored at home, and she wanted to be with her friends. And the ironic thing is that most of those friends' parents wanted them to catch it. It isn't just that it's inconvenient for parents like me when our children can't go to nursery, it's also that it's good for children to get chickenpox while they're young. Most of them get it from nursery anyway, and they're already infectious before the spots come out - but despite being well, you're not allowed to send them.

Anita Pearson Proprietor of the Bluebells Nursery in north west London.

We don't like children to come back to nursery until at least seven days after their spots have come out. Sometimes they're well, but even then their spots get sore and they often get tired and want their parents. There's also the risk of a member of staff getting chickenpox, or shingles. But the main reason is the other parents - we just don't think it's fair to them, it might not be a good time for their children to get chickenpox. It might not be convenient for them to take time off work - or they might have a holiday coming up.

webTitle: Good vibrations: the quest for the ultimate theory of everything

fields.headline: Good vibrations: the quest for the ultimate theory of everything
fields.standfirst: In this exclusive online essay taken from the current edition of the London Review of Books, George Ellis considers the astonishing implications of Superstring theory
fields.trailText: George Ellis on Superstring theory
fields.body:
The Elegant Universe: Superstrings, Hidden Dimensions and the Quest for the Ultimate Theory by Brian Greene (Vintage, 448 pp., £7.99)
Buy it at BOL

The great ambition of scientists is to grasp the far from obvious nature of the physical world at ever more fundamental levels, and in doing so, to unify our understanding of phenomena that had previously appeared to be disparate. We have been enormously successful in this, demonstrating that complex objects are made from simpler components, and they in turn are made of even simpler ones. Everything around us, ourselves included, is composed of molecules, which are composed of atoms - carbon, nitrogen, oxygen, phosphorus and so on - which are composed of negatively charged electrons, and a nucleus of positively charged protons and uncharged neutrons, which are composed of quarks. Thus underlying the immense complexity of life is a simplicity of microscopic composition.

The way in which these various particles combine and interact is controlled by just four fundamental forces: the electromagnetic force, which unifies electricity and magnetism and is the common basis of light, radiowaves and X-rays (all now identified as electromagnetic waves); the gravitational force, which as well as causing things to fall onto the floor, causes the planets to move around the sun and galaxies round each other; the weak nuclear force, which is responsible for hard-to-detect effects such as the radioactive decay of neutrons into protons and electrons; and the strong nuclear force, which holds the protons and neutrons in the nucleus of an atom together, thus making it stable despite the electrical repulsion between the protons that tends to rip it apart.

It has taken centuries to arrive at the amazingly successful understanding of the structure of the physical world that we now have, whose basic feature is the law-like descriptions we can give of the behaviour of matter, testable in detail by experiments. These laws are formulated mathematically, enable us to make quantitative predictions, and are universal inasmuch as they are believed to apply to all matter at all times and in all places. If we discovered matter that didn't obey them, that would signal that we needed to modify our understanding and look for more general relationships still.

Our understanding of both particles and the forces involved in their interactions has evolved in response to ever more refined data from experiments. In particular, the question of whether, at its most fundamental level, matter behaves in a 'wave-like' or 'particle-like' way has been a source of continuing puzzlement. Our present belief, based in quantum theory (the theory that describes the behaviour of matter at very small scales), is that, at sub-atomic levels, matter isn't either wave-like or particle-like in nature but both, depending on the circumstances, and behaves unpredictably in a manner quite unlike anything we are familiar with in everyday life.

Our ideas about forces have also undergone a major evolution, from being thought of as simply constituting the direct action of one object on another, either through contact or at a distance, then as being mediated by the effects of various 'fields' pervading space and time - e.g. the electromagnet ic field that currents and magnets generate, exerting forces on charged particles - and finally to being understood as involving the exchange of force-carrying particles, photons in the case of electromagnetism, gluons in the case of the strong nuclear force.

Forces and particles, then, are not as distinct from each other as was once thought. Additionally, it seems now that not even the four 'fundamental' forces are independent of each other, but that the electromagnetic and weak nuclear forces are in fact different aspects of a single, more fundamental force, which would have functioned as a single interaction in the very early days of the Universe but appears under present-day conditions to comprise separate forces. Attempts to include the strong nuclear force also in this unifying scheme are well advanced.

Even our understanding of space and time has evolved, these formerly distinct concepts now being understood as separate aspects of a single four-dimensional space-time continuum. This has two quite different sets of implications. On a large scale, gravity (which controls the evolution of the Universe) is now seen as being caused by the curvature of four-dimensional space-time, and as able to convey energy over vast distances by means of gravitational waves. This in turn has led to a major revision of the concept of a 'vacuum' - understood nowadays not as an emptiness with nothing happening in it, but as a seething sea of particle and anti-particle pairs continually coming into existence and annihilating. All of this follows from the unification of relativity theory and quantum theory, two of the great intellectual achievements of this century.

Despite all these advances, however, there are still great gaps to be filled in. The quest now is for an even more fundamental theory that would unify gravitation and quantum theory - something that has so far eluded us. The hope is that such a theory would also include the other three fundamental forces in a single scheme, and show them to be simply different aspects of a single 'super-force', explaining into the bargain many properties of fundamental particles that at the moment appear somewhat arbitrary.

The most promising attempts made to date have given us the family of what are known as Superstring theories, in which our ideas of both particles and of space-time are revised in an astonishing way. According to Superstring theorists, our perceived four-dimensional space-time has to be seen as only an approximation to a ten or eleven-dimensional space-time, with the other six or seven spatial dimensions rolled up so small that they are indistinguishable from a point. On top of which, particles are no longer to be seen as point-like objects, but rather as patterns of vibrations of extended two-dimensional objects like strings or ribbons; thus electrons and quarks, for example, would be made up of vibrating Superstrings.

This whole structure is subject to so-called 'Supersymmetry', whereby kinds of particle with apparently quite different properties are found to be related to each other and indeed may be transformed into each other under certain circumstances. For this method of unification to work, we need to identify symmetries in the inter actions re presented by (often hidden) similarities in the laws of physics. A simple example: if a physical system's interactions are constant in time, then its dynamical properties are the same at later times as they were at earlier times, and its energy is conserved; if the system's interactions are constant in space, then its momentum is conserved. And just as it's possible to represent mathematic ally the symmetries involved in the rotations of a solid object (a cube, say) that move it in such a way as to leave it exactly where it was but with the different faces rotated into each other, so we can represent the relation between families of fundamental particles in terms of abstract rotations that transform them into each other. Realising this has enabled physicists to predict the existence of previously unknown types of particle, which are required if we're to complete the symmetry patterns. Experimental proof of their existence has been a major vindication of this form of analysis.

Up until quite recently, there were five alternative Superstring theories on offer, each with somewhat different symmetries, but this has now become an area of much excitement, as new unifications are achieved between models previously seen as distinct, suggesting that there may be only one theory that encompasses and unifies all of the others. The excitement came about with the discovery by the American theoretical physicist, Edward Witten, of previously undetected further sets of symmetries (or 'dualities'), which link various parts of the theory, in particular its reasonably well- understood low-energy aspects to the rather ill-understood high-energy ones, where it's not even clear how to formulate the theory. This should help us to understand 'strong-coupling' behaviour, which occurs when the interactions in a physical system are in tense because the energies involved are high, and which has hitherto been inaccessible because we don't know how to solve the immensely complex relevant equations. We can now do this by using one of the new symmetries to compare strong-coupling behaviour with the corresponding properties in a 'weak-coupling' regime, where the interactions are weak and thus easy to analyse. As the hype would have it, the discovery of these theoretical structures may mean we can one day complete the physicists' ultimate dream - a Theory of Everything (TOE) that will explain the behaviour of all the fundamental particles and forces in a single framework.

In The Elegant Universe, Brian Greene guides us through these fundamental ideas and recent developments in as full and comprehensible a way as is possible without going into the exceedingly difficult mathematics involved. He aims to explain many of the central ideas of Superstring theories by means of analogy and explanatory diagrams rather than equations, and I can only say that his book is an explanatory tour de force.

He starts with the basic ideas of relativity and quantum theory, explaining why these need to be unified, and then moves onto Superstrings. Here he goes into detail about the notion of 'quantum spin' (a microscopic version of the spin that can be put on a tennis ball) that separates particles into two distinct families: matter particles, which spin at one speed, and force-carrying particles that either don't spin or spin twice as much, but four times as much when the force is gravitational. He next shows how the theory of Supersymmetry connects these two families of particles and in so doing predicts the existence of many new part icles which we've yet to detect. From there, Greene goes on to the strange idea that the Universe may have more dimensions than meet the eye, may have 'both extended and curled-up dimensions'. The hope that we will be able to unify existing physical theories by means of these extra dimensions follows from ideas originally introduced by Theodor Kaluza and Oskar Klein, who suggested that space-time was really five rather than four-dimensional, the postulated fifth dimension carrying the electric and magnetic fields.

Superstring theory in fact requires the Universe to have no fewer than nine spatial dimensions. The question then arises of why the three of them we are familiar with should be large and the other six so small as to be unnoticeable. Another problem arises from the extraordinarily complex structure that these curled-up dimensions are required to have: they are connected together in a contorted topology that is extremely difficult to describe. Nevertheless, the theory holds that they 'are an integral and ubiquitous part of the spatial fabric: they exist everywhere'.

Greene is now at the point where he can deliver the final, astonishing, unifying vision:

"From one principle - that everything at its most microscopic level consists of combinations of vibrating strands - string theory provides a single explanatory framework capable of encompassing all forces and all matter... The observed particle properties... are a reflection of the various ways in which a string can vibrate... Force particles are also associated with particular patterns of string vibration, and hence everything, all matter and all forces, is unified under the same rubric of microscopic string oscillations - the 'notes' that a string can play.

This result necessitates the existence of an infinite number of other particles in addition to those we've detected so far, but almost all of them will have to be so massive that we cannot now, nor indeed will be able ever, to achieve experimentally the energies that would be required to observe them.

Greene comes right up to date by describing the dualities that tie the various aspects of string theory into a unity (the so-called 'M theory'), and discusses the way this can be used to calculate properties of black holes, before speculating about how it might all relate to cosmology. In particular, the theory has been used to calculate the number of physic al states that are no longer accessible to an observer because they are hidden behind the 'horizon' of a black hole. This calculation serves to confirm in an interesting way the idea first discovered by Bekenstein and Hawking, that when they collapse, massive astrophysical objects create a black hole which has remarkable thermodynamic properties, similar to those of ordinary thermodynamics - thus linking quantum theory, gravitational theory and thermodynamics in a way never before achieved.

It would be hard to imagine anyone producing a clearer account than this of the difficult ideas involved, and Greene even brings out something of the actual excitement of scientific discovery when he recalls his own role in exploring some of the remarkable changes of structure that can occur in the topology of the new nine-dimensional space sections.

Having said this, a word or two of caution is in order. First, Superstring theory is still far from complete; it is in many ways as yet simply a set of suggestions of the way things might be, rather than a well- developed theory of how we know that they are. The form of the 'central theory' remains unknown, and the actual calculations that have been done to date have mainly to do with various weak-field versions of what is merely a hypothesis. Some features even of these are far from clear: for example, how the apparently extremely stable properties of the known families of identical particles can be reliably deduced from the proposed model as being vibrations of a string, and whether all the features of General Relativity theory are satisfactorily recovered. Secondly, the theory relies on massive extrapolation from selected aspects of our existing physics onto very different scales and into very different conditions and thus goes way beyond the point where we have any proof that what is suggested is remotely right. Not only are there at present no experimental data supporting this vastly complex structure, but there may never be any, because the scale and energies required by much of the theory are such that it may for ever be beyond experimental investigation. It is possible that some variant of Super string theory will one day explain in a satisfactorily unified way the behaviour of precisely that spectrum of particles which we can detect in the world around us, including being able to predict their masses. If so, that will be one of the greatest feats of theoretical physics ever achieved. But we are a long way from that situation at pre sent. Even the concept of Supersymmetry, which plays a central role in the theory and should be amenable to experimental test, may or may not be true; none of the predicted supersymmetrical partner particles to known particles have yet been detected. Superstring theory is the one truly comprehensive attempt to find such a fundamental physical theory that we currently have, and it is a magnificent one. This is not enough of course to guarantee that it's right. It may have latched onto the correct intimations about the nature of the as yet unknown aspects of fundamental physics, but then again it may not. Greene doesn't try to conceal this uncertainty, but he is himself an enthusiast for the theory, something it's important not to lose sight of when reading this book.

There was only one place in The Elegant Universe where I felt uncomfortable about what Greene was saying. It comes when he gets on to discussing the possibility of an ultimate 'Theory of Everything', and touches briefly on the issue of reductionism. He does not examine this as carefully as he might have done. He writes, for example: 'Almost everyone agrees that finding the TOE would in no way mean that psychology, biology, geology, chemistry or even physics had been solved or in some sense subsumed.' But why would any sensible person suppose such a thing? Any serious suggestion that Superstring theory might have such 'greedy' reductionist implications is likely to bring the whole programme into disrepute. If its reductionist implications are to be considered, then this should be done in a much more nuanced fashion. The philosophical implications of a theory dealing as this one does with the nature of emergent order and meaning in complex, hierarchically structured systems, should either be passed over altogether or dwelt on for longer than they are here. Greene might also have drawn attention to the limitations inherent in all of our mathematical and physical models of reality, and the need not to confuse them with reality itself.

webTitle: Iraq warns Iran after mortar attack in Baghdad

fields.headline: Iraq warns Iran after mortar attack in Baghdad
fields.trailText: Iraq today blamed Iran for a mortar attack that killed four people in Baghdad and warned ominously that it reserved the right to "take suitable action".
fields.body:
Iraq today blamed Iran for a mortar attack that killed four people in Baghdad and warned ominously that it reserved the right to "take suitable action".

Another 38 people were wounded in the attack on a residential building in the Iraqi capital. The Iraqi news agency INA quoted a security spokesman as saying that two of the victims were Iraqis and the other two were non-Iraqi Arabs living in Iraq.

"Agents of the Iranian regime yesterday evening fired six mortar bombs at a residential building in Baghdad inhabited by Iraqis and Arabs, and the attack led to the martyrdom of two Iraqis and two Arabs and the injury of 38 others," an Iraqi official said.

The official said the wounded, some of whom were in critical condition, were taken to a nearby hospital. Children, women and elderly were said to be among the victims. He said security authorities had found an Iranian 60mm mortar and two unexploded bombs near the place where the attack took place.

Iraq lost no time in blaming the Iranian government, calling the assault "a flagrant aggression against its security and sovereignty". In a warning that bodes ill for the region - Iran and Iraq fought a war from 1980 to 1988 - Iraq said it reserved the right to take suitable action in response.

On Monday, Iraq's most influential newspaper, Babel, warned Iran against any attack on its territory and accused US secretary of state Madeleine Albright of encouraging Tehran to commit "aggression" against Baghdad.

Ms Albright last week announced an easing of trade sanctions against Iran in a move to thaw US-Iranian relations, which have been frozen since the Iranian revolution in 1979.

Any improvement in relations between Washington and Tehran will be viewed with alarm in Baghdad, already a pariah state because of its invasion of Kuwait in 1990. Iraq's sense of isolation can only increase if the US and other countries cosy up to Iran, allowing it to shed its "rogue" status.

Tension between Iraq and Iran has escalated in the last few weeks over cross-border attacks by the Iraq-based Mujahideen Khalq, the main exiled Iranian opposition group.

Baghdad said last week that its air defences had shot down an Iranian reconnaissance drone near the border with Iran. The next day, Iran said the Mujahideen had killed two of its soldiers in a clash near the Iraqi border.

The Mujahideen said their anti-aircraft systems last week repelled an air attack by Iran against one of their military bases inside Iraq.

Analysts said the air attack was a reprisal for the Mujahideen's earlier mortar assault on a Tehran residential district near a Revolutionary Guards base.

fields.headline: The way forward
fields.standfirst: The chancellor's proposals could help to fight poverty, says Jane Millar
fields.trailText: The chancellor's proposals could help to fight poverty, says Jane Millar.
fields.body:
The integrated child credit, announced in yesterday's budget, represents a major change in our system of financial support for children. The key feature of the proposal is very simple: that all poor children should receive the same type of financial support whether the parents are working or not.

All families will continue to receive child benefit, as they do now, with the ICC providing extra support for poor families. It has been welcomed by anti-poverty pressure groups and campaigners and is likely to be generally popular. But it is also an example of the way in which good policy ideas can be very difficult to implement in practice.

At the moment we support poor children through two main types of payments. For children with unemployed parents there are child payments embedded within income support and job seeker's allowance. These vary with the number and ages of children and are paid as part of the weekly family benefit payment. For children with employed parents support comes through the tax system. The children's tax credit reduces the overall tax liability for families with children and the working families tax credit gives additional support to low-paid working families. The amount paid varies according to the number of children in the family and is reduced as earnings rise. In general families receive their tax credits through the pay packet, either as a reduction in tax or as a cash addition.

It is these two separate systems that the new ICC seeks to bring together. Children of unemployed parents will receive support in the same way as children whose parents are working in low-paid jobs. There will be no need to shift from one system to another when people move in and out of work, no need to keep on filling in long and complicated forms. As the Treasury put it, the new system will be both "seamless and transparent" and "portable and secure".

This has clear attractions from the policy side. It will be an important element in meeting the promise to eliminate child poverty. It will help to improve work incentives by making the financial transition to work much simpler. It will promote social inclusion by treating all families alike and as part of one system. It will be paid to the main carer, just like child benefit, and so get directly into the family budget.

But, despite the simplicity, it presents some major operational challenges. In particular there are problems in designing a means test that is simple and straightforward but also responsive to changes in family income. If families receiving ICC have to make fresh claims every time income rises or falls then many of the advantages will be lost. Perhaps we can learn something from Australia and Canada, where similar integrated systems have been introduced in recent years. In both countries the means test is based on information provided in tax returns.

Almost all adults complete such returns and the only piece of additional information required is a partner's tax number, so that the tax office can put together the two tax returns and calculate family income.

Changes in family composition usually have to be reported and if income falls significantly then it is possible to make a new claim immediately.
