fields.headline: Well wishers
fields.standfirst: Water is one of the most urgent problems facing  the planet. As world leaders meet to discuss the  problem, Sue Wheat looks at how one pump built  for a community in Africa has transformed the  lives of its inhabitants
fields.trailText: Water is one of the most urgent problems facing the planet. As world leaders meet to discuss the problem, Sue Wheat looks at how one pump built for a community in Africa has transformed the lives of its inhabitants.
fields.body:
For Lucy Adingo, water is life. She is an impressive woman, a community leader, headmistress and one of the 38% of Ghana's women who has received an education. It was a simple statement but also a fundamental truth. Humans can survive several weeks without food, but die in four or five days without water. For the 1.4bn people in the world who don't have access to safe water (one quarter of the world's population) that means their water is a dirty, fetid soup.

I stood with Lucy in front of the dam that once was used for everything - drinking, bathing, cooking, building, watering livestock. Fortunately, the village of Kandiga where Lucy lives - a poor, rural community of around 150 people in the arid upper East region - no longer has to rely on this water source for human consumption.

In 1997 a local aid organisation RuralAid (funded by British charity WaterAid), provided the materials and training to build a well. The men and women of Kandiga provided free labour by digging the 20ft well and collecting and crushing stones for concrete. The building process took about two weeks but the well will last decades. The cost was around £1,200 (less than £10 per head).

The well will save Ghana money in the long-term. At any one time, half of Ghana's hospital beds are occupied by patients suffering from water-related diseases.

Without clean water, sickness is constant. In Africa, water-related illnesses kill around 27,000 people every day. Drinking unsafe water affects Ghanaians' education as well as their health. "Before the well, our children were constantly sick with diarrhoea and cholera, which meant we had to spend savings on medicines and hospital visits, leaving no money for school fees," explains Lucy.

Carrying water is also hugely time-consuming and children, particularly girls, help their mothers to collect it daily, so school is often not an option. Women carry up to 20kg of water for miles on their head (that's equivalent to an overseas luggage allowance) - an exhausting activity, especially when you're malnourished. And time is lost from undertaking important activities such as farming, looking after the children, or earning a living from some income-generating activity.

Without water, food also becomes scarce. "Our livestock used to die and we couldn't grow vegetables and fruit for food or for sale," says Lucy. For communities without a water source nearby, even when food is available, if there is not enough water to cook, preparing meals is a constant struggle.

Lucy talks about the well as if it has magical properties - it has even prompted a building boom in the village. "Now we have water, we can build and mend our houses," she explains. "Before, we had to carry so much water from the dam it was very difficult and we couldn't build very quickly in the heat because we didn't have clean water to drink."

The well has also brought economic independence, especially to women. Many now earn the vital cash they need to pay for food and school fees through selling groundnuts and making butter from shea nuts or brewing pitu (a local drink).

Having an alternative source of income through vegetable growing will improve soil conditions. One of the few means of earning cash for many rural households is to sell firewood. But with deforestation occurring rapidly, wood is scarce. Many households are now using millet stalks as fuel which means that the soil's nutrients are not replenished. Soil erosion increases, the fertility of the soil declines and the amount of food produced the following year falls. Less food means poorer health, and the cycle continues.

Even for the 49% of rural communities in Ghana that do have safe water, the fight is not over. Climate change means that the dry season (known as "the hunger season") has increased over the last 20 years from around six months a year to eight. The amount of ground water has fallen, harvests have declined, food is scarce and income is reduced. With fewer trees surviving, a vicious cycle of soil erosion and deforestation is in motion and the Sahara's borders are spreading. Water is life. But when the forces of nature are reducing the amount of water available, life is precarious.

The problems
There is growing recognition that the world is beginning to feel the first pangs of a chronic and systematic water crisis. More than a billion people do not have access to a water supply and three billion do not have adequate sanitation. Each year 3-4m people die of easily preventable waterborne diseases, including more than 2m young children who die of diarrhoea.

 New problems of environmental degradation are emerging. Aquifers are being mined at an unprecedented rate. Almost 10% of the world's agricultural food production depends on using mined groundwater but water tables are falling as much as a metre a year in many parts of Mexico, India, Yemen and China.

 Water diversions for irrigation have had devastating effects in Central Asia, with the Aral Sea shrinking to a fraction of its original size. The Huang He (Yellow river) did not run into the sea for more than 220 days in 1997.

 Deforestation, land degradation salinisation and water contamination by chemicals, fertilizers, and human waste are all serious issues in many parts of the world. Rapidly growing cities and industries together with the use of more chemicals in agriculture have undermined the quality of many rivers, lakes and aquifers.

 In the next two decades it is estimated that water use by humans will increase by about 40%, and that 17% more water will be needed to grow the food for the growing populations. In addition, the water demands for industry and energy will grow rapidly. Increases in the demand for irrigation water are likely to be matched by increases of 20% and 70% in the demand for water for industry and municipal use.

 Increasing withdrawals for human use could impose intolerable stresses on the environment, leading not only to loss of biodiversity, but to a vicious circle in which the stressed ecosystems can no longer provide the services for plants and for people.

 But if additional water for irrigation is not forthcoming, then the increases in rain-fed agriculture to meet the demand in food for nearly 8bn people will be enormous and would also have very detrimental environmental impacts. It would require that far more land be cleared for agriculture and losses of forests and habitats, and biodiversity on a massive scale.

 Fresh water is becoming ever more precious. Only 2.5% of the world's water is not salty, and of that two-thirds is locked up in the icecaps and glaciers. Of the rest, some 20% is in areas too remote for human access, and of the remaining 80%, about three-quarters comes via monsoons and floods, and cannot be captured for use by people. What is left is less than 0.08 of 1% of the total water on the planet.

The solutions
The rate of expansion of irrigated land and the use of hand pumps will determine future water stress. The conventional wisdom in agriculture is that irrigated land will have to keep pace by expanding hugely in future. However, this will inevitably lead to more large dams, more severe water shortages and serious risk of deteriorating natural ecosystems. Traditional farming practices are often found to be more cost effective than large irrigation schemes when all the benefits of an ecosystem, like providing firewood and fishing are taken into account.

 About 300 new large dams (higher than 15 metres) are being added each year to the more than 39,000 in existence. Big dams almost always involve large displacements of people and other social problems, with the benefits tending to go to the rich. The World Commission on Dams will, later this year, provide a new consensus on when dams are appropriate, and on how they should be planned, designed, built and operated. About 1% of dam capacity is lost each year through silting.

 Recharging groundwater - or underground - aquifers will become increasingly important as water levels fall. It needs to be done on a large scale in some areas and there is much debate about how to do it. One way might be to encourage the use of flooded paddy fields above the most seriously depleted aquifers. If groundwater is over-abstracted it leads to water quality loss, land degradation and poor public health.

 There is scope for increasing rainfall "harvesting" through new and traditional methods, and through groundwater storage. These environmentally-friendly approaches are best suited to decentralised, community-based projects as they are cheap and can be managed locally. However, when water is collected upstream it reduces the run-off that people downstream can use.

 Water harvesting is not just for rural communities in arid areas. Increasingly, as at the Dome or at Frankfurt airport, rainfall can be captured from vast roofs to provide all the water needed for cleaning, gardening and flushing toilets.

 Semi-natural and artificial wetlands will be used increasingly to improve polluted waters and treat domestic effluents. However, as populations increase, the pressure to use land for farming becomes more extreme.

 Protecting wetlands, floodplains and forests in upper catchment areas can protect people downstream from floods and damage to crops as well as providing natural storage areas for water.

 Desalinating sea water now costs far less than in the past and this technology is expected to play a major role in providing water to coastal communities and industries in the future. But it is energy intensive and only rarely can it be cheap enough for food crops.

 Many cities and towns experiencing water shortages are expected to turn to low or no-water sanitation systems. Municipal water supplies could be supplemented by extensive use of reclaimed urban wastewater for non-drinking uses.

 One key is to grow crops that need less water. Biotechnology has a future in developing drought-resistant strains but there are other problems associated with this technology.

 Better irrigation methods are important. Water can be applied uniformly to crops using precision irrigation.

 Restrictions need to be placed on fertilisers, pesticides and chemicals which pollute water.

 Financial resources: total investment in water services today is about $70-80bn a year. Government is by far the largest investor with the private sector contributing around $15bn, International aid contributes about $9bn. Investments will need to be massively increased over the next 25 years.

John Vidal

World Water Vision
World Water Council

fields.headline: Out of the maze
fields.standfirst:
Jan Parker on advice for people working with refugees
Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Jan Parker on advice for people working with refugees.
fields.body:
You are a social worker, trying to help an asylum seeker threatened with eviction, or a teacher who knows of a refugee family refused registration with a GP. You are the pregnant Latin American woman denied an interpreter, whose doctor mistakenly thought she wanted a termination. Or the Somalian asylum seeker who failed to turn up at language lessons because he couldn't see the blackboard and had no money for new glasses. Where do you turn for advice? How do you begin to negotiate the maze of legal entitlements and restrictions?

Complex legislation regarding refugees and asylum seekers will become more complex still after April 1, with the introduction of new measures in the Immigration and Asylum Act. These will include the dispersal of asylum seekers to areas outside London and the south-east, the stripping away of asylum seekers' right to any choice in where they are housed, and the replacement of cash payments with a system of vouchers and a maximum £10 cash a week.

In an attempt to clarify the situation and help asylum seekers and those working with them, the Refugee Council has launched a new information service.

Central to the initiative is a thick, loose-leaf binder packed with clear, impressively jargon-free explana-tions of the new legislation, plus descriptions of best practice and examples of asylum seekers' particular needs and problems.

Describing itself as "the infor-mation survival kit for public and voluntary sector employees", it covers everything from the obvious - national and international law, the asylum and detention processes, rights and obligations in housing, health, education, employment and welfare benefits - to the often overlooked: cultural differences and concerns, children's needs, the psychology of exile and the provision of effective emotional support to those not only arriving in a new country and alien culture but often dealing with the effects of fear, persecution and sometimes torture.

The service, which includes a comprehensive resources directory, is aimed at anyone whose work brings them into contact with asylum seekers and refugees, from community groups and frontline workers to senior policy-makers.

Orders have already been received from police and local authorities around the country, plus advice centres, housing associations, refugee organisations, solicitors and a few health authorities. The Refugee Council hopes the pack will soon be stocked by local libraries.

Neil Bateman, joint commis-sioning manager with Suffolk social services and health authority, has already put it to good use. "We used to have asylum seekers in very small numbers but are currently supporting around 300, so we have been on a very steep learning curve. Having this range of good quality information in one place, written with the asylum seekers' best interests in mind, has proved invaluable in social services, health, education and beyond."

Crucially, he adds, it not only answers questions but also alerts its users to issues they may never have even considered. "The pressure of trying to support asylum seekers in this ridiculously complex system means it is very easy to overlook people's cultural, emotional, mental health and other non-financial needs. The Refugee Council service steers you in the right direction."

The council is keen to stress that the service is in no way a gesture of support for the new legislation - it and other groups have opposed it vigorously and called much of it unfair, ill thought out and unwork-able. Yet it is the law, and many thousands will soon be living and working within it.

According to Jean Candler, press officer at the Refugee Council, "It is a matter of pragmatism: how we can best help people within the new legal framework."

 A year's subscription to the Refugee Council Information Service costs £180, (voluntary sector £80; refugee community organisations, free). Contact the Refugee Council, 3 Bondway, London SW8 1SJ (Tel: 0207-820 3042).

fields.headline: Poison soup
fields.standfirst: Shahid Husain on  how decades of  mismanagement are  turning the Indus  river into salt water
fields.trailText: Shahid Husain on how decades of mismanagement are turning the Indus river into salt water.
fields.body:
The Indus, one of the great rivers of the world, is in trouble. Through its 1,000 miles length the river which gave its name to the Indian sub-continent has been used and abused by man and is now facing a slow death.

The Indus has always been at the centre of economic life of the western part of the continent, what is now Pakistan. Its waters supply the country's major cities including Karachi, which at 13m people is one of the world's biggest.

In its long journey from the Himalayas, it has scoured out the fabled and infamous Khyber Pass, and once in Pakistan it has been harnessed through giant dam building and irrigation projects to provide electricity and food for an ever growing, ever poor population.

But despite high hopes, the mega-development schemes have created even more problems and now threaten disasters on a frightening scale. The river is at the centre of a row over how it can be saved from being poisoned and becoming an almost entirely salt river.

On one side is the World Bank, architect of some of the schemes that have led to the crisis. The bank wants to finance giant drains to pour irrigation water back into the Indus and to privatise the water supply and make it an economic commodity. The idea is to prevent the excess use of irrigation water and encourage sophisticated and efficient drip-feed methods which grow good crops and will reverse the salinity problem.

The critics of the plan - environmentalists, academics and alliances of small farmers - say another mega scheme will make things worse rather than better. It will, they contend, favour the rich farmers and big landowners and cut out the poor, including up to 3m small farmers who produce more food per acre than the rich feudal landowners.

At the heart of the problem is the past misuse of the Indus. Large parts of inland Pakistan used to be a shallow sea. When it dried up the salts sank below the land and the rains washed the top soil down to create fertile plains. Irrigation increased yields dramatically.

Irrigation began on a large scale in the 19th century, but only with modern machinery and big development money in the post-war era did the Indus become fully ex-ploited. The giant Tarbela dam was the largest earth dam in the world when it was built 30 years ago but it is already 32% silted up and restricted in its ability to provide electricity and fresh water.

Yet that problem is insignificant compared with the issue of salinity. As billions of gallons of water have been poured through unlined irrigation channels into the parched plains, it has seeped down into the water table. As the water has risen so have the salts from the long for gotten sea. The result is that crops have died.

The World Bank says that 10m acres of land a year are now being degraded by this process causing a loss in potential production of £1.5bn a year. The agricultural losses are turning Pakistan from a net exporter of grain to an importer.

Up to 37.6% of the irrigated areas are now waterlogged, 14% of the surface is saline and 6% is severely saline, according to the bank. Moreover, while at the turn of the century the water table was deeper than 90ft, now it reaches the surface in some places, completely destroying farmers' ability to grow any kind of crop.

Also suffering are Pakistan's large inland freshwater lakes, Manchar and Hammal, once extremely valuable fisheries and vital for bird life. The damage is said to be retrievable but many fishermen on Manchar, one of Asia's largest lakes have already lost their catches.

The proposed solution is a £500m programme to drain the water back into the Indus from where it came - but the salt plus the addition of excessive fertiliser, pesticides and other chemicals to the fields has turned the water in some places into a poisonous soup.

Despite the size of the river, returning this water will inevitably kill life over large stretches. For the human population - and the cities of Hyderabad, Kotri and Karachi are all downstream of the planned irrigation drains - the outfall drains will render the river water undrinkable without massive purification.

Alternative less grandiose solutions have been suggested by academics and environmentalists. Nisar Hassanaly Effendi, a leading Pakistani agriculturalist, suggests vast evaporation ponds in unproductive areas. The excess water, he says, should be pumped into the ponds in hot areas where it will evaporate easily. "The pumping costs will be relatively small compared to the construction of siphons to put the water bank into the Indus. Under no circumstances is the effluent fit to be put into the Indus. It will kill the river's unique blind dolphin species and entire sweet water fish population," he says.

Professor Mohammad Noman, of Pakistan's University of Engineering and Technology said he doubts that it is possible to construct evaporation ponds for such huge quantities of water. He argues that the main issue is not being addressed. The seepage through nearly 1,000 miles of canals and ditches is alarming, with around 50% of the water never reaching the crops. The canals and ditches should be lined, he says. In addition, the growing of water-intensive crops like rice should be abandoned in favour of wheat and cotton which was traditionally grown in the area. "In countries like Pakistan, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund impose projects, which in the long-run have a negative impact on the economy," he said.

Currently, the schemes have been put on hold while a national debate takes place. The military coup has overshadowed the debate, giving the bank and others time to mull over the solutions.

 Shahid Husain is the author of an Oxfam-funded report on the problems of the Indus which will be published later this year.

fields.headline: Off cuts
fields.trailText: Laurie Taylor
fields.body:
On February 15, Duncan Campbell reported for this paper on the reaction in the United States to the news that jails had just welcomed their two millionth inmate. No other country in history, wrote Campbell, has ever had a higher proportion of its citizens in jail and some commentators on the situation were already suggesting that the US was effectively creating a prison-industrial complex to rival its military-industrial complex.

Two weeks after this news broke, the New York University school of law mounted a one-day conference at which leading international criminologists were invited to consider the causes and consequences of a penal policy which had ensured that the US, with 5% of the global population, was responsible for 25% of the world's prisoners.

A major concern for non-American contributors was the prospect of the American obsession with prison being gradually exported to other developed countries around the world. Delegates could already point to significant increases in the prison populations of Italy, Spain, Portugal and the UK.

Part of the problem, as David Downes, professor of sociology at LSE, argued in his contri-bution, is that once a country has embarked on a course of "govern-ing through crime with the heightened emotionalism and bidding-up of punitive measures which this entails", it is extremely difficult to call a halt. If crime rates fall, then prisons gain the credit; if they go up, "we clearly need more of the same medicine".

But perhaps the greatest paradox in this debate is the unwillingness of observers to analyse the relationship between the size of the US prison population and the country's much celebrated capacity for creating new jobs.

There's nothing very surprising about low male unemployment figures in the US when the present practice of excluding prisoners from the labour force count effectively reduces them by over 30%. As Downes observes, "It is a tragic irony that a major flaw in the political economy of the US - its grotesquely high prison population - unduly inflates what is taken to signify a major success - its unusually low unemployment rate."

Will Europe withstand the American example? Downes was not optimistic. "The components of a steep rise in imprisonment in Europe," he told delegates, "have already been assembled."

 Laurie Taylor talks to David Downes about the significance of mass incarceration in the US in Radio 4's Thinking Allowed at 4pm today.

fields.headline: After the vows
fields.standfirst: A few years ago, a group of parents  gave non-religious christenings to their  children. Michael Young and Rosie  Styles have been back to see what  they think now
fields.trailText: A few years ago, a group of parents gave non-religious christenings to their children. Michael Young and Rosie Styles have been back to see what they think now.
fields.body:
The Baby Naming Society was established in 1994 for the support of parents who do not want a church baptism but want some other sort of celebration when a child born. The form and content of the ceremony is not prescribed.

Instead, parents are encouraged to arrange their own ceremonies and to decide themselves on the promises they want to make to the new-born child. These might include: "Will you endeavour to bring up (baby) in a home filled with love and kindness, tolerance of others, respect for humanity and the earth which supports us?" or "Will you promise to give (baby) time and attention, provide moral guidance and introduce him/her to the joys of life while recognising that s/he is a free spirit to discover the world in his/her own way?"

There has been a lot of interest in this form of rite of passage since Jack Straw gave it a warm welcome last year in the report of his ministerial group on the family. We have just conducted a small survey of people who approached us for help and asked them to tell us what happened and whether it had any lasting effect. Our sample consisted of 226 of the families who were in touch with us in 1996. After deducting the 75 parents who did not get the questionnaire because they had moved house or did not respond for other reasons, we were left with 110 who replied.

The form of the ceremony was decided by the parents. They chose where the ceremonies should be held - mainly in the family home except where it did not have enough room. They chose who should preside over the occasion - it was usually a friend or relation and sometimes the parents themselves. They chose the music that was played and the poetry that was read. Above all, they chose the vows they made to their new-born child who was usually between six and 11 months at the time.

The great majority thought the occasion had been rewarding and two-thirds of people said they would do it all again for another child. One third had already held a second ceremony, "I loved the freedom to have a tailor made ceremony," said Sue Taylor, "and the second time we did it we added vows for our older child to look after his little sister."

One couple had wondered if they could manage it at all. "The prospect of arranging a ceremony was very daunting. We felt that although we are atheists, the arrival of our first child was the most significant occasion in our lives -more so than our marriage - and we wanted all our friends and family to share in this."

Jean Frost was of like mind. "Writing our own ceremony allowed us to shift the focus to welcoming the child and appreciating the uniqueness of each human being. Making the promises felt somehow more meaningful than the church equivalent, when it's sometimes obvious at the point promises are being made that there is no intention to keep them."

Three years after their ceremonies people were still very much aware of the promises they had made. Six families did not make any. But of the 104 who did make promises, 102 said they could remember what they promised and 99 had made an effort to keep them. As Bob Jones said, "Every day they guide how we raise our child." Parents were reminded of them "When he's asleep, or poorly, or starting something new", (Richard White). "When he says, I love you", (Debbie Smart). "When times get hard in the family unit", (Jo Smith). "When relations with my partner are at breaking point", (Frank Turner).

In the society's guide to ceremonies we stress that cohabiting fathers are wrong if they think that signing the birth certificate gives them any rights. They have no rights over their children unless they sign a joint parental responsibility agreement with the mother. 0f the 32 single parents, 17 did not know about the legal position before they read our guide. In these families, nine have now made agreements; nine have subsequently got married.

Some people wanted it to be less of a home-grown affair. Tim Sparks spoke for them. "It would be nice to have someone official, confident and trained to lead naming ceremonies. It would be nice if it could be linked with the signing of legal documents, the joint responsibility agreement or a will, and the nomination of legal guardians who agree to care for the child should the parents die prematurely."

 Lord Young of Dartington is chairman of the BNS and Rosie Styles director. To protect confidentiality all the names above have been changed. The full report, which has been funded by the Home Office family policy unit, is available at £3.50 including p&p from: Baby Naming Society, Yeoman's Cottage, Kerswell Green, Kempsey, Worcester WR5 3PF.

fields.headline: Faith and hope
fields.standfirst: Patrick Weir on new research into  assessing evidence of discrimination,  real or perceived
fields.trailText: Patrick Weir on new research into assessing evidence of discrimination, real or perceived.
fields.body:
Published in 1992 and based on only preliminary research, the findings of the Commission for Racial Equality's second review of the Race Relations Act nevertheless broke new ground in that for the first time the issue of discrimination on the grounds of religion, as experienced in mainland Britain - particularly by minority ethnic communities - was formally recognised.

However, in response to its recommendation that legislation outlawing such discrimination should be considered, the then home secretary, Michael Howard, was unmoved, citing a lack of "hard evidence of discrimination against individuals on religious rather than racial grounds..." In the light of concerns made known to the commission, a consultative exercise involving religious communities around Britain concluded in 1996 that the framing of legislation was imperative. The home secretary remained unmoved.

A change in thinking has now enabled a more progressive approach to the issue, and, significantly, paved the way for the first government-backed study of its kind in the UK. Commissioned last April by the Home Office, Derby university is undertaking extensive research into what the project leader, Paul Weller - a professor of inter-religious relations - admits is a complex and delicate area: "However, there is more of an environment now to look at the problem as it is recognised at more levels in society. And consultative measures, as noted by various religious groups, weren't sufficiently rigorous as they drew no real consistency of response."

An interim report, based on meetings with national religious bodies and secular groups, and a questionnaire of local, regional and national religious organisations, has recently been published. There are four aims: to assess evidence of religious discrimination, both actual and perceived; to describe the patterns shown by this evidence including its overall scale, the main victims and perpetrators and the main ways in which the discrimination manifests itself; to indicate the extent to which religious discrimination overlaps with racial discrimination/ethnicity; to identify the range of policy options available for dealing with such discrimination.

Local fieldwork, involving semi-structured interviews with religious and secular groups, is concentrated on four areas where religious diversity exists. Completed in Leicester, where there are dominant Jain, Jewish and Hindu communities, researchers are currently collecting data in Newham, which has a large Muslim population alongside smaller Hindu and African- Christian groupings. This work will conclude in June in Cardiff and Blackburn, which have respectively large Sikh and Muslim populations.

"We are also looking at new movements, more popularly known as sects or cults, and those labelled new age, plus pagan traditions," explains Weller. "Non-established religious groups must have a say. And individual biographies are also important, as people can tell their own stories." Although the university isn't due to submit its final report to the Home Office until September, some legislative change is already afoot. The incorporation into domestic law of the European Convention on Human Rights with regard to religious discrimination, through the Human Rights Act, comes into force in October.

"This is an important development, because people in British courts will now be able to appeal directly to convention rights on matters of belief and conscience in support of any issue," says Weller. "It is limited, however, in that presently it only offers redress in respect of public authorities."

In terms of the Fair Employment Act in Northern Ireland, which outlaws religious discrimination in the field of work, an important question arises: "Since the Race Relations Act now operates there, why shouldn't the Employment Act apply here?"

The interim report also maps out a spectrum of analytical models - based on those used for racial discrimination - aimed at recognising what religious discrimination might be and how it might be understood.

"We need to differentiate, for example, between discrimination as attitudinal, which may or may not be evident in actions or structures, and religious hatred that results in violence," explains Weller. "Direct and indirect discrimination in terms of job opportunities and unexamined policies and practices must also be addressed. Given the religious diversity of the UK, we need to learn more about these issues."

Changing people's attitudes is yet more problematic. "Education in schools and colleges and dialogue between religious bodies is one way forward," says Weller. "Following the Race Relations Act, work notices advising blacks not to apply were less evident. And while the act established what was morally unacceptable, whether those who wrote the notices were still inwardly racist is unclear."

fields.headline: Charity virgins
fields.standfirst: New professional fundraisers are  appearing on high streets all over  the country and, as Adam Woolf  reports, they're proving  remarkably successful
fields.trailText: New professional fundraisers are appearing on high streets all over the country and, as Adam Woolf reports, they're proving remarkably successful.
fields.body:
Walking down your high street, you're in a hurry when you notice a young person sporting the logo of a well known charity stand-ing on the edge of the pavement. Armed with a clipboard and a re-assuring smile, they catch your eye and ask politely whether you can spare a few moments for a short chat.

This new breed of fundraisers hit our towns two years ago. If you haven't seen them on your high street yet, you soon will. They do not accept cash and there are no collect-ing tins in sight. It's your account number, sort code and signature that they are after. They want you to fill in a direct debit form giving a regular donation to the cause.

This is face to face - or direct dialogue - fundraising. Around 30 mainstream charities have experi-mented with the technique. Most report startling success; so much so that other charities are now falling over themselves to get involved.

Face to face fundraising was pioneered by Greenpeace in Austria. The idea was simple. Rather than write, advertise or telephone people to seek their support, simply ask them directly.

Although it worked on the continent, Greenpeace was not keen on importing this method to the UK. "Initially we were resistant to the idea, we thought that it would never work in Britain. It's a very un-British idea talking to people in the street. We thought it would make people feel uncomfortable," says Annie Moreton, director of marketing at Greenpeace UK. "We were wrong. The results have been great and the feedback from the public has been positive." While Greenpeace and others are still committed to flag days and collecting money on the street, donors signing direct debits are what they are really after. The results from one trial by ActionAid shows why.

The development charity signed up over 250 people in three days. Each pledged between £4 and £15 a month. That represents an income to ActionAid of over £2,200 a month. A few people may cancel, but most will stay loyal to the charity and continue to give.

Donation by direct debit is now the lifeblood for most charities. This is because "regular committed donors gives us long-term financial stability and allow us to plan ahead", according to John Grounds of Action Research, the medical research charity, which has experimented with face to face fundraising techniques on people's doorsteps.

During the last decade fundraisers' search for new donors has been increasingly complex and expensive. Charity fundraisers often compare their trade to mining or searching for oil. They have used advertising, direct mail and even direct response television advertising to "prospect" for new supporters. These methods yield mixed results. They tended to appeal to the same type of donors, so charities often end up competing with each other for the support of the same people.

Face to face fundraising has opened up new "seams" of fresh donors. They are highly prized by the charities. They are known in the business as "charity virgins". They are new to giving, and keen to commit and many are people under 30. This age group is "notoriously difficult to reach" according to Andrew Watts, head of policy, Institute of Charity Fundraising Managers.

Young people respond to face to face fundraising for three reasons. First, talking is more their medium. Says Annie Moreton: "They do not want to read direct mail letters."

Second, most face to face fundraisers are young people themselves. Joanna Gilson, head of direct marketing at Amnesty International UK, says: "People tend to recruit in their own image. Young trendy looking people recruit people who look like them." The third reason is that those holding the clipboards are professional fundraisers trained in the subtle art of signing people up to the cause. Many seem to be employed by Professional Fundraising Partnership (PFP), a private fundraising agency based in Brighton. Although a few charities - like ActionAid - employ their own face to face teams, PFP seems to be the market leaders. This year alone PFP plans to recruit over 200,000 donors all over the UK for client charities.

How much they charge charities for this service, PFP will not tell, citing "client confidentiality". The charities are also reluctant to go into details because they "do not want the competition to know". However, they argue that it represents excellent value for money.

With direct mail and advertising, charities have to cover the costs up front, whatever the results. With face to face they pay per recruit.

Charities and PFP insist that there is nothing wrong with this relationship. The individual fundraisers are not on commission. They receive a flat salary. Pressure selling is not permitted and any member of the public who signs a direct debit form can simply call their bank to cancel it. It is also "less intrusive than calling people at home", says Watts.

Some people may feel unhappy about charities employing professional fundraisers on the street. It somehow devalues the cause if people are being paid to raise funds rather than doing it because they care. Yet charities have always paid external agencies to help them raise money. For charities to survive they cannot afford to be sentimental.

In a complex and complicated world people are responding favourably to the direct and straightforward approach of face to face fundraising. "People get the opportunity to ask questions. It is more interactive and thorough," argues Grounds. It works because "when they make a commitment they do it from a position of knowledge not ignorance".

fields.trailText: Fifteen neighbours from the same street in Scarborough, Yorkshire, agreed to re-take their driving tests for a car magazine experiment, and all 15 failed.
fields.body:
Tender trap: Firefighters were called to a lingerie and sex aids party at a house in Stockport, Greater Manchester, to free a woman locked in a pair of handcuffs.

Sticklers for detail: A company which makes Blackpool rock is putting its logo and website address through each stick.

Street of shame: Fifteen neighbours from the same street in Scarborough, Yorkshire, agreed to re-take their driving tests for a car magazine experiment, and all 15 failed.

Lush puppies? An alcoholic who thought he was breaking into an off-licence stole 18 pairs of shoes from a footwear shop in Bedford after mistaking them for bottles.

Blue tits: An American internet directory censored the website of a Wakefield artist promoting Yorkshire birdlife because it detected numerous references to tits.

Bruised pride: The winner of a competition to find the most accident prone person in East Anglia slipped and badly bruised her toes as she was about to leave her home in Gorleston-on-Sea, Norfolk, to go to the award ceremony.

Down the pan: Councillors at Erewash, Nottinghamshire, have been criticised for spending £490 on hiring a coach for a trip to examine standards of cleanliness at neighbouring public toilets.

Poetic justice: Quotations from poets on the beauties of nature are proving more effective than warning notices in deterring thieves from stealing plants out of parks in Spennymoor, County Durham.

Post early: The subpostmaster in the Welsh village of Bethlehem has already started receiving cards to be posted next Christmas.

Radio drama: Police who rushed to a house in Combe Martin, Devon, after reports that somebody was screaming for help discovered that it was a pet Amazon blue parrot singing along to a radio programme.

Hard luck: Three days after concreting over his garden, a man from Lydd, Kent, won a lawnmower in a prize draw.

fields.headline: Age-old gripe
fields.standfirst: Andrew Wall finds no way through  the silence surrounding government  policy
fields.trailText: Andrew Wall finds no way through the silence surrounding government policy.
fields.body:
How responsive is New Labour? In the NHS, much is made of the government's intention to improve information to patients and the public. But what happens in practice if you want to challenge current policy?

At a conference on June 9 last year, I heard Frank Dobson, the then secretary of state for health, describe our wonderful NHS as free at the point of use for those in need. Unable to catch the chair's eye to challenge Dobson on the spot, I subsequently wrote to him on June 22 pointing out that what he said was untrue for many of the oldest and frailest citizens. They do not receive free health care if they have the misfortune to land up in a nursing home and have assets over £16,000. How could the Labour government justify this discrimination, which offends the founding principles of the NHS?

There was no answer. A repeat letter on August 29 met the same fate. On September 9, I rang his personal assistant. She would ring back. She didn't. I rang again on September 20, and on September 29 a letter arrived saying: "In view of the volume of correspondence that the minister receives day by day, it is not generally possible for him to deal personally with letters received from the general public." The rest of the letter reiterated the present situation but did not address my original point that the policy was unfair and against the statutory requirement (in the 1946 act) that the NHS provide free health care at the point of need.

My next letter made this clear. Again there was no answer. I rang on November 9. From this conversation it appeared that ministers can receive at least 70,000 letters a year. These are forwarded, after a slight delay, to a correspondence unit. The person to whom I spoke had 100 letters on her desk requiring answers. She sounded fed up. Naturally, she and her colleagues can only give standard replies. Speaking to her supervisor, I established that, in her opinion, the only way to get at the minister is through your MP. Accordingly, I did this on November 23.

His office helpfully sent me a copy of the parliamentary debate on long-term care and funding, which occurred in early December.

But still the original point lay unanswered. I suggested that the local MP pursue the minister further. That was on January 11 - and nothing has been heard since.

So what lessons can be learnt? First, it is obviously pointless writing to a minister. The next approach might be - in this case because it is about health policy - to use the community health council, but there is little evidence that the CHC will be able to access the minister's in-tray any more than the average citizen.

Age Concern is conducting a campaign, the Debate of the Age, which includes this issue but also covers many other aspects of discrimination against elderly people. It is probably unhelpful to their greater agenda to push one point only. It is clear from the increase in the number of phone-in programmes that many citizens have a beef they want to get off their chest.

If you get on to Radio 4's Any Answers or You and Yours you will have your two minutes of airtime, but will this make any difference? Similarly, letters to the paper may make you feel better, but, as there is little comeback, it is also frustrating.

There is an injustice here and, in a democracy, it should be possible for any citizen to register his or her concern. But it is clear that this requires skill. The matter must first be seen as important by more people than yourself and then ways have to be found to maintain the issue in the public consciousness. This is the reason for not giving up but using every opportunity to reiterate the issue.

Finally, there must be some possibility that something can be done, as banging on regardless quickly loses allies. This particular matter requires government commitment.

At last, there is some evidence that the pressure is getting to the government and they cannot indefinitely disregard the recommendations of the commission on long-term care.

But do not waste your time writing to politicians. Maintaining the accountability of our government to us citizens requires much more than a first class stamp.

 Andrew Wall is a former health service manager.

webTitle: Government accused of cronyism in NHS

fields.headline: Government accused of cronyism in NHS
fields.standfirst: Report calls for review of the way hospital and NHS trust board members are appointed
fields.trailText: An independent inquiry today attacked the government for politicising the NHS by appointing Labour supporters to hospital boards.
fields.body:
An independent inquiry today attacked the government for politicising the NHS by appointing Labour supporters to hospital boards.

The report's release was an embarrassing counterpoint to Mr Blair's scheduled pep talk to NHS officials and to chancellor Gordon Brown's Budget increase in funding for Britain's beleaguered health service.

In yesterday's Budget, Mr Brown announced a £2bn increase for the NHS as part of a massive four-year boost to health spending, the biggest sustained increase in the service's 52-year history.

But the report from the commissioner for public appointments, Dame Rennie Fritchie, takes the edge off Labour's generally well-received Budget by accusing the government of cronyism and calling for a fundamental review of the way people are appointed to run hospitals and local NHS trusts.

The report found that out of the total number of local councillors appointed to health authorities and NHS trusts between May 1, 1997, and November 11, 1999, 284 were from the Labour party, 36 were Liberal Democrats and 23 were Conservatives.

Dame Rennie said: "There are examples where a candidate's political association has been a decisive factor in their early selection and appointment and that decisions have not always been based on merit."

Her report concluded that the process of selection had been politicised. The problem stemmed from the system of inviting MPs and local authorities to nominate candidates, she said.

Although the practice of inviting MPs to comment on a shortlist of candidates was introduced by the Conservative government when NHS trusts were first established, Dame Rennie said it had gained a new momentum since Labour came to power.

In an assessment which will surely resurface in the London mayoral race, Dame Rennie blamed Frank Dobson for the increased politicisation of the NHS.

"Much of this stems from the wish of the then secretary of state for health, Mr Dobson, to increase the presence on NHS boards of representatives from the community and the accompanying decision to seek nominations from MPs and local authorities," she said.

Dame Rennie called for the practice of systematically consulting MPs about shortlisted candidates should be ended - as should the practice of seeking nominations directly from local authorities.

She added: "It is clear that there have been instances where a person's political association has been a decisive factor in the consideration of their candidature and that appointments to the NHS have not always been on merit. The public needs to know that people who are appointed to run NHS boards are there on merit and are fit for the purpose."

Dame Rennie set up an independent scrutiny group last July to look into complaints that NHS trusts and health authority members were being picked for political reasons. She made more than twenty recommendations for improving the way chairs and non-executive directors were appointed, including:

 considering the role and purpose of NHS boards and the range of skill and experience required in appointees
 ending the practice of systematically consulting MPs about shortlisted candidates
 ceasing the practice of seeking nominations directly from local authorities
 looking at what can be done to speed up the decision-making process
 reviewing the current approach to re-appointments
 stopping the introduction of late entrants into the appointment process.

webTitle: UN raises alarm on toxic risk in Kosovo

fields.headline: UN raises alarm on toxic risk in Kosovo
fields.standfirst:
Nato warplanes used 10 tonnes of depleted uranium in shells

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Nato aircraft pounded Serbian tanks in Kosovo with 31,000 rounds of toxic depleted uranium ammunition last year, exposing the local population, aid workers and K-For troops to a known health hazard, the United Nations revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Nato aircraft pounded Serbian tanks in Kosovo with 31,000 rounds of toxic depleted uranium ammunition last year, exposing the local population, aid workers and K-For troops to a known health hazard, the United Nations revealed yesterday.

A basic large-scale map supplied by Nato for the first time indicates that the shells were used in 20 locations along the Albanian border, and eight more inside the province.

The UN's Balkan task force, which is evaluating the environmental impact of the conflict in Kosovo and Serbia, only received information about the use of the armour-piercing depleted uranium (DU) shells on February 7, four months after a personal intervention by the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan. The UN had first requested the information last summer.

But after internal bickering about the sensitivity of the DU issue, the UN and specialists from the World Health Organisation, the International Atomic Energy Agency and other scientific bodies, yesterday concluded that the information supplied by Nato was insufficient to carry out conclusive scientific research into the health damage on the ground. But they recommended that "where contamination has been confirmed, measures should be taken to prevent access".

Lord Robertson, Nato's secretary general, told Mr Annan in a letter that DU ammunition was used whenever American A-10 ground attack aircraft engaged Serb tanks or armoured vehicles: "It was used throughout Kosovo in approximately 100 missions. A total of approximately 31,000 rounds of DU ammunition was used."

Pekka Haavisto, the head of the task force, said this amount was equivalent to 10 tonnes of depleted uranium, a by-product of uranium enrichment for nuclear plants which, in civilian conditions, is regarded as toxic waste.

"People should be protected, these areas should be marked clearly. If small children go to play in these areas, taking some uranium dust or even some part of the ammunition left at these sites, there certainly is this toxicity risk," Mr Haavisto said.

Troops from several Nato countries serving in Kosovo are understood to have been told to take precautions against DU contamination.

DU is used to toughen warheads. Upon impact the shells explode in a fireball, producing a fine dust. Immediate inhalation is life-threatening, but the long-term effects are uncertain.

"An intact munition embedded in the ground is not hazardous provided it is not disturbed, but if it's in a dusty form in suspension, there is a potential chemical and a secondary radiological problem," said Dr Michael Clarke, scientific spokesman for the National Radiological Protection Board.

The danger comes mainly from inhalation or swallowing particles of DU.

Although suspicions have long surrounded the use of DU ammunition in the 78-day air war, and Nato has never denied its deployment, confirmation and details on the extent of its use revive concern about toxic pollution and the health risk.

Lord Robertson said that the ammunition used a non-critical by-product of the uranium refining process.

However, researchers are less concerned about potential radioactivity than the toxic nature of depleted uranium, a heavy metal. Evidence accumulated by some scientists since the Gulf war, where 10 times as much DU was used, has linked it to birth defects in Iraq and long-term illnesses, including cancer. But none of the research has been conclusive.

After years of delay due to the sensitivity of the issue among western member states, the World Health Organisation is due to finalise a study next month which will set standards on depleted uranium and define minimum levels of contamination. The Royal Society is also conducting research on the effect of depleted uranium on health.

webTitle: Will Europe's third way be the dot.com way?

fields.headline: Will Europe's third way be the dot.com way?
fields.standfirst: Can Tony Blair convince the rest of Europe that Britain has the formula for success? And can he convince his audience at home that Europe will adopt it? Guardian foreign affairs expert Simon Tisdall previews the Lisbon summit
fields.trailText: Can Tony Blair convince the rest of Europe that Britain has the formula for success? And can he convince his audience at home that Europe will adopt it? Guardian foreign affairs expert Simon Tisdall previews the Lisbon summit.
fields.body:
The gathering of European Union heads of government which opens tomorrow in Lisbon has been dubbed the "dot-com" summit. Its stated aim is to draw up a strategy to increase employment by promoting enterprise, competition, and a "dynamic, knowledge-based economy".

One measure expected to be agreed is a three-year target for reducing the cost of internet access to US levels. Another goal is connecting all schools to the net by 2001, and providing training for teachers in IT technologies. There are also proposals to advance the single market by deregulating trans-national transport and air links, encouraging e-commerce, liberalising the energy market, and further reducing state subsidies.

So far, so good. Few would argue with these objectives. But, as ever, the political context is crucial to whether the summit will produce tangible results.

Tony Blair has played an important role in formulating the objectives. As the exponent of the "third way" between the free market and socialism, he wants Europe to follow the lead he believes he has given in Britain. To argue his case, he will point to the UK's recent economic success, including falling unemployment and a rising GDP.

But Mr Blair also needs to show a sceptical British public that Europe can work for them, and is capable of embracing change. Some analysts believe the outcome of the summit is crucial to Britain's prospects for joining the Euro.

Lionel Jospin, the French prime minister, has a different perspective. Though a socialist, he has pursued a privatisation programme and last week he announced tax cuts, and the French economy, like others in Europe, is growing. But Mr Jospin is under fierce pressure from trade unions and the left not to cut public spending and pay, or in other ways to weaken the welfare state. His policy continues to lay stress on social cohesion and solidarity - codewords used to defuse fears that Anglo-Saxon-style economics are being imposed from outside.

France's fears are shared, to an extent, by some other EU members, including Germany, where the economy remains regulated and the enthusiasm of the Social Democrat chancellor, Gerhard Schroeder, for the third way - the "neue mitte" - has waned over the past year. But Mr Blair seems to have made some advances in convincing his partners that free enterprise and free markets, within limits, are the way ahead.

Much is riding on the summit for Romano Prodi, the European Commission president, who is struggling to make his mark after taking over last year. Not content with overseeing the EU's enlargement and internal reforms to the commission, spearheaded by his deputy, Neil Kinnock, Mr Prodi wants to be credited with leading the charge towards the "new economy" of the "New Europe". Although in this sense Mr Prodi is an ally of Mr Blair's, the latter is wary of Mr Prodi's federalist superstate instincts.

Overall, the Euro area is growing economically at 4% after a period in the doldrums. The Lisbon summit hopes to build on this. But, as always in the EU, national politics can upset the best laid community plans - and in the end, it will be the responsibility of national governments, not the commission, to make them work.

fields.headline: Mum's the word
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: If you can't describe to your parents what you do at work without doomed references to ISPs and internet bandwidths, you might consider the excruciating possibility of inviting them to the office.
fields.body:
If you can't describe to your parents what you do at work without doomed references to ISPs and internet bandwidths, you might consider the excruciating possibility of inviting them to the office.

The New York e-services firm Organic has done just that after its young employees found themselves fighting an uphill battle to convince their parents of the legitimacy of their careers. Bring Your Parents to Work Day involved 125 parents spending half a day shadowing their children around the Organic offices, in an effort to persuade them that leaving the banking profession for a job on the web wouldn't bring shame upon the family.

In a piece of classic situational comedy, parents were first asked to stand up before the group and explain what it was their child did there. "She does business development, which is just a fancy way of saying sales," said Frank DeBernardis, with the sort of crushing reductionism that his daughter Jennifer won't, one imagines, be getting rid of in a single session.

Driven to distraction

 The Victoria line, London Underground, Monday night and there's an anarchist at the controls of the public address system. As the train pulls into Euston station, a weary driver informs passengers that, "in the true style of managers fiddling while Rome burns", two of the escalators are out of action, and the train won't even be getting to Walthamstow because of construction work. "I'd like to apologise for the poor service on this line," he continues with an air of defeat, "and for the fact that the escalators aren't working because they decided to spend millions on a new uniform."

Off the rails

 Meanwhile, on the Docklands Light Railway on Friday, only the lightning reactions of an operator prevented a man who had climbed down onto the track - to retrieve what looked like his shoe - from disappearing under a train. The driver, in full view of a platform load of horrified passengers, slammed down the kill switch to cut the power and halt the train, while the man casually picked his way over two live rails and sauntered back to the platform. He had disappeared before staff could apprehend him.

fields.headline: Tobacco smuggling
fields.standfirst: The government today announced a £209m plan to crack down on the growing trade in smuggled tobacco. Matt Wells looks into moves to curb the lucrative business
fields.trailText: The government today announced a £209m plan to crack down on the growing trade in smuggled tobacco. Matt Wells looks into moves to curb the lucrative business
fields.body:
Why is the government so concerned about smuggled tobacco?
Quite simply, every puff on a contraband cigarette burns away money that would have gone to the Treasury in tax. The smuggling trade costs the government billions of pounds a year in lost revenue, which it claims would otherwise be ploughed back into public services such as the NHS. The sale of hand-rolled tobacco is almost entirely transacted on the black market, costing the treasury £800m a year. One in four packets of cigarettes is bought illegally.

Where do all these cheap cigarettes come from?
Much of the contraband tobacco comes from mainland Europe, where duty on cigarettes is much lower than in Britain. Duty and VAT lost through cross-channel bootlegging amounted to £1bn in 1998. Only 5% of smuggled goods were detected by customs officers.

Who is responsible?
Customs intelligence operations have revealed that criminal gangs used to dealing in heroin and cocaine are switching to tobacco because they can expect lighter jail terms and do not suffer the same penalties, such as the seizure of all assets. Tobacco manufacturers - including most recently British American Tobacco - have also been accused of tacitly encouraging the shady trade.

Where are the contraband cigarettes sold?
Mostly in dodgy newsstands, hot dog stalls, under the counter at pubs and in illegally-supplied tobacconists. It's a lucrative market - as the price of genuine cigarettes soars (Gordon Brown slapped 25p on the price of a packet of 20 in yesterday's Budget), the attraction of a £1 bootleg packet of B&H grows.

So what does the government propose to do about it?
The woman keeping a firm grip on the government's purse-strings, paymaster general Dawn Primarolo, announced a three-pronged strategy today, including 1,000 more frontline staff, better technology such as more sophisticated x-ray scanners at ports, and tougher penalties for those caught in possession of or dealing in contraband tobacco. All genuine cigarette packets will carry a "duty paid" stamp so customers know what they are getting. "All those involved in tobacco smuggling from the smugglers to the distributors should be under no illusions your time is up," said Ms Primarolo.

What effect will this have?
It is a measure of the scale of the problem that the government's ambition is, in the first three years of the strategy, only to stem the current upward trend. By 2003, Ms Primarolo hopes to have netted £2.3bn for Treasury coffers to spend on "priority areas".

How does the government's desire to reap more revenue from cigarettes sit with its stated policy of reducing the levels of smoking and its resulting cost to the health service?
Ministers claim that tobacco smuggling undermines the aim to reduce smoking, because the trade floods the market with cheap cigarettes. The tobacco manufacturers claim that putting up the duty on tobacco simply encourages smokers to seek out cheaper alternatives rather than actually give up. Public health minister Yvette Cooper claims the government has a comprehensive strategy: yearly increases in duty on cigarettes, measures to curb smuggling and support for smokers who want to quit.

What has been the reaction to the drive to curb smuggling?
Cancer charities and anti-smoking campaigners reacted with delight to the news, but tobacco manufacturers warned that the Budget tax rise would lead to an increase in smuggling and could drive some retailers into bankruptcy. "This announcement is a clear victory for the black market and another kick in the teeth for independent retailers," the Tobacco Alliance said.

fields.headline: Sanitary protection
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about those womanly products on the net
fields.trailText: Everything you need to know about those womanly products on the net
fields.body:
1. Prudence. Locked-in fiscal stability. A civic society. But Gordon Brown couldn't bring himself to say...

2. Sanitary protection? Oh no. Sanpro? Horrible word. Tampons? Heaven forbid!

3. It's left to us then to announce the good news. The VAT on women's sanitary products was cut from 17.5% to 5% in yesterday's Budget.

4. This is the same rate that applies to domestic fuel, and will cost the Treasury (and save women) £35m each year.

5. Sanitary protection has been classed as a luxury product for tax purposes - a classification which organisations like the Women's Environmental Network have found risible.

6. But don't start celebrating yet. The cut won't apply until next January - "to give businesses time to adjust their pricing structure". Odd that this consideration never seems to relate to increases in tobacco and alcohol taxes...

7. Perhaps we shouldn't blame the chancellor. Menstruation has always been the subject of coy euphemism...

8. and even the government's NHS Direct ignores the subject completely.

9. Indeed, one could argue that only when unmentionable sewage washes up on beaches does it receive much coverage.

10. Take heart. You can find plenty of menstrual culture, cute sites for teenagers and alternative menstrual products on the web. Now, that didn't hurt, did it? We never even mentioned blood...

fields.headline: Literati shamed by Beryl's bull
fields.trailText: Even for Beryl Bainbridge, the plain-speaking author of An Awfully Big Adventure who has an unerring nose for literary bull, this was deliciously wicked. A Booker prize bridesmaid for a record five times, Bainbridge, 64, has been scathing about book prizes and the ability of academics to judge them. Now she has turned her acerbic wit on literary pretension and its most common vice - bluffing about books you have not yet read.
fields.body:
Even for Beryl Bainbridge, the plain-speaking author of An Awfully Big Adventure who has an unerring nose for literary bull, this was deliciously wicked. A Booker prize bridesmaid for a record five times, Bainbridge, 64, has been scathing about book prizes and the ability of academics to judge them. Now she has turned her acerbic wit on literary pretension and its most common vice - bluffing about books you have not yet read.

When she was asked what her favourite book of the year was at the King's Lynn literary festival last week she picked an overlooked masterpiece called As Flies To Wanton Boys, by Rhoda F Cornstock.

According to several people attending the event, there was an immediate murmur of approval from the 100-strong audience.

Ms Cornstock, however, and her "intriguing depiction of incest in rural circles" was just a figment of Ms Bainbridge's imagination.

An actress in her youth, Ms Bainbridge kept a straight face throughout. Michael Holroyd, the biographer, and the novelist Paul Bailey, also on the panel, played along with the ruse, but finally Mr Bailey revealed the joke to the audience. Then, last night, it emerged that it was Mr Bailey who actually cooked up the prank.

Andrew Hewson, agent for Ms Bainbridge, said it was he who "found Ms Cornstock" and her neglected oeuvre. "The literary legend started with Paul. He and Beryl have corresponded about Ms Cornstock's work for some time." Norfolk was the obvious place to launch her ground-breaking novel on rural incest to an unsuspecting world.

Although there were whispers that some in the audience were angry that the joke was on them, Mr Hewson laughed off the episode. "Beryl was not insulting anyone. It was just a jolly old joke."

Her co-conspirator had gone to ground last night.

Ms Bainbridge knows all about the neglect that her imaginary protégé suffers. "Sometimes I wonder whether I'm being given prizes at my age out of sympathy or pity," she said after winning the WH Smith prize for Master Georgie, which missed out on the bigger prizes despite being described as the "best book ever not to have won the Booker".

webTitle: Disney angers unions with Pearl Harbor pay wheeze

fields.headline: Disney angers unions with Pearl Harbor pay wheeze
fields.trailText: A row has erupted over Disney's scheme to defer payment to the crew of imminent blockbuster Pearl Harbor. "I want to change the way $100m movies get made," says Bruce Hendricks, the studio's president of motion picture production. But his new method - which involves withholding payment from the film-makers until the movie accrues its target box-office take - is likely to further deteriorate relations between Hollywood studios and beleaguered industry unions.
fields.body:
A row has erupted over Disney's scheme to defer payment to the crew of imminent blockbuster Pearl Harbor. "I want to change the way $100m movies get made," says Bruce Hendricks, the studio's president of motion picture production. But his new method - which involves withholding payment from the film-makers until the movie accrues its target box-office take - is likely to further deteriorate relations between Hollywood studios and beleaguered industry unions.

Disney's new deal may popularise deferments as a way of studios producing more films above $100m while avoiding co-financing pacts, which reduce profits. So far, Pearl Harbor's director of photography, editor, production designer and lighting director have agreed to defer payment - amounting to a saving of between $5m and $10m - while effects house ILM has agreed to "meaningful deferments" said to cost close to $25m.

The studio pledges that if the film reaches a domestic gross of about $140m (a target only a handful of films reached in the last year), crew members will recoup what they would have been paid under normal circumstances.

Critics of the move insist that industry workers may now find themselves having to choose whether to work for cheap or not work at all. Even with deferred pay, they lose money: a salary paid in two years will lose employees the interest they could have accrued in the interim. A spokesman from the Directors Guild of America claimed to be "appalled by this trend". Loadsamoney director Michael Bay happily admits: "I am going into this thinking that I am not going to make a dime. But I would rather gamble on myself."

According to Disney's Hendricks, "certainly the production won't be as comfortable as people are used to. But no one was arm-twisted into doing this movie. Everyone knew that to do this movie, that's what needed to happen". The controversial move, he continues, was "just something I came up with after seeing it done with such studio movies as The English Patient," clearly unaware that that Oscar-winning film's crew have yet to be paid three years after its successful release.

webTitle: Hurricane 'illuminates US justice', says film boss

fields.headline: Hurricane 'illuminates US justice', says film boss
fields.trailText: Jack Valenti, the president of the Motion Picture Association of America, has sent an open letter to critics and litigants against Norman Jewison's contentious Rubin Carter biopic, The Hurricane, saying those upset with the Denzel Washington film about the wrongly imprisoned boxer are missing the point.
fields.body:
Jack Valenti, the president of the Motion Picture Association of America, has sent an open letter to critics and litigants against Norman Jewison's contentious Rubin Carter biopic, The Hurricane, saying those upset with the Denzel Washington film about the wrongly imprisoned boxer are missing the point.

"So many times it has been heard: 'Why can't Hollywood make great films like they used to?''' Valenti writes. "Alas, when such a film arrives, it is often greeted with criticism, none of which connects to the dramatic narrative which informs the films. The tragedy of this avalanche of censure is that it intrudes on the message of the movie, which illuminates the rightness of American justice," he adds, queasily.

The film's critics have alleged that The Hurricane massages the facts of Carter's imprisonment for dramatic effect. In a December article for The New York Times, a former reporter on the case argued that Jewison's movie created a false impression of the legal battles and overemphasised the impact of Canadian activists who helped overturn his conviction.

fields.headline: The rise of King Ganguly
fields.trailText: The Prince of Calcutta is now King of India. Charged with realising the dreams of the world's most passionate cricket fans, Sourav Ganguly started in wonderful fashion. Not only did his team inflict a rare one-day series defeat on South Africa (buoyant after their first Test-series victory in India) but he also managed to coax the best out of Sachin Tendulkar. It was no surprise that Ganguly's form did not suffer either.
fields.body:
The Prince of Calcutta is now King of India. Charged with realising the dreams of the world's most passionate cricket fans, Sourav Ganguly started in wonderful fashion. Not only did his team inflict a rare one-day series defeat on South Africa (buoyant after their first Test-series victory in India) but he also managed to coax the best out of Sachin Tendulkar. It was no surprise that Ganguly's form did not suffer either.

Ganguly's strengths are clear. He is a master batsman - power and poise, with guts to match. The greatest left-handed Indian batsman of all time, some would argue, and it is difficult to think of many challengers. Certainly, he is in the trio - along with Tendulkar and Rahul Dravid - that forms the powerhouse of the current Indian batting line-up. But there is more to him than that. Winning matters to Ganguly and defeat weighs heavily. He fights to the last, bursting with defiance. He can also bowl tidy, tantalising seamers, but will probably go the way of most captains and underbowl himself. If that means that Sachin delivers his Bombay mix more often, then the Indian team will benefit.

More than anything, Ganguly has enthusiasm. At times he is excitable. Better that, though, than a captain who appears oblivious to the surrounding tumult. But there is even more. Ganguly is a good communicator, a Mr Motivator, and has a penchant for spotting chinks in the opposition and seizing the initiative.

Team man or not, nothing drives a player like personal ambition. And Ganguly has balti-fuls. His omission from the Asian XI for ICC's cricket week irked him: Ganguly v Jadeja isn't even a contest. His public displeasure was given substantial impetus when he moved to top of the one-day batting rankings. And Aravinda de Silva's hamstring may yet allow Ganguly to take his rightful place at Dhaka.

If he were included he would be the only Bengali in the game. In fact, being the 'Bengal Tiger' has rarely been helpful. There is a school of thought that Bengalis don't find it easy winning a place in the national side. And many Bengalis are convinced that Ganguly's origins have denied him the captaincy until the case in favour became irrefutable. A silver bat, a plush apartment, and felicitations have been bestowed upon him. Garlanded pictures of Ganguly beam at Bengalis from street-corners, and Bengalis beam back. He is the favourite son of the state. Cricket academies have multiplied in his time, and the Sourav Housing Complex, comprising 80 flats, is rising up in his honour.

This love of Ganguly is unwavering. Even the communist roots of Bengal do not shake at the thought of his silver-spooned upbringing. Chandi Ganguly, his father, is a former cricketer and a successful businessman. When President Truman talked of a chicken in every pot and two cars in every garage he was not thinking of the Gangulys. Twenty-two cars adorn the driveway of the Ganguly bungalow in Calcutta, and Sourav only won three. The chicken count is uncertain, but the house does have 20 bedrooms. Ganguly is clearly more Maharaja than street urchin.

That too has caused problems in the past. Following his Ranji Trophy debut for Bengal in 1989-90, at the age of 17, Ganguly earned selection for the tour of Australia in 1992. He didn't make it into the Test side and was sidelined until 1996 when he made centuries in his first two Tests, in England. But his success was more than merely that of a debutant. His selection had been scathingly criticised in India. He was the token Bengali in the squad, or his father had bought him into the team, said the scandalmongers. And, Ganguly was bloody-minded enough to overcome all that and still score a debut hundred, fittingly, at Lord's. No-one questions his selection now. If the Prince's rise was less than princely, his rule has begun with a royal stamp.

fields.headline: Oscar hero snubbed?
fields.trailText: Will 61-year-old Oscar-rescuer Willie Fulgear be invited to the Academy Awards ceremony? Now that most of the stolen statues have been found, the Academy is under pressure to ensure their saviour, an LA scrap collector, is given both the $50,000 reward and a seat at Sunday night's beanfeast.
fields.body:
Will 61-year-old Oscar-rescuer Willie Fulgear be invited to the Academy Awards ceremony? Now that most of the stolen statues have been found, the Academy is under pressure to ensure their saviour, an LA scrap collector, is given both the $50,000 reward and a seat at Sunday night's beanfeast.

The police, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences and the trucking company that the trophies were stolen from (allegedly by two employees - one of whom prosecutors have declined to press charges against) have all publicly thanked Fulgear.

However, "no decision is being made with regard to the reward, or an invitation for Mr Fulgear to attend the awards, until the police department's investigation is completed, and we don't know when that will be," Academy spokeswoman Leslie Unger reiterated yesterday.

The problem is in part that, in Fulgear's words, "any time something like this is missing and you find it, you're automatically the No. 1 suspect". Fulgear has a criminal history, which he isn't keen to revisit: "I never thought about keeping the Oscars," he said in a radio interview. "I did eight days in jail one time, for a parking ticket. I can't take jail. I wasn't thinking nothing like that. It ain't worth it."

By the time his name is officially cleared, Fulgear may have long since missed the Hollywood backslapathon. But Fulgear restated his claim on the reward money, saying he'd like to invest in a house, and leave some for his 22-year-old son, whom Fulgear has raised alone. Does this man's story sound like the premise for a weepie movie to you too?
