fields.headline: Israel hails Pope, the history-maker
fields.standfirst: No ordinary pilgrim, John Paul faces manipulation by all sides on his long-dreamed-of visit to the Holy Land
fields.trailText: In a moment laden with feeling, the Pope came last night to the Holy Land on a pilgrimage that will combine his yearning for private, spiritual reflection with a public message of reconciliation.
fields.body:
In a moment laden with feeling, the Pope came last night to the Holy Land on a pilgrimage that will combine his yearning for private, spiritual reflection with a public message of reconciliation.

"Today it is with profound emotion that I set foot in the land where God chose to 'pitch his tent'," he said, after shuffling down the steps of a Jordanian airliner on to the wet runway at Tel Aviv's airport.

"In this year of the 2,000th anniversary of the birth of Jesus Christ, it has been my strong personal desire to come here and to pray in the most important places which, from ancient times, have seen God's interventions, the wonders he has done," he said.

The Pope has dreamed of this journey from the beginnings of his papacy in 1978. But there was no mistaking him for a humble pilgrim. He landed to the blare of trumpets from a military honour guard, and was greeted by Israeli dignitaries including the president, prime minister and mayor of Jerusalem, along with Christian, Muslim and Druze religious leaders.

The pomp of the reception underlined the political significance of this first state visit to Israel by a bishop of Rome, and also the Pope's efforts to heal centuries of distrust between Catholics and Jews.

But the brief welcoming ceremony also contained an augury of the tortuous journey that lies ahead as the Pope follows in Jesus's footsteps.

For the next six days every word he utters will be scrutinised for meaning - not just by ordinary Jews, but by Palestinian and Israeli officials who seek endorsement for their political aspirations.

Moments after the band played the Israeli and Vatican anthems, it launched into Jerusalem the Golden, a hymn asserting the historic claim of the Jews to the holy city.

Even the Pope's accommodation has become contentious, with Palestinian activists stealthily raising their national flag near the apostolic residence on the Mount of Olives in east Jerusalem, and Israeli officials just as hurriedly ripping it down.

The last papal visit - in 1964 - was a furtive affair, during which Pope Paul VI never once uttered the word Israel. This Pope acknowledged that era was over.

He said that "Jews and Catholics together must make courageous efforts to remove all forms of prejudice". Such efforts for healing must go further still, embracing the third faith of the Holy Land - Islam - he said.

They were sweet words for the country's president, Ezer Weizman, who gave the official welcome. Yet he could not resist extracting more political advantage from the Pope's presence, by driving home Israel's claim to Jerusalem - a claim unrecognised by the international community.

"You are arriving this evening in Jerusalem, the city of peace, the capital of the state of Israel, the heart of the Jewish world," he said. "Jerusalem has been the heart of the Jewish people throughout all the generations, it is what gives us our spiritiual inspiration. Jerusalem is the city of eternity."

Palestinians will get their chance to reply to Israel's political manoevrings today when the Pope visits Bethlehem, which is under the control of the Palestinian National Authority.

What the local papers say

Yediot Ahronot Tel Aviv

There has not been a pontiff like him, who has contributed to the deepening of ties and enhancement of understanding between Christianity and Judaism, and between Israel and the Vatican. There has not been a pontiff like him who has worked to erase the church's anti-Semitism

Maariv Tel Aviv

When the vicar of Christ paces the Via Dolorosa, this will destroy the efforts of Israeli politicians to turn Jerusalem into a Jewish ghetto. Billions of Christians and Muslims will see and remember that the city is also holy to them

Jerusalem Post

The political revolution in Vatican-Israel relations exemplifed by the Pope's visit should continue with the political equivalent of a change in theology. Although the Vatican no longer speaks of internationalising Jerusalem, neither has it fully recognised Jerusalem as Israel's eternal capital

Al-Quds international Palestinian paper

The Pope's visit to Israel carries a message of tolerance and coexistence and forgiveness for three religions in the troublesome region. It is courageous for the Pope to apologise to the Muslims and Arabs because of the crusaders' atrocities

webTitle: Pope's passionate plea for Palestinian homeland

fields.headline: Pope's passionate plea for Palestinian homeland
fields.standfirst: Pontiff casts caution aside to call for an end to 'sad conflict' in Holy Land
fields.trailText: Pope John Paul II has at last touched down in the Holy Land. He has fulfilled  his life's ambition - but it has hardly been a mission of joy or serenity.
fields.body:
Pope John Paul II has at last touched down in the Holy Land. He has fulfilled his life's ambition - but it has hardly been a mission of joy or serenity.

From the start, the Pope's millennium visit has been mired in political, sectarian and diplomatic wrangles, as Israel, the Palestinians and the deeply-schismatic Christian community vie for his attention and endorsement.

John Paul II and his serried ranks of advisers have been obliged to tiptoe delicately around some of the most explosive issues in a land where the slightest insult - real or imagined - can cause mortal offence, and even bloodshed.

So far, so good. The Pope has been warmly received by Israelis and Palestinians, and has adroitly side-stepped their most burning dispute: the future of Jerusalem. But this morning he has cast aside caution, with a passionate plea for the Palestinians to have their own homeland.

In Bethlehem, where Christianity started and where it maintains a precarious presence on the front line between Jews and Muslim Arabs, he called for peace for all the peoples of the region.

"No one can ignore how much the Palestinian people have had to suffer in recent decades. Your torment is before the eyes of the world. And it has gone on too long," he declared.

"The Holy See has always recognised that the Palestinian people have the natural right to a homeland, and the right to be able to live in peace and tranquillity with the other peoples of this area.

"In the international forum, my predecessors and I have repeatedly proclaimed that there would be no end to the sad conflict in the Holy Land without stable guarantees for the rights of all the peoples involved, on the basis of international law and the relevant United Nations resolutions and declarations."

Such a speech was music to the ears of his Palestinian audience, among whom the words "suffering" and "United Nations resolutions" have an almost religious significance. And his host, Yasser Arafat, president of the Palestinian National Authority, must have been hugely gratified when the Pope kissed a golden bowl of Palestinian soil - a gesture normally reserved for his arrival in sovereign states.

Although the pontiff studiously avoided any mention of statehood, his call for a Palestinian homeland may provoke some pursed lips among Israeli leaders. But they must have been pleased by his pointed refusal to make any reference, on his arrival in Tel Aviv, to the hotly-disputed city of Jerusalem.

The Israelis themselves made their point in the very first moments of the papal visit, when the welcoming band struck up 'Jerusalem of Gold' - a song celebrating Israel's capture of the eastern, Arabic zone of the city in 1967.

Later, the mayor of Jerusalem, Ehud Olmert, scored a very public point by greeting the Pope's helicopter, and escorting him into the city.

Olmert, an outspoken hard-liner with a shark-like rapacity for publicity, insisted that neither church officials or Palestinians should share the honour - or the limelight.

fields.headline: Digital go-getters gain
fields.standfirst:
Tax breaks underline promise to boost internet entrepreneurs
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The government underlined its commitment to turn Britain into a nation of internet entrepreneurs and leaders in high-growth, hi-tech industries with a package of tax breaks designed to reward the most go-getting workers and investors.
fields.body:
The government underlined its commitment to turn Britain into a nation of internet entrepreneurs and leaders in high-growth, hi-tech industries with a package of tax breaks designed to reward the most go-getting workers and investors.

The chancellor's key measures included a new starting rate of corporation tax which means businesses will pay just 10% on the first £10,000 of profits.

But he also unveiled a radical overhaul of the capital gains tax system designed to make Britain a magnet for small business investment. While his package of measures applies to all start-up businesses, it was clearly designed to nurture the vibrant e-commerce sector, which the government views as key to wealth creation.

For the next three years any small business buying computers, or investing in e-commerce and new information technology will be able to immediately write off against tax the full 100% of the cost in the year of purchase.

The most dramatic corporate tax change unveiled in yesterday's Budget cut the waiting time, or taper, before qualifying for the minimum 10% tax take on share sales from 10 years to just four - one year less than had been expected.

From now on if employees buy any number of shares in their own company (not through SAYE sharesave schemes) and sell them within a year they will be liable a tax bill of 40% of the gain (for higher rate tax payers). But in year two that will reduce to 35%, then to 30% in year three, 20% in year four and thereafter just 10%. That is the lowest rate in the developed world.

To encourage big companies to back smaller unquoted companies there is also a new corporate venturing deal, which will hand an immediate 20% tax deduction to the backer when they make an investment - so a £100,000 injection into a start-up would prompt an instant £20,000 cashback.

In addition, hi-tech companies will be able to give £100,000 of share options to 15 employees - rather than the previous 10 - to help them lure and keep highly qualified people.

The government said the changes would boost productivity, by allowing shorter shareholding periods, which in turn encourages serial entrepreneurs. The changes would also promote wider share ownership among employees and would increase the incentive for "business angel" investors to provide risk capital to early stage entrepreneurial activities.

Although the chancellor's CGT measures were very largely applauded, Mr Brown's encouragement to the e-economy did not win universal support - especially for not recognising the pace at which cyber-sector changes are occurring.

Richard Stevens of Ernst & Young said: "This is good news for holders of business assets and a genuine encouragement to entrepreneurs. But in re spect of e-commerce the taper may not be sensible. The longer it takes to make a business valuable, the less tax you will pay. If you do things quickly and create wealth for the nation quickly then you will end up paying more tax.

"E-commerce moves very, very fast and some of these businesses could be penalised by a four-year rule".

Andy Thomson, of Venturedome, an internet portal for entrepreneurs, said: "The tapering system is unnecessarily complicated and should be replaced by a flat rate, even if that is higher than 10%."

He added: "The £100,000 of stock options . . . is not quite the incentive it might seem at first glance. If the level had been set at £250,000 it would have done more to lure high quality senior managers to start-ups."

Mike Warburton, senior tax partner with Grant Thornton, warned that the new measures could create a two-tier labour market. He pointed out many company owners would simply refuse to share equity with their workers.

"You will get people who will be motivated by having shares in their company: these will be the go-getters. But companies which keep shares in family ownership will still be able to recruit - only they will be hiring a different type of person. There will still be many people satisfied with a company car and a pension."

Julian Smith of PricewaterhouseCoopers said the system could also be abused by promiscuous non-executive directors, who sit on numerous boards picking up a few thousand in fees but now able to qualify for potentially huge and lucrative tax breaks on company shares.

However, the Institute of Personnel and Development said it was "particularly pleased" with the chancellor's series of business-friendly tax relief measures, aimed primarily at small and medium-sized enterprises, which together employ 56% of the B ritish workforce.

And the Institute of Directors' director-general, George Cox, said: "It is not just the tax measures which are significant - welcome though they are - it is the confirmation of the government's belief in creating an enterprise culture."

Digby Jones, director general of the Confederation of British Industry, described the Budget as "positive" for small and medium sized enterprises. He said: "The changes to the capital gains tax regime... will benefit SMEs looking for risk capital. It is also being extended to investments in smaller quoted companies, which we welcome."

Referring to the chancellor's decision to continue tax breaks for Britain's 1.7m employees in SAYE share schemes, Mr Jones said: "We welcome the new all-employee share ownership scheme and government's decision to retain SAYE sharesave. The new scheme should be attractive to employers and employees while preserving Sharesave encourages high participation among lower paid staff."

Andy Thomson, of Venturedome, an internet portal for entrepreneurs, said: "The tapering system is unnecessarily complicated and should be replaced by a flat rate, even if that is higher than 10%." He added: "The £100,000 of stock options . . . is not quite the incentive it might seem at first glance. If the level had been set at £250,000 it would have done more to lure high quality senior managers to start-ups." Mike Warburton, senior tax partner with Grant Thornton, warned that the new measures could create a two-tier labour market. He pointed out many company owners would simply refuse to share equity with their workers. "You will get people who will be motivated by having shares in their company: these will be the go-getters. But companies which keep shares in family ownership will still be able to recruit - only they will be hiring a different type of person. There will still be many people satisfied with a company car and a pension." Julian Smith of PricewaterhouseCoopers said the system could also be abused by promiscuous non-executive directors, who sit on numerous boards picking up a few thousand in fees but now able to qualify for potentially huge and lucrative tax breaks on company shares. However, the Institute of Personnel and Development said it was "particularly pleased" with the chancellor's series of business-friendly tax relief measures, aimed primarily at small and medium-sized enterprises, which together employ 56% of the B ritish workforce. And the Institute of Directors' director-general, George Cox, said: "It is not just the tax measures which are significant - welcome though they are - it is the confirmation of the government's belief in creating an enterprise culture." Digby Jones, director general of the Confederation of British Industry, described the Budget as "positive" for small and medium sized enterprises. He said: "The changes to the capital gains tax regime... will benefit SMEs looking for risk capital. It is also being extended to investments in smaller quoted companies, which we welcome." Referring to the chancellor's decision to continue tax breaks for Britain's 1.7m employees in SAYE share schemes, Mr Jones said: "We welcome the new all-employee share ownership scheme and government's decision to retain SAYE sharesave. The new scheme should be attractive to employers and employees while preserving Sharesave encourages high participation among lower paid staff."

webTitle: Iceland seeks cooler image with online rebranding

fields.headline: Iceland seeks cooler image with online rebranding
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Supermarket group Iceland is to rebrand itself Iceland.co.uk in an attempt to cash in on the internet boom and advertise its online shopping and home delivery service.
fields.body:
Supermarket group Iceland is to rebrand itself Iceland.co.uk in an attempt to cash in on the internet boom and advertise its online shopping and home delivery service.

The chain, which has more than 700 stores and is trying to ditch its downmarket image, is to spend £8m on new fascias that will replace the distinctive 1980s-style Conran-designed logo at present hanging over its stores.

Iceland's chairman, Malcolm Walker, announced plans to rename the store chain he founded 30 years ago as he confirmed that he had decided to abandon the notion of an attempted deal with the struggling Storehouse group, which includes Bhs and Mothercare.

Iceland's tentative approach to Storehouse chairman Alan Smith, designed to preserve a deal to open 100 Iceland food halls in Bhs outlets, had a frosty reception from investors.

Finance director Andrew Pritchard said: "We cooled on the idea when it became obvious our shareholders wanted us to stay with what we know."

Iceland's decision to pull out came as a potential bidder for the loss-making group, the Poundstretcher discount retailer Brown & Jackson, announced that it too was no longer interested. Shares in Storehouse lost 23%, falling 10.5p to 36p as news of the double blow emerged.

Iceland was reporting full-year profits of £59.1m, up from £55.1m. Mr Walker said the dot.com rebranding was to underline the fact that internet shopping is now an integral part of the business.

He said at current sales levels Iceland would generate online sales of more than £15m this year, putting it among the dot.com elite.

In a reference to the heady valuations of some e-business players, he said: "For all the valuations of these companies we are one of the largest UK net business in terms of sales."

Net orders are 5,000 a week and Mr Pritchard said: "We are the third-biggest retailer in the country on the net, after Tesco and Amazon, and we are making money doing it."

fields.headline: Today's other news
fields.trailText: Van Damme has no internet muscle, Shaft remake shocks with its lack of sex, Wim Wenders returns to the Buena Vista social club, and, on the casting couch, Julianne Moore could be flying high and Robert Redford takes on the Chinese
fields.body:
Has-been action star Jean-Claude van Damme has been asked to resign from the board of an online casting company, apparently because he had little to contribute. In a barbed press release, The Entertainment Internet chairman Michael Jay Solomon says the board "will be composed of active participants only, each of whom shall provide expertise or input that serves to increase the value of the corporation". Cheerio, then, the Muscles from Brussels.

Samuel L Jackson's Shaft (the remake of the sassy 70s flick) "doesn't have sex", Harry Knowles' website reports, aghast. "Shaft never scores!?!?!?!?", stammers Knowles on Ain't It Cool News, after a reviewer reported - enthusiastically - on the film. "What the hell is that? That's like having Bond never hit the sheets. Shaft is your typical machismo black super-action god. I'd sure as hell film Shaft getting on with some gratuitous loving. It's the man's modus operandi!"

Wim Wenders is making a second film about the Buena Vista Social Club, with the working title The Amsterdam Concerts. The made-for-TV documentary will comprise unused footage Wenders shot during the band's concerts in Amsterdam in spring 1998 - a fraction of which was used in the hit film.

Casting couch

 Brad Pitt may be reteaming with Robert Redford, in Universal Pictures' Spy Game. Redford is to star a CIA agent who during his last day at the agency must mastermind the rescue of a protege captured by the Chinese. The director is Mike van Diem.

 Julianne Moore is vying with Cate Blanchett to headline I Was Amelia Earhart, based on a 1996 fictionalised bio of the famed aviatrix. In Jane Mendlesohn's story, to be directed by Fred Schepisi, Earhart reveals what happened one fateful day in 1937 when she and navigator Fred Noonan vanished near New Guinea.

 Edward Furlong will buckle and swash in The Knights of the Quest, a medieval adventure epic set after the Crusades: the first English-language feature from veteran Italian writer-director Pupi Avati.

 David Fincher, last in cinemas with Fight Club, is in talks to direct The Panic Room. The project concerns a struggle between a woman and her daughter to elude a pair of intruders who break into their home. Nicole Kidman may star. Fincher is also developing Passengers, a sci-fi thriller about aliens that inhabit the bodies of humans for wild romps; and Black Dahlia, an adaptation of the James Ellroy book about an unsolved 1949 murder and the cops who ruin their lives trying to crack the case.

webTitle: Neeson turns down hometown honour after religious row

fields.headline: Neeson turns down hometown honour after religious row
fields.trailText: Liam Neeson has turned down the freedom of his Northern Ireland home town of Ballymeena, saying the religious controversy last month's offer had generated made it 'inappropriate' to accept
fields.byline: By Film Unlimited staff and agencies
fields.body:
Liam Neeson has turned down the freedom of his Northern Ireland home town of Ballymeena, saying the controversy last month's offer had generated between Catholics and Protestants made it 'inappropriate' to accept the honour.

Neeson, a practising Catholic, said in a statement that although he was proud of his association with the his small home town and appreciated the city council's gesture, "it would be inappropriate for me to accept in view of the stated opposition of some members (of the city council) and the resultant controversy".

Neeson, who played the role of 1920s Irish nationalist leader Michael Collins in the film of the same name, said in the statement: "I regard the enduring support which I have received over the years from all sections of the community in Ballymeena as being more than sufficient recognition for any success which I may have achieved as an actor". The controversy surrounding the offer centred around comments attributed to Neeson in which he claimed to have felt a second-class citizen growing up in the mostly Protestant town, and that he had to stay indoors during the loyalist July 12 commemoration of the Battle of the Boyne.

Unionist councillor Maurice Mills argued that the freedom of Ballymeena should instead be offered to Ian Paisley, the area's MP. 'Mr Neeson', said Mills, 'has vilified the people of this town and in particular the Protestant people of this town and he has also questioned the celebration of the 12th of July. I don't think someone who expressed words such as that could be described as one of the leading sons of Ballymena.

fields.headline: Royal hairnet rebuff ruins ricotta
fields.standfirst:
Australia and the monarchy: special report

The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: The curse of silly hat syndrome struck the royal family again yesterday when the Duke of Edinburgh refused to wear a hairnet and booties at a cheese factory in Australia, condemning a batch of experimental lemon ricotta to the waste chute.
fields.byline: Christopher Zinn  in Wagga Wagga and  Matt Wells
fields.body:
The curse of silly hat syndrome struck the royal family again yesterday when the Duke of Edinburgh refused to wear a hairnet and booties at a cheese factory in Australia, condemning a batch of experimental lemon ricotta to the waste chute.

Perhaps mindful of the ridicule heaped upon Prince Charles's choice of headgear on a recent tour of the Caribbean, the duke pointedly refused to don the protective clothing demanded by hygiene rules. His aide told the chief cheesemaker Barry Lillywhite: "He's only going to be here four minutes. He hasn't got the time to put all that on."

Officials tried to play down the controversy by pointing out that the cheese, flavoured with lemon myrtle herb and worth £1,000, was only a demonstration run. But Mr Lillywhite said the 200kg batch would be sent for tests to see if it had been contaminated.

Given the duke's thinning thatch, Mr Lillywhite was more worried by the presence of a shaggy security dog, who despite requests for special consideration gave the Charles Sturt University's cheese factory a thorough once-over just before the visit. "We'll probably end up throwing out today's product," the cheesemaker said. "You can't take the risk of contamination."

All may not be lost. If the cheese is still edible, it might be put on sale as a special "Prince Philip" variety.

While the duke was making waves in Wagga Wagga, the Queen waded into choppy waters of another variety. As head of state, she would have been expected to open the Sydney Olympics later this year. But as controversy continues to surround her constitutional role, John Howard, the prime minister, has decided to confer the honour upon her representative in Australia, the governor general, Sir William Deane, who is Australian.

The Queen was confined to touring the Olympic facilities yesterday.

Earlier, on a visit to Sydney children's hospital, she surprised Rachel Kirk, 11, who has cystic fibrosis, by telling her: "My mother's just had puppies." Her Majesty was, apparently, referring to the Queen Mother's dogs.

Another royal embarrassment was hurriedly avoided when a video of Mr Bean was fast-forwarded as the Queen entered. Children had been giggling at a scene where a lookalike of the monarch comes unstuck.

webTitle: Double hanging at jail prompts call for prison reform

fields.headline: Double hanging at jail prompts call for prison reform
fields.standfirst: Special report: Prisons
fields.trailText: Two prisoners found hanged in the same cell yesterday had been taken off suicide watch just nine days ago, it was revealed last night.
fields.body:
Two prisoners found hanged in the same cell yesterday had been taken off suicide watch just nine days ago, it was revealed last night.

Farouk Mohammed Nasri, 54, and Carl Jacques, 23, were discovered dead at 6.20am in their double cell in Leicester prison. They were hanging from bed sheets tied to the cell's window bars.

Nasri, from Tottenham, north London, was on remand awaiting trial at Nottingham crown court for the murder of his girlfriend, Jennifer Elverson and her son Benjamin, seven, in a fire at their home in Normanton, Derby, on November 14.

Jacques had been jailed for four months for theft by Derby magistrates on March 9 after failing to pay for petrol at a filling station.

The men had been sharing a cell in the prison's A-wing since March 16. Sources said the men were taken off suicide watch about nine days ago.

The prison service confirmed to the Guardian last night that the men had both been on, and then taken off, suicide watch, but could not say when that had occurred. An internal prison investigation and a police inquiry have been launched.

A police source said it was unclear whether the deaths were a double suicide, or whether one man had killed the other then killed himself.

No notes were found. The police are not looking for other suspects.

Harry Fletcher, the assistant general secretary of the National Association of Probation Officers, said: "It's terrible. There needs to be an investigation into the whole suicide watch procedure."

In a separate incident at Parkhurst prison, on the Isle of Wight, another prisoner, Michael McCarthy, 22, was found hanged at 6.10am. He was found by a prisoner in an area reserved for vulnerable inmates. McCarthy had just begun serving five years and five months for burglary. His is the first death at Parkhurst since 1996.

These deaths bring the number of suicides in British jails this year to 19, a rate comparable with the highest-ever recorded figure of 91 during the whole in 1999 - more than twice the 1993 figure.

Double suicides in British prison are very rare, although two men died in the same cell at Brixton, south London, in December last year. In 1990, two 19-year-old men were found hanged in adjoining cells in Hindley remand centre, near Wigan.

In 1993, Leicester's Victorian jail was described by Inquest, the charity which campaigns for the families of people who die in custody, as the "suicide capital of the prison system". Three prisoners, all on remand, committed suicide there last year after two years with no deaths.

Sir David Ramsbotham, the chief inspector of prisons, said in a review last year that a "fresh approach" to suicide was needed in the "massively overcrowded" local prisons such as Leicester, where the vast majority of suicides take place.

He said a "complete culture change" was needed, following the success of initiative at bigger jails like Parkhurst.

The director of the Prison Service, Martin Narey, said that he wanted to introduce cells without window bars, with no points from which prisoners could be hanged.

In his 1998 report on Leicester prison, which currently holds 356 prisoners, Sir David said staff displayed "pride and sense of purpose". But he complained of cuts in the prison budget, and of inadequate facilities for education and exercise.

Deborah Coles, the co-director of Inquest, said last night: "It doesn't seem that the lessons are being learned. Local prisons have the most limited regimes in terms of out-of-cell activities.

"David Ramsbotham's review came up with some very sensible recommendations [but] they are impossible to implement in this kind of prison where the emphasis is on containment and control rather than humanity and care."

webTitle: Why Blair decided to take charge of NHS reform

fields.headline: Why Blair decided to take charge of NHS reform
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Alan Milburn had six months' inside knowledge about the massive spending increase for the Department of Health - a desperate attempt by the government to alter the terms of political debate on the future of the national health service.
fields.body:
Alan Milburn had six months' inside knowledge about the massive spending increase for the Department of Health - a desperate attempt by the government to alter the terms of political debate on the future of the national health service.

Mr Milburn knew about the secret agreement between Tony Blair and Gordon Brown, the chancellor, which acknowledged that only a significant long-term spending increase - the largest rise in the NHS history - would bind suspicious NHS professionals into the process of modernisation.

What Mr Milburn could not have known last autumn, during the discussions, was that he would be asked to oversee the NHS modernisation strategy, or that the prime minister would take charge of the reform programme.

Yesterday, Downing Street made clear that Mr Blair would now personally lead the "no strings dialogue" with NHS professionals until next July when ministers set out detailed targets for faster delivery of the service.

"It will be [Blair's] number one priority," a source said, adding that it did not represent a vote of no confidence in the modernising credentials of Mr Milburn.

Mr Blair will start in the Commons today when he challenges the NHS on why similar trusts or clinical groups perform differently, some more than 30 per cent more efficiently than others. "We have got the transparency, we have given the money and now we want the answers," said one ministerial source.

In the treasury discussions, it was agreed that doctors, NHS administrators, surgeons and nurses, would not listen to the argument for reform unless the debate on NHS funding were ended. Polls had also shown that the public felt ferociously let down and were blaming the government.

By Christmas, decisions had been taken in principle. Mr Brown was to bring forward the spending announcements for the NHS covering 2001-02 to 2003-04, which had been slated for the summer three-year comprehensive spending review. For the coming financial year 2000-01, the second year of the first spending review announced in 1998, he would also have to bust the supposedly "immutable" departmental spending limits by finding extra cash for the NHS. This meant putting the extra cash upfront without knowing precisely how it would be spent. "It is a change of course, but we are goodwill hunting," said one ministerial source.

Debate raged inside government through November, December and January over exactly how much of the "war chest" could be released. And would the announcement be in the budget, or would it be later? If it were left too late, the electoral damage to Labour might be irreversible.

After the winter flu epidemic, which stretched the NHS again, and the attacks from the British Medical Association, and the Labour peer, Lord Winston, the tide was turning to an early and big announcement. In fact, during the flu crisis Mr Milburn was confident enough to speak on radio, predicting massive year on year increases for the NHS.

In a strangely muddled performance on January 9, after a lengthy phone talk with Mr Brown, the prime minister famously pledged to raise NHS spending to the EU average over the next six years.

But the attempt to seize the initiative was bungled. It was not clear if his remarks represented a pledge or an aspiration, and anyway the treasury was not keen on tying British spending to the collective whims of the European chancellories. The pledge foundered as experts argued over interpretations of the EU average spending figures.

But by then the die was cast. Government spending was well below forecast and government receipts much higher. The spending pledge could be made credibly in the Budget without frightening the City.

Mr Milburn, in the meantime, was working up his reform programme. Think tanks have joined the new strategy unit, with the role of harnessing the enthusiasm arising from the spending announcement, and the long-term commitment to a service free at the point of use, to create support for ideas that will probably challenge long-held professional orthodoxies.

Mr Blair knows he will be punished severely if voters do not see real improvements by the next election.

webTitle: Brown's 6.1% year on year makes good PM's pledge

fields.headline: Brown's 6.1% year on year makes good PM's pledge
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: It was being billed by the government yesterday as the largest ever cash boost to the national health service and for once, even the independent experts agreed the spin doctors had given the real doctors something to cheer about.
fields.body:
It was being billed by the government yesterday as the largest ever cash boost to the national health service and for once, even the independent experts agreed the spin doctors had given the real doctors something to cheer about.

After enduring two years of belt tightening in the aftermath of Labour's election, the NHS will enjoy above inflation increases of 6.1% a year on average over the next four years - twice the historical average. And unlike the last time the chancellor announced a boost for health spending, the treasury number crunchers cannot be accused of using creative accounting techniques to grab the headlines.

Independent statisticians at the Institute of Fiscal Studies last night vetted the chancellor's figures and agreed this was the most generous increase in spending since at least 1979 - as far back as their analysis goes. For most of the NHS's more than 50 year existence, spending has risen by just 3.3% above in inflation.

The IFS said yesterday's boost would bring Britain's health spending up to the European Union average by 2004, meeting the prime minister's pledge on television this year.

However, at 8% of national income, it will still be below the spending levels achieved in France and Germany where health takes 9.6% and 10.7% of GDP.

And if spending rises in the rest of Europe over the next four years, the average will also rise, moving the goal posts for Mr Blair's pledge.

By the end of the period, spending on the NHS will have grown from £49.3bn a year, to £68.7bn - a 50% increase in cash terms, and a 35% increase once the likely effect of inflation is taken into account.

But to achieve this unprecedented increase, the chancellor has torn up his three year spending programme for the public sector announced in July 1998. Under the original plans laid out in the first comprehensive spending review, NHS spending was set to rise on average at 4.7% a year be tween April 1999 and March 2002 - above the historical average but below the 5.4% average the Tories achieved between 1989 and 1993.

Instead, the NHS bonanza will begin this April, in what should have been the second year of the comprehensive spending review. The promised £52.2bn - already a £2.9bn increase on the previous year - has now been boosted by an extra £2bn.

"If spent right it will deal with some of the major problems faced by the health service," a spokesman for the King's Fund said. Even the doctors were enthusiastic. Ian Bogle, chairman of the British Medical Association, said: "We are delighted that the government has responded so quickly to our call for a fundamental review of health service funding. We see this as a first major step to putting the health service on a firm, long term basis."

The health secretary, Alan Milburn promised that the new four year settlement would provide a platform for modernisation.

But the IFS cautioned that people had high expectations of the government on health, and had already been disappointed once.

webTitle: Cuban boy a step closer to going home to father

fields.headline: Cuban boy a step closer to going home to father
fields.standfirst: More about the Gonzalez case
fields.trailText: The chances of the six-year-old refugee Elian Gonzalez returning to live with his father in Cuba increased yesterday, after a federal judge in Miami ruled that the US attorney general, Janet Reno, has the legal authority to decide his fate.
fields.body:
The chances of the six-year-old refugee Elian Gonzalez returning to live with his father in Cuba increased yesterday, after a federal judge in Miami ruled that the US attorney general, Janet Reno, has the legal authority to decide his fate.

The judgment, which is likely to be appealed, is a major defeat for Florida-based Cuban exiles who are fighting to keep the boy in the US.

Elian was found clinging to an inflated inner tube off the coast of Florida on November 25 last year, after his mother and 10 other people drowned when their boat capsized during an attempt to escape from Cuba to the US.

In January, the US immigration and naturalisation service (INS) ordered that usual international procedure should be followed in Elian's case, and that he should be returned to the custody of his nearest relative - Juan Gonzalez, his father.

This was approved by Ms Reno, who has legal responsibility for the the decisions of the INS.

But Elian's great-uncle in Miami, Lazaro Gonzalez, contested the decision, saying the boy had more of a future in the US.

The case has turned into a political battle between anti-Castro Cubans and their allies, and the Cuban government and its supporters, for whom Elian has become a nationalist symbol.

In a 50-page ruling yesterday, Judge Michael Moore comprehensively dismissed the challenge by Elian's Florida relatives, who had asked the Miami court to overrule Ms Reno and order an asylum hearing. He ruled that granting asylum was "a matter within the discretion of the attorney general".

"Even this well intended litigation has the capacity to bring about unintended harm," his judgment went on.

"In light of the attorney general's clearly articulated views on the matter of whether Elian Gonzalez should return home, as well as the reality that each passing day is another day lost between Juan Gonzalez and his son, the court can only hope that those on each side of this litigation place the interests of Elian Gonzalez above all others."

Though the initial reaction from legal experts was that Judge Moore had correctly interpreted the law, the Miami relatives and their supporters have 30 days in which to lodge an appeal.

If one is lodged, the US court of appeals has wide discretion over whether to expedite it. Whatever the outcome, a further referral to the US supreme court is probable, meaning that Elian is unlikely to return to Cuba for several more months.

The case has become so politically charged that an intervention by the US congress is also likely, in spite of the judge's warning. Many Republican politicians want congress to grant US citizenship to Elian, a move that would make an early return to Cuba even less likely.

The longer the case runs, the less legal and administrative procedures may be able to determine Elian's fate: in an election year the boy is likely to be increasingly at the mercy of political forces in Florida - a key swing state in this year's presidential battle between the Republican George W Bush, and the Democrat Al Gore.

webTitle: Helpless in face of bolt from blue

fields.headline: Helpless in face of bolt from blue
fields.standfirst: Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Frank Hogbin began his job as general manager of the FW Hays Rover dealership in Chiswick, west London, in January. Now, just two months later, the future of his showrooms and those of his 57 staff are in the balance.
fields.body:
Frank Hogbin began his job as general manager of the FW Hays Rover dealership in Chiswick, west London, in January. Now, just two months later, the future of his showrooms and those of his 57 staff are in the balance.

Mr Hogbin, 41, said: "Normally, we'd expect to sell at least one car a day and a few more at the weekend, but we haven't sold a new Rover since last Wednesday. We've had four orders cancelled, and one or two others are in the balance.

"The customers are concerned about things - like what happens to the three-year warranty if Rover doesn't exist anymore, how they will get spare parts, and the future value of the car, the hardest one to deal with. Unfortunately, perception is reality in these situations.

"The parent company, William Jacks, took over the dealership only last September - for a substantial amount of money - and we've spent £100,000 refurbishing the showroom and the after-sales facility. We're very much in this for the long term. Now we feel that the rug has been pulled out from under our feet. The news came like a bolt out of the blue and there isn't anything we can do. It's very frustrating.

"It's sadly ironic that this should happen after we've gone through all the trials and tribulations of the last five or six years, when we've probably got the strongest product in terms of quality we've ever had. I absolutely believe in the product.

"There will always be a hard core that will stick with a manufacturer but the uncertainty is the problem. People just want to know whether Rover will exist for the foreseeable future. The longer the uncertainty goes on, the bigger the problem. We can't tell our customers lies ... a number have said they're behind us all the way and I always tell them that the best way to support us is to get their cheque books out and buy a new Rover."

webTitle: Millionaire plans bid to take on Alchemy

fields.headline: Millionaire plans bid to take on Alchemy
fields.standfirst:
Businessman aims to set up takeover consortium as fall-out hits the dealers

Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: A millionaire businessman is seeking to make a counterbid for Rover, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
A millionaire businessman is seeking to make a counterbid for Rover, it emerged yesterday.

John Hemmings, of Birmingham, is trying to put together a consortium to counter Alchemy Partners' offer to buy the ailing British car company from BMW.

The West Midlands had the relevant technical, managerial and entrepreneurial expertise to create a viable bid, he said.

But he admitted that Alchemy, a London-based venture capital business, was in pole position, having secured six weeks of exclusive negotiations with BMW.

Mr Hemmings, an e-commerce and computing entrepreneur who also sits on Birmingham city council as a Liberal Democrat, hoped other people would join him.

"We've only got six weeks," he said. "At the very least we need a nucleus of people in touch with each other able to move fast should the Alchemy thing fall to pieces."

About 500 Rover shop stewards yesterday met union leaders who are due to meet BMW executives this week. The German ambassador, Hans Friedrich von Ploetz, yesterday warned Britain not to allow the Rover issue to escalate into a political dispute which could cost the country millions of pounds of investments.

Commenting on the government's fury at being misled by BMW executives, Mr von Ploetz said: "I don't think it will be helpful for governments to join in this game. The real question is the way ahead."

He said German firms had invested about £17bn in Britain and further investment could be at risk if the Rover affair got out of hand.

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary who has said he was deliberately misled by BMW, is due to meet the German company's chairman, Joachim Milberg, tomorrow.

Rover dealers have asked him to get BMW to compensate them for their investment in building up their Rover franchises. Alchemy has already indicated that it plans to abandon the Rover models and build new sports cars under the MG marque.

Trade union officials are planning a "people's march" in Birmingham on April 1 to protest against the sale of Rover. Tony Woodley, chief motor industry negotiator for the Transport and General Workers Union, said the unions' campaign was "a battle for Britain and British manufacturing" which had struck a chord with the British people.

fields.headline: It's grim up north - official
fields.standfirst:
Our great midland and northern university cities are spurned, while Oxbridge gets the funds

North-south divide: special report
fields.trailText: Now the truth is out. After months of argument about a north-south divide - first dismissed, then grudgingly acknowledged by Tony Blair - we know, at last, that this government has a regional policy of sorts. No longer is it based on encouraging the rebirth of our great provincial cities, and surrounding regions by creating a level economic playing field across England through curbing growth in the overheating, overcrowded, overbearing south, and East Anglia.
fields.body:
Now the truth is out. After months of argument about a north-south divide - first dismissed, then grudgingly acknowledged by Tony Blair - we know, at last, that this government has a regional policy of sorts. No longer is it based on encouraging the rebirth of our great provincial cities, and surrounding regions by creating a level economic playing field across England through curbing growth in the overheating, overcrowded, overbearing south, and East Anglia.

Rather, it is a negative, laissez faire model which encourages the onward expansion of these well blessed regions with fat Whitehall cheques for research funding, and new planning guidelines to accommodate tens of thousands of new homes (albeit at much higher densities) on the spurious grounds that big business wants to invest there. So the argument goes: how can, why should, a government of enterprise stand in the way of the market? Surely growth in the south trickles down to the rest of the country? And if we put the brakes on, business will simply abandon Britain and relocate over the channel rather than move north, won't it? Ummm.

In this context, the decision to relocate the £500m, government-funded Diamond synchrotron research project in Oxfordshire, rather than underpin its present base in Cheshire, marks a defining moment for the government, and a kick in the teeth for northern MPs. Not in their wildest dreams could they have envisaged their government actively widening the already gaping north-south divide.

When facing the heavy hand of business, which wants to invest in these southern hi-tech clusters because of their international reputation - courtesy of successive governments pumping in billions of research funding - New Labour knows which way to turn. And the regions, particularly the north-west, lose out yet again. No matter that all the scientists involved wanted the project to stay in the north west; no one questions the huge success of Britain's existing synchrotron at the Daresbury laboratory, near Warrington. The (government-appointed) regional development agency had been making monumental efforts to get ministers to see sense.

Gordon Brown may have moved yesterday to redress the regional imbalance with a £1bn public-private regional venture capital fund, but there is much ground to make up. This is no simple, knee-jerk north-south argument. It goes to the heart of government, striking a blow at fairness, equity and plain common sense. And it is not just confined to England's less-favoured regions, where backbench Labour critics of the Blairite project had been getting more vocal by the day. Ian Gibson, Labour MP for Norwich North, and a respected senior scientist at the University of East Anglia in another life, believes the government has dismally failed in its duty to support science outside the south.

This story will run and run because it exposes the government where it is weakest. But Downing Street spokesmen can bring precious little hope of regional equity to the three northern regions. They can't even help local agencies identify matching funds to trigger off multi-billion pound European Union programmes to revive the depressed economies of South Yorkshire, Merseyside, Cornwall, and Wales. And they certainly can't develop a coherent regional policy.

Last year, to be fair, they made a stab at it by creating eight regional development agencies (RDAs), with a total budget of under £1bn. The aim of the RDAs, creature of John Prescott's Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions (and not, intriguingly, the Department of Trade and Industry), was to iron out regional disparities and pull the poorly performing regions up the Euro wealth league. The problem is, the RDAs themselves appear to be in competition, with the south-east (GDP per head 18 points above the Euro average) going for growth, on the basis that it will "stimulate wealth creation for the country as a whole", and the poorly performing north-east (35 points behind) attempting to do the same thing.

Some economists believe the regions have been encouraged to take part in an "uncoordinated scramble for higher growth" - while the government evades its responsibility for promoting more even development within the UK.

Downing Street, of course, defends its hands-off approach on the grounds that "all Britain is our core constituency", that there are no no-go areas for New Labour. That argument, of course, won't wash - on the science front, or elsewhere.

Why, for instance, do four centres of learning - Imperial College and UCL in London, Oxford and Cambridge - get the lion's share of research funds, while provincial universities scramble around for cash? As Oxford (location for the Diamond project) and Cambridge (location for much more) have learnt, research spending one day means hi-tech spin off - and many jobs - the next. Sadly, those great northern and midland university cities, with an infrastructure much superior to Oxbridge and London, are not so well blessed.

The problem is, the RDAs themselves appear to be in competition, with the south-east (GDP per head 18 points above the Euro average) going for growth, on the basis that it will "stimulate wealth creation for the country as a whole", and the poorly performing north-east (35 points behind) attempting to do the same thing. Some economists believe the regions have been encouraged to take part in an "uncoordinated scramble for higher growth" - while the government evades its responsibility for promoting more even development within the UK. Downing Street, of course, defends its hands-off approach on the grounds that "all Britain is our core constituency", that there are no no-go areas for New Labour. That argument, of course, won't wash - on the science front, or elsewhere. Why, for instance, do four centres of learning - Imperial College and UCL in London, Oxford and Cambridge - get the lion's share of research funds, while provincial universities scramble around for cash? As Oxford (location for the Diamond project) and Cambridge (location for much more) have learnt, research spending one day means hi-tech spin off - and many jobs - the next. Sadly, those great northern and midland university cities, with an infrastructure much superior to Oxbridge and London, are not so well blessed.

fields.headline: £1bn fund to combat disparity
fields.standfirst:
North-south divide - special report
Budget 2000 - special report
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown moved to defuse backbench criticism of a growing north-south economic divide with a new £1bn venture capital fund to kick-start innovation and job creation in the regions as well as Scotland and Wales.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown moved to defuse backbench criticism of a growing north-south economic divide with a new £1bn venture capital fund to kick-start innovation and job creation in the regions as well as Scotland and Wales.

With the government under attack over near-standstill budgets for eight new English regional development agencies (RDAs), the chancellor pledged to work with the business-led RDAs to achieve "balanced economic development" across Britain with a modern regional policy.

The extra cash will come from a partnership between the government, business and the European Investment Bank, he said.

Derek Mapp, chairman of the East Midlands RDA and spokesman for the eight agencies, said they expected that the new fund would initially be spread over three years with the government providing £250m - possibly by amalgamating existing schemes - with business contributing another £250m and the EIB £500m.

"Instead of a disparate approach where different government departments are doing different things they are saying let's get all this linked together with quite a lot of new money," he said. "This is probably the first attempt at some regional dispersal and it will allow us to leverage in a significant amount of extra funding with the government providing the necessary security."

Mr Brown announced provisional regional targets in England, amounting to £835m - with the remaining £165m presumably going to Scotland and Wales. He said £85m would go to the south-west; £120m to the north-west; £130m to the north-east and Yorkshire; £250m to the midlands and the east and £250m to London and the south-east.

The chancellor also said that the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, would next week be announcing a regional innovation fund to help the formation of local "clusters" for hi-tech industries - along the lines of successful growth centres around Cambridge and the M4 corridor.

But the government is certain to face criticism that its rhetoric does not match the economic reality on the ground. Last week's decision to bow to pressure from the Wellcome Trust by agreeing to relocate the £500m government-funded Diamond synchrotron project in Oxfordshire - rather than underpin its present successful base in Cheshire - is seen by many backbenchers, leading scientists, and the North West RDA, as a blow to regional policy by encouraging southern clusters at the expense of the north.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: With the current furore over asylum seekers filling the media, it's good to see the Daily Telegraph doing its best to avoid fanning the flames of racism and knee-jerk xenophobia that can so easily characterise coverage of the subject.
fields.body:
 With the current furore over asylum seekers filling the media, it's good to see the Daily Telegraph doing its best to avoid fanning the flames of racism and knee-jerk xenophobia that can so easily characterise coverage of the subject. Fortunately the Telegraph had the restraint to place only a small article on its front page yesterday, under the headline "Gang rape by asylum seekers", about an attack on a woman in St Leonards, near Hastings. "Three eastern European asylum seekers were being sought," wrote David Sapsted. "The attack took place in Warrior Square, St Leonards, an area where hundreds of asylum seekers live." Well, it was obviously them then. Unfortunately, Hastings and St Leonards are popular sites for foreign language students from all over Europe, so the area is usually full of people with assorted accents anyway. And what a shame the Telegraph could not find room (as the Mirror did) for the quote from the police saying: "We cannot make any assumptions about the race or status of the men." Very poor show.

 The Sydney 2000 Olympics are just a few months away, and the Diary is right behind our British athletes as they prepare. By a stroke of luck, Cutting Edge, the official British Olympic Association newsletter arrives, detailing exciting news of our team's official car sponsor - Rover. "Rover will embark on an extensive marketing campaign," the newsletter bubbles, "utilising some of the key values of the Olympic movement - quality, personal excellence, success, leadership and 'extraordinary drive'." Mmmm.

 Nice to see Gordon Brown chucking some cash at the NHS in the Budget yesterday, although much of the contents had been extensively trailed in all newspapers. Top marks to David Smith in the Sunday Times last week, with his exclusive: "Middle class to escape rise in stamp duty". A story almost entirely accurate, except for the rise in stamp duty announced by Gordon. Oh dear.

 With Matthew Norman currently on secondment to the Frank Dobson mayoral campaign (many people forget that Matthew was a founder member of Labour's Shadow Communications Agency back in 1987), the Diary is lining up top celebrities to model its exciting "Oooh You Amaze Me!" T-shirts. Fatboy Slim and Zoe Ball are currently top of the list, along with Chris Evans, now that he has redeemed himself in the eyes of many by making a generous £200,000 donation to Ken. Hats off to Chris - and T-shirts on!

 Just when Philip Gould Month looked like being cancelled due to lack of public interest - rejoice! Following yesterday's Diary appeal, an anonymous tipster calls with details of the boyish focus group guru's 50th birthday party. Philip, who helped make New Labour what it is today, has hired the London Eye wheel on Thursday, March 30. Starting at 7.30pm guests will go for a spin, followed by drinks at the Marriott Hotel in County Hall, the home of the GLC before it was flogged off by the Tories. How much more New Labour could you get?

 Some extraordinary news from the Western Mail, which hasn't had the publicity it deserves. According to a new book by someone called Graham Phillips, the Virgin Mary is buried in Llanerchymedd, Anglesey. A restrained Dr Trystan Hughes of Bangor University remarks that the claim is "historically far-fetched". Indeed.

 Dobbo's internet lackeys yesterday blocked a cunning wheeze after some joker set up an amusing new web address ( http://i.am/a.c*** ) that led to poor old Dobbo's official site. Unfortunately another amusing web address ( http://i.am/a.f***wit ) pointing to a picture of Mr Tony Blair on the official Labour website, is still at large in cyberspace.

fields.headline: Share options shift NI burden
fields.standfirst: The IT workers
fields.trailText: Axon, an e-commerce company based in Surrey, was yesterday celebrating a potential £1m gain from the Budget after the chancellor promised action to remove a Catch-22 problem that has left start-up companies creaking under huge national insurance liabilities.
fields.body:
Axon, an e-commerce company based in Surrey, was yesterday celebrating a potential £1m gain from the Budget after the chancellor promised action to remove a Catch-22 problem that has left start-up companies creaking under huge national insurance liabilities.

Until yesterday Axon was facing a £1m bill to pay for employer's NI when its staff exercise share options. Last year its NI liability was just £200,000, but as Axon's share price has jumped 500% over the past year, the liability in the next tax year would be £1m, mak ing a massive dent in its profits of £4.5m.

The company, which started in 1995 and now employs 200 people, designs business-to-business solutions for blue-chip clients such as Orange and BP Amoco.

The issue has hit thousands of small internet start-ups which have used share options as an incentive to staff and have seen their share prices soar. Accountants have warned that many are effectively insolvent as a result of having to put aside reserves for future NI payments on options when they are exercised.

But the chancellor said yesterday that he will begin an ur gent consultation exercise to reduce the NI burden. Early indications are that employers will be allowed to transfer their NI liability on to employees. An employee exercising an option is likely in future to have to pay not just the marginal tax rate but also their employer's NI bill of 11.7%, producing a maximum tax bill of 51.7%.

Axon finance director Robin Halliday said: "It sounds like very positive news for employers, but the devil is in the detail. NI has been a huge issue for us; it's been like a tax on success. We're excited about what he's promising, but you often find with budgets that when you look at the fine print, what you originally expected is not there."

But the extra tax burden on staff means that employers are likely to be forced to grant extra options to compensate, warned tax specialist Rose Edmunds of accountants Grant Thornton.

Ernst & Young also warned that some companies could still be bankrupted if employees exercise their share schemes before any new rules come into force. "The NI problem is going to go through a lingering death. If employees sell their shares tomorrow, some companies are still going to face enormous bills."

webTitle: When the choice is emigrate or close down

fields.headline: When the choice is emigrate or close down
fields.trailText: Malcolm Cowen, a self-employed information technology consultant, says the Budget poses him a stark choice: either to close down his business or emigrate, temporarily splitting his family as he leaves behind his wife and three sons.
fields.body:
Malcolm Cowen, a self-employed information technology consultant, says the Budget poses him a stark choice: either to close down his business or emigrate, temporarily splitting his family as he leaves behind his wife and three sons.

It is a decision forced on him by the introduction of a new tax rule, he argues, which it is estimated will run some 66,000 small businesses to the wall. Under the IR35 regulation, self-employed consultants trading their knowledge - as opposed to a more tangible commodity - will have 95% of their company's entire turnover viewed as salary and be forced to pay employers' national insurance accordingly. At the same time, they are ineligible for corporation tax - charged at 20% - and will have the whole amount taxed as PAYE, which in the majority of cases, will be 40%.

The Inland Revenue sponsored the measure, claiming that many consultants were abusing the rules by driving down their salary to unrealistic levels to avoid tax. But yesterday, Mr Cowen, while heralding the tax breaks for small businesses buying computers or going online, described this regulation as "disastrous".

"The idea of giving the tax incentives for small businesses investing in computers or e-commerce is a good one," he added, "but I wonder where they're going to find the people to install them. With this rule, small businesses like mine will just have to close down."

The IT consultant, who last year gave himself a salary of £24,000, ploughing the rest of his £58,000 turnover back into the company, continued: "Under this new rule, I'll have to pay twice as much in national insurance as I would as an employee of a company, while, as company director, still not getting the benefits employees do - such as sick pay, compassionate leave and social security benefit.

"I'll also be taxed on everything as PAYE. Basically, I'll be paying something like £10,000 extra a year."

For the father-of-three, whose 15-year-old company, Cowen Software employs only himself and his wife Beryl, 52, the hike will make trading in Britain impossible.

"Some people will be able to hike the prices up, which means everyone will pay more, but those in small businesses just won't be able to. To cover my costs, I'd have to put up my prices by 20-30%. People just won't pay that.

"I've now got two choices: to close down my company, get a job, be paid less but be taxed less and be not much worse off while getting the national insurance benefits enjoyed by employers. But, at 53, I'm not sure what my chances are of that.

"Or to emigrate to Germany - where they introduced this rule a couple of years ago and quickly scrapped it. Either way the government will get less tax from me."

webTitle: And a big hand from e-business

fields.headline: And a big hand from e-business
fields.trailText: G ordon Brown, the suited son of a Scottish Presbyterian minster and now pushing 50, is an unlikely friend of the T-shirt-wearing e-entrepreneurs making their millions in the converted lofts of London.
fields.body:
G ordon Brown, the suited son of a Scottish Presbyterian minster and now pushing 50, is an unlikely friend of the T-shirt-wearing e-entrepreneurs making their millions in the converted lofts of London.

But while the words might grate a little, there was evidence yesterday that appearances can be deceptive. At a time when companies from BP Amoco to Iceland are getting the dot.com vibe, perhaps we should not be too surprised that a man who grew up in a country of heavy industry and shipbuilding can get it, too.

Britain's burgeoning internet and technology sector can only applaud the tax cuts on share ownership, the incentives for business to go online and also the hint that rules on employing skilled foreign nationals will be relaxed.

"Outstanding" was how Ernesto Schmitt, the 31-year-old president of internet music start-up Peoplesound.com described Mr Brown's dispatch after watching it on a webcast beamed to his laptop computer.

"Encouraging" was the more measured response of Robin Saxby, the chief executive of FTSE 100 chip maker ARM Holdings - who has been vocal about the government's need to adopt more of a laissez-faire silicon valley-style approach to Britain's hi-tech businesses.

For Mr Schmitt, a Labour supporter with strong business-friendly leanings, the two most important pledges were those over capital gains tax and work permits. Any measures to encourage worker-ownership of businesses and outside investment in companies should be encouraged, he said.

Similarly, permit application delays often lead to UK companies losing staff to American rivals, and any changes to make the system simpler and more flexible will be beneficial. The most ambitious British internet companies are looking to build global businesses and highly value staff with experience of overseas markets.

There is also a shortage of skilled technology workers in Britain, and many companies complain that one of their biggest challenges to growth is their ability to recruit new staff. In raw terms, a relaxation of work permit rules to give overseas skilled workers easier access to the jobs market will simply increase the ability of UK firms to compete on a global scale.

However, the government may need to re-examine the IR35 proposals, which treat long-term contractors as employees and impose additional costs on companies and workers.

We should also not lose sight of the fact that many of the reforms which Mr Brown proposed were symbolic, rather than significant.

His pledge that up to 15 essential personnel at hi-tech firms can be offered share option incentives of £100,000 from April 6, for example, will not have much of an effect on companies such as Peoplesound. Even the lowest paid secretary at the London-based start-up can expect a six-figure shares payout if the company floats as planned later this year. Top managers will make millions.

All internet firms will benefit from the market growth resulting from the commitment to allow one million small businesses buying computers and investing in e-commerce to write off against tax the full 100% of the cost in the year of purchase. Tax cuts for the electronic filing of tax and VAT returns will also encourage computer literacy.

However, one of the hottest issues - reform of the punitive taxes at present levied on share options - was only partially tackled. Brown promises that his sidekick, Stephen Timms, will look at the issue, but he had better look quickly since a failure to act will excacerbate a brain drain which is already under way.

Boardroom excess

Leading British hi-tech companies such as ARM and QXL.com argue that legislation introduced in 1998 to cap boardroom excess is stifling hi-tech enterprise.

The pair, and dozens of companies like them, use large options packages to attract workers but claim the burden of having to make provisions for national insurance payments on options can bring many young companies, where value is being built faster than cashflow, to their knees. ARM has warned it may have to move divisions overseas to escape the rules; QXL had to make a £14.8m share option provision in its third-quarter figures which only compounded its losses. They have worked hard to convince the Treasury of their arguments.

Mr Brown's pledge to look at the issue was received cautiously by hi-tech firms. Mr Saxby admitted that "the devil can be in the detail". John Browning, co-founder of internet networking group First Tuesday, warned that a dialogue between government and industry must be started and concluded quickly if Britain's internet sector is not to lose its momentum.

For hi-tech entrepreneurs like Mr Schmitt and Mr Saxby, who are more at home in silicon valley than the City of London, the business climate in Britain under the guidance of a sympathetic government has improved immeasureably over the past year. But Mr Brown cannot let up if his rhetoric is to become reality.

webTitle: It's the visionary enterprise capitalists wot get the pleasure

fields.headline: It's the visionary enterprise capitalists wot get the pleasure
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown resembled  a shore leave sailor in a  dockside pub, pockets  stuffed with fivers. "Ish  only 'cosh I'm sho pruden'  I've gorrall thish money to  shpen."
fields.body:
Gordon Brown resembled a shore leave sailor in a dockside pub, pockets stuffed with fivers. "Ish only 'cosh I'm sho pruden' I've gorrall thish money to shpen."

"Oo wanz a drink? Hey, you, trible Drambuie for my fren'. Yer see, I'm pruden', thash wha' I am ... "

Well of course he didn't sound like that, but there was some extravagant bragging to go with the giveaways. These included up to £50,000 for schools with more than a thousand pupils to be spent as the head teacher wishes.

Most polling stations are in schools. So we can expect to pop in to vote and see a sign saying: "This fine mahogany trophy cabinet [or possibly the staff room sub to Penthouse] provided through the generosity and prudence of Mr Gordon Brown."

"Prudence" and variations received nine mentions, "boom and bust" only two, but "cautious" made several appearances, as did "locked into fiscal tightening".

They finally merged into a pair of convoluted, buttock-clenching phrases: "we have decided on a prudent and responsible approach which will lock in fiscal tightening"; and my own favourite: "because we have not spent more, and will not spend more, at the expense of being prudent!", a sentence which curls around itself and finally disappears up its own fiscal black hole.

I get the impression that the chancellor finds this kind of talk rather exciting. I expect he secretly combs West End phone boxes looking at the cards: "Gorgeous model locks in fiscal tightening", or "Prudence with optional massage? Oriental lovely offers personal tax relief." The chancellor has also invented a new phrase, "the civic society", which seems to be code for "creating more jobs so that young men don't go round stealing car radios."

It sounded rather quaint: "Mr G Brown will give a slide lecture next week entitled 'Bygone Kirkcaldy' to the civic society ..."

He sat down to enthusiastic if not overwhelming applause from his own side and a glum silence from the other. At this stage it is William Hague's traditional role to cheer his party up - which he did with a rumbustious attack on everyone.

He quoted Alastair Campbell's first on the record lobby briefing in which, when asked about tax rises, he replied with this crisp analysis: "Yeah, those are the figures, as set out in the last PBR, either the Budget or whatever, the red book, the projections, had they been, yeah, I dunno, whatever."

"It's no consolation," said Mr Hague, to happy laughter from his side, "that the real deputy prime minister is no more eloquent than the official one."

The official one, John Prescott, sat there scowling. He may not loath being attacked in the commons any more than anyone else, but it looks that way.

Mr Hague also referred to Labour's "heartlands".

I am not sure when this became a synonym for "poor." Again our great works of literature will have to be rewritten: "blessed are the heartlands, for they shall have a 50% rise in winter supplement" and "it's the visionary enterprise capitalists who take advantage of the technological revolution wot gets the pleasure, it's the heartlands gets the blame."

Mr Brown watched the Hague speech with what passes for a merry smile on his face and would look like terminal heartburn on anybody else's. But of course even sailors on leave have to face up to reality the morning after. With Mr Brown's budgets, the hangover tends to come after a week or so.

webTitle: Handouts aim to lift incomes of pensioners and poor families

fields.headline: Handouts aim to lift incomes of pensioners and poor families
fields.trailText: The chancellor yesterday unveiled sweeping handouts for elderly people and low-income families in an attempt to tackle poverty that drew rare praise from charities.
fields.body:
The chancellor yesterday unveiled sweeping handouts for elderly people and low-income families in an attempt to tackle poverty that drew rare praise from charities.

The biggest winners in the Budget were pensioners, who stand to gain cheaper heating, greater access to income support and further refunds on their television licences.

Mr Brown said that by next April, retired people would be an annual £1,000 better off than when Labour entered office. At the core of his proposals was a relaxation of the rules surrounding income support. From next month, pensioners with up to £6,000 of savings will be able to claim support, doubling the current limit of £3,000.

The chancellor said: "I have decided to do more today for elderly citizens with modest savings whose very thrift has perversely and unfairly debarred them from receiving the income they need."

The change will deliver an average boost of £250 a year to 500,000 people, with many benefiting to the tune of over £1,000. Personal allowances for pensioners were raised to £5,790, and to £6,050 for over -75s, meaning a further 6m people will pay no income tax.

Elderly people will get an annual winter fuel payment of £150, up from £100. Extending his handout of free television licences to those aged over 75, Mr Brown said those with unexpired licences beyond November will be entitled to refunds.

In another significant move, the social security secretary, Alistair Darling, is to launch a consultation on a "pensioners' credit" - which could deliver a sharp increase in income for older pensioners living on less than £100 a week.

Age Concern applauded the measures but expressed disappointment that there was no rise in the basic state pension. Sally Greengross, the charity's director general, said: "Prudent older people caught in the poverty trap because they saved towards their retirement will welcome the chancellor's decision to increase the capital limits for income support. But ultimately the poorest pensioners need a major increase in the basic state pension so they are not forced to rely on benefits."

Turning his attention to families, the chancellor increased child benefit for the first child by 50p to £15.50 and for subsequent children to £10.35 a week from April 2001. He claimed the minimum family income would rise by 7% to £214 a week.

The government's Sure Start grant for low income mothers is to rise from £200 to £300, and money will be made available for mothers who choose to stay at home for a longer period after giving birth.

Under the proposals, a low-paid family with two children on a wage of £10,000 a year will now be £2,700 a year better off. The chancellor said the rises in income would help achieve the "greatest reduction in child poverty in 50 years". He also announced plans to set up a network of lo cal and regional childrens' funds, to support voluntary bodies in lifting young people out of poverty.

Martin Barnes, director of the Child Poverty Action Group, said he applauded Mr Brown's "stubborn and persistent commitment" on the issue but added: "Child poverty cannot be ended without a significant increase in basic family income."

The NSPCC said any increase in the income of the poorest households would help reduce child abuse. A spokeswoman said: "Abuse happens across society but it happens most in low income families. The measures will help reduce the stress on these families and in turn help reduce some of the factors that can lead to abuse."

Measures to help those looking for work included an extension of the New Deal training programme to adult unemployed people. Mr Brown said the long-term unemployed aged over 50 would be guaranteed a higher income if they returned to work. Those earning under £15,000 will get an extra £60 a week.
