fields.headline: Prudence, meet politics
fields.standfirst: The chancellor's great giveaway to the NHS showed him to be just another politician after all
fields.trailText: The chancellor's great giveaway to the NHS showed him to be just another politician after all
fields.body:
Like a maestro debuting his fourth and finest symphony, Gordon Brown's hour at the dispatch box yesterday should have been his most golden. The climate shines on him more generously than any chancellor you can name. Just days ago Britain learnt that its economy had nudged ahead of France to become the fourth mightiest in the world. Under Brown, the country's accounts have moved from blood red to reassuring black. Yesterday he could brag and boast his way through an astonishing battery of numbers: growth higher than predicted, inflation lower than planned, unemployment at its lowest for 20 years and a deficit in 1997 converted into a £12bn surplus today. Even the usually-ascetic chancellor couldn't resist offering a toast to himself. This fine record was the result of a strong economy and "our prudent management".

But self-congratulation was not enough for the restless Mr Brown. He quickened the pace, the maestro wowing his audience with sheer audacity. He revealed delights that would have made even his Tory predecessors blush. He slashed through capital gains tax too fast for the scribblers on the opposition benches to keep up. Within seconds he was on to inheritance tax, hacking away at it at such speed that the thing was in ribbons before MPs could pause for breath. Once he was done, the House could only marvel at a Labour chancellor who had served up a budget that could have been written by the Elders of Middle England. They will now pay the lowest corporation tax anywhere and, if they inherit money, only four in a hundred of them will pay tax on it. The reviews on planet Daily Mail should be stellar.

But he was not done yet. Having tickled the New Labour converts, he would soothe the old Labour faithful. "Something for the heartlands," was the tacit message as he announced bundles of cash for education and health. He had pulled it off again. Just as last year he seemed to squeeze a £40bn injection to schools and hospitals into the same budget as a penny tax cut, so yesterday he simultaneously announced giveaways for the well-off and spending for the needy. Within 50 rapid-fire minutes, galloping Gordon had cut taxes, increased spending - and still kept the public coffers in the black. Surely this was yet another Brown blockbuster, satisfying left and right alike?

And yet it didn't quite feel that way. Despite the confidence of the opening, the final flourish on health sounded oddly defensive. That was because a performance which had begun with economics ended in politics. Far from displaying Gordon Brown as the unchallenged master of the universe lionised in Westminster mythology, yesterday's speech revealed him as a mortal politician - as vulnerable to the gusts of mood and "events" as any of his colleagues.

For although Brown's speech lasted less than an hour yesterday, it looked as though it began two months ago - on David Frost's sofa. There, on January 16, Tony Blair sought to cool anger over the winter crisis in the NHS by admitting that spending was too low - and promising increases of around 5% above inflation for the next six years. To the naked eye, yesterday's speech seemed like an urgent attempt to honour that pledge - with a commitment to spend a staggering £69bn on health over five years. (In fact Brown exceeded Blair's promise, pledging cash rises at 6.1% above inflation.)

That may be unfair. An alternative version says Brown and his aides realised more than a year ago that health was too hot a political issue to be handled like the rest of government activity. Where other departments could be told to reform first and receive new money later - and to wait for the Treasury's comprehensive spending review to take its course - health, the Brownies realised, was a special case. Ministers might be able to attack teachers for low standards, witholding extra cash until they changed their ways, but no politician could dare do the same to doctors and nurses. When David Blunkett appears on the Today programme pitted against a teacher, chances are the audience is rooting for him. When Alan Milburn squares off against a cancer specialist, it's the doctor demanding money who wins everytime. Brown's team calculated that they would have to cut through the "noise" about resources by breaking their own rules and announcing money up-front first, insisting on reform second. That's why Brown promised the cash yesterday, with Tony Blair launching the major review today.

Either way, the chancellor acted like a conventional politician yesterday, reacting to events rather than shaping them. With most ministers that would be no big deal; but you notice it with Brown - partly because normally he does such a good job of appearing above the everyday fray. Colleagues dislike the way he dodges the flak - ducking when trouble looms over Kosovo or the NHS crisis - but it adds to the aura of Brown as a heavyweight, a grown-up among political juniors. Sometimes he seems more like an emissary from the global economy than a humble British cabinet minister. But that mystique was punctured a little yesterday.

There are three other worries. First, BMW's dumping of Rover left many Britons anxious to hear Brown say something for manufacturing industry. BMW insists its hand was forced by the strong pound: it made exporting British goods economically unviable. Yet nothing in the Budget hinted at a fall in sterling: on the contrary, tax cuts and increased spending, as promised yesterday, could well have the opposite effect. But Treasury insiders argue that their record of fiscal discipline - turning debts into surplus - should have begun to reduce the value of sterling by now. The fact that it has not suggests not that the pound is too strong - but that the euro is too weak.

A second concern centres on one of Brown's loudest applause lines yesterday. He announced sackloads of money for schools - going straight to the head teacher's cash-box and bypassing the local education authority. That has obvi ous, anti-bureaucratic appeal. But that logic could eviscerate local government, eventually depriving authorities of half their budget and a large chunk of their raison d'etre. This is hard to square with Brown's constant rhetoric about a decentralised, devolved Britain flowering into a rich, civic society.

Finally, the chancellor may come to regret bowing to politics on health. What's to stop other ministers now demanding similar up-front injections of cash ahead of reform? Has he perhaps created an incentive against reform, by rewarding the service with the deepest problems ahead of those which have most improved?

These are not urgent worries. Gordon Brown's centrality to this government was confirmed rather than undermined yesterday. He is still, at the very least, a co-conductor of the Labour orchestra - standing at the front, calling the tune.

webTitle: Although it's a great Budget, we must believe in it, too

fields.headline: Although it's a great Budget, we must believe in it, too
fields.standfirst: The chancellor's speech brought good news for everyone, but . . .
fields.trailText: The chancellor's speech brought good news for everyone. So why doesn't it all feel quite as good as it should?
fields.body:
Great news for everyone. Stunning news for the NHS. Very good for poor and middling families. Many more children taken out of poverty. Poorer pensioners have done well. Schools have a dollop more with more yet to come. The regions have a billion between them. Even airline passengers, drinkers and drivers are winners. In all the land only smokers have been punished. So rejoice, rejoice.

Fine goals and targets, audits of success and generosity were rolled out yesterday. One million poor pensioners are now £20 a week better off in real terms: eat your heart out Barbara Castle, they've never had so big an increase. Only 50,000 people remain long-term unemployed: the New Deal is working. 1.2m children will have been lifted out of poverty this year - and child poverty will be halved by 2010, (abolished 10 years later). Not just working families, but families living on income support are far better off, with an extra £1,500. Half of all pupils will be in higher education in 10 years time. Who could ask for anything more?

Never have the country's finances looked so rosy. The golden figures poured like doubloons from the chancellor's lips. Growth is wonderful and sustained, outdoing its forecast year after year. Unemployment, and therefore the social security budget, is dropping like a stone. Inflation is the lowest in 40 years. A phenomenal surplus of £12bn is bursting the chancellor's pockets. Oh joy! No one alive has ever lived in such good economic times.

So why doesn't it all feel quite as good as it should? Why isn't this dancing in the streets time? Where's the surge of rekindled May 97 high emotion? Try to feel it again by saying: "Look at all that's been achieved! Would you have guessed so much could be done in under four years?" But no, something is missing. Listening with hope to Gordon Brown the heart does not beat faster. In fact now and again the gorge rises a bit. Ungrateful, or what?

The something missing is a tribal, clannish thing. We want him to talk to us, his people, but he insists on talking to the enemy too. All those familiar Brownisms - prudent, prudent, prudent - somehow fail to charm. Every time he gives something to his own, he gives something to the enemy too. So we get a triumphant reminder that inheritance tax is almost defunct: as the rich avoid it, 96% of the people never pay any. (Hurray for the inheritance principle?) We get a heavy cut in capital gains tax too, down to 10% for business. Terrific. As expected, he pushes on with the 1p cut in income tax. Great. The total tax "burden" (as Labour should not agree to describe it) is staying the same. Britain stays at 39% while far more productive Germany with a far higher standard of living and less inequality, take 49%.

Does it matter? If he can do all these wonderful things for the people and the services that really need it, does it matter how much tax is taken? It does if taxing more allows even more spending, without raising interest rates. But why tax for taxing's sake? Ideology does not feed poor children, buys no new teachers or nurses, builds no health centres or colleges. The history of ideology in British politics is dismal - think Michael Foot and Margaret Thatcher. And yet this is not the end of history. Politics do still matter. People need to be given a coherent account of what the government is doing and why, who they are for, who against. Parties need to define themselves with rallying cries to their natural supporters. People see very little of what is actually happening but they believe the stories they are told. Why else would an astounding 40% of people tell the Guardian/ICM poll this week that they feel worse off this year than last, when for most of them it simply cannot be true? They've been reading the wrong newspapers instead of reading their pay slips. That is why Gordon Brown's deft and crafty playing to the galleries on both right and left may in the end be self-defeating. It tells no story.

One of the most admirable and likeable things about New Labour has been its obsession with what works . Teams of researchers and policy advisers dig out the evidence and plunge into gritty details of how to get people jobs, stop them doing crime or get children to learn. They are serious, compared to the contemptible frivolity of ideological Tory ministers who preferred a flag to wave and the politics of gesture, however perverse the actual result.

B ut the result of Labour's ideology-free politics is a risk of losing contact. Where's the red thread that links a hundred good practical schemes? Where is the signpost, so people don't get lost? There was too little glue in Gordon Brown's speech. Playing both ends against the middle, he risks failing to get the great credit he deserves from his own side. Prudent he may have said, over and over again, yet there was an air of throwing money in every direction in something of a panic - the same panic that made the prime minister promise such monster sums to the NHS on the David Frost show (why on earth there and then?). There's a bung to keep education quiet for a bit and a plethora of fiddly measures designed to keep everyone happy. A few of them are mildly daft - like the government giving more money for every penny donated to charity (remember, that means taxpayers' money going to dogs, Eton and every religion, even Odin worshippers). Presumably that was an over-reaction to the mad Hague claim that cutting tax means people give more to charity.

The root problem is that the Tories are such a feeble foil. Opposing them is so easy is just doesn't give Labour enough chance to define their own identity. So when the chancellor adroitly mocked the Tory tax-cutting plans, pointing out that 75% of Tory proposed tax cuts would benefit the top 5% of punters, it did not cut much ice, because what the Tories say barely counts. Portillo is laying out a plan to augment health funding with more private provision - a big Tory idea for the next election. This budget didn't just spike his guns, it decommissioned them for once and all. This whacking great NHS increase and the mighty review (oh, not another!) to decide how to spend it will end any debate (for now) on whether a modern democracy can will the ends to pay for a modern health service.

Make no mistake. This is a terrific budget. Almost all of it is very good news. If this kind of growth is sustained it should mean that in a few years public services really will look and feel more like the quality of the rest of our lives. Large numbers of the poor will have had more money and more help than ever before. The question for Labour is how they can take all this good news and sell it, so people believe it. No spin, just the facts, but plain facts need a strong clear vision to make people take them to their hearts.
fields.bodyText: Great news for everyone. Stunning news for the NHS. Very good for poor and middling families. Many more children taken out of poverty. Poorer pensioners have done well. Schools have a dollop more with more yet to come. The regions have a billion between them. Even airline passengers, drinkers and drivers are winners. In all the land only smokers have been punished. So rejoice, rejoice. Fine goals and targets, audits of success and generosity were rolled out yesterday. One million poor pensioners are now £20 a week better off in real terms: eat your heart out Barbara Castle, they've never had so big an increase. Only 50,000 people remain long-term unemployed: the New Deal is working. 1.2m children will have been lifted out of poverty this year - and child poverty will be halved by 2010, (abolished 10 years later). Not just working families, but families living on income support are far better off, with an extra £1,500. Half of all pupils will be in higher education in 10 years time. Who could ask for anything more? Never have the country's finances looked so rosy. The golden figures poured like doubloons from the chancellor's lips. Growth is wonderful and sustained, outdoing its forecast year after year. Unemployment, and therefore the social security budget, is dropping like a stone. Inflation is the lowest in 40 years. A phenomenal surplus of £12bn is bursting the chancellor's pockets. Oh joy! No one alive has ever lived in such good economic times. So why doesn't it all feel quite as good as it should? Why isn't this dancing in the streets time? Where's the surge of rekindled May 97 high emotion? Try to feel it again by saying: "Look at all that's been achieved! Would you have guessed so much could be done in under four years?" But no, something is missing. Listening with hope to Gordon Brown the heart does not beat faster. In fact now and again the gorge rises a bit. Ungrateful, or what? The something missing is a tribal, clannish thing. We want him to talk to us, his people, but he insists on talking to the enemy too. All those familiar Brownisms - prudent, prudent, prudent - somehow fail to charm. Every time he gives something to his own, he gives something to the enemy too. So we get a triumphant reminder that inheritance tax is almost defunct: as the rich avoid it, 96% of the people never pay any. (Hurray for the inheritance principle?) We get a heavy cut in capital gains tax too, down to 10% for business. Terrific. As expected, he pushes on with the 1p cut in income tax. Great. The total tax "burden" (as Labour should not agree to describe it) is staying the same. Britain stays at 39% while far more productive Germany with a far higher standard of living and less inequality, take 49%. Does it matter? If he can do all these wonderful things for the people and the services that really need it, does it matter how much tax is taken? It does if taxing more allows even more spending, without raising interest rates. But why tax for taxing's sake? Ideology does not feed poor children, buys no new teachers or nurses, builds no health centres or colleges. The history of ideology in British politics is dismal - think Michael Foot and Margaret Thatcher. And yet this is not the end of history. Politics do still matter. People need to be given a coherent account of what the government is doing and why, who they are for, who against. Parties need to define themselves with rallying cries to their natural supporters. People see very little of what is actually happening but they believe the stories they are told. Why else would an astounding 40% of people tell the Guardian/ICM poll this week that they feel worse off this year than last, when for most of them it simply cannot be true? They've been reading the wrong newspapers instead of reading their pay slips. That is why Gordon Brown's deft and crafty playing to the galleries on both right and left may in the end be self-defeating. It tells no story. One of the most admirable and likeable things about New Labour has been its obsession with what works . Teams of researchers and policy advisers dig out the evidence and plunge into gritty details of how to get people jobs, stop them doing crime or get children to learn. They are serious, compared to the contemptible frivolity of ideological Tory ministers who preferred a flag to wave and the politics of gesture, however perverse the actual result. B ut the result of Labour's ideology-free politics is a risk of losing contact. Where's the red thread that links a hundred good practical schemes? Where is the signpost, so people don't get lost? There was too little glue in Gordon Brown's speech. Playing both ends against the middle, he risks failing to get the great credit he deserves from his own side. Prudent he may have said, over and over again, yet there was an air of throwing money in every direction in something of a panic - the same panic that made the prime minister promise such monster sums to the NHS on the David Frost show (why on earth there and then?). Opposing them is so easy is just doesn't give Labour enough chance to define their own identity. fields.headline: Mr Brown's healthy brew
fields.standfirst: But the pound remains a cause for anxiety
fields.trailText: The chancellor is sitting on Fort Knox in the form of a £12bn budget surplus - one of the biggest in history - but in practice he has had to put Scrooge's cap on because his largesse has been constrained by the need not to upset the City by spending too much at a time when the economy is in danger of overheating.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown's fourth Budget contains a broadside of measures to appease Labour heartlands, mollify Middle England and stimulate small businesses ahead of a general election next year. The chancellor has again pulled off the political conjuring trick we are now getting used to. He is planning an almost unprecedented 6.1% annual increase in health spending - above the rate of inflation - for the next four years (plus an extra £1bn for schools) while simultaneously tightening the fiscal stance (the balance between borrowing, spending and taxation) quite substantially by over 1% of of gross domestic product. He is sitting on Fort Knox in the form of a £12bn budget surplus - one of the biggest in history - but in practice he has had to put Scrooge's cap on because his largesse has been constrained by the need not to upset the City by spending too much at a time when the economy is in danger of overheating.

On the first of the two tests on which we said this budget should be assessed - the need to boost spending substantially on health and education - he has come out with flying colours. But on the second -measures to bring down the over-strong pound - the jury is still out. The Treasury argues that it has already hugely tightened fiscal policy in recent years in the hope that this would take the pressure off the pound, but that has not worked. The problem, it believes, is the weak euro, not the strong pound, and when the EU economy awakens from its slumbers, as it is now showing signs of doing, the problem will sort itself out. Maybe. But until it does, the Treasury's prediction of a near 6% rise in export volume this year (compared with 2.5% last year) looks like wishful thinking.

But even within his fiscal constraints Mr Brown has money to scatter around, thanks to lower debt interest payments, higher tax receipts and reduced outlays on social security. Small and medium-sized businesses will welcome his £225m reduction in capital gains tax liabilities on business assets and a sheaf of other measures, including £280m for a new all-employee share plan. He also promises to look at the problems of dot.com companies, worried about tax liabilities arising from share options on which their early success depends. Middle England will be relieved that the problems of the health service are to be tackled (after the neglect of Labour's first two years) even if they are not yet convinced that Mr Blair's target of matching European generosity is on the horizon.

This was a Budget in which Labour threw itself as never before behind nurturing entrepreneurs, while also giving help to the poor - especially pensioners. Their increases, while hardly dramatic, are more generous than they look because they have been craftily targeted to help the really needy. Only a year ago, education was due to get more than health in this latest budget - an extra £3.5bn compared to health's £2.9bn. But since then the health service has been hit by flu and a winter crisis. Public support for Labour's handling of health steadily bled away in its first two years, but this last winter created a critical haemorrhage. Hence the prime minister's decision to intervene. He will speak more fully in the Commons today of Labour's new programme for the NHS, but the key injection - cash - was dealt with by the chancellor yesterday. Instead of an extra £2.9bn, the health service will receive £4.9bn for the financial year that starts in 10 days time - a 7.4% increase. This will be the first of four increases through to April 2004, averaging 6.1%. The health service has seen nothing like it. Its increases have averaged only 3.3% since its foundation and the last Conservative government averaged only 2.9%. True, the Tories pushed up spending by 9% in 1991 to save their "internal market", but no government has achieved such a sustained level of investment. It is a health managers' dream, an opportunity to look and plan for the medium term rather than merely tomorrow. A health budget which was £45.1bn only last year, will rise to £68.7bn by April 2004 - a 50% increase in cash terms and a 35% increase in real terms. Sceptics will say that not even this huge investment will lift British health spending to the European average, as Mr Blair promised in January on the David Frost programme. They would be right, in that it is due to lift spending (both public and private) to 7.6% of GDP. But that is only 0.4% short of the crude European average.

Although education has only received £1bn extra compared to health's £2bn on this April's planned increases, education still achieved a higher proportionate rise: some 8%. There is no doubt that health is in a much sorrier state than education, so honour would be achieved by health receiving the bigger cash injection with education maintaining a higher proportionate rise. Headteachers were delighted not just with the extra funds but the method of distribution direct to the school. What was particularly welcome was the freedom for the schools to chose how the extra was spent: on books, technology or staff.

There was much less excitement on the anti-poverty front, where the two previous budgets introduced the best deal for the poor for a generation. But earlier announcements were consolidated, with the New Deal's welfare-to-work programmes extended to long-term unemployed, older workers and lone parents. By the end of the next financial year 1m children will have been lifted out of poverty and there are already plans to lift another million over three years through an integrated child credit. If that is achieved, the government will be on target to cut child poverty in half by 2010 - a new halfway house before the ultimate goal of complete abolition by 2020. One welcome new trend was the chancellor's readiness to point to the redistribution that Labour is achieving. Civic society is being renewed.

Mr Brown, in sum, may have "given away" about as much as he could without frightening the City. Many people will still be understandably bemused as to why a chancellor sporting a record budget surplus, with more expected in coming years, cannot do even more to rectify the glaring deficiencies in health, education and transport. But within his self-imposed constraints, the chancellor has done himself proud.

fields.headline: Tories mock chancellor's 'taxation by stealth'
fields.trailText: William Hague yesterday mocked Gordon Brown as the "stealth chancellor" who boasted of cutting taxes while secretly increasing the overall burden by the equivalent of 8p in the pound.
fields.body:
William Hague yesterday mocked Gordon Brown as the "stealth chancellor" who boasted of cutting taxes while secretly increasing the overall burden by the equivalent of 8p in the pound.

In the traditional Budget responses from the opposition leaders, the chancellor also came under attack from the left as the Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, accused him of putting tax cuts before help for pensioners and adding "insult to injury" for the elderly.

The Tory leader made clear that tax will move to the political centre stage in the run-up to the general election when he rounded on the chancellor for omitting from his Budget statement the £4.5bn of "stealth taxes" he had imposed on Britain. To Tory laughter, Mr Hague said: "He is like a mugger who grabs your money and then wants you to thank him for giving you your bus fare to get home."

Mr Hague told MPs that - even after taking account of yesterday's changes - the overall tax burden would rise by 9p in the pound and would see a cut of only 1p. "For every extra pound that you're letting them keep in their pay packets, you are stealing nine times as much from their back pockets," Mr Hague told the chancellor. "So you have done what all Labour chancellors have done: to increase taxes and the only difference is that you're much stealthier about it."

The Tory leader dismissed the chancellor's claim that he was helping families, saying that he was in fact penalising families by introducing the replacement for the married couple's allowance - the children's tax credit - a year after the abolition of the married couple's allowance.

To laughter, Mr Hague added: "Even the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, wouldn't be very happy with a train-operating company that phased out the 9.15 to Waterloo a year before it phased in the replacement bus service."

Mr Hague "unambiguously welcomed" the extra money for health and education, though he said that the Tories would examine the announcements carefully because "we know all about your triple accounting". He added: "We know that his headline grabbing on Budget night leaves a sour taste in the mouth of doctors and nurses and patients whose expectations are raised and then dashed."

Mr Kennedy, in his response to the Budget, said the real meaning of the chancellor's "prudence with a purpose" mantra was "spending for a second term".

"When we argued that sums of this nature could and should be put into the health service that was described as completely financially irresponsible - today of course it is now the mantra," he said.

The chancellor was cutting taxes rather than spending adequately on education or the elderly, he said. While only £1bn extra would go into schools this year, the cost of the penny cut in the basic rate of tax would be £2.6bn. Making his first Budget response as party leader, Mr Kennedy warned that there would be "genuine anger in the country" over the failure to direct more money to pensioners. Despite higher winter fuel payments and "recycled announcements" of free television licences, there remained a "great missing morality at the centre of this Budget".

The chancellor had announced a consultation on how to develop a new "pensioners' credit", designed to help both those in poverty and those with modest savings, but this would come too late for many pensioners, the Lib Dem leader said.

The Budget also came under fire from the Liberal Democrats for failing to address environmental issues - a theme Mr Kennedy is attempting to make his own. A consultation on reducing stamp duty on the development of "brownfield" sites - as opposed to untouched green space - delayed real action, he said.

The plight of struggling farmers had also been neglected by the chancellor, the Liberal Democrats argued.

However, Mr Kennedy, MP for Ross, Skye and Inverness West, jokingly applauded a freeze in duty on spirits and the cut in air tax for flights between the Scottish islands and the mainland.

fields.headline: Married, one employed, one child
fields.trailText: Bill and Alice Harford and their young daughter, who live comfortably on his doctor's salary of £80,000, aren't too disappointed by yesterday's announcements. Their loss of the married couple's allowance and Miras has been offset by basic rate tax reductions. The family may postpone its decision to move house, since they would pay 4% stamp duty on the £500,000 home they had set their hearts on. The rises in petrol duties will cost them more to run their 5 series BMW, though there has been no change in vehicle excise duty.
fields.body:
Bill and Alice Harford and their young daughter, who live comfortably on his doctor's salary of £80,000, aren't too disappointed by yesterday's announcements. Their loss of the married couple's allowance and Miras has been offset by basic rate tax reductions. The family may postpone its decision to move house, since they would pay 4% stamp duty on the £500,000 home they had set their hearts on. The rises in petrol duties will cost them more to run their 5 series BMW, though there has been no change in vehicle excise duty.

Otherwise, the Budget has been mostly good news: child benefit is increasing to £15.50 from April 2001, Bill will enjoy a £100 tax cut when he electronically files his return to the inland revenue, and the family will pay less flight duty when they fly to their villa in Tuscany, if they fly economy rather than first class.

fields.headline: Priority No1: the NHS
fields.standfirst:
Brown's immediate £2bn boost and 10,000 extra nurses - Blair takes personal responsibility for health service

The future of the NHS: special report
Budget 2000 - special report
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown yesterday threw a £2bn lifeline to the ailing NHS as part of a huge four-year boost to health spending designed to allay public concern over Labour's most vulnerable area in the run-up to the next election.
fields.byline: Larry Elliott, Michael White  and John Carvel
fields.body:
Gordon Brown yesterday threw a £2bn lifeline to the ailing NHS as part of a huge four-year boost to health spending designed to allay public concern over Labour's most vulnerable area in the run-up to the next election.

After a winter of crisis in Britain's hospitals, Mr Brown opened his brimming war chest to bring forward part of his planned summer spending round. He pledged a 35% real increase in funds for the NHS by 2004, the biggest sustained increase in its 52-year history.

The first fruits of the chancellor's surprise announcement - the centrepiece of his fourth Budget - will be a sustained drive to recruit 10,000 more nurses and better intensive care, but Mr Brown emphasised that the extra cash would have to be matched by reform and modernisation of the NHS.

To underline Labour's determination to recapture public confidence after sustained criticism of poor services and long waiting lists, Tony Blair will be taking personal responsibility for the NHS. The prime minister will make a Commons statement on health today explaining how he and the health secretary, Alan Milburn, will spearhead the public debate about the future of the NHS and ensure the government gets the best value for Mr Brown's billions.

Last night the prime minister met healthcare professionals and told them that today he would be setting out plans to publish more tables highlighting the vastly different costs of operations from region to region, outlining increased powers for nurses and a further tranche of cash for preventive and primary care.

The chancellor said the 6.1% a year real increase in spending was the reward for his disciplined handling of the economy, which he expects to grow robustly over the next three years despite the impact of the strong pound on manufacturing. With the economy in its ninth year of sustained growth, Mr Brown said he would have a budget surplus of £12bn this year, £15bn better than he expected a year ago. Next year, even after the extra spending, the surplus will still be £6bn, leaving plenty of scope for pre-election tax cuts or further spending increases.

"We have been prudent for a purpose. New money we can provide because we have made our choice: a Budget that unites the whole country, a Budget for all our people," Mr Brown said.

Treasury officials strongly denied that the chancellor had been panicked into a spending spree, although many at Westminster believed that the move reflected the direct intervention of the prime minister to twist Mr Brown's arm.

While health was the most eye-catching announcement in the Budget, there was also an extra £1bn for education, to allow David Blunkett to hand up to £9,000 for primary schools and up to £50,000 to secondary schools.

More money for transport and combating crime mopped up the rest of Mr Brown's £4bn boost to public spending, which dwarfed tax cuts of just over £1bn.

The British Medical Association, often critical of Mr Blair, led a chorus of delight from within the NHS. "We are delighted that the government has responded so quickly to our call for a fundamental review of health service funding. We see this as a first major step to putting the health service on a firm, long-term basis," said its chairman, Ian Bogle.

Government sources said the increases would take health spending from £49.3bn to £68.7bn by 2004, equivalent to 7.6% of GDP and within touching distance of the European average of 8%.

Despite Conservative scepticism about Mr Brown's figures, the sheer scale of the chancellor's commitment to "a publicly funded NHS, true to the original principles of its founders" took MPs on all sides by surprise.

Cash spending will rise by 50% from £1,850 a household to over £2,800 by 2004. One Whitehall official said: "This is a step change in the money available. Now we need a step change in the results we get from it."

Some of the new money has been earmarked to wipe out £600m of accumulated NHS debts.

With the four-year programme for increased health spending already agreed, the education department was set to become the big beneficiary of the chancellor's comprehensive review of other Whitehall spending.

"Education will be the big selling point in the summer. So David is smiling. I can't see how this can do anything but help," one of Mr Blunkett's ministerial colleagues said last night.

Education spending had been set to increase by £3.5bn over the coming financial year and yesterday's Budget raised this to £4.5bn. Health spending had been due to rise by only £2.9bn, but overtook education as a result of the chancellor's statement to get an increase of £4.9bn.

fields.bodyText: Gordon Brown yesterday threw a £2bn lifeline to the ailing NHS as part of a huge four-year boost to health spending designed to allay public concern over Labour's most vulnerable area in the run-up to the next election. After a winter of crisis in Britain's hospitals, Mr Brown opened his brimming war chest to bring forward part of his planned summer spending round. He pledged a 35% real increase in funds for the NHS by 2004, the biggest sustained increase in its 52-year history. The first fruits of the chancellor's surprise announcement - the centrepiece of his fourth Budget - will be a sustained drive to recruit 10,000 more nurses and better intensive care, but Mr Brown emphasised that the extra cash would have to be matched by reform and modernisation of the NHS. To underline Labour's determination to recapture public confidence after sustained criticism of poor services and long waiting lists, Tony Blair will be taking personal responsibility for the NHS. The prime minister will make a Commons statement on health today explaining how he and the health secretary, Alan Milburn, will spearhead the public debate about the future of the NHS and ensure the government gets the best value for Mr Brown's billions. Last night the prime minister met healthcare professionals and told them that today he would be setting out plans to publish more tables highlighting the vastly different costs of operations from region to region, outlining increased powers for nurses and a further tranche of cash for preventive and primary care. The chancellor said the 6.1% a year real increase in spending was the reward for his disciplined handling of the economy, which he expects to grow robustly over the next three years despite the impact of the strong pound on manufacturing. With the economy in its ninth year of sustained growth, Mr Brown said he would have a budget surplus of £12bn this year, £15bn better than he expected a year ago. Next year, even after the extra spending, the surplus will still be £6bn, leaving plenty of scope for pre-election tax cuts or further spending increases. "We have been prudent for a purpose. New money we can provide because we have made our choice: a Budget that unites the whole country, a Budget for all our people," Mr Brown said. Treasury officials strongly denied that the chancellor had been panicked into a spending spree, although many at Westminster believed that the move reflected the direct intervention of the prime minister to twist Mr Brown's arm. While health was the most eye-catching announcement in the Budget, there was also an extra £1bn for education, to allow David Blunkett to hand up to £9,000 for primary schools and up to £50,000 to secondary schools. More money for transport and combating crime mopped up the rest of Mr Brown's £4bn boost to public spending, which dwarfed tax cuts of just over £1bn. The British Medical Association, often critical of Mr Blair, led a chorus of delight from within the NHS. "We are delighted that the government has responded so quickly to our call for a fundamental review of health service funding. We see this as a first major step to putting the health service on a firm, long-term basis," said its chairman, Ian Bogle. Government sources said the increases would take health spending from £49.3bn to £68.7bn by 2004, equivalent to 7.6% of GDP and within touching distance of the European average of 8%. Despite Conservative scepticism about Mr Brown's figures, the sheer scale of the chancellor's commitment to "a publicly funded NHS, true to the original principles of its founders" took MPs on all sides by surprise. Cash spending will rise by 50% from £1,850 a household to over £2,800 by 2004. One Whitehall official said: "This is a step change in the money available. Now we need a step change in the results we get from it." Some of the new money has been earmarked to wipe out £600m of accumulated NHS debts. With the four-year programme for increased health spending already agreed, the education department was set to become the big beneficiary of the chancellor's comprehensive review of other Whitehall spending. "Education will be the big selling point in the summer. So David is smiling. I can't see how this can do anything but help," one of Mr Blunkett's ministerial colleagues said last night. Education spending had been set to increase by £3.5bn over the coming financial year and yesterday's Budget raised this to £4.5bn. Health spending had been due to rise by only £2.9bn, but overtook education as a result of the chancellor's statement to get an increase of £4.9bn. However, education ministers said last night that they were not losing out because their increase over this year's budget was 8.5%, while health got 7.9%. The eventual outcome would depend on the comprehensive spending review, but gains made by the health department would strengthen arguments for spending more on education.

fields.headline: The difference in your pocket
fields.standfirst: Good news for pensioners, but low earning single parents are surprise sufferers
fields.trailText: New tax breaks will hand the average household an extra £460 a year, the chancellor promised yesterday, but the surprise losers in a Budget hailed as lifting children out of poverty are low earning single parents and families with one child.
fields.body:
New tax breaks will hand the average household an extra £460 a year, the chancellor promised yesterday, but the surprise losers in a Budget hailed as lifting children out of poverty are low earning single parents and families with one child.

A childless couple who both earn £40,000 a year will gain an extra £764 a year from Mr Brown's largesse, according to figures from accountancy firm PricewaterhouseCoopers. But a single parent with one child struggling by on £10,000 a year will see their income fall by £66.60 in the coming year. A married couple with one earner making £10,000 a year and one child will also see a fall in income next year of £58.80.

Single parents will be hit hard by the loss of the additional tax allowance for children - announced in the last Budget - which gave 10% relief on £1,970. The taxman therefore whips £197 from their income this year.

The children's tax credit will more than make up for the loss, but that does not kick in until 2001-2. Tax experts yesterday expressed surprise that the chancellor had not moved to close the one-year shortfall, which was spotted as a potential problem last year.

For working mothers, a self-proclaimed child-friendly chancellor is only promising jam tomorrow.

Higher earning lone parents, however, will be better off from improvements to personal allowances and the cut in the basic rate of tax to 22p from 23p that comes into force on April 6.

Pensioners reap the benefits of better personal allowances and income tax cuts without the loss of married couple's allowance that hits under 65s.

A lone pensioner on £12,000 a year will be better off by £50 a year, while a married pensioner couple on £15,000 will gain £166 a year.

Add to that already announced increases in the basic pension, the increase in the winter fuel allowance to £150 and higher tax breaks on Isa savings accounts, and pensioners will be able to raise a cheer to the chancellor.

But the biggest winners, even with the loss of the married couple's allowance, are couples who are both in work. The dual income, no kids 'Dinkies' see an annual gain of £414 on a joint income of £40,000, rising to £764 on incomes above £80,000. The benefit comes from the fall in basic rate tax, coupled with increases in personal allowances and the national insurance threshhold.

But their gains will trickle away in "stealth" taxes such as the abolition of mortgage interest relief and the hefty tax bill they face if they move to a £250,000-plus dream home.

Dinkies surfing the London property boom with a house purchase of £300,000 will be hit with a tax bill of £9,000, £1,500 more than last year, or more than enough to wipe out other tax gains. They will also lose Miras, which last year was worth £208.44 a year for the maximum £30,000 qualifying loan.

Tobacco users will see their tax gains go up in smoke.

A packet a day smoker will lose £91.25 over the next 12 months from the 25p per packet increase in tobacco duty announced yesterday.

Case studies

Couple, both employed

Bella and Max live in a fashionable part of west London. Since an accident, Bella has had to work from home. Their plans to sell their Notting Hill flat and move out to the country have taken a hit, with stamp duty on property above £250,000 rising to 3%.

As Bella uses a wheelchair, the couple rely heavily on private transport. While Max is pleased petrol duties have risen only in line with inflation, his estate car will miss out on the extension of the vehicle excise duty reduced rate for cars up to 1,200cc. The offer of 100% tax relief to any small business buying computers, or investing in e-commerce and new information technology might help to persuade Max to realise his dream of launching an online art auction.

The couple, who are diligent savers, will enjoy the increase in next year's Isa limit to £7,000 per person.

Lone pensioner

Michael O'Sullivan lives alone in a small village in Northern Ireland. The increase from £5,720 to £5,790 in the personal allowance for someone aged under 75 will make a small difference to his monthly income, together with the other income tax changes. It can get quite cold in the winter, so the £50 increase to £150 a year in the winter allowance for fuel is an added bonus. The 25p increase in the price of cigarettes has annoyed him, but at least there is no increase in the duty on whisky. Michael spends most of his day watching TV and is looking forward to not having to pay his licence when he turns 75.

Married, one employed, one child

Bill and Alice Harford and their young daughter, who live comfortably on his doctor's salary of £80,000, aren't too disappointed by yesterday's announcements. Their loss of the married couple's allowance and Miras has been offset by basic rate tax reductions. The family may postpone its decision to move house, since they would pay 4% stamp duty on the £500,000 home they had set their hearts on. The rises in petrol duties will cost them more to run their 5 series BMW, though there has been no change in vehicle excise duty.

Otherwise, the Budget has been mostly good news: child benefit is increasing to £15.50 from April 2001, Bill will enjoy a £100 tax cut when he electronically files his return to the inland revenue, and the family will pay less flight duty when they fly to their villa in Tuscany, if they fly economy rather than first class.

Married, two employed, two children

Wendy and Andy live in Middlesex with their twin daughters, Natalie and Nicola. Wendy teaches a dancercise class for tots and works in a children's clothing store. Andy, who is a chef, enjoys a drink after work with his colleagues, will not be too upset by the 1p per pint increase in the tax on beer - though the freezing of duty on spirits may encourage him to mix his drinks.

Wendy's Ford Fiesta which takes her to work each day will earn her a reduced rate of vehicle excise duty. The family are relieved, too, that the chancellor has not increased the tax on insurance policies - their household premiums are already set to rise following a recent claim.

Pensioner couple

Victor and Margaret Meldrew would not believe the chancellor's latest concession to drivers of green cars. Having already splashed out on an eco-friendly city car to earn the reduced rate of VED, Victor now finds that his old Vauxhall Nova would have qualified after all.

With the 10p starting rate of income tax being extended to savings from April 1999, the couple will be able to reclaim some tax and will be heartened by the £150 a year increase in pensioners' winter fuel payments and the VAT cut on energy-saving materials.

They will benefit from the uprating of the pensioners' tax allowance to £5,790 and, looking ahead,will enjoy a £3 per week increase in state pension. Finally, their children can look forward to a bigger inheritance following the increase in IHT threshold to £234,000.

Single, employed person

Andy is a coal miner who lives in south Yorkshire. Like most people, he will benefit from the marginal increase in the personal allowance, the reduction in the base rate of income tax to 22%, and changes in the national insurance banding. He is trying to give up smoking, so the 5% increase in the price of cigarettes may well be a blessing in disguise if he manages to give up. If he doesn't, as a 20-a-day smoker he will definitely feel the increase. Either way, the extra one pence on a pint of beer will make his nights out a touch more expensive. Andy is concerned about the future of his coal mine and, therefore, his job, but is encouraged by the government's plan to create action teams, matching the unemployed in the highest areas of unemployment with suitable vacancies in neighbouring areas.

Single parent, one child

Maddy brings up her baby Jack alone in London after they were abandoned by her partner Alex. The changes in the working family tax credit for children under the age of 11 will result in a slight increase in her weekly income.

The scrapping of the additional allowance for children will cost her £197 in the coming tax year.

The increase from £17.10 per week to £17.55 in child benefit for single parents will only slightly offset this.

Naturally, she will benefit from the slight increase in the personal allowance, as well as the decrease in the basic rate of income tax and the national insurance changes.

As a mother, Maddy hopes the government means what it says about increasing investment in education.

Single, self-employed person

Laurence lives alone in London and teaches bridge. As an enthusiastic beer drinker, the penny on a pint will cause a dent in his wallet over the year - whether this will be offset by the cut in income tax depends on how much he drinks.

Laurence also has a big, old, gas-guzzling car, so the 2p a litre increase in fuel duty might make him cut down on his mileage - although this is unlikely as he uses the car to get to and from work.

He saves £5.50 a week on Class 2 national insurance, but this will be weighed up against an increase of 1% in the Class 4 NI rate. Beyond this, the cut in income tax rate and the slight increase in the personal allowance will make him slightly better off.

 Reports by Ian Wylie and Jessica McCallin

webTitle: Prudent, punchy but watch out for potholes

fields.headline: Prudent, punchy but watch out for potholes
fields.trailText: Dr Gerard Lyons, global head of treasury research at Standard Chartered Bank, gives the city's reaction to the Budget
fields.body:
This was a mixed Budget for the City and for the economy. The numbers were prudent, the speech was punchy but the detail was full of pot-holes. Even though the economy is in good shape, it faces a bumpy ride.

The City wanted a tough Budget and got it. The worry is not the tax "giveaway", which was relatively prudent, but there is concern about the future trend on public spending, particularly if the economy slows. The Budget's tax changes will provide a net boost to the economy of £1.2bn in the first year, a net £2.6bn in the second year (2001/02) and £2.5bn in the third year (2002/03).

This contrasts with Gordon Brown's first two Budgets when he raised taxes significantly. Last year he gave away a small amount, although in the process many people were hit hard by targeted tax increases.

The fiscal sums make sense. However, it is clear that political pressure is beginning to bite, with the chancellor relaxing the constraints on public spending. The main beneficiary is the health service. Public spending is now set to rise by an inflation-adjusted 2.5% per year. This summer's comprehensive spending review is likely to endorse this trend for the next three years. Because public spending has been kept under tight control in recent years the new trend on expenditure is not alarming. With a strong economy boosting revenues, the government's public sector net borrowing will be in surplus by £11.9bn this year before falling.

Although these numbers are credible it is worth stressing that the margin of error on the Treasury's numbers is high, averaging £9bn per year over the past five years. Tax receipts are £11.4bn higher than expected a year ago. Just as in the past year, the numbers could turn out dramatically different from those forecast. The key will be the strength of the economy.

The Treasury is upbeat about economic prospects, and rightly so. Last year, Standard Chartered was one of the few forecasters to get the British economy right and this year it expects 3.4% growth. The chancellor predicts economic growth around 3%, with domestic demand growing almost 4%. Within this good picture, it is clear that even the government is expecting a poor performance by manufacturing and a large deterioration in the trade deficit. The reason is simple: the pound is too strong.

Clearly the City does not want Britain to join the euro, because that would lead to higher taxes and regulations, damaging investment and jobs. There is a clear argument for a weaker pound but unfortunately the chancellor said nothing about this. Instead he is focusing his Budget attention on the "new" e-commerce economy.

Fortunately, the Budget will not add to pressure for the Bank of England to raise rates. At 6% rates are high enough. But, with oil prices high and the economy strong, the likelihood is that rates could still increase again, to 6.5% by the summer.

The chancellor does not believe fiscal policy should be used for demand management. That is the remit of the Bank of England. While the south-east is booming, many regions are suffering. The chancellor has justifiably announced measures to boost the regions, where the impact of spending may have the most beneficial impact without triggering inflation pressures. Yet he raised stamp duty on high-value houses, hitting the south-east through a measure that does little to help labour mobility.

The specific measures announced show the chancellor at his best and worst. He continues to meddle. Under the Conservatives there was a desire to simplify the tax system. Now there is an active decision to intervene.

Fifty-nine tax changes were announced in the Budget. Some measures are good but it is doubtful that such continuous tinkering improves the efficiency of the economy.

One worry for the City is the future direction of public finances. The time to undertake radical measures to address relentless upward pressure on public spending and on taxes is when the finances are in good shape.

Instead, this is a classic pre-election Budget. Yet it might be difficult to curb spending after the election or if the economy slows.

The gilt market will like this Budget, because it confirms a favourable fiscal position and the measures announced are unlikely to add to inflationary pressures. The equity market, too, will take comfort from the tone of Mr Brown's message and business friendly initiatives such as those aimed at e-commerce. The incentives to encourage employees to take a share in their company are encouraging. The stock market still fears higher interest rates.

The Budget is neutral for the pound, yet it is clear that sterling is too strong and needs to fall to help rebalance the economy.

 Dr Gerard Lyons is global head of treasury research at Standard Chartered Bank

webTitle: Cigarettes to cost more than £4 as smuggling fears brushed aside

fields.headline: Cigarettes to cost more than £4 as smuggling fears brushed aside
fields.standfirst: Tobacco tax to go to health service  Beer up 1p a pint and wine up 4p a bottle
fields.trailText: The price of a packet of 20 cigarettes is rising above £4 for the first time after the chancellor's decision to ignore the arguments that increased duties will encourage smuggling and fuel the gradual increase in tobacco consumption.
fields.body:
The price of a packet of 20 cigarettes is rising above £4 for the first time after the chancellor's decision to ignore the arguments that increased duties will encourage smuggling and fuel the gradual increase in tobacco consumption.

Mr Brown said he would raise the price of cigarettes 5% above the rate of inflation - roughly equal to another 25p a pack - and he promised this would mean an additional £300m going directly to the health service.

Anti-smoking campaigners said the move would contribute towards saving 1,000 lives a year. Admitting that increasing cigarette prices is "regressive" and has a disproportionate impact on poorer families, the campaign group Ash urged Mr Brown to allocate at least £60m of the extra revenue to establish "world-class smoking cessation facilities". The tobacco industry said the increase was a "smugglers' charter". A spokesman for the Tobacco Manufacturers' Association said a quarter of all cigarettes were sold on the black market for between £2 and £2.50 a packet and that proportion would increase with every penny on the official price. The tobacco companies said the rise in duty was counter- productive and the Treasury's tax take would fall.

The wine and spirits association complained that the inflation-linked increase in duty on a bottle of wine took the tax to £1.16, compared with 2p a bottle in France.

"Already one in every seven bottles drunk here comes across the Channel and that is growing fast," a spokesman said. "At this rate, by the next Budget, nearly 25% of all wine consumed in the UK will be bought in France."

Both real ale group, Camra, and the beer industry criticised the chancellor for failing to tackle the growing problem of beer smuggling. Mike Benner, head of campaigns at Camra, said: "Criminals are making huge profits selling cheap French fizz to anyone who has cash at the ready." The chancellorsaid in his speech yesterdaythat the Treasury would be issuing a report on how it intended to combat illegal imports.

webTitle: Some lose in drive to ease child poverty

fields.headline: Some lose in drive to ease child poverty
fields.standfirst: Lone parents could lose up to £40 a week  Working families tax credit increased  Disabled to receive more
fields.trailText: The government's drive to eliminate child poverty took a step forward with a raft of budget measures to help low-income families both in and out of work.
fields.body:
The government's drive to eliminate child poverty took a step forward with a raft of budget measures to help low-income families both in and out of work.

But the chancellor has done nothing to help some families, particularly lone parents, who will lose out on up to £40 a week for the coming "gap" year between the abolition of the married couples allowance this April and the introduction of its replacement, the children's tax credit in April next year.

From June the credit for children under 16 in the working families tax credit (WFTC) and the disabled person's tax credit (DPTC) will go up by an extra £4.35 a week to £25.60. This is on top of the £1.10 increase over and above indexation in the credit for children aged under 11 and the uprating for indexation already coming in this April.

These increases will provide more help to about 1.4m low-income working families and will guarantee a family with one child and someone working full-time a minimum income of £207 a week from June and £214 a week from April next year.

A further 3m children under 16 whose parents are on income support (IS) and other income related benefits will also receive an additional £4.35 per week from October.

The value of the new children's tax credit, announced in last year's Budget and due to replace the married couple's allowance from April 2001, has been increased. It will now reduce the annual tax liability of families with children by up to £442 instead of £416 as originally expected.

More help is to be directed at families when a baby is born with a package of tax credit reforms to give mothers more choice about their return to work. From May next year all families will be able to have an existing WFTC or DPTC claim award reassessed as soon as the baby is born, instead of waiting up to six months for it to run out. This will make them eligible straight away for the extra child credit for the new baby worth £25.60 a week and possibly for extra support if their family income has fallen.

Families where the mother is the sole earner would be unable to benefit from this change because she would not be eligible for a tax credit once she went on maternity leave. To get round this problem, which particularly affects lone mothers, any mother who works 16 hours or more prior to the birth and is in receipt of statutory maternity pay or maternity allowance will count as being in work and therefore able to claim the child credit top up under WFTC for her new baby.

These changes mean that low-income working families with a new baby could be up to £30 a week better off in the first few weeks of the child's life. Under this system a family with two children on £15,000 a year will receive £2,200 a year.

These measures are expected to go some way to helping many mothers who want to be at home in the first months of their child's life, but are forced to return to work early because they cannot affors to stay at home.

The chancellor also announced a new wide-ranging government review of maternity pay and parental leave, which will seek to find more ways of helping new parents.

More than 200,000 parents will also receive more help from the new sure start maternity grant, payable to all low-income families provided they meet basic health check up requirements for their child. This will rise from £200 to £300 this autumn. This one-off payment, designed to give new parents extra money to buy essential items for their new baby, replaces the existing £100 maternity payment from this April.

More than 12m children will gain from increases in child benefit, paid at the same rate to all families with children regardless of income or hours worked, which goes up to £15.50 for the first child and to £10.35 for subsequent children from April 2001.

Martin Barnes, director of the Child Poverty Action Group, said: "This is a welcome Budget for many of the 4.4m children living in poverty in the UK."

However, he voiced concern that the chancellor has failed to give a guarantee that child benefit will remain untaxed."

webTitle: Cautious welcome from the financial community

fields.headline: Cautious welcome from the financial community
fields.trailText: Financial markets last night delivered a cautious welcome to the chancellor's Budget package, with analysts predicting it would not add to the pressures for higher interest rates.
fields.body:
Financial markets last night delivered a cautious welcome to the chancellor's Budget package, with analysts predicting it would not add to the pressures for higher interest rates.

Though most believed that monetary policy will still have to be tightened, with the repo rate likely to rise from 6% to 6.5%, they argued that Gordon Brown had resisted the temptation to give away too much.

"If the chancellor has locked in the fiscal tightening he talked about, then interest rates are not likely to go up as far as they have done in the past," said David Brickman at PaineWebber.

Nick Parsons at Commerzbank in London said that while the chancellor had signalled higher spending it was carefully focused.

He said: "People will feel good but they won't be much better off. The last thing the chancellor would want at this stage is a spending binge which would have to have to be countered by the Bank of England."

Mr Parsons said he still expected to Bank's monetary policy committee to raise rates at some stage but not next month. "I think a rate hike next month would signal unnecessary disapproval," he said. "It is hard to find fault with it (the Budget)."

On the foreign exchanges the pound initially strengthened against the dollar before easing back from a high of $1.5773 to $1.5722, and sterling finished below its best level for the day against the euro, which closed at 61.69p after 62.09p.

The pound lost ground as traders absorbed the implica tions of the chancellor's proposals and the growing belief that his spending proposals and tax cuts had not altered expectations about interest rates.

The chancellor's message caused few ripples in the equities market, with the FTSE 100 share index standing at 6,606.09, down 17.6 points, when he began his Budget speech and ending the day at 6,620.3 for a fall on the day of just 4.2 points.

"Overall, it looks favourable in terms of the fiscal surplus he has projected. It seems he's keeping a fairly tight hand on fiscal policy," said Juli Collins-Thompson at BNP. "Right now I would stick to our view that rates will probably peak at 6.5%, but this is an initial reaction."

Fraser Coutts at 4cast agreed that rates were likely to peak at 6.5%. "On the surface of things it's steady as she goes and there's nothing too much for the markets to concern themselves about," he said.

webTitle: New savings limits to benefit millions

fields.headline: New savings limits to benefit millions
fields.trailText: Savers are in line for £2,000 extra in tax relief on their investments after a surprise extension to the rules on individual savings accounts yesterday.
fields.body:
Savers are in line for £2,000 extra in tax relief on their investments after a surprise extension to the rules on individual savings accounts yesterday.

When ISAs were introduced last April the government imposed a £7,000 tax-free limit for the first year only, after which it would fall to £5,000. But yesterday the £7,000 limit was extended for a further year, giving a 40% tax rate payer a potential extra tax saving worth around £50-£100 a year, depending on how investments perform.

Millions of people will bene fit from the new limits. So far this year 6.7m ISA accounts have been opened, taking in £17bn in savings. A spokesman for leading investment company Jupiter said: "It shows the government is really embracing the savings culture."

The chancellor also announced he would be putting into place many of the recommendations outlined in the Cruickshank banking review published on Monday.

He said the government would be bringing in legislation to open up access to payment systems such as cash machine networks and to monitor charges. Banks would be expected to make their charging more transparent and base their charges on the economic cost of providing services.

fields.headline: Mother given a helping hand
fields.trailText: Helen Vowles has her hands full at home and her head stacked with plans for the future, both of which Gordon Brown's package is going to help.
fields.body:
Helen Vowles has her hands full at home and her head stacked with plans for the future, both of which Gordon Brown's package is going to help.

For the single working mother on low income, with a second child due in August, the rise in working family tax credit and the new SureStart maternity grant mean £4.35 more per week plus a one-off £300 when the baby arrives.

"You get it taken away on something else in Budgets, though, don't you," said Ms Vowles, who is 27 and earns £615.25 monthly for the 17 hours a week she puts in running an advice centre's helpline. "The petrol's the one which will get me."

Public transport in east Leeds is not convenient for her daily commute to the advice centre, because she needs to drop off her four-year-old daughter Jade at a nursery en route.

Instead she will drive and face extra bills for the 20 litres of petrol she buys each week for her F-reg Ford Escort.

"It won't be a lot but it's still money going out. But I'm glad that he's putting a lot of it into the health service and education." Jade starts school in the autumn and Ms Vowles's planned escape route to a proper career is taking her gradually through national vocational qualifications aimed at work in outdoor pursuits centres.

Her main Budget worry had been housing or mortgage changes which might threaten to increase the £303 monthly she pays for her two-bedroom house on the edge of Leeds. Other spare cash from her wage, plus maintenance payments which have just gone down by £80 because of her ex-partner's circumstances, vanish on food and clothes and toys for Jade.

She welcomes measures designed to encourage single mothers and the unemployed back into the job market, after a stultifying period on the dole herself. "I'm glad about the increase in tax credit but I've sometimes wondered about too many rises in benefits tempting people on to the social. I can only say 'don't' because it's so great getting into a working environment when you've been hanging around feeling that nobody wants you and you don't know what to do with your life."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Insurance companies and members of the Lloyd's market stand to lose a tax break on provisions for unpaid claims.
fields.body:
Insurance companies and members of the Lloyd's market stand to lose a tax break on provisions for unpaid claims.

The insurance industry described the move retrograde in a Budget which had some good news, including no change on insurance premium tax, currently 5%.

The government will consult on its proposals, which would effectively tax insurance firms' investment income on money they set aside for claims.

Mary Francis, director general of the Association of British Insurers, said there were already prudent rules for accounting and supervisory purposes and any reduction in provisions would weaken the security of policyholders.

The government is proposing that general insurance companies and Lloyd's members should face a clawback of the tax benefit they get by not discounting their provisions for unpaid claims.

The new rules would also apply where firms significantly overestimate provisions for claims.

The measures would apply for accounting periods starting onJanuary 1, 2001 and for members of Lloyd's in the 2001/02 tax year.

 The inheritance tax threshold is to rise in the next year to £234,000 from the current £231,000.

 Cider will rise by 1p a litre and higher strength alcopops will rise by 1p per 33cl bottle.

fields.headline: Long-term unemployed benefit
fields.standfirst: Four options for over 25s without work  Disabled and single parents highlighted
fields.trailText: The government plans to tackle the problem of the older long-term unemployed by offering them a version of the New Deal package that has   found work for 185,000 young people over the past two years.
fields.body:
The government plans to tackle the problem of the older long-term unemployed by offering them a version of the New Deal package that has found work for 185,000 young people over the past two years.

From April next year, those aged over 25 and out of work for more than 18 months will have four New Deal options - work, work-based training, work experience in the voluntary sector or self employment.

The chancellor said that staying at home on benefit doing nothing was not an option.

Unemployed people refusing to take up one of the four options risk losing benefits, including the £40 a week job seeker's allowance. Like the under 25s, the older, long-term unemployed will be entitled to help from a personal jobs adviser at their local jobs centre for up to four months.

The Department for Education and Employment esti mates that about 150,000 people will benefit from the 25-plus scheme in its first year.

Companies offering jobs under the New Deal programme to people aged 25 or over will be entitled to a government subsidy of £75 a week per person for six months. The subsidy for under 25s is now £60 a week.

The present New Deal for the young long-term unemployed also offers four options - a job, full-time education or training, voluntary work or work with the government's environmental task force.

The New Deal programme, first rolled out in April 1998, was funded by the £5.2bn windfall levy on the privatised utility companies. Mr Brown yesterday announced a number of other measures aimed at helping people, including lone parents, move from welfare to work. These included the formation of action teams in 35 of the highest unemployment black spots from autumn this year, and a £100 job grant for people moving back into work after more than a year on the dole queue. The New Deal package for young people is also to be improved.

The government intends to develop pilot schemes to help people with disabilities remain in work.

The extension of the New Deal scheme was widely welcomed. The National Council for One Parent Families said the chancellor had responded to its calls to ease lone parents return to work. "The new staged approach, including a training option with a cash payment and the ability to keep more of their earnings for those working only a few hours and receiving income support, should benefit many lone parents whether they are ready to work immediately or need more preparation," a spokesman said.

But Graham Finegold, chief executive of Workforce, a charity which helps people find the right job, said that if Mr Brown wanted to achieve his target of full employment he would have to address the requirements of people with special needs, who found it particularly difficult to get a job.

Employment secretary David Blunkett said employment and windfall levy allocations of £455.5m would be phased in over the next two years to fund the extension of support to get people back to work.

"A strong, stable economy and our welfare to work programmes helped cut unemployment to a 20-year low and halved youth unemployment," he said. "We have begun to transform the welfare state from a dole delivery system into an engine of the economy.

"The Budget measures are the next step in that transformation - building on the success of the New Deal; intensifying job search for everyone on job-seekers allowance; modernising the welfare state to be delivered through a merged employment service and benefits agency and extending help to those who are economically inactive."

webTitle: Crackdown on trusts and tax dodgers

fields.headline: Crackdown on trusts and tax dodgers
fields.trailText: Sweeping new measures against tax dodging are likely to sound the death-knell for offshore trusts and arm the Inland Revenue with powers to collect information on all savings accounts and investment income. Action against the trusts alone is estimated to net the chancellor £500 million.
fields.body:
Sweeping new measures against tax dodging are likely to sound the death-knell for offshore trusts and arm the Inland Revenue with powers to collect information on all savings accounts and investment income. Action against the trusts alone is estimated to net the chancellor £500 million.

Mr Brown sweetened the pill of his anti-dodging crackdown by defying Brussels to abolish the 20% withholding tax paid by British residents on eurobond interest.

This will please the City, as it comes at a time when Britain is fighting European Union attempts to end the existing tax-free status of eurobond interest paid in London to non-residents.

But the decision came alongside moves that will effectively end the use of trusts, both on and offshore, for tax purposes. In parallel to this, Mr Brown announced a legislative package that will give the revenue the ability "to collect routine information about the savings income of all individuals."

The information will be shared with the tax authorities only of countries that establish reciprocal arrangements with Britain, but the law will be changed to make it easier to set up i such arrangements.
