fields.headline: Schools' booster to bypass councils
fields.standfirst:
Education Top-up grants to be paid direct Heads to choose how to spend cash Welcome from teachers
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: An extra £1bn for education over the next financial year will include top-up grants paid direct to schools, adding £40,000 to the budget of a typical secondary, £9,000 for a primary and £15,000 for a special school.
fields.body:
An extra £1bn for education over the next financial year will include top-up grants paid direct to schools, adding £40,000 to the budget of a typical secondary, £9,000 for a primary and £15,000 for a special school.

The cash injection came in addition to increases already promised during the comprehensive spending review, producing a real-terms rise of 8.5% in education spending.

David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, said money going into state schools in England would increase 10.4% in real terms over the next 12 months.

Almost £300m will be channelled directly to schools, eliminating the opportunity for local councils to divert part of the cash into other services.

Heads and governors will be told they can choose whether to spend the extra grant on teachers, books, equipment or any other item that can be expected to raise educational standards. Although cheques will be paid through local education authorities, the schools will have total control over how the money is spent.

Mr Blunkett said primaries with fewer than 100 pupils would get an extra £3,000 for the financial year starting next month. Those with 101-200 pupils receive £6,000 and those with more than 200 pupils get £9,000.

Secondaries with up to 600 pupils would get £30,000, those with 601-1,200 pupils £40,000 and those with more than 1,200 receive £50,000. Special schools each get £15,000.

There will be an extra £20m for primary schools to provide catch-up tuition in literacy and numeracy for low achievers. This comes on top of £42m already allocated for booster classes.

A further £53m will be targeted at extending education maintenance allowances, a pilot scheme for paying grants of up to £40 a week for young people to stay in education after 16. The chancellor said three times as many would now benefit.

The £1bn education package included £837m for England. Other details will be announced by ministers tomorrow and information for the rest of the country will follow separately.

Mr Blunkett said yesterday's Budget would add £45 to spending for each pupil over the coming year. Taking into account previously announced increases, the extra benefit would total £180 per pupil.

"This is real extra money for schools. Over the three years to 2001-02, it means an average real-terms increase per pupil of £300. That compares with a cut of £50 under the last three Tory Budgets," he said.

Teachers' leaders welcomed the spending boost, but some were sceptical about whether it was genuinely new money. John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, said: "We are delighted with the funding and the method of distribution. This is exactly what we have been asking for."

But Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the National Union of Teachers, said: "I hope this is not another mirage. Schools need real additional funding. An accountancy wheeze which makes the government look good in the headlines but leaves the pupils and teachers short of the resources needed will further stoke up cynicism."

The Association of University Teachers said there was no word yet about whether the £1bn for education would include extra resources for the hard-pressed universities.

"If there are more students coming to higher education they will need to be supported financially and not treated as second-rate students.

"Cuts to spending on each student must stop and pay must be improved. We either want world-class universities or face a future in the lower divisions."

webTitle: Fourth rise in housing purchase tax during this parliament

fields.headline: Fourth rise in housing purchase tax during this parliament
fields.trailText: The chancellor attempted to take the heat out of the booming housing market by announcing the fourth increase in stamp duty since Labour came to power.
fields.body:
The chancellor attempted to take the heat out of the booming housing market by announcing the fourth increase in stamp duty since Labour came to power.

The widely anticipated increase will only affect only those properties sold for more than £250,000, prompting the National Association of Estate Agents to dub it "a tax on home-movers in the south". The increase of half a percentage point is aimed at putting the brakes on the property boom in London and the south-east, where prices in some areas have soared by more than 30% in a year.

From next Tuesday the rate of duty on properties costing from £250,001 to £500,000 will rise to 3%, while for properties sold for £500,001 or more the duty goes up from 3.5% to 4%. For properties costing between £60,000 and £250,000, the duty remains unchanged at 1%. Below £60,000 sales are free of stamp duty.

The increase means that someone buying a home costing £300,000 - less than the price of an average detached house in London - will see their stamp duty bill rise from £7,500 to £9,000. For a property costing £500,001, the duty paid increases from £17,500 to £20,000.

With the increase less than many had expected, mortgage lenders, estate agents and other commentators declared that it would do little to damp down soaring prices. Some warned that it could in fact lead to even higher prices at the top end of the market by discouraging owners of more expensive properties from putting these up for sale, thereby reducing supply.

Hugh Dunsmore-Hardy at the National Association of Estate Agents said he was disappointed the chancellor had again chosen to hit the southern half of the country, adding that the increase did not sit comfortably with the government's aim of making house-buying and selling easier.

Meanwhile Simon Knight, at Independent Mortgage Collection, the home-loan brokers, said that the past two or three years illustrated there was clearly no link between stamp duty and people's desire to get into a property.

"Since 1997 we have seen stamp duty go from 1% to 4% on £500,000-plus properties," he said. "At the same time we have seen property prices surge more than ever."

The new rates coincide with the abolition of mortgage interest tax relief (Miras), which takes effect next month and will add more than £230 a year to mortgage payments for millions of people with home loans of £30,000 or more.

They also come in the wake of four mortgage rate increases since the autumn which together have added £32 to the monthly bill of someone with a £60,000 housing loan.

Mr Brown said 95% of house purchases would be unaffected by the stamp duty increase, which is nevertheless expected to raise £325m in 2000-01, £370m in 2001-02, and £440m in 2002-03.

However, the Council of Mortgage Lenders claimed that the increase would lead to increased distortions in property prices. For example, one home-mover buying a £249,000 house would pay duty of £2,490 while another whose property costs £251,000 will now pay £7,530.

The CML described stamp duty as "a tax on mobility" which is at odds with the needs of a modern economy based on flexibility and a highly mobile workforce.

In some parts of London, £250,000 is not even enough to buy a flat. In Kensington and Chelsea, the average price of a flat is £302,000, according to recent Land Registry data.

Michael Quinlan, tax partner at PricewaterhouseCoopers, spoke for many when he said the increase was "less of a tweak than we feared" - many commentators expected to see the rate for homes costing more than £500,000 upped to 5%. He added that homebuyers who can complete before next Tuesday would escape the new higher rate.

Anthony Davis at Ernst & Young said that the increase amounted to "making very rich people pay very slightly more for their properties".

webTitle: An extra £1,400 on the cost of 'somewhere decent to live'

fields.headline: An extra £1,400 on the cost of 'somewhere decent to live'
fields.trailText: Chris Hart is furious about yesterday's hike in stamp duty. She now has to find £8,250 to pay the stamp duty on the £275,000 house she is buying in Iver, Middlesex, compared with £6,875 before the chancellor raised rates.
fields.body:
Chris Hart is furious about yesterday's hike in stamp duty. She now has to find £8,250 to pay the stamp duty on the £275,000 house she is buying in Iver, Middlesex, compared with £6,875 before the chancellor raised rates.

"I budgeted for £6,875 and now I've got to find another £1,375 somewhere. I think it's outrageous. We are not rich, we are just a family trying to achieve a goal in life.

"We are having to take on a huge mortgage anyway just so that we can get a decent house. Now we will have to go without something else," she said.

She sold her three-bedroom home for £159,000, but moving up to a £275,000 four-bedroom house takes her into the £250,000-plus category in which the higher rate begins to bite. Yesterday the chancellor raised duty on these houses from 2.5% to 3%, and for those above £500,000 took the rate from 3.5% to 4%. Mrs Hart works at Hayes Manor School and has only been able to afford the move up to a detached home because of an inheritance she received just before Christmas.

She said that she can't pull out of the deal now - partly because of the impact this would have on all the others in the chain, who include first-time buyers.

"We started in a flat, moved to a terraced house, then a semi. Now we want a bigger home. I don't think it's too much to ask."

Mrs Hart said the stamp duty she was going to have to pay was "a lot of money. I would like to know what they are going to do with it. Generally it is an added burden for anybody when they are looking to buy".

The fact that the transaction is already in progress will not prevent her being hit by the increase. The only way for her to escape the new rate would be to complete before next Tuesday.

webTitle: Carrot and stick to tackle the cheats

fields.headline: Carrot and stick to tackle the cheats
fields.trailText: A 14-month "amnesty" for those working in the shadow economy was announced by the chancellor with the threat of severe penalties for those still cheating on tax and benefits after the summer of 2001.
fields.body:
A 14-month "amnesty" for those working in the shadow economy was announced by the chancellor with the threat of severe penalties for those still cheating on tax and benefits after the summer of 2001.

Mr Brown is responding to a report earlier this month by Lord Grabiner QC that suggested about 120,000 people were moonlighting while claiming welfare.

Fraudulent benefit claims were draining £500 million annually from the Treasury, said Lord Grabiner, without taking account of the lost tax revenues.

But the chancellor is keen to give those who may be trapped in the shadow economy a breathing space to get their affairs in order and join the mainstream workforce.

He said yesterday: "A confidential phone line will advise claimants on how to move from the hidden economy and end fraudulent claims, how to get work, register as a business or become self-employed - for those who fail to respond, tougher rules and penalties will be imposed."

New powers for investigators and the courts are to be introduced - including a new offence of fraudulently evading income tax which will be tried by magistrates.

webTitle: Prudence and the health service pep pill

fields.headline: Prudence and the health service pep pill
fields.trailText: The chancellor laid down his familiar rhythm section - prudence, discipline, no return to boom and bust - in characteristic breakneck style, then added some of his favourite riffs in the form of tax breaks for enterprise and  measures against child poverty. It was all very worthy, but just a little dull, a workmanlike budget but no Sgt Pepper, no Blonde on Blonde.
fields.body:
Smart record companies have cleaned up in recent years by re-packaging classic albums for the CD market, and for the best part of his time at the despatch box yesterday that was what Gordon Brown's fourth package appeared to be. The chancellor laid down his familiar rhythm section - prudence, discipline, no return to boom and bust - in characteristic breakneck style, then added some of his favourite riffs in the form of tax breaks for enterprise and measures against child poverty. It was all very worthy, but just a little dull, a workmanlike budget but no Sgt Pepper, no Blonde on Blonde.

But what the audience didn't know was that the chancellor had a couple of bonus tracks up his sleeve, two real crowd pleasers certain to get Labour's fans - disgruntled of late - out of their seats. First there was the £1bn extra for education, designed to pave the way for the Budget's crescendo - the cash injection for the NHS.

Without the higher spending, the blizzard of measures announced by the chancellor would have seemed curiously unbalanced, even disappointing given the resources at the Treasury's disposal. As it was, the huge sums promised to spare the government another winter of turmoil over health gave Brown's fourth budget a thread - a story to tell the electorate.

The story goes like this. First, the gov ernment gets the fundamentals of the economy right. It keeps inflation low, encourages workers to show responsibility in wage bargaining, shows zealotry in repairing the state of the public finances.

The early stages of Brown Budgets are all about reassuring the City and the public that Labour can be trusted to run the economy, and yesterday's was no different from the previous three. Even with the extra cash for health and education, fiscal policy remains tight and there should be no need for the Bank of England to respond by putting up interest rates.

But, for the chancellor, macro-economic stability is not enough. He believes fervently that weak productivity is the main reason Britain has lower living standards than Germany, France and the United States. So stage two of Brown's narrative is to enact a series of supply-side reforms to labour, capital and product markets designed to improve economic efficiency. Cuts in capital gains tax, incentives for e-commerce, support for Don Cruickshank's assault on the stranglehold exerted by the high-street banks, and the expansion of the new deal to all adult workers fit this category.

A s Brown repeatedly says, all this prudence is for a purpose. Provided people are prepared to abide by the terms of his updated protestant work ethic, there will be rewards both for individuals - "hard working families" - and for the nation as a whole. The story concludes with increases in public spending and, because no chancellor since Stafford Cripps has taken more relish in donning a hair shirt, a modest reduction in taxation.

If the strategy works, the story should have a happy ending. The increases in health spending look stupendous, with a real increase of 35% over five years taking health spending as a proportion on GDP to 7.6% - not quite up to the European average pledged by the prime minister on the Frost programme earlier this year, but getting quite close. With health pocketing an extra £2bn next year and education an additonal £1bn , there should be enough money to keep voters sweet in the run-up to the next general election.

Treasury sources were insistent that the chancellor had been forced into the health package by the prime minister, saying that the outline strategy had been agreed with Alan Milburn last year when he was still chief secretary to the treasury. That may be so, but the danger, from the chancellor's point of view, is that the money may disappear into a black hole unless it is used to lubricate reform of the NHS.

The perception of other spending ministers will be that they can extract money from the Treasury provided they have a big enough crisis on their hands. In what remains of the negotiations for the comprehensive spending review in the summer, David Blunkett is now going to be able to drive an extremely hard bargain.

Absent from the Budget was any mention of the damage being caused by the strong pound. Indeed, the economic forecasts contained in the Treasury's red book paint a picture of steady growth of 3% this year and 2.5% in each of the two years after that. These look plausible, although the strains on the tradeable sector of the economy are underlined by current account deficits of around £20bn in 2000, 2001 and 2002.

Public finances look strong enough to cope with an economy that performs slightly less well than the chancellor is expecting, but even if it suffered a pronounced slowdown, the government would find the money for education and health somehow. Mr Blair has no desire to be a one-hit wonder.

webTitle: Air tax slashed to boost travel and tourism

fields.headline: Air tax slashed to boost travel and tourism
fields.trailText: Air passenger duty has been halved from £10 to £5, bringing relief to millions of passengers and a boost to the tourist industry.
fields.body:
Air passenger duty has been halved from £10 to £5, bringing relief to millions of passengers and a boost to the tourist industry.

The saving will cost the Treasury around £80m, but the tax - a relic of the last government - was beginning to look ridiculous. In some cases, it has amounted to a quarter of a low-cost air fare.

The change will affect in-bound, outbound and domestic leisure travellers, although the government is doubling the duty on business travellers to and from destinations outside Europe to £40.

Richard Tobias, the chairman of F-Passenger Duty for all, said: "This will help attract more holidaymakers to Britain as well as making an overseas holiday more affordable for families." Tim Jeans, the marketing director of low-cost carrier Ryanair, said the move would mean cheaper airline tickets for those passengers flying this summer on low-cost airlines.

He said that for too long passengers had been charged this "pernicious duty" - regardless of how much they had paid for their ticket. "This campaign is a victory for the passenger."

fields.headline: £285m boost for fight against crime
fields.standfirst: Police to step up recruitment
fields.trailText: Nearly £100m of the extra £285m announced by the chancellor yesterday for the Home Office drive against crime is to be used to help the   police to "attract and retain good officers".
fields.body:
Nearly £100m of the extra £285m announced by the chancellor yesterday for the Home Office drive against crime is to be used to help the police to "attract and retain good officers".

The remainder of the money will go on as yet unspecified "capital modernisation projects".

The home secretary, Jack Straw, is not expected to announce further details until Friday at the earliest but of the extra money for the police £91m is for England and Wales and £9m for Scotland. Some of the money will be used to accelerate taking on the 5,000 extra police recruits over the next three years promised by Mr Straw at the last Labour conference.

Some of the new money is expected to be used by forces to take recruitment over and above the allocation from the central "crime fighting fund".

But the bulk of the new money for the police announced yesterday is expected to be used to boost retention and to contribute towards the cost of modernisation schemes such as a new digital police radio system and further expansion in the use of DNA technology.

The extra funds are unlikely to quell the political argument over police numbers, however. As written answers to the Liberal Democrats' home affairs spokesman, Simon Hughes, disclosed last week, the Home Office still predicts that by March 2003 total police numbers will have fallen by 1,200 since the May 1997 election.

fields.headline: Elderly win an income guarantee
fields.trailText: Thanks to the already announced 1p cut in the basic rate of tax to 22p from this April and the inflation-linked increases in personal tax allowances, most people will be better off, despite the abolition of the married couples' allowance which took away £197 a year from married taxpayers.
fields.body:
Thanks to the already announced 1p cut in the basic rate of tax to 22p from this April and the inflation-linked increases in personal tax allowances, most people will be better off, despite the abolition of the married couples' allowance which took away £197 a year from married taxpayers.

The well-heeled will benefit most, with a professional couple without children earning £40,000 each gaining as much as £764. A single person earning £40,000 will gain £382 a year, but a couple with two children and the same joint income would only be £269 better off. A single person earning £20,000 will be £207 a year better off but, perversely, a single parent earning £30,000 is worse off - losing £48.60 because of the loss of the single parents' allowance and the one year delay in the introduction of the child's tax credit.

Pensioners are also winners. A pensioner couple on a joint income of £30,000 are £166 a year better off, while a single pensioner with income of £20,000 will be £155 better off.

And there was also some more cheering news for low income pensioners with a promise of a pensioners' credit with the aim of lifting the poorest out of poverty and protecting those with modest savings.

Pensioners will have to wait until the next parliament to see just how they benefit as the DSS has first to launch a consultation exercise. But the chancellor said that the new credit should mean that a pensioner with income of less than £100 a week, or a couple with less than £150,would qualify for the new pension credit to boost their income

In a further boost to low income pensioners, the capital limits which affect their entitlement to the minimum income guarantee, which has replaced income support for the elderly, will be doubled, though they will have to wait another year until that takes effect. From April 2001 the lower limit will be doubled so that they will be able to hold on to savings or pensions income of £6,000 before there is any reduction.

Half a million more of the elderly who were previously disqualified from claiming the extra money will be able to do so from next year, making them at least £250 a year better off. And the upper limit, above which there is no entitlement, will be increased from £8,000 to £12,000, so more pensioners will be able to hang on to more of their savings.

From next year the amount pensioners receive as the minimum guaranteed income will also be increased. For single pensioners it will be worth a maximum of £80, or £90 if they are over

Added to this pensioners will be pleased by the improved winter fuel payments will go up by £50 to £150 next winter and the affordable warmth programme to install energy efficient heating.

There is no commitment to link increases in the state pension to earnings, despite intense lobbying after this year's rise, linked to inflation, amounted to 75p.

webTitle: Motorist is back in the driving seat

fields.headline: Motorist is back in the driving seat
fields.standfirst: Bulk of money will go on new roads  Fiscal steer is towards leaner, greener cars
fields.trailText: A £280m package of road spending and public transport measures, with the emphasis on road building, is to be announced by the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, later this week.
fields.body:
A £280m package of road spending and public transport measures, with the emphasis on road building, is to be announced by the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, later this week.

The additional spending will be on "congestion hotspots", but the bulk of the money will go on road building. This rep resents a change of emphasis by Mr Prescott and a belated response to the road lobby which has been pressing for further assistance.

The pro-car stance was bolstered by moves to give the motorist greater incentives to switch to greener, leaner cars using ultra-low-sulphur fuels.

Bowing to pressure from manufacturers to encourage people to buy cars, Gordon Brown raised duties on petrol and diesel by just under 2p a litre and froze vehicle excise duty at £155 until next March.

Officials admitted the rise in the price of crude oil from $23 to $30 a barrel had already boosted petrol costs by 7p a litre since the last Budget - twice as much as the hated and now abolished fuel duty escalator would have given.

The chancellor underlined his green credentials by giving a 1p discount for ultra-low-sulphur petrol and extending the £55 discount for smaller cars to a further 2.2m owners.

He also unveiled a graduated system for taxing new cars from next March, rewarding those running on cleaner, more fuel-efficient engines.

But, notably avoiding the issue in his Commons speech, Mr Brown announced a radical reform of company car taxation that effectively penalises the high-mileage driver and rewards low-mileage users of fuel-efficient cars.

Duty will rise to £160 next March but the present £55 discount will be extended to 2.2m drivers of cars with a 1,200cc engine rather than the present ceiling of 1.1 litres, which applies to 1.8m owners.

These new beneficiaries are said to include owners of 700,000 models of the Ford Fiesta, 200,000 Vauxhall Corsas, 200,000 Vauxhall Novas and 200,000 Renault Clios.

From next March all new, Y-registered cars will go into four bands, with duty calculated according to their carbon dioxide emissions and offering a discount of up to £70.

That includes a £10 bonus for cars using cleaner fuels and technology such as hybrid models, but a £10 "fine" for diesel-powered cars, which emit more particulates.

Cars in the lowest band, A - such as the Ford Focus - will pay as little as £90 in duty while those in the highest, band D - such as the Peugeot 406 - could pay up to £160.

Lord Macdonald, the transport minister, said the driver vehicle licensing agency would soon launch a campaign to persuade motorists that "driving a more fuel-efficient ve hicle will cut their vehicle excise duty and fuel bills as well as helping the environment".

He added that motorists would save almost £250m through the tax changes during the coming year.

Consultants also warned that business motorists driving high mileages faced a real "hit" under the proposed reform of company car taxation.

Mr Brown plans to switch from April 2002 to a system based on a car's emission rather than that at present, based on mileage discounts. The latter had unintentionally given incentives to drive more business miles, up to 300m a year, to gain bigger discounts.

Under the new system the charge will build up from 15% of the car's price for low-emission models to a maximum of 35%. Age related discounts will also be abolished while diesel cars will cost 3% extra.

Alison Haynes, a partner at Deloitte & Touche, said the tax charge for high-mileage business drivers could rise from 15% to 35%.

The government has decided to allow six-axle lorries to use British roads at a new 44-tonne limit. A target date of next January has been set for their introduction.

The government's view is that 44-tonne lorries are no larger than existing lorries but are simply allowed to carry heavier loads. It claims that they do less damage to roads than existing 40-tonners because they have a better weight distribution.

Lord Macdonald said that 44-tonne lorries will mean fewer journeys, or the equivalent of removing 230 return journeys from London to Edinburgh every day.

webTitle: On aggregate, it is bad news

fields.headline: On aggregate, it is bad news
fields.standfirst: Green pledge 'strangled'
fields.trailText: The surprise inclusion of an aggregates tax extended the range of green measures introduced by the chancellor, but his latest package disappointed environmentalists as much as it pleased them.
fields.body:
The surprise inclusion of an aggregates tax extended the range of green measures introduced by the chancellor, but his latest package disappointed environmentalists as much as it pleased them.

The Budget included confirmation of the controversial climate levy, lower VAT on the installation of home insulation and consultations on using "brown field" reclaimed land.

Mr Brown said the climate levy on industrial energy, with yesterday's transport measures, would save 6m tonnes of carbon dioxide emissions by 2010 in pursuit of the government's global warming target. The take in green taxes is offset by lower national insurance, saving employers £1.35bn.

Charles Secrett, director of Friends of the Earth, blamed the prime minister for blocking measures such as a pesticides tax, which have been accepted in principle by the Treasury.

"The green promise of the last Budget has been strangled at birth because Number 10 is terrified of business complaints about environmental measures," he said.

The CBI nevertheless complained that the Treasury had not gone far enough with concessions on the climate levy, and the quarrying industry reacted furiously to the aggregates tax. The industry fought to persuade the chancellor to accept a voluntary scheme.

"This is bad news for the environment, all forms of construction and will threaten jobs, particularly in rural areas," said Simon van der Byl, director general of the Quarry Products Association.

Mr van der Byl dismissed government claims that the tax would encourage recycling of building rubble and said the industry scheme would have delivered a range of other environmental improvements.

webTitle: Pensioners say they will feel the bad news first

fields.headline: Pensioners say they will feel the bad news first
fields.trailText: Derrick and Kathleen Spink watched the chancellor with a scepticism rooted in seven decades' experience of budgets and pointed out at once that the bad news is going to take effect a lot more quickly than the good.
fields.body:
Derrick and Kathleen Spink watched the chancellor with a scepticism rooted in seven decades' experience of budgets and pointed out at once that the bad news is going to take effect a lot more quickly than the good.

"The money on petrol, drinks and the rest will be charged from tomorrow," said Kathleen, who helped keep the books for the couple's fish and chip shop in Bradford until they retired seven years ago. "But this £82 guarantee a week for pensioners - which sounds fantastic - well, he didn't give anything away about how it's going to happen and when."

The passage of time itself is already thinning out the friends and contemporaries of Derrick and Kathleen, who are 74 and 75, as well as eating into the savings they set aside when they sold the shop and opted for the safety - and the 10% interest rate in 1992 - of a building society account.

In the longer term, the chancellor's raising of the savings threshold for income support will bring some additional help, when the steady drain on their capital to meet bills takes their nest egg below the new £12,000 limit.

In the immediate future, the £50 extra on winter fuel allowance is the Spinks' only straight gain, and the chancellor counterbalanced it with his petrol tax, which will hit the their main source of pleasure - apart from their daughter's wedding in June - outings in their 10-year-old Audi.

"Still, it is the minimum," said Derrick. "And we're very pleased that he's putting more money into the health service, particularly all the extra tax on tobacco."

Gordon Brown could easily have been a fly on the wall the day before the Budget, when Derrick and Kathleen were making this precise point about smok ing - a habit they have managed to avoid - costing the NHS billions.

The extra funds have a particular resonance in the couple's bungalow, where Derrick has to sleep in an armchair because of a trapped sciatic nerve. Told in November that the first chance of a consultant's appointment was this May, he asked about paying and was shocked to find that an appointment was made for him within two days.

The chancellor's fiscal spurs to investment via the rolling cuts in capital gains tax are largely another world, although the couple have an extra £400-odd a year from shares issued when their building society converted.

Rather than the stock exchange, they will be watching the progress or otherwise of Alastair Darling in setting up a "pensioner's credit", which would raise their weekly pension by two-thirds.

fields.headline: Brown shies from talking tampons
fields.standfirst: Tax cut on sanitary items
fields.trailText: It is the tax cut that dare not speak its name - at least not in the Budget announcement. Chancellor Gordon Brown is to slash value added tax on women's sanitary products - the so-called "Tampax tax" - but was just too embarrassed to say so.
fields.body:
It is the tax cut that dare not speak its name - at least not in the Budget announcement. Chancellor Gordon Brown is to slash value added tax on women's sanitary products - the so-called "Tampax tax" - but was just too embarrassed to say so.

Sustained lobbying from female Labour MPs, led by Calder Valley MP Chris McCafferty, persuaded the chancellor to introduce the change, which ends the policy of treating tampons and sanitary towels as luxury items incurring the full 17.5% VAT rate.

The tax will be cut from next January to just 5% - the lowest possible under European rules limiting the goods that can be zero-rated.

However, while Mr Brown conceded the reduction, worth £35m a year, women MPs were amused to find that he could not be persuaded to utter the words "sanitary protection" in the Commons chamber. "We tried to get him to say 'sanpro'," said one MP. "But even that didn't seem to appeal."

Instead, details of the tax cut were referred to in accompanying Budget documents and coyly pointed out by Treasury aides after the chancellor's address. Challenged over Mr Brown's inexplicable failure to mention the change, which comes after decades of campaigning by women's pressure groups, one adviser said: "Female treasury ministers have worked very hard on this and Gordon decided to let them take the credit."

The move was welcomed by Asda, which has been pressing for a reduction in the price of sanitary items. The chain, which has not charged customers VAT on sanitary products for more than a year, preferring to shoulder the tax itself, said it was delighted.

webTitle: Boost for enterprise cushioned by attack on poverty

fields.headline: Boost for enterprise cushioned by attack on poverty
fields.standfirst: Budget 2000 - special report
fields.trailText: The government yesterday underlined its ambition to generate a vigorous US-style business culture by unveiling a package of measures to stimulate enterprise, cushioned by fresh steps to eradicate poverty and low pay.
fields.body:
The government yesterday underlined its ambition to generate a vigorous US-style business culture by unveiling a package of measures to stimulate enterprise, cushioned by fresh steps to eradicate poverty and low pay.

Describing the choice between enterprise and fairness as false, Gordon Brown offered generous tax breaks to encourage entrepreneurs to create wealth, and extra money for pensioners and "hard-working families", a phrase used repeatedly in his speech.

The chancellor also showed sensitivity to motorists and drinkers by holding the annual increase in road fuel duty and most alcohol taxes in line with inflation. But tobacco duties were increased by 5% in real, inflation-adjusted terms to help fund the NHS. Wealthy homebuyers were hit by a new increase in stamp duty, which increases the amount payable on homes worth £500,000 to £20,000.

In his fourth Budget, Mr Brown announced a radical shake-up of the capital gains tax regime, under which all business investment held for four years is rewarded with a 10% rate; a new all-employee share ownership scheme; permanent 40% investment allowances for small firms; a new regional network of venture capital funds worth £1bn, and a scheme giving tax-free share options worth £100,000 each to 15 key employees of high-risk businesses.

Together with previously announced cuts in corporate tax rates, these measures would make Britain the place "for companies to start, to invest, to grow and expand", said Mr Brown.

Stressing his determination to tear down the barriers to full employment, Mr Brown said the working families tax credit, designed to top up the incomes of the very low paid, would be increased to guarantee a minimum income of £214 a week from April 2001. To ease the transition from welfare to work, a new job grant will be introduced from spring 2001 for the long-term unemployed, starting at £100, and the same help offered by the new deal to young people is to be extended to the rest of the working population.

Stepping up the government's efforts to eliminate child poverty, forecast to fall by 1.2m as a result of all the measures introduced by Labour since coming to power, the chancellor announced extra maternity payments for mothers on low income and an extra 50p a week for the new children's tax credit when it is introduced next year.

Mr Brown gave pensioners an extra £50 to help with winter fuel payments, raised to £12,000 the amount of savings they can have before reaching the income support cut-off point and announced plans for a new pensioners' credit.

Industry welcomed the Budget, but there was disappointment that there were no specific measures to help manufacturing.

Ruth Lea, head of the policy unit at the Institute of Directors, said: "We liked his enthusiasm for enterprise culture. Overall I give him eight of 10."

The TUC general secretary, John Monks, said: "Despite some welcome initiatives, it's vital that economic policy helps, rather than hinders, manufacturers, particularly exporters."

Describing the choice between enterprise and fairness as false, Gordon Brown offered generous tax breaks to encourage entrepreneurs to create wealth, and extra money for pensioners and "hard-working families", a phrase used repeatedly in his speech. The chancellor also showed sensitivity to motorists and drinkers by holding the annual increase in road fuel duty and most alcohol taxes in line with inflation. But tobacco duties were increased by 5% in real, inflation-adjusted terms to help fund the NHS. Wealthy homebuyers were hit by a new increase in stamp duty, which increases the amount payable on homes worth £500,000 to £20,000. In his fourth Budget, Mr Brown announced a radical shake-up of the capital gains tax regime, under which all business investment held for four years is rewarded with a 10% rate; a new all-employee share ownership scheme; permanent 40% investment allowances for small firms; a new regional network of venture capital funds worth £1bn, and a scheme giving tax-free share options worth £100,000 each to 15 key employees of high-risk businesses. Together with previously announced cuts in corporate tax rates, these measures would make Britain the place "for companies to start, to invest, to grow and expand", said Mr Brown. Stressing his determination to tear down the barriers to full employment, Mr Brown said the working families tax credit, designed to top up the incomes of the very low paid, would be increased to guarantee a minimum income of £214 a week from April 2001. To ease the transition from welfare to work, a new job grant will be introduced from spring 2001 for the long-term unemployed, starting at £100, and the same help offered by the new deal to young people is to be extended to the rest of the working population. Stepping up the government's efforts to eliminate child poverty, forecast to fall by 1.2m as a result of all the measures introduced by Labour since coming to power, the chancellor announced extra maternity payments for mothers on low income and an extra 50p a week for the new children's tax credit when it is introduced next year. Mr Brown gave pensioners an extra £50 to help with winter fuel payments, raised to £12,000 the amount of savings they can have before reaching the income support cut-off point and announced plans for a new pensioners' credit. Industry welcomed the Budget, but there was disappointment that there were no specific measures to help manufacturing. Ruth Lea, head of the policy unit at the Institute of Directors, said: "We liked his enthusiasm for enterprise culture. Overall I give him eight of 10." The TUC general secretary, John Monks, said: "Despite some welcome initiatives, it's vital that economic policy helps, rather than hinders, manufacturers, particularly exporters."

fields.headline: Main points in the Budget
fields.standfirst: Budget 2000 - special report
fields.trailText: Health
fields.body:
Health

NHS to get £2bn more from April. Allocations over the next four years to rise at 6.1% a year above inflation.

Education

An extra £1bn for schools. Primaries can expect £3,000 to £9,000 extra; secondaries £30,000 to £50,000.

Income tax

1p cut in the basic rate to 22p from April 6. Personal allowance rises by £50 to £4,385.

Housing

Stamp duty up to 3% on sales from £250,000 to £500,000 and to 4% for sales above £500,000.

Motoring

Petrol up 2p a litre. No change in road tax.

Alcohol

Beer up by 1p a pint; wine by 4p a bottle. No rise on spirits.

Tobacco

Packet of 20 cigarettes up by 25p. Rise of 22p on a 25 gram pack of hand-rolling tobacco.

Travel

Airport tax halved to £5 for economy flights in Europe.

Savings and inheritance

Individual savings account (Isa) limit rises to £7,000. Inheritance tax threshold up £3,000 to £234,000.

Benefits

Working families tax credit for family with one child and one full-time worker to rise to £214 in April 2001.

Pensioners

Income guaranteed at £82 a week for single pensioners; £172 for couples.

webTitle: US high court rejects new cigarette curbs

fields.headline: US high court rejects new cigarette curbs
fields.standfirst: Smoking: special report
fields.trailText: The US supreme court handed the tobacco industry a significant victory yesterday when it ruled against further government restrictions on cigarette advertising and production.
fields.body:
The US supreme court handed the tobacco industry a significant victory yesterday when it ruled against further government restrictions on cigarette advertising and production.

The court ruled by a 5-4 vote that the government's food and drug administration (FDA), overstepped its authority in 1996 when it issued sweeping regulations involving cigarettes and smokeless tobacco. It upheld a ruling by a US appeals court in Richmond, Virginia, in 1998 that the FDA lacked explicit authority from Congress to expand its reach to tobacco.

The ruling will shift the battle over federal tobacco regulation to the Republican-controlled Congress, which could give the FDA the power to regulate cigarettes.

The supreme court decision dealt a sharp blow to the Clinton administration, which had made increased regulation by the FDA the centrepiece of its anti-smoking crusade.

However, the industry's travails are far from over. Tobacco companies have agreed settlements worth $246bn (£155bn) with US states in the last year, and face individual lawsuits and a racketeering investigation by the justice department.

Philip Morris had already agreed to limited regulation by the FDA as part of a campaign to prove its openness to change. But the industry had objected to the broader powers in the 1996 proposals.

fields.headline: Shipman refuses to help police
fields.standfirst: Shipman trial: special report
fields.trailText: The serial killer Harold Shipman has refused to be interviewed by Greater Manchester police about the suspicious deaths of 100 of his patients.
fields.body:
The serial killer Harold Shipman has refused to be interviewed by Greater Manchester police about the suspicious deaths of 100 of his patients.

The former doctor from Mottram, near Hyde, was given 15 life sentences in January for murdering 15 women patients.

Detective Superintendent Bernard Postles, who led the original murder inquiry, said that Shipman, who is at Frankland prison, County Durham, had refused to co-operate with their investigations.

"I am disappointed that he has continued to disregard the feelings of the victims' families," said Mr Postles yesterday.

Mr Postles added it was not the end of the investigation and if Shipman decided to admit his involvement a team of officers would be sent to interview him.

Shipman's wife, Primrose, and his 17-year-old son have moved from their home in Greater Manchester to Whitby, north Yorkshire, so they can be closer to him.

webTitle: Immigrants needed to save west from crisis

fields.headline: Immigrants needed to save west from crisis
fields.standfirst:
Italy pays the price for a declining population, as the UN warns that worse is to come for developed world

Global population: special report
fields.trailText: Europeans will need to rely increasingly on immigrants to pay their pensions because of declining birth rates, according to a United Nations report published yesterday.
fields.body:
Europeans will need to rely increasingly on immigrants to pay their pensions because of declining birth rates, according to a United Nations report published yesterday.

"In the next 50 years the populations of most developed countries are projected to become smaller and older as a result of low fertility and increased longevity," said the UN's population division. "Population decline is inevitable in the absence of replacement migration."

The only way that some of these countries could maintain their ratio of workers to pensioners without allowing more immigration would be to raise the retirement age.

The decline is most severe in Japan and in many European countries. Italy is particularly hard hit, with a fertility rate of about 1.2 children per woman - among the lowest in the world - and a population which is falling, despite the arrival of about 70,000 immigrants a year.

According to the projections, Italy is expected to lose 28% of its population by 2050, the steepest decline of the countries covered by the report. It would need 6,500 immigrants for every million inhabitants to maintain the worker-pensioner ratio. Otherwise the retirement age would need to rise to 77.

Japan, where the proportion of foreigners is barely 1%, would need 5,000 immigrants for every million inhabitants each year just to stand still.

The population unit studied eight low-birthrate countries for the report: the UK, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, Russia, South Korea and the United States. It also looked at the European Union and Europe.

The UK would be able to keep its population steady up to 2050 by raising immigration from an average of 73,000 a year to 88,000.

"However, the number of migrants needed to keep the population in working-age constant are about twice the level of the past decade," said the report. Without immigrants the retirement age would have to rise to 72 to maintain the ratio of workers to pensioners.

Overall, the population of the 15 countries of the EU, which now stands at more than 375m people, is expected to fall to 330m by 2050.

The population of the US, by contrast, is projected to grow from just under 280m now to almost 350m in 50 years.

The report said that governments should consider the age they set for retirement, the benefits they want to provide to the elderly, and their immigration policies.

But not everyone accepts the premise of the study. Paul Demeny, of the Population Council think-tank in New York, said a declining population was not necessarily a problem.

Fertility rates could also rise again. "These affluent societies, Europe, Japan, North America, have plenty of economic potential to adjust to these relatively slow-moving changes without courting economic disaster," he said.

webTitle: 'They were God-fearing people like us, and God knows we needed them'

fields.headline: 'They were God-fearing people like us, and God knows we needed them'
fields.standfirst: Global population: special report
fields.trailText: When a ship carrying 825 Kurdish asylum seekers and immigrants hit a sandbank just off Italy, the ageing residents of the nearby village of Badolato thanked God for their Christmas present.
fields.body:
When a ship carrying 825 Kurdish asylum seekers and immigrants hit a sandbank just off Italy, the ageing residents of the nearby village of Badolato thanked God for their Christmas present.

It was December 27, 1997. Boats raced to the ship and ferried its human cargo to land. The Kurds were penniless and did not speak Italian, but for the villagers of Badolato, on Italy's toe, they had one priceless asset - youth.

Most of the houses in the 1,000-year-old village, 900ft above the Mediterranean, had been abandoned over four decades. A population of 7,000 had dwindled to 700.

Few babies were being born - most local couples had one child at the most. The elementary school had closed, businesses were failing, buildings were crumbling. It was just a matter of time before Badolato became a ghost town.

And then the Ararat arrived: a Russian-made rustbucket that had left Istanbul for Rome six days earlier. The perils and £1,500 price tag had deterred elderly Kurds from making the journey, so the new arrivals were mostly under 40. They had not planned to make a life in Calabria, one of Italy's poorest regions, but that was what they were offered.

Central and regional government gave the Kurds food and money and promised to settle them in empty houses. Officials promised them work in new enterprises that would make the most of their skills.

The Kurds were astounded and grateful. Their children would grow up Italian. Within days television crews were in Badolato, reporting how a shipload of people seeking a new life had chanced upon a place crying out for new blood.

The government proclaimed Badolato a beacon for the rest of Italy, with the arrivals providing a practical solution to the problem of Italy's shrinking population.

Today's United Nation report reveals the scale of the crisis. By 2050, Italy's population is projected to decline from 57m to 41m and the working-age population will drop from 39m to 22m. As a result, the country will need to accept an average of 350,000 migrants a year for the next 50 years to maintain the ratio of four workers for every pensioner.

The crisis is already acute. Confindustria, the confederation of Italian industry, revealed this month that 50,000 information technology jobs will be left vacant this year.

Badolato was supposed to be a trailblazer. But two years on the Kurds have all but gone. Those that remain are angry and the village has lost hope. The revival was stillborn.

In the first few weeks it looked very different. Coaches whisked the 660 men and 165 women and children to the abandoned school where they were to stay while derelict houses were made habitable.

"They were God-fearing people like us, and God knows we needed them," said a villager, Antonio Carnucco, 80.

The Kurds were struck by the absence of youngsters. "It was all old people," said Ihsan Tatargan, 34, who arrived with his wife, Aysel, 27, and four young children.

But things began to sour. The 110 Kurds who had come from Egypt were deported on the grounds that only those from Turkey and Iraq could claim to be in need of asylum.

Money promised for language classes and business start-ups did not arrive. Workshops and initiatives for the newly arrived civil engineers, tile-makers and labourers did not materialise. A Kurdish restaurant opened, but hired only one refugee before closing last November.

The Kurds found themselves turfed out of their houses after three months. The owners wanted rent and the government, after granting residence permits, stopped paying. So the refugees moved back to the abandoned school.

Police urged them to leave Italy. Buses were laid on to take them to the railway station. This week there were just 40 Kurds left, including four families, all still living in the school. Most of them, it turns out, have found work in Germany, Sweden and France, and have returned only to renew documents.

Gerardo Mannello, the mayor, insisted that hope was alive. Bureaucratic bungling had slowed the money but it should arrive by April. Fresh projects were being planned. "It is not too late," he said.

Outside his office Kurds wandered past boarded-up houses and waited for post. The natives gazed at them in despair.

"It's such a waste. My neighbours are as old as I am. We don't hear or see children any more, they're just a memory," said Giuseppe Cossare, 81.

fields.headline: Beijing chilly to Taiwan overture
fields.standfirst: Taiwan and China: special report
fields.trailText: Taiwan's new president, Chen Shui-bian, pressed ahead with his charm offensive yesterday, trying to entice Beijing into peaceful dialogue about the island's status.
fields.body:
Taiwan's new president, Chen Shui-bian, pressed ahead with his charm offensive yesterday, trying to entice Beijing into peaceful dialogue about the island's status.

Speaking in Taipei, Mr Chen, the pro-independence winner of Saturday's presidential election, said it was his "duty, vision and responsibility to seek lasting peace across the Taiwan Straits".

The Taiwanese parliament also dropped the formal legal ban on direct trade links with the mainland.

But in Beijing, a spokesman countered by repeating China's formal position that Taiwan was a part of "One China".

And in a statement that appeared to reinforce China's rigid opposition to Taiwan's independence, the Chinese premier, Zhu Rongji, said yesterday that Beijing would never negotiate with anyone advocating independence for the island.

However, the US special envoy Richard Holbrooke, who was visiting Beijing, said he had held "constructive talks" covering the Taiwan issue with China's foreign minister, Tang Jiaxuan.

Leaders of Mr Chen's Democratic Progressive party (DPP) meet today to discuss dropping from the party's constitution a clause demanding that the island change its name to the "Republic of Taiwan"; its official title, the "Republic of China" is deemed more acceptable by Beijing.

Yesterday's moves followed posturing from both sides since the weekend election of Mr Chen to the presidency, about the central issue - whether Taiwan must accept, as precursor to any talks, that it is part of China.

Mr Chen had proposed a peace summit, saying he was willing "to sit down and talk with the Chinese side about all issues, including 'One China'". But he made it clear that the Chinese formula could be discussed only "as long as it is not a principle. It can be an issue, but not a precondition," he said.

Mr Jiang said in Beijing that Mr Chen was welcome "to come to the mainland for talks" - and that he himself was willing to go to Taiwan. But this was possible, he insisted, only if the Taiwanese "recognise the principle of One China. Under this precondition, anything can be discussed." The question now is whether this gap can be bridged by language that would satisfy both sides.

The DPP wants to reach an understanding with Beijing based upon a less contentious definition of common Chinese identity. "Since the People's Republic of China and the Republic of China are all part of the same cultural and historical China, the two countries and their societies have the responsibility to work out a mutually beneficial relationship," says a DPP adviser, Chen Pichao.

The hope is that Beijing will accept a formula that emphasises common ties. "The fact is that we are not going to reach agreement on sovereignty," says the adviser. "So let's shelve it and establish a [separate] consensus."

webTitle: Killing of Sikhs clouds Clinton visit to India

fields.headline: Killing of Sikhs clouds Clinton visit to India
fields.standfirst:
Kashmir slaughter eclipses US attempts to raise objections to nuclear proliferation

The India-Pakistan conflict: special report
fields.trailText: The first visit by a United States president to India in 22 years began in a mood of horror and fury yesterday, with India and Pakistan accusing each other of masterminding a massacre of 40 unarmed Sikhs in a village in Kashmir.
fields.body:
The first visit by a United States president to India in 22 years began in a mood of horror and fury yesterday, with India and Pakistan accusing each other of masterminding a massacre of 40 unarmed Sikhs in a village in Kashmir.

Whoever carried out the attack, its timing on the eve of Bill Clinton's five-day tour of India - with all the western media coverage such a visit generates - is unlikely to have been coincidental. President Clinton described the attack as a "horrible development".

The unidentified gunmen, who descended on the village of Chati Singhpura Mattan, 40 miles south of Kashmir's summer capital, Srinagar, ordered the men out of their houses before shooting them at point-blank range. The attack on Monday night was the first on Kashmir's Sikh minority since violence broke out in the state 10 years ago.

India yesterday accused two militant Islamic groups based in Pakistan, the Lashkar-e-Toiba and Hizbul Mojahedin, of carrying out the killings.

Pakistan rejected the claim and said India was exploiting the tragedy for political purposes. "We condemn the killing," said Pakistan's foreign minister, Abdul Sattar.

After talks with Mr Clinton, the Indian prime minister, Atal Bihari Vajpayee, emerged to condemn the attack as a "primitive act of barbarism". It was part of a pattern of "ethnic cleansing" that had "been under way for a decade", aimed at driving non-Muslims out of Kashmir, he said.

"We and the international community reject the notion that jihad [holy war] can be a part of any civilised country's foreign policy. We have the means and will to eliminate this menace," he added.

The massacre eclipsed, at least initially, attempts by the US to raise its concerns with India about nuclear proliferation in the region. These are likely to dominate Mr Clinton's meeting in Islamabad on Sat urday with General Pervez Musharraf, Pakistan's military ruler. Mr Clinton sounded his most understanding note yet towards New Delhi's develpping nuclear capabilities, but he refused to lift US sanctions imposed after the country's 1998 nuclear test.

Mr Vajpayee promised that India would not conduct further nuclear tests or "engage in a nuclear arms race". But he defended India's right to maintain "a mininum nuclear deterrent". New Delhi has so far refused to sign the comprehensive test ban treaty on nuclear weapons, despite pressure from Washington.

In a significant tilt away from Pakistan, a US ally in the cold-war era, Mr Clinton said that talks between India and Pakistan could begin only when violence ended. There must be respect for the line of control, the unmarked mountain border between the Indian and Pakistani-controlled parts of Kashmir. And "some way must be found to renew the dialogue", he said.

India accuses Pakistan of sending armed militants across the line of control into Kashmir. Islamabad denies thisbut admits to offering the "freedom fighters" moral support.

Officials said yesterday that between 10 and 12 uniformed men arrived in Chati Singhpura Mattan after dark, announced that they were conducting a "crackdown" and separated the men from the women. The Sikh men were then sprayed with bullets in two areas, 200 yards apart.

"They shot them dead, point blank," said the director general of police, F A K Bhan. Soldiers yesterday searched the hills and forest near by while in Jammu - the state's winter capital - a curfew was imposed as some 15,000 furious Sikhs blocked roads.

In the past, the militants have carried out random killings of Hindus, but the Sikhs - many of whom run trucking companies in the valley - had been considered neutral in the campaign to divorce Kashmir from India. Hindu villages are guarded by security patrols, but not the Sikh villages, which until now seemed to need no protection.

Yesterday a senior Indian official, Brajesh Mishra, said that New Delhi had evidence that militants linked to Pakistan were responsible, though he refused to identify his sources.

He named Lashkar-e-Toiba, led by Abu Mahaz, as the perpetrator, in a combined operation with Hizbul Mojahedin. But militant leaders in Pakistan rejected the charge.

fields.bodyText: The first visit by a United States president to India in 22 years began in a mood of horror and fury yesterday, with India and Pakistan accusing each other of masterminding a massacre of 40 unarmed Sikhs in a village in Kashmir. Whoever carried out the attack, its timing on the eve of Bill Clinton's five-day tour of India - with all the western media coverage such a visit generates - is unlikely to have been coincidental. President Clinton described the attack as a "horrible development". The unidentified gunmen, who descended on the village of Chati Singhpura Mattan, 40 miles south of Kashmir's summer capital, Srinagar, ordered the men out of their houses before shooting them at point-blank range. The attack on Monday night was the first on Kashmir's Sikh minority since violence broke out in the state 10 years ago. India yesterday accused two militant Islamic groups based in Pakistan, the Lashkar-e-Toiba and Hizbul Mojahedin, of carrying out the killings. Pakistan rejected the claim and said India was exploiting the tragedy for political purposes. "We condemn the killing," said Pakistan's foreign minister, Abdul Sattar. After talks with Mr Clinton, the Indian prime minister, Atal Bihari Vajpayee, emerged to condemn the attack as a "primitive act of barbarism". It was part of a pattern of "ethnic cleansing" that had "been under way for a decade", aimed at driving non-Muslims out of Kashmir, he said. "We and the international community reject the notion that jihad [holy war] can be a part of any civilised country's foreign policy. We have the means and will to eliminate this menace," he added. The massacre eclipsed, at least initially, attempts by the US to raise its concerns with India about nuclear proliferation in the region. These are likely to dominate Mr Clinton's meeting in Islamabad on Sat urday with General Pervez Musharraf, Pakistan's military ruler. Mr Clinton sounded his most understanding note yet towards New Delhi's develpping nuclear capabilities, but he refused to lift US sanctions imposed after the country's 1998 nuclear test. Mr Vajpayee promised that India would not conduct further nuclear tests or "engage in a nuclear arms race". But he defended India's right to maintain "a mininum nuclear deterrent". New Delhi has so far refused to sign the comprehensive test ban treaty on nuclear weapons, despite pressure from Washington. In a significant tilt away from Pakistan, a US ally in the cold-war era, Mr Clinton said that talks between India and Pakistan could begin only when violence ended. There must be respect for the line of control, the unmarked mountain border between the Indian and Pakistani-controlled parts of Kashmir. And "some way must be found to renew the dialogue", he said. India accuses Pakistan of sending armed militants across the line of control into Kashmir. Islamabad denies thisbut admits to offering the "freedom fighters" moral support. Officials said yesterday that between 10 and 12 uniformed men arrived in Chati Singhpura Mattan after dark, announced that they were conducting a "crackdown" and separated the men from the women. The Sikh men were then sprayed with bullets in two areas, 200 yards apart. "They shot them dead, point blank," said the director general of police, F A K Bhan. Soldiers yesterday searched the hills and forest near by while in Jammu - the state's winter capital - a curfew was imposed as some 15,000 furious Sikhs blocked roads. In the past, the militants have carried out random killings of Hindus, but the Sikhs - many of whom run trucking companies in the valley - had been considered neutral in the campaign to divorce Kashmir from India. Hindu villages are guarded by security patrols, but not the Sikh villages, which until now seemed to need no protection. fields.headline: More digs at Durkin
fields.trailText: Tim Gardam of Channel 4 says that Greenpeace was offered the chance to be interviewed for Martin Durkin's Equinox documentary on GM crops (Letters, March 18) but declined to take part. He fails to mention that Durkin's last encounter with Greenpeace resulted in an Independent Television Commission judgment against him.
fields.body:
Tim Gardam of Channel 4 says that Greenpeace was offered the chance to be interviewed for Martin Durkin's Equinox documentary on GM crops (Letters, March 18) but declined to take part. He fails to mention that Durkin's last encounter with Greenpeace resulted in an Independent Television Commission judgment against him and Channel 4 which concluded that "comparisons between the unedited interviews conducted by the production company, and transcripts of the programmes transmitted showed that the views of the four complainants, as made clear to the interviewer, had been distorted by selective editing". As one of those four complainants, I did not want to repeat the experience of having my views distorted - not least because Martin Durkin has never apologised for his unprofessional behaviour. Greenpeace took part in last week's BBC Horizon programme on GM crops, and we will always cooperate with responsible film-makers.
Peter Melchett
Exective director, Greenpeace

 In discussions with Martin Durkin's "Kugelblitz" crew as to the content of their proposed "science documentary" on silicone breast implants last year, we were totally and unequivocally misled as to the intent and content of that piece. Never would we have agreed to participate in what was little more than implant advertising for British plastic surgeons replete with overstuffed bouncing balloons and breasts. Hardly "science".

It appears that the American silicone manufacturers' highly financed PR campaign to hide the real dangers of breast implants of all kinds has now been exported to Britain and broadcast by C4/Equinox. We will report the deceptive and abhorrent actions we experienced to the ITC, accurately described by George Monbiot (Comment, March 16).
Sally Kirkland, Ilena Rosenthal
Humantics Foundation for Women Breast Implants, USA ilena@san.rr.com

fields.headline: Driven to the wall
fields.trailText:
We have heard a lot in the media about the ogre BMW and its destruction of Longbridge. But the British media, in particular the local television and newspapers, have hounded Rover cars with bad publicity, deriding their new products and driving sales to an all-time low.
Daniel Edmonds
Stourbridge, W Mids

Stourbridge, W Mids

 During the 40s wave after wave of bombers failed to interrupt production at Longbridge. A small committee (of the makers) of Messerschmitts has only taken a week to achieve just that.

Ludlow, Salop

Hampton Hill, Middx

Eleanor Silk
London

fields.headline: Begging for consistency
fields.trailText: Roy Greenslade says "our society is rich enough to bear beggars" (We hate you, Media, March 20), but I fear he is not helping asylum seekers by confusing the two groups.
fields.body:
Roy Greenslade says "our society is rich enough to bear beggars" (We hate you, Media, March 20), but I fear he is not helping asylum seekers by confusing the two groups. I agree our society is rich enough to bear asylum seekers and deplore the sensationalist press coverage. But the intrusive beggars who patrol the London Underground are not to be accepted.

I am not a purveyor of urban myth. I have observed a family of four small boys being guided on to a Bakerloo line train at Marylebone by their mother; they were playing and laughing on the platform then each assumed an expression of misery as they made their way through the train, poking and prodding us to get our attention, giggling as they got off at the next station, showing each other how much money they had collected. I have experienced begging women with children, begging women who sing and a begging man who only stopped insisting that I give him money when his mobile phone interrupted him.

People like me who travel in the Underground outside of rush hour find the experience very unpleasant. Unlike the Scots and Geordies Mr Greenslade mentions, the new batch of beggars approach us and will not take a polite No for an answer. As a paid up member of the "chattering classes:" I often give money to beggars, but this bunch do not appeal to our sense of fairness and generosity, they intimidate us.
Sarah McCartney
London sarah@little-max.co.uk

 Is there really a plague of women armed with children demanding our money (Leader, March 20)? As a busker in the London Underground for over 15 years I have witnessed several trends: young individual homeless men appeared in the late 80s; Irish women with children followed in the early 90s; eastern Europeans appeared in the mid-90s. These trends were clearly the result of wider political events. Menacing? Never. The menace comes from politicians who peddle aggressive measures whilst begging for our vote.
Linus Uhlig
London linus@uhlig.new.labour.org.uk

 It is wrong for beggars to use their children to help them collect money, but it is all right for politicians to use their children (and to-be-born babies) in order to help them collect votes.
Mike Ellwood
Abingdon, Oxon mwe@rl.ac.uk

 What is the difference between exploiting children by begging and exploiting children in advertising?
DJ Browning
Altrincham, Cheshire.
mufc1@compuserve.com

 Polly Toynbee's comment that she looked at mothers begging with babies and thought "those kids are going to write a book one day" (Novelist sinks teeth into Orange, March 21) is refreshingly different angle to that of immigration minister Barbara Roche, who on the eve of the UN Day against Racism, commemorating the Sharpeville massacre and the 1965 US civil rights march, describes the behaviour of begging asylum seekers as "vile". Isn't it a dangerously short step to using the same term actually to describe the people involved?

Last week Labour MEPs supported my report on combatting racism in the EU. It included a call to ensure that immigration and asylum policy "avoids stoking xenophobic attitudes or discrim- inatory and hostile behaviour to ethnic minorities". Tackling racism in our society must be a seamless web, not saying one thing to Neville and Doreen Lawrence and another to Daily Mail readers.
Sarah Ludford MEP
sludford@europarl.eu.int

fields.trailText: You must have missed Susan Kramer's inspirational speech at the Lib Dems' spring conference (Leader, March 21). Has the Guardian an embargo, except for sniping?
fields.body:
You must have missed Susan Kramer's inspirational speech at the Lib Dems' spring conference (Leader, March 21). Has the Guardian an embargo, except for sniping? The letter (March 21) about Susan and her cat - his appearance on her website is clearly only for humorous purposes - was, of course, legitimate: the pointer on the preceding page was not. I am changing my newspaper and drawing attention on the Lib Dem's website to this nasty little act of malice.
Cllr Susette Palmer
London

Tom Corcoran
Friends Of Elmo Jones, London

fields.headline: CIA sets record straight
fields.trailText: Duncan Campbell (I spy an ally, March 15) says that I alleged that certain specific countries spy on the US "from Germany to Korea. France heads the list": I made no allegations about any specific country.
fields.body:
Duncan Campbell (I spy an ally, March 15) says that I alleged that certain specific countries spy on the US "from Germany to Korea. France heads the list": I made no allegations about any specific country.

Second, he says that I stated that the US "steals economic secrets". Nonsense. My entire set of answers made clear that the US used covert collection to learn about various countries' bribery, violations of economic sanctions, and hidden sales of products that can be used to make chemical weapons. The US government does not conduct the sort of industrial espionage Mr Campbell alleges.

Third, he suggests that any technical information the US might learn incidentally to the above sorts of intelligence collection "would be passed on". I was clearly referring to information being passed on to another part of the US government, not to private companies.

I did compliment his original study as being intellectually honest enough to point out that past alleged cases of American economic espionage all involved bribery by the companies being spied upon. But now he has pushed his luck. In my view, "intellectually honest" no longer applies to his prose.


James Woolsey
Former director, Central Intelligence Agency

fields.headline: Now the banks are robbing pensioners
fields.trailText: Every fourth Friday my state pension of £265 is paid into the bank (Brown to clamp down on banks, March 21). Over Christmas I managed to get overdrawn by £93. I was informed on January 6 and warned that until my account was in credit I would be fined £3.50 a day plus £5 a month. Meanwhile, all direct debits would be stopped. I have virtually no other income.
fields.body:
Every fourth Friday my state pension of £265 is paid into the bank (Brown to clamp down on banks, March 21). Over Christmas I managed to get overdrawn by £93. I was informed on January 6 and warned that until my account was in credit I would be fined £3.50 a day plus £5 a month. Meanwhile, all direct debits would be stopped. I have virtually no other income.

The next pension cheque was due on January 21 but even with severe economies it took me another four weeks to get straight. But then I got notification that £63 had been extracted to cover the period January 4 to February 6. So on my relatively modest overdraft I was being charged roughly 66% per month! This in spite of the message at the bottom of every statement: "Your interest rate for borrowing up to £100 on this account is 20.5% per annum." And even if my overdraft should exceed this amount, they tell me "interest will be charged at 29.5% pa". No mention of 66%!

God knows how I'll ever get straight again. They carry on charging me £3.50 per day, £5 per month and (God help me!) a cool £27.50 every time they cancel a direct debit: Gas, Electric and BT so far.
Name and address supplied

 I hold a modest account with Credit Agricole in France. I can ring them up and hear a human voice - I can even get through to the manager. If my funds rise above a certain level, they are transferred to a tax-free deposit account earning 2-3% interest, but will be automatically transferred to my current account if I'm in danger of overdraft. Back home I have been a Lloyds Bank customer for 40 years, and have recently become a shareholder. Whatever I am losing in service I must be gaining in shareholder value, and may be able to send some of that profit to France so as to exploit the absurdly high exchange rate.
Liz Budd
Cambridge

 I graduated from Portsmouth Polytechnic in 1991 with a £3,500 overdraft which I am still paying off. I only borrowed about half. The rest mounted up with interest rates and charges of £15 for bouncing cheques. This was during the era of the Tory government that condemned union leaders for abusing their power.
Karl Osborne
London
