fields.headline: Season's greetings
fields.standfirst: Spring arrived yesterday. Or perhaps not
fields.trailText: Across England's green, pleasant land, the sounds and scents of spring suddenly abound. The piquant tap-tapping of the woodpecker is overborne by the pounding of pneumatic drills. Roadworks ahead! A certain harbinger of spring. Along arterial roads and motorways, a dawn chorus of self-reproducing juggernauts greets the early riser, wandering lonely as a cloud of diesel fumes. Hosts of nodding, golden daffodils come ready-wrapped at traffic lights, £1.20 a bunch. And hark! In sylvan glades, the rustic chatter of chainsaws; in the awakening cities, scrums of pub drinkers spilling out over beer-sticky pavements.
fields.body:
Across England's green, pleasant land, the sounds and scents of spring suddenly abound. The piquant tap-tapping of the woodpecker is overborne by the pounding of pneumatic drills. Roadworks ahead! A certain harbinger of spring. Along arterial roads and motorways, a dawn chorus of self-reproducing juggernauts greets the early riser, wandering lonely as a cloud of diesel fumes. Hosts of nodding, golden daffodils come ready-wrapped at traffic lights, £1.20 a bunch. And hark! In sylvan glades, the rustic chatter of chainsaws; in the awakening cities, scrums of pub drinkers spilling out over beer-sticky pavements.

Are these sure signs that spring is here? Geminus of Rhodes (130-70BC) was more particular, separating the four seasons by equinox and solstice. Going by his astronomer's book, spring officially began yesterday, although the exact vernal equinox was 7.35am GMT on Monday. Pagans would tend to agree. They mark the spring switch with Oestara, an equinoctial holiday in the "wheel of the year" celebrating new-born life, eggs and twigs and such. But here, consensus sadly crumbles. Meteorologists count March, April and May as the spring months, making March 1 the seasonal off. Agrarian societies of yore traditionally viewed February, with its first earthy stirrings, as the end of winter. Further confusion arises from the medieval legacy of quarter days - on which rents and tithes are paid. The "spring" quarter day falls on March 25, known as Lady Day. The other quarters are Midsummer on June 24 (not the summer solstice on June 21), Michaelmas and Christmas. Scotland being Scotland, and more northerly, the quarters are different again. But if the weather is "wet and foul" at Candlemas (February 2), recycled in the US as "groundhog day", then winter is proverbially held to be almost done.

British summer time, which starts on March 26; the new financial year (April 6); and the Paris and Milan "spring collections" (skimpy plumage for the mating season) offer yet more contradictions of timing. Then there is the added complication of global warming. Defying frost, Shakespeare's "darling buds of May" are two months ahead of themselves this year. Perhaps the only sure way of knowing when spring really has begun is to feel it. To do this, you must be in touch with yourself; be "grounded". On such an intimate subject, even the spring-heeled Guardian hesitates to offer advice.
fields.bodyText: Across England's green, pleasant land, the sounds and scents of spring suddenly abound. The piquant tap-tapping of the woodpecker is overborne by the pounding of pneumatic drills. Roadworks ahead! A certain harbinger of spring. Along arterial roads and motorways, a dawn chorus of self-reproducing juggernauts greets the early riser, wandering lonely as a cloud of diesel fumes. Hosts of nodding, golden daffodils come ready-wrapped at traffic lights, £1.20 a bunch. And hark! In sylvan glades, the rustic chatter of chainsaws; in the awakening cities, scrums of pub drinkers spilling out over beer-sticky pavements. Are these sure signs that spring is here? Geminus of Rhodes (130-70BC) was more particular, separating the four seasons by equinox and solstice. Going by his astronomer's book, spring officially began yesterday, although the exact vernal equinox was 7.35am GMT on Monday. Pagans would tend to agree. They mark the spring switch with Oestara, an equinoctial holiday in the "wheel of the year" celebrating new-born life, eggs and twigs and such. But here, consensus sadly crumbles. Meteorologists count March, April and May as the spring months, making March 1 the seasonal off. Agrarian societies of yore traditionally viewed February, with its first earthy stirrings, as the end of winter. Further confusion arises from the medieval legacy of quarter days - on which rents and tithes are paid. The "spring" quarter day falls on March 25, known as Lady Day. The other quarters are Midsummer on June 24 (not the summer solstice on June 21), Michaelmas and Christmas. Scotland being Scotland, and more northerly, the quarters are different again. But if the weather is "wet and foul" at Candlemas (February 2), recycled in the US as "groundhog day", then winter is proverbially held to be almost done. British summer time, which starts on March 26; the new financial year (April 6); and the Paris and Milan "spring collections" (skimpy plumage for the mating season) offer yet more contradictions of timing. Then there is the added complication of global warming. Defying frost, Shakespeare's "darling buds of May" are two months ahead of themselves this year. fields.headline: Ostrich farm 'fraud netted dealers £22m'
fields.trailText: Five businessmen pocketed millions of pounds in an ostrich farm fraud which duped thousands of people out of their savings, Leicester crown court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
Five businessmen pocketed millions of pounds in an ostrich farm fraud which duped thousands of people out of their savings, Leicester crown court heard yesterday.

The men spent £25,000 to set up the the Ostrich Farming Corporation Ltd - but took almost £22m from investors in less than 18 months.

More than 2,000 people were persuaded to part with their cash by glossy brochures promising high returns from what was billed as the meat of the future.

Investors' money was allegedly siphoned into offshore accounts, then laundered through bogus companies.

The businessmen set up the firm based near Mansfield, Nottinghamshire, to sell ostriches as an investment opportunity. Investors were invited to buy chicks for £500 or adult birds costing up to £14,000.

The birds would then be micro-chipped with the owner's details and reared on a specialist farm in Belgium before being sold as meat.

But Julian Baughan, QC, prosecuting, said the accused men had "cheated the public, to get money out of them, by telling lies."

He added: "It is a tribute to the success of this fraud that so many members of the public were induced to invest in it. To give the scheme a personal touch investors were told that the birds would be micro-chipped with the details of the investor.

"There would also be regular reports prepared of each birds' progress and its progeny."

The company promised high returns because of a predicted growing demand for ostrich meat.

Mr Baughan said more than 2,200 investors paid the company almost £22m. He said 80% of the revenue was received by the company in five months.

"It was a wall of money," he told the jury.

The men had no experience of ostriches or farming and none had ever owned an ostrich.

While some ostriches were bought and raised on the farm in Belgium, millions of pounds were siphoned into offshore accounts, said Mr Baughan.

To make the money difficult for the investors to trace, it went through other companies registered offshore.

Mr Baughan said the Ostrich Farming Corporation paid £7.5m to Wallstreet, a firm set up in the Cayman Islands by one of the accused men.

Other firms were launched called Company Administration and Jarvis Marketing to pay the corporation's sales force.

But the companies were also used to further "filter away investors' money" and then to be plundered by the accused men, claimed Mr Baughan.

He said documents of various transactions between the intermediary companies were found during an investigation by accountants employed by the Serious Fraud Office.

Four of the businessmen are in the dock but the fifth is absent due to ill health and may be tried later.

The jury was told that he was a bankrupt who allegedly set up accounts in the name of his unsuspecting 85-year-old mother to launder cash.

All five men have denied conspiracy to defraud between December 1994 and April 1996.

Brian Ketchell, 49, of Newark, Nottinghamshire, allegedly made £1.356m.

Allan Walker, 57, also of Newark, is alleged to have dishonestly made £1.367m.

Kevin Jones, 41, of Barnsley, South Yorkshire, is alleged to have made £2.1m and his brother Russell Jones, 42, of Doncaster, South Yorkshire, allegedly made £700,000.

The absent fifth defendant is alleged to have made £1.19m.

The Ostrich Farming Corporation was wound up by the courts in April 1996.

The trial is expected to last at least 14 weeks.

fields.headline: Anarchy for the USA
fields.standfirst:
She was the darling of the Republicans, the original dutiful conservative wife and feminist-baiter. Now she's declared war on her former allies and is urging citizens to take to the streets in protest at America's corrupt political system. Duncan Campbell on the rebirth of Arianna Stassinopolous Huffington, once dubbed 'the most upwardly mobile Greek since Icarus'

The US elections: special report Arianna Stassinopolous Huffington homepage
fields.trailText: She was the darling of the Republicans, the original dutiful conservative wife and feminist-baiter. Now she's declared war on her former allies and is urging citizens to take to the streets in protest at America's corrupt political system. Duncan Campbell  on the rebirth of Arianna Stassinopolous Huffington
fields.body:
She wants to overthrow the government. She wants people to take to the streets in acts of civil disobedience and organise boycotts of big corporations. She thinks the war on drugs is a waste of time and money. Her heroes are the demonstrators who brought the World Trade Organisation to a standstill in Seattle. Her enemies are the Republican party establishment. She reckons poor people and black people in America should rise up and demand their rights. She's angry as hell.

This is not some fugitive member of an urban guerrilla group issuing her manifesto. This is Arianna Stassinopolous Huffington, once the queen-pin of the Republican establishment, once a conservative Washington political wife, once a cheerleader for House leader Newt Gingrich and his rightwing Republican Revolution and, in a previous life, the first foreign president of the Cambridge Union, berater of feminism and advocate of New Age spirituality.

Her political transformation from the conservative right to the opposite side of the spectrum has infuriated some of her former allies, won her a new loyal battalion of friends on the left and given her one of the highest profiles of any woman in American politics. Currently, she is crisscrossing the country brandishing copies of her Overthrow the Government manifesto. So what has happened?

The scene is the Bergamot Station, a community and arts centre in Santa Monica, the liberal heartland of Los Angeles. Around 150 people have gathered to catch half an hour of Arianna - the first name is all that is necessary - talking about her new book and answering questions. It will only be half an hour because then she's off to the television studios for another interview, then Washington, then, well, everywhere. Everyone wants Arianna on their show or at their party these days. As the presidential race slips down a couple of gears after the departure of John McCain, there is a gaping political vacuum to be filled - and who better to fill it than Mrs Huffington?

The tall, slim, elegant figure with the trademark red hair takes to the platform with the ease born of many years as a television pundit. Her theme tonight is the collapse of respect for the body politic and the need for everyone to get out there, break with conventional politics and, if necessary, break some laws while they do so.

The presidential race has become a "demolition derby", she says; voters have a choice between "the pro-life corporation party and the pro-choice corporation party". No wonder half of the electorate didn't bother last time. The United States has become "two nations", with a shocking 36m people living in poverty. "The whole other America is not part of the political debate." Yes, it's good, she says, that McCain had raised the issue of campaign reform - trying to limit the way that big business funds political campaigns in return for later favours - but really, he had too easy a ride from the media, who had been "making goo-goo eyes at him".

The book she is promoting, Overthrow the Government, is a 300-page spin through the current political scene. It does not have the vision of a Noam Chomsky or the literary exuberance of a Christopher Hitchens, but is packed with handy facts and statistics, and plenty of soundbites: "America is a fast-ticking time bomb . . . American politics is becoming a sewer . . . How long will it be before the field is filled with only psychopaths - candidates immune to the cost, to their families and themselves, of round-the-clock sleaze and slander? It's the survival of the unfittest."

She sideswipes the media - "whether it's due to lethargy or lechery, reporters are more and more frequently choosing the salacious over the significant, the expedient over the essential" - and attacks the government's "inhumane" anti-drugs policy: "Black men are arrested for drugs five times as often as white men, even although only 13% of all monthly drug-users are African American." She notes that only 29% of the eligible black electorate used their vote at the last election.

Much of what she says might form part of a standard liberal agenda to fight poverty and discrimination, but it is not so very long ago that she was at the very heart of the system which she now attacks so virulently.

The daughter of a Greek journalist, she first came to the public attention as president of the Cambridge Union. She wrote The Female Woman, attacking feminism for ignoring women's "special needs" of children and family, and was promoted by the right as their response to Germaine Greer. In the 70s, she went out with Times columnist Bernard Levin, at a time when he enjoyed the same sort of celebrity in the UK that she does now in the US.

She moved to New York, met and in 1986 married Texas oil billionaire Michael Huffington; her bridesmaids included a Getty, a Roosevelt and a star television interviewer, Barbara Walters. She helped Huffington win office as a carpetbagging Republican congressman in Santa Barbara, California, by spending a then record $5.4m on campaigning. This was followed by an even more expensive ($30m) but ill-fated bid for a Senate seat in 1994 by Huffington against the liberal incumbent, Diane Feinstein. In the meantime, Arianna became one of Washington's best-known hostesses and there was even talk of Michael Huffington seeing if he could buy his way into the White House. But there was no comeback after the disastrous Senate race and, in 1998, the couple parted, with Michael, following years of "no comments" on his sexuality, coming out as gay. He has now joined the Democrats.

Apart from all the politics and the parties, Arianna wrote six books, including biographies of Maria Callas and Aristotle Onassis, both accused of plagiarism. She became a syndicated columnist, a talk show regular, and a television satirist. She had also been been associated with John Roger, the controversial leader of the Movement for Spiritual Awareness. Her friends admired her energy, generosity and determination. Her enemies saw her as calculating, manipulative and ferociously ambitious, the real puff behind Michael Huffington and "the most upwardly mobile Greek since Icarus".

Then came her dramatic disillusionment. She left Washington with her two young daughters for Brentwood in Los Angeles, started holding the most glittering of the area's political salons, throwing book launch parties for the likes of Jesse Jackson and Jesse Ventura, the wrestler-turned-governor of Minnesota, and effectively sparking off the idea of actor-director Warren Beatty running for president to promote the progressive agenda. Now comes the new book and a call to people to engage in acts of civil disobedience and take to the streets.

Arianna says that anyone who has been reading her columns over the past five years will know that what has happened to her thinking is "no overnight flip-flop", that she considered herself "fooled, seduced, blinded" by Gingrich and that she now has no political heroes at all. Her move came partly, she says, when she realised that the super-rich were happy to put their hands in their pockets for a fashionable museum or for the opera, but less interested in wanting to help the homeless and impoverished. So is she serious?

Marc Cooper, who writes for the country's main radical weekly, the Nation, and broadcasts daily on LA's most radical radio station, KPFK, reckons she is very much for real. "Arianna is no dummy and no dilettante. Her politics have always been iconoclastic. Yes, she was a conservative Republican but there was always a quirkiness to it." She had always shown a concern about the poor, he said: "It might have been noblesse oblige but it was certainly not, 'Let them eat cake.' If you read her columns over the last few years, you will see a consistent political journey from knee-jerk Republican towards a kind of progressive populist position. Her commitment is real. She doesn't close the door at night and have a good laugh and say, 'That will have sold some books.' She is a great listener, her mind is open, she is not afraid to revise her opinion and she's taking risks."

David Corn is the Washington editor of the Nation. He met Arianna half a dozen years ago when she was still committed to the so-called Republican Revolution which claimed it would see the poor being empowered by their policies. "I wasn't favourably impressed. I thought she was trying to ride that wave." Then, says Corn, she started challenging the Republican establishment over its failure to deliver. "She showed a certain amount of backbone, but backbone is easier to have if you're married to a millionaire."

Corn, who had been relentless in his attacks on Gingrich, started getting calls from her congratulating him on his broadsides at the time that her marriage was starting to unravel and she was moving to Los Angeles. "She got a physical distance from the Republican crowd and kept following this path of thinking what was wrong with the system." Corn reckons she has the typical "fervour of the convert, particularly an intelligent convert ... she became quite passionate in her advocacy and did not shy away from the obvious conclusions." Both Corn and Cooper say she is putting her money where her mouth is, channelling funds to organisations she supports.

Ellen Miller of Public Campaign, which was set up in 1997 to campaign for full public funding of politicians so that they would be removed from the corruption of the corporate backing, is also an Arianna admirer: "She's an extremely capable and intelligent woman and she's extremely important to us." As a former big-name Republican, she gives the campaign an extra credibility and is one of the 100 members of its advisory board.

Bob Scheer, who writes from the left in the LA Times and who shared a platform with her at the Santa Monica event, also admires Arianna's change of heart - although, as a Democrat, he does not buy the notion of everyone starting new parties and taking to the streets. She could, suggests political writer Joe Conason in his review of her book, become "California's answer to Jesse Ventura, especially if everyone remembers to forget about the past".

Not everyone is impressed. The Nation columnist Katha Pollitt has accused Arianna of "repackaging" herself. To which Corn has replied: "Some lefties, alas, would rather have targets than allies, maintain enemies rather than welcome converts." Other critics find her solutions facile. They cite her west coast New Agery - "think of family volunteering as aerobics for the soul" - and her suggestions to people to "start a new party" as if that were a simple solution to the crisis in American politics. Her old Republican allies regard her as an "opportunistic turncoat", says Corn. And some critics, like Conason, wonder how her new-found detestation of salaciousness in politics squares with the woman who chatted with such relish every night on television during the Monica Lewinksky affair.

So where does she go from here? Would she really fancy being governor of California? How big a part does she want to play? She is not yet 50 - her announcement of an impending birthday in July at the Santa Monica meeting drew appreciative gasps - and she has the media at her feet. Over the next six months or so, leading up to the presidential elections, she will be be able to enter the arena whenever she wants and many candidates would welcome her endorsement as well as her hors d'oeuvres.

Her website, overthrowthegov.com, shows a cartoon of a tall, elegant red-haired woman at a party being told by a man: "Personally, I think things are fine just as they are." At which point the woman throws the chap over her shoulder, sending his Martini glass flying. Whether the new Arianna Huffington can sling the corrupt American political body over her shoulder on behalf of all of those people who are mad as hell, we shall have to wait and see.

fields.headline: National Roundup
fields.trailText: Case over kicked dog dropped
fields.body:
Case over kicked dog dropped

A postman accused of kicking a dog which had to be put down has had the case against him dismissed because he is too ill to stand trial.

Billy Ace, 46, collapsed in the witness box before Swansea magistrates last week as he answered charges of causing unnecessary suffering to a Yorkshire terrier which was kicked 13ft across a patio and landed on its head.

Jon Tarrant, prosecuting, said the RSPCA had agreed to drop the charges after hearing that it would be up to three months before Mr Ace was fit to give evidence.

He complained of feeling unwell after being in the witness box for 10 minutes on the second day of the trial. He was taken to hospital with an irregular heartbeat and discharged after four days.

The court had heard that the three-year-old terrier, Ria, who weighed two pounds, was the pet of Alexandria East, six, of Mumbles, near Swansea. The dog had to be put down.

In a statement yesterday Mr Ace, who had told the court he had been trying to defend himself after the dog bit him, said he was delighted the RSPCA had dropped a prosecution he believed should never have been brought.

"I have maintained that my actions were reasonable," he said. "The dog was aggressive and on occasions out of control. I regret that the dog died. It was never my intention, and I again offer my sympathies to the owners, who were understandably distraught."

Alexandria's father, Neil East, had told magistrates that he approached Mr Ace to get the dog, which was barking around his feet, but he kicked her hard.

The post office said no further action would be taken against Mr Ace. - Geoffrey Gibbs

Four held over acid attack

Police were yesterday questioning four men in connection with a doorstep acid attack four years ago that left a teenage babysitter scarred for life. Beverley Hammett was 19 when concentrated nitric acid was thrown in her face, almost blinding her, as she answered the door of a house in Seaton, Devon in July 1996.

She was babysitting for the owner, Susan Humphrey, whom police believe was the intended victim.

Mrs Humphrey's estranged husband Peter Humphrey, who was said to be obsessively jealous, denied involvement but was jailed for 12 years at Exeter crown court in March 1998 after a jury found him guilty of aiding and abetting a person or persons unknown to cause grievous bodily harm to his wife. His appeal against conviction was rejected.

The four men were arrested early yesterday in a joint operation by officers from Devon and Cornwall, Avon and Somerset and North Wales police.

A man of 51 was arrested in Seaton. Two others, aged 47 and 28, were picked up at separate addresses in Yeovil. A 28-year-old man from Holyhead was also detained. - Geoffrey Gibbs

Motorbikes 'ruining rare habitats'

A leading wildlife agency yesterday criticised motorcycle scramblers who turned rare wildlife habitats into a "lunar landscapes".

English Nature said off-road motorcycles had damaged large areas of several sites of special scientific interest - protected areas of countryside. It welcomed government plans to tackle the problem of third party damage to SSSIs in the countryside and rights of way bill, which yesterday got a second reading in the Commons.

English Nature's chairwoman, Lady Young of Old Scone, said: "These proposed powers are just what we have been pushing for.

"Problems often arise on SSSIs which are common land where people are mistaken in thinking they can do what they like. This is a great improvement to the current system."

The agency said off-road motorcycling had damaged large areas of several SSSIs over recent months including two important heathlands in Berkshire and Bedfordshire.

Parts of these two sites had been reduced to a lunar landscape of bare earth and mud by continuous motorcycle scrambling, it said.

Owners and land managers of SSSIs around the country also faced arson, abandonment of vehicles and fly-tipping. Under the bill, damaging an SSSI would be an offence, English Nature said.

Currently the agency has to apply for a nature conservation order before action can be taken.

Orkney gets huge wind generators

Construction of what will be Britain's tallest wind generator began yesterday on Burgar Hill in Orkney.

The machine, one of two being built on the site, will stand on a 215ft tower and have a 236ft propeller.

Getting the components for the turbines, manufactured in Denmark, to Burgar Hill from Kirkwall involves the biggest road haulage operation ever undertaken on the Orkney islands. Road junctions have had to be altered and corners widened along the 20-mile route.

The two machines, able to generate a quarter of Orkney's electricity needs, are due to be operational in May, but building work, by the Danish company NEG Micon, has to be completed before rare red-throated divers start nesting on a nature reserve of the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds.

Solicitor's £175,000 theft spree

A solicitor who stole more than £175,000 from his clients to fund his passion for luxury cars has been jailed for three years and eight months.

Stuart Nelson, 48, raided the accounts set up for the beneficiaries of mainly elderly widows while executing their wills and holding power of attorney over their affairs.

The cars he bought included a Bentley Turbo for £48,000 and a Jaguar XJ12 for £29,338 during his five-year spree. Nelson initially denied 15 charges of stealing a total of £299,367, but his trial earlier this month was halted when he changed his plea to guilty to 10 charges of theft totalling £178,930.

A jury at Norwich crown court was discharged from giving verdicts on the remaining five charges of theft and they were ordered to remain on file. Judge David Mellor told him on Monday that he had "besmirched" his profession and brought disgrace and hardship on himself and his family.

He added: "You devoted much of your professional skills to pillaging clients' accounts and covering your tracks over a substantial period of years."

The judge said that Nelson's depression was not an excuse for the thefts and an aggravating feature was that the crimes were carefully planned.

Nelson, a married father of two who was also a scoutmaster, earned £33,000 a year as a salaried partner with the law firm Metcalfe, Copeman and Pettefar in King's Lynn, Norfolk.

Nelson was dismissed from the firm where he had worked for 24 years after auditors discovered his financial irregularities. The firm said all those cheated had been reimbursed by the company's insurers.

webTitle: Creamed off Abbey abandons herd as milk prices plummet

fields.headline: Creamed off Abbey abandons herd as milk prices plummet
fields.trailText: A herd of cows at an ancient abbey has fallen victim to the dairy farming crisis, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
A herd of cows at an ancient abbey has fallen victim to the dairy farming crisis, it emerged yesterday.

Ampleforth abbey in North Yorkshire has decided to close its dairy unit and sell its 190 cows because of falling milk prices.

A report last week warned that the dairy industry was facing "meltdown" because of the price of milk, which has fallen by a third in three years and is at its lowest since records began in 1970.

The Ampleforth herd, once said to be the largest under one roof in the north-east, produced milk and the Abbey brand of yoghurt for consumption at the abbey and its famous school, Ampleforth college. Produce from the farm, which has been operating for nearly 100 years, was also sold to the public.

Peter Bryan, procurator at the abbey, said the operation had to close. Since demand from the monks and the school had declined and milk prices were falling, losses were forecast to continue.

In the past four years more than 4,200 dairy farms have gone out of production - 16% of the UK's total. Farmers receive an average of less than 10p a pint, with consumers paying around 34p.

 Nearly 100 West Country farmers picketed the Unigate distribution plant in Totnes, Devon, yesterday in protest at the low milk price for dairy farmers.

The picket, organised by rogue farmers' union Farmers for Action, allowed tankers to enter, but only deliveries for schools were allowed to leave the plant, which produces 300m litres of milk a year.

The organiser, Richard Haddock, said: "Farmers are only getting 15p per litre of milk. This is below cost, and is driving this industry to its knees."

He said Tesco had agreed to come to terms with the union on the price of milk. "The supermarkets are finally realising that we have power. But until we get things in writing we shall continue to demonstrate it, at every milk plant in the country."

fields.headline: Stress 'led mother to kill baby'
fields.trailText: A mother who could not cope with the demands of being a single parent smothered her 10-week-old baby, Chester crown court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A mother who could not cope with the demands of being a single parent smothered her 10-week-old baby, Chester crown court heard yesterday.

Gaynor Thomas, 37, was under a lot of stress when she killed her son Dominick in March last year, the court heard. Thomas, of Ellesmere Port, Cheshire, has pleaded not guilty to manslaughter.

Robin Spencer QC, prosecuting, said: "There is no doubt that Dominick died from asphyxiation - his breathing was obstructed. The prosecution say that the defendant smothered him.

"It is not suggested that she intended to kill him or even to do him really serious harm, but for some reason she assaulted him by deliberately and unlawfully covering his face or pressing his face against something which stopped his breathing.

"There is no doubt that the defendant found it difficult to cope as a single parent and social workers were involved with the family. She found life a struggle, she seems constantly to have been in debt."

Dominick had been visited 10 times by health visitors and had been seen twice by doctors. He was pronounced dead at the Countess of Chester hospital in March last year.

A postmortem examination indicated that his breathing may have been obstructed on a previous occasion. In November 1998, six weeks before his birth, Thomas was visited by a health visitor and a social worker. She told them that the pregnancy was not planned. On other occasions, she told them she was having difficulties coping as a single parent.

During a stay in hospital, her neighbours attempted to clean up her house, which was dirty and squalid, said Mr Spencer.

He said the baby may have been killed because he was fractious and crying. His mother had a drinking problem and had drunk probably a litre of cider that evening, he said.

The postmortem examination found that Dominick's injuries included a fractured rib, a fracture to his skull and bruising on his head. There was evidence of old bleeding in his lungs, which indicated his breathing had been obstructed before.

"Surely this fatal episode which ended Dominick's life so tragically was not the first time that he had suffered physical abuse in her care," said Mr Spencer.

He urged the jury to put aside their emotions when considering the evidence surrounding the baby's death.

The trial continues today.

webTitle: Water quality at risk as UK attempts dilution of EU law

fields.headline: Water quality at risk as UK attempts dilution of EU law
fields.trailText: Plans to prevent chemicals suspected of causing birth defects and cancer from being released into the environment are being held up by the government which wants to water down new European laws.
fields.body:
Plans to prevent chemicals suspected of causing birth defects and cancer from being released into the environment are being held up by the government which wants to water down new European laws.

If EU ministers agree, farmers and chemical and water companies will be forced to progressively clean up contamination of rivers, lakes, canals and underground aquifers over 20 years. But Britain merely wishes companies to "aim" to achieve reductions in chemical releases.

Critics believe this approach will weaken the measures so as to make them virtually useless. Behind Britain's attempts to strip the proposed EU directive of legal force is the fear that the UK will be prosecuted by the European court if it fails to carry out its duties. The environment department has been stung by a recent decision to prosecute the UK for a second time over sewage contamination of Blackpool beaches. The government has again failed to meet EU standards for water quality at the Lancashire resort.

For years the department has being trying to rid Britain of the "dirty man of Europe" tag acquired under Lady Thatcher's regime and it fears a tough water directive would lead to more prosecution.

Civil servants believe that a green lobby in Britain continues to conspire with Brussels to make the UK an easy target for the European court.

The environment minister, Michael Meacher, has ordered a review of policy after meeting the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds and the World Wide Fund for Nature. Environmental groups have told Mr Meacher that since the the directive replaces some existing European law it will make environmental protection weaker, not stronger.

Graham Wynne, chief executive of the RSPB, said civil servants had "taken all the legally binding obligations out and the timetables needed to achieve them".

Papers leaked to the Guardian reveal British attempts to dilute the EU water framework directive have been under way for months. Labour MEPs were instructed by Millbank to oppose 32 of 33 amendments designed to tighten the laws proposed by Europe. Many, however, were incensed at the interference and are pushing for "member states [to] ensure" that all countries "progressively eliminate pollution of waters" so that by 2020 discharges cease - in line with an agreement made by 12 of the EU states, including Britain, 18 months ago.

Environmental groups have accused Mr Meacher of going back on the deal he signed.

webTitle: Orangemen invited to march in Dublin

fields.headline: Orangemen invited to march in Dublin
fields.standfirst:
Sinn Fein furious as order accepts mayor's request to join ceremony

Northern Ireland: special report
Sinn Fein homepage
Grand Orange Lodge of Ireland
fields.trailText: Orangemen are to march in Dublin for the first time in more than half a century after the Irish capital's lord mayor invited them to attend a ground breaking ceremony there in May.
fields.body:
Orangemen are to march in Dublin for the first time in more than half a century after the Irish capital's lord mayor invited them to attend a ground breaking ceremony there in May.

Mary Freehill said she wanted to promote reconciliation, and was pleased that the Orange Order had accepted her invitation to unveil a plaque marking the organisation's foundation in Dublin in 1798. But Sinn Fein reacted with fury.

The march, which will be headed by the small Dublin and County Wicklow Lodge, will take place just before the contentious marching season gets under way in Northern Ireland.

It will be confined to Dawson Street in Dublin city centre, where the Grand Lodge of Ireland was founded.

Organiser Ian Cox said they would be keeping the march small. There would be bands playing hymns, but there would be no triumphalism. It would be an experiment to gauge the mood towards further parades.

Ms Freehill said she was looking forward to the event. The Orange Order represented an important part of Irish culture and had the right to parade in Dublin. She expected there would be little controversy.

But Sinn Fein was angry. One of its city councillors, Larry O'Toole, said: "The Orange Order can't be divorced from the siege of the Garvaghy Road and other controversial sieges in the six counties. It should not be allowed to march in Dublin while those situations are ongoing."

The Orange Order in Portadown has mounted a protest on Drumcree Hill just outside the County Armagh town for almost two years after it was refused permission to march down the nationalist Garvaghy Road. This year's march is due to take place on July 2, although the parades commission will again adjudicate.

The Orange Order has one annual march in the Irish republic. It meets at Rossnowlagh in County Donegal, and the event always passes off without trouble. David Jones, spokesman for the Orange Order of Portadown, welcomed the Dublin initiative.

He said it was ironic Orangemen could be invited to march in the republic while having their rights to parade blocked in Northern Ireland.

Relations between the Orange Order and the Irish authorities are improving. Grand master Robert Saulters last month visited Irish prime minister Bertie Ahern in Dublin and also met the president, Mary McAleese.

Sinn Fein said the Orange Order would use the event for propaganda purposes. It urged an urgent debate within the city council.

Christy Burke leader of the Sinn Fein group, said: "It is hard not to believe that the Orange Order is using this event to boast of their demand to be allowed to bulldoze their way down the Garvaghy Road in July.

"The Orange Order that wants to march in Dublin is the very same Orange Order that is laying siege to Garvaghy Road and seeking to impose its will on nationalist communities throughout the six counties."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Father held on death charges
fields.body:
Father held on death charges

A man accused of murdering his two children and their mother appeared at Slough magistrates court, Berkshire, yesterday. Zainulabedin Zaidi, 34, made no application for bail and the case was adjourned until next Tuesday.

The charges follow the discovery of the bodies of Shazia Zaidi, Zaidi's former wife, and their children Saba, seven, and Zeeshan, six, at a house in Bracknell.

Child crushed by drawers dies

A boy aged two died in hospital after a chest of drawers fell on him at his home in Leamington Spa, Warwickshire police said yesterday. Police said the child had been alone in a bedroom and they were not treating the incident as suspicious.

Ex-IRA man granted bail

Angelo Fusco, a former member of the IRA challenging extradition to Northern Ireland over the killing of SAS Captain Herbert Westmacott 20 years ago, was yesterday given bail by the Irish high court. He was freed from prison on his own surety of IR£500 and two independent sureties of IR£5,000. He was ordered to surrender his passport.

fields.headline: Ovarian cancer screening on trial
fields.standfirst:
Cancer Research Campaign
Ovarian Cancer Coalition
Medline plus - Ovarian cancer
fields.trailText: More than 200,000 women are to be invited to take part in a trial of ovarian cancer screening, which campaigners hope will prove that a national programme in the UK would save thousands of lives.
fields.body:
More than 200,000 women are to be invited to take part in a trial of ovarian cancer screening, which campaigners hope will prove that a national programme in the UK would save thousands of lives.

The trial, in 12 regions, will cost £22m and is being funded by a number of organisations, led by the Medical Research Council, the Cancer Research Campaign and the Imperial Cancer Research Fund. It has taken campaigning organisations and concerned doctors many years to get to this point.

Ovarian cancer is seldom detected before it spreads to other organs. By that time, it is too late for most women. More than 70% will die within five years. More than 100 women die from ovarian cancer every week in the UK - 5,000 a year.

Yesterday Ian Jacobs, professor of gynaecological cancer surgery at Queen Mary and Westfield College, London, who will head the trial, said it was possible to halve the death toll by screening post-menopausal women, the group most likely to get the disease.

"What we think is realistic is to work towards reducing the number of deaths by 50%, so that only 30-35% of those diagnosed will die," he said.

Two methods of detecting an ovarian tumour will be used - an ultrasound scan which can show changes in the size, shape and texture of the ovaries and a blood test which will reveal the presence of a substance called CA125 released by the tumour into the bloodstream. Half the women will be screened each year using one of these methods. The remaining 100,000 will be monitored but not screened.

By the end of the trial, enough information will have been amassed to show whether screening saves lives. Scientists must establish that tumours are detected early enough to make a difference and that women are willing to be tested every year.

Politicians will then have to decide whether the benefits of screening will justify the huge expense. Critics of the breast cancer and cervical cancer screening programmes have suggested the money spent on them could be better used.

Professor Jacobs agreed that the costs of ovarian cancer screening would be enormous. "But it seems that the implications of taking on an ovarian cancer screening programme will be similar to breast cancer or cervical cancer."

fields.trailText: The singer formerly known as Cat Stevens released his first album for 22 years in the House of Lords yesterday, with a broadside against moral degeneracy and the repeal of section 28.
fields.body:
The singer formerly known as Cat Stevens released his first album for 22 years in the House of Lords yesterday, with a broadside against moral degeneracy and the repeal of section 28.

The new album, a double CD called A is for Allah, consists of children's songs about Islam and recitations from the Koran.

London-born Stevens, who since becoming a Muslim 23 years ago has been known as Yusuf Islam, said the Lords had become one of the last bulwarks of moral principles because of its opposition to repeal of the section which forbids the promotion of homosexuality in schools.

The government intends to introduce a clause stressing morality in teaching about family relationships this week in an attempt to overturn the Lords' defeat of its attempt to repeal section 28.

Yusuf said: "We have to turn the moral agenda in education upside down; bringing back morality is vital. Kids need an alternative to rock'n'roll. [Section 28] is part of the deterioration of moral statutes we are witnessing every day."

fields.headline: Met accused as case collapses
fields.standfirst:
Assault charge against Stephen Lawrence friend thrown out: Duwayne Brooks says police are harassing him

Stephen Lawrence: special report
fields.trailText: Lawyers for Duwayne Brooks accused Scotland Yard of suppressing a crucial statement that yesterday led to a sex assault charge against him being dropped at the Old Bailey.
fields.body:
Lawyers for Duwayne Brooks accused Scotland Yard of suppressing a crucial statement that yesterday led to a sex assault charge against him being dropped at the Old Bailey.

Mr Brooks, 25, was with Stephen Lawrence on the night the teenager was murdered by a racist gang in April 1993. The collapse of yesterday's case means that Mr Brooks has been arrested by police six times since the murder without being convicted in what he alleges is harassment.

The judge yesterday halted the trial of Mr Brooks before it even got before a jury, after the defence argued that continuing the prosecution for indecent assault would be an abuse of process.

The case collapsed after evidence emerged of a statement made to police by a mediator appointed to help the 18-year-old alleged victim, in which doubt was cast on the teenager's account. Mr Brooks's lawyers are angry that this statement was not revealed to them for two months.

After hearing a day of legal argument, Judge David Stokes QC ordered that the prosecution be halted because it would be unfair to to let the case go before a jury.

The case against Mr Brooks rested solely on the alleged victim's account. The reliability of that was potentially undermined by the statement made to police by the mediator, Augusta Gibrill.

She saw the victim 11 times after the alleged attack was first reported to police on September 16 1999, a fortnight after the teenager said the assault had occurred. By November 3 Miss Gibrill had become concerned about the reliability of the complainant. The mediator told an investigating officer that the alleged victim had said Mr Brooks had not assaulted her and that she had made it up.

The mediator later altered this, saying that when she asked the alleged victim if she had made up the allegation, the teenager had neither confirmed nor denied the suggestion. Miss Gibrill never signed her police statement, but was allowed to remain in her post as a mediator for several weeks. She agreed to talk to defence lawyers and again would not sign her statement, rendering it useless.

'Series of errors'

The Macpherson report into the Stephen Lawrence murder called for police to use mediators to liaise with black crime victims. Miss Gibrill was the first such appointment.

A pre-trial hearing was told that the alleged victim's mother claimed that her daughter was being used by police to get at Mr Brooks. The mediator was appointed by the Greenwich area commander Peter Zieminski and briefed over lunch - which was "not appropriate", the judge said.

Judge Stokes said Miss Gibrill had been appointed with the best of motives in mind, but had not been properly briefed on what to do. He said: "The fact is that the prosecution have caused this situation by a series of errors and misjudgments."

Judge Stokes said no notes had been kept by the mediator of conversations with the complainant and added: "She was told not to coach the complainant but she ignored that advice."

The crown prosecution service had initially charged Mr Brooks with rape, but dropped this before the case came to the crown court.

Judge Stokes said he had no choice but to halt the trial for indecent assault. "Bearing in mind the potential conflicts and inconsistencies demonstrated on the face of the papers between that potential witness and the complainant it would indeed be unfair to try this defendant and therefore I propose to stay these proceedings."

Mr Brooks described the judge's decision as a victory for justice. "I have never done anything wrong. If we had gone to trial I would have stated that in my evidence," he said. "The judge agreed with defence counsel that the failings of the police and prosecution would not have allowed me to have a fair trial. All this public money wasted. All these taxpayers' money wasted."

Mr Brooks's solicitor, Jane Deighton, said: "The crucial statement was suppressed for two months by the police and/ or the CPS. The prosecution of Duwayne has to be looked at in the context of his role over the last six years, where he is the surviving victim of the attack on him and Stephen Lawrence.

"From that moment he has been stereotyped by police as a villain when in fact he is a hero. Since then on at least six occasions, for no good reason, he has been arrested and released.

"This is the second time a prosecution against him has been stayed by a judge as an abuse of process. I know of no other individual to whom that has happened in my 20-year career as a defence lawyer."

Mr Brooks is already suing the Metropolitan police for the way its officers treated him after the murder of his friend Stephen Lawrence.

The report by Sir William Macpherson found that Mr Brooks had been stereotyped by officers because he was black. His lawyers said they were considering suing over the arrest for indecent assault.

Asked about the allegation that the crucial statement by the mediator was suppressed, Scotland Yard said: "At an early stage we were pressing the CPS for a decision regarding the disclosure of certain matters. We will now be discussing the issues that have arisen with them."

A Met spokeswoman said that police had carried out a "thorough and professional investigation" and added: "The officers investigating this case ensured their actions were at all times as open and transparent as possible. They worked closely with both the complainant's family and local people to maintain confidence. There were particular sensitivities involved in this case which the officers were aware of throughout the course of this investigation. We will reflect on the judge's comments and look into what has happened."

The CPS denied that it had treated Mr Brooks unfairly. A spokesman said: "The judge made no specific criticism of the CPS. There was no criticism of our decision to prosecute."

The failed prosecutions

September 16 1999 Arrested and charged with attempted rape and indecent assault. Originally refused bail by police and court. Finally bailed on September 29 on condition he resided in Birmingham. At his committal hearing on November 5 police announced they had dropped the charge of attempted rape. Yesterday an Old Bailey judge threw out the case as an abuse of process.

August 17 1999 Arrested in Peckham, south London, for taking and driving away a car and threatening behaviour. Taken to Peckham police station and bailed until August 6, when police notified him that they were taking no further action.

July 4 1999 Stopped by police in in his car, which was searched. A photocopying tool was found (he works as a photocopying engineer). Police alleged it was an offensive weapon and charged him with possession of a bladed article. They also found credit cards and chequebooks in the car and he was arrested for handling stolen goods. He was bailed to appear before Tower Bridge magistrates. The case was discontinued on August 3.

July 8 1998 Stopped under the Prevention of Terrorism Act in the City of London. Searched and arrested for possession of a knife and theft of a credit card. Bailed from the police station and when he returned on August 4 was charged with possession of an offensive weapon. The action was discontinued in September after his employer confirmed the knife was part of his work toolkit.

May 27 1998 Police requested an interview about an allegation of kidnapping at Catford station. He was bailed until July 23 when police announced that they were taking no further action.

October 1993 Surrendered voluntarily to Bexleyheath police station, where he was charged under section 2 of the Criminal Justice Act, relating to an allegation of violent disorder at a British National party march. Eventually the proceedings were stayed on December 13 1994 after the judge ruled an abuse of process. The judge had invited the CPS to discontinue the case earlier, but it refused to do so.

fields.headline: Solitary 'makes dangerous inmates worse'
fields.standfirst: Chief inspector of prisons finds the long term confinement of Britain's toughest prisoners is jeopardising their mental health
fields.trailText: The long term confinement of the hard core of Britain's most dangerous prisoners in solitary punishment cells is jeopardising their mental health and making them more disruptive, according to a report published today by the chief inspector of prisons.
fields.body:
The long term confinement of the hard core of Britain's most dangerous prisoners in solitary punishment cells is jeopardising their mental health and making them more disruptive, according to a report published today by the chief inspector of prisons.

Sir David Ramsbotham said the two year experiment in the creation of two close supervision centres, or special units, at Woodhill prison, near Milton Keynes, and at Durham prison had produced mixed results. While a small group of 11 had conformed and progressed, a much larger group, involving about 30 inmates, had continued to resist and their behaviour had worsened.

An official inspection report on the special units published today also revealed that seven "high control cells" have been established in Britain's maximum security prisons in which the most disruptive inmates are given a "56 day lie-in" as punishment or simply to give relief to staff.

The director general of the prison service, Martin Narey, last night justified the practice, saying it was having to deal with a small number of inmates who had murdered other prisoners, in one case had killed a member of staff, and who continually assaulted other inmates and took hostages.

"We need to find a way of holding them in conditions which are acceptable and which do not reward outrageous and dangerous behaviour," he said. "No other country has yet managed to solve this problem."

The chief inspector said there was a question mark over whether the legal powers existed to hold inmates for up to 56 days in those conditions. His report questioned the legality of the isolation of inmates in the Woodhill special unit in similar punishment cells for indefinite periods.

So far 53 prisoners have been detained in such conditions, in one case for 206 days at Woodhill where the period of isolation is open-ended.

The main fear of those involved was reported to be "losing their minds", and the inspection report recommended that the unlimited isolation of inmates in punishment cells should cease.

The prisoners involved are locked up for 23 hours a day in a basic cell with a mattress on a raised concrete plinth, cardboard furniture, a sink, toilet and a small mirror. No contact is allowed with other prisoners and they are not even allowed a radio. All contact with the outside world is through a hatch in the door and when they are unlocked for exercise they are met by six officers in full riot gear.

"They do not have human contact with staff except for people in riot gear," Sir David said yesterday.

The close supervision centres were set up in 1998 with the aim of combining containment with therapy.

They replaced the prison service "merry-go-round" under which the most difficult inmates were kept in perpetual solitary confinement by being shunted from one jail to another every 28 days.

But the chief inspector's report made it clear that although the staff in Woodhill CSC were highly professional, they had so far been unable to address clinical mental health needs.

Staff at Woodhill had "weathered extreme challenges to their authority in the early months, and at the time of our inspection were divided in their belief that the system could succeed with some prisoners.

"In contrast, the staff at Durham's I wing had grown in confidence, as they managed to build an impressive unit for CSC prisoners with acknowledged mental health needs," the inspection report said.

Inmates who make progress at Woodhill "graduate" to the I wing at Durham in the hope they will be transferred eventually to the main prison system.

Mr Narey said the prison service would amend the rules to clarify the legality of the use of segregation but he was confident a legal challenge from the prisoners would not succeed in the courts.

He said the special units had proved successful for two prisoners who had been returned to the main prison system and for a further seven who were also on the brink of being transferred.

"No other country has found the answer to this problem. In the close supervision centres we have only 40 prisoners, in the United States they have more than 18,000 in such conditions."

Danger criminals in the special units

Charles Bronson has spent the past 26 years in prison for armed robbery, of which 22 have been in solitary confinement after repeated hostage taking, twice leading rooftop protests, and more than 20 assaults on officers. Given a further life sentence in February for an hostage incident in Hull. Now back in Woodhill.

Robert Maudsley, known as Hannibal the Cannibal. Jailed in 1974 for stabbing and garotting his uncle. He killed again in Broadmoor special hospital in 1977 and killed two in Wakefield prison. In one case he cut off his victim's head.

Rifat Mehmet, from Walworth, south London, serving 27 years for armed robbery. Convicted in 1983 of carrying two loaded automatic pistols during a raid on a store in Neasden, north London. During his getaway he fired three shots. Escaped from a prison van with the help of an armed accomplice in 1986 during which he attacked a prison officer with a Stanley knife.

Warren Slaney, former professional boxer from Leicester. Life sentence for double murder in which he shot the owner of a hot dog business and his assistant in 1990.

Reginald Wilson was given a life sentence after clubbing to death a doctor in 1990 in Middlesbrough. Boasted he had committed the perfect crime.

Michael Sams, now in Durham close supervision centre. Given four life sentences for murder and five years ago attempted to strangle a probation officer.

webTitle: Ministers split over British role in US missile defence shield

fields.headline: Ministers split over British role in US missile defence shield
fields.trailText: A rift has opened between the Ministry of Defence and the Foreign Office over US plans for a "son of star wars" missile defence shield in which the early warning radar base in Fylingdales, North Yorkshire, would play a crucial role.
fields.body:
A rift has opened between the Ministry of Defence and the Foreign Office over US plans for a "son of star wars" missile defence shield in which the early warning radar base in Fylingdales, North Yorkshire, would play a crucial role.

The plan has already caused discord in the Nato alliance, with many of the European allies arguing that it would unleash a new arms race.

The split within the British government came to light during a visit to Westminster on Monday by Michael Douglas, Hollywood actor and UN "messenger of peace". He raised concerns with ministers over Washington's plans for the national missile defence system.

The Foreign Office minister, Peter Hain, warned of the "potential conflict of interests" between the missile defence project and the anti-ballistic missile treaty, which puts limits on the US and Russia.

But the defence secretary, Geoffrey Hoon, asked on Channel 4 News how Britain would respond if the US asked to use the Fylingdales base, said: "The history of our close friendship with the US is that we are sympathetic to such requests."

Mr Hain told BBC2's Newsnight: "I don't like the idea of a star wars programme, limited or unlimited. Unilateral moves by Washington would be very damaging."

The US defence department has made it clear it is a question of when the system goes ahead, not if. It has submitted proposals to extend it to defend the US against missiles fired from the Middle East, Africa, west Asia and North Korea.

fields.trailText: Blood donors throughout the European Union are to be asked if they have visited Britain or other countries with BSE so that scientists can assess the risk of them spreading the human form of the disease, CJD.
fields.body:
Blood donors throughout the European Union are to be asked if they have visited Britain or other countries with BSE so that scientists can assess the risk of them spreading the human form of the disease, CJD.

Medical advisers to the European commission say checks should be made on all British meat exports for 16 years up to 1996 and on the dangers of transmission of other diseases through blood transfusions before deciding whether to ban donations from people who have stayed in BSE-affected countries.

EU-wide blood controls may be introduced, including the filtering of white blood cells from donations, since these are thought most likely to carry the infective agent of CJD.

EU scientists accept there is no proof this will help cut the risk of transmission of CJD, despite the fact Britain already does it as a precaution.

The Department of Health last night expressed scepticism over whether EU-wide bans would make blood any safer.

The latest recommendations from the commission's medical products and medical devices committee reflect the difficulty in balancing the potential risks of transmitting the incurable CJD with the consequences bans on potential donors could have on blood supplies. There currently is a world shortage of blood.

There is no proven or even probable case of CJD having been passed on through blood transfusions.

There is as yet no test for identifying CJD in people's blood and no ethical code on whether people who might be identified as having it before symptoms occur should be told of the diagnosis.

webTitle: Two arrested in Lawrence murder investigation

fields.headline: Two arrested in Lawrence murder investigation
fields.standfirst: Stephen Lawrence: special report
fields.trailText: Two people were arrested last night in connection with the racist murder of Stephen Lawrence, the teenager stabbed as he waited for a bus in Eltham, south London, seven years ago.
fields.body:
Two people were arrested last night in connection with the racist murder of Stephen Lawrence, the teenager stabbed as he waited for a bus in Eltham, south London, seven years ago.

Sources with knowledge of the police investigation said the development in the long-running saga was "significant".

The arrests came on the same night that Stephen's parents, Doreen and Neville Lawrence, and the head of the Metropolitan police's racial and violent crimes task force, Deputy Assistant Commissioner John Grieve, in making an appeal for fresh information on their son's murder on the BBC's Crimewatch programme.

A Scotland Yard spokeswoman said: "Two men were arrested this evening in connection with the murder. They are currently in custody in a south London police station."

The arrest of new suspects did not come as a result of the television appeal but was announced by Mr Grieve in Crimewatch Update.

Both of those arrested were white males in their 20s. One was arrested in Scotland, the other in south-east London. They will be questioned later today and are believed to be known to the five prime suspects in the murder.

In another significant development, it is believed that other suspects previously investigated in connection with the murder were arrested on suspicion of helping illegal immigrants into the country.

Kent police said: "We can confirm that five men were arrested yesterday morning in connection with an investigation by Kent special branch and immigration officials into the facilitation of illegal immigrants." Mr Grieve also said that new forensic techniques had given fresh impetus to the inquiry - further tests will also be carried out on a knife and a coat found close to the murder scene - and that police were "very close" to iden tifying a potentially vital witness who was at the scene.

A source said last night: "Tonight is the most optimistic police have been for three years over catching the killers."

fields.headline: Legendary editor wins life award
fields.trailText: Harold Evans, former Sunday Times editor, was given the gold award for achievement over a lifetime at last night's British Press Awards.
fields.body:
Harold Evans, former Sunday Times editor, was given the gold award for achievement over a lifetime at last night's British Press Awards.

Mr Evans, who writes a regular column for the Guardian, was praised for career displaying a "unique mix of style, brilliance and dramatic achievements", including scoops such as the first interview with Kim Philby.

The Observer won two awards: Ben Laurance was financial journalist of the year and Nick Paton Walsh, 22, was young journalist of the year.

Guardian journalists Maggie O'Kane, David Teather and Larry Elliott were nominated for foreign reporter, business journalist and financial journalist respectively, while Polly Toynbee was short-listed for columnist of the year.

The Sunday Telegraph wasnewspaper of the year. The News of the World took the scoop of the year prize for Lord Archer's resignation.

Feature writer of the year was Ann Treneman of the Times. Richard Dorment was named critic of the year, and Matt Pritchett the best cartoonist, both of the Daily Telegraph.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: A Kosovo Homecoming | Frontiers
fields.body:
The experiences of Illiriana Kacaniku as she returned from a refugee camp in Turkey to her Bosnian home in Mitrovica were recounted in a special feature last summer. The programme ended on an uncertain note, with Illiriana arriving to discover her home town partitioned into Serbian and Albanian enclaves. Her house was in the wrong section and NATO peacekeepers would not let her cross the line. Now, as violence continues to rack the communities, Illiriana's story continues in A Kosovo Homecoming (11.0am, Radio 4).

Dr Roger Pitman of the Harvard Medical School is one of the world's leading specialists in post-traumatic stress disor der. He is convinced that our reactions to disturbing experiences are notemotional but physical. He tells Peter Evans in this season's final edition of Frontiers (9.0pm, Radio 4) that one answer may lie in managing our hormones.

fields.headline: Class acts
fields.standfirst:
In the past few weeks the Labour party has come third in two byelections. Something will have to change before the local elections in May

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: For six years Tony Blair has enjoyed unchallenged authority in his party. Whatever their doubts about New Labour, members and activists swallowed everything from the rewriting of Clause IV to the Blair-Brown pledge not to raise income tax, because they were hungry for the electoral success Mr Blair seemed to know how to bring.
fields.body:
For six years Tony Blair has enjoyed unchallenged authority in his party. Whatever their doubts about New Labour, members and activists swallowed everything from the rewriting of Clause IV to the Blair-Brown pledge not to raise income tax, because they were hungry for the electoral success Mr Blair seemed to know how to bring.

But now there are concerns that New Labour is not a guarantor of electoral success after all. First it was Wales where Tony Blair's nominee, Alun Michael, failed to win a majority. Then it was Europe when a non-campaign gave the Tories their first nationwide success since 1992. Over the past few weeks the party has come third in two byelections in a row.

It may well be that to win elections in a modern white-collar society, Labour has to extend its appeal beyond its traditional working-class heartlands into the ever-growing middle class. But, the doubters are arguing, Labour cannot expect to keep on winning elections if, in apparently endlessly massaging the concerns of the middle class, the party forgets its appeal to "core" working-class supporters.

Claims that Labour has lost touch with its traditional vote have rested on what has been happening in predominantly working-class constituencies. When the party crashed to defeat in Europe and Wales, it lost most heavily in working-class areas. In the European elections last year, Labour's vote fell on average by 20 points in predominantly working-class seats, whereas in middle-class seats the drop was just 11 points. The Welsh strongholds of Rhondda and Islwyn were symbolically lost to Plaid Cymru.

Evidence from the British election panel survey (Beps) adds weight on the doubters' side. This survey, financed by the Economic and Social Research Council, is interviewing a panel of more than 2,000 voters on a regular basis throughout the course of this parliament. The switches of allegiance it throws up have been dramatic.

For all Labour's attempts to appeal to the middle class, it remained a recognisably working-class party in 1997. No less than 49% of the Beps panel in working-class occupations turned out for Labour, compared with just 34% of those in top salaried occupations. The class gap in Labour support had narrowed but the party still appealed more strongly to the working class.

Yet when Labour crashed to defeat in the 1999 European elections, it had lost its traditional class profile entirely. The party was no more successful at getting working- class voters to back it at the polls than it was middle-class ones. Just 12% of those in working-class occupations turned out for Labour while 13% of those in top salaried occupations did so.

Where did these lost working-class Labour voters go? Some of them stayed at home. No less than 75% of working class Beps panellists did not vote in the European parliamentary elections, compared with just 60% of those in salaried occupations. True, working-class voters were less likely to turn out in 1997 too, but what was a 9 point gap in abstention rates widened to 15 points in 1999. Overall, no less than 65% of those who backed Labour in 1997 stayed at home compared with just 54% of Conservatives.

So why did traditional Labour voters stay at home? The answer appears to be because they do not consider New Labour to be radical enough. For example, Beps panellists were asked what they thought about income redistribution. Did the government need to put greater effort into making people's incomes more equal or not? As well as asking them what they believed, they were also asked what they thought Labour's policy on redistribution was. This enabled us to identity three groups of people. One comprises those who think Labour's views on redistribution are the same as theirs. Another consists of those who think that Labour is less keen on redistribution than they themselves are. And the third contains those who think Labour is more keen on redistribution than themselves.

It turns out that Labour's problem is not that large sections of the electorate have become keener on redistribution than they think Labour are. True, this group comprises 35% of voters in 1999 compared with just 29% in 1997. But those at the other end of the spectrum, that is who are less keen on redistribution than Labour, are at 43% not only still more numerous but they have also risen somewhat from 40% in 1997.

Rather Labour's problem is with those who are keener on redistribution than they believe the party is. Apparently they no longer see any particular merit in backing Labour. In 1997, such "leftwing" voters were far more likely to turn out for Labour than were those who felt Labour were keener on redistribution than themselves - by 44% to 25%. But in 1999 "leftwing" voters, more common among the working class, were barely more likely to back Labour than were those on the "right" - just 10% to 9%.

New Labour needs to remember that its electoral success rested on a two-pronged coalition. There is no doubt it needs the support of middle-class and less radical voters. But it needs to retain its traditional voters too. And it is here that New Labour appears to have been failing. To keep the doubters at bay, Tony Blair will need to demonstrate in the local elections in May that he has begun to win those traditional voters back.

John Curtice, a professor at Strathclyde University, is deputy director of the Centre for Research into Elections and Social Trends (Crest)

fields.headline: Take no prisoners
fields.standfirst: Gladiators? It was for wimps. Robot Wars? Strictly for geeks. If you want to see human nature in all its nasty, brutish glory, only one show makes the grade - Fifteen-To-One.  Matt Lucas  is both mesmerised and repelled
fields.trailText: Gladiators? It was for wimps. Robot Wars? Strictly for geeks. If you want to see human nature in all its nasty, brutish glory, only one show makes the grade - Fifteen-To-One.
fields.body:
"You know your problem?" wrote People's Laureate Paul Heaton "You keep it all in." The British, as we are all only too aware by now, are a nation of cold, hardened, stiff-upper-lippers. And there's absolutely no reason why our daytime television should reflect anything else.

Not for us the wild outpouring of emotion that accompanies Ricki or Jerry. Our pregnant daughters, cuckolded sons, transsexual brothers and obese sisters remain behind closed doors, destined to suffer a silent eternity. If they do come out, they don't go on Trisha for their catharsis. That privilege is left to girls from, yes that's right, Essex who "are thinking about becoming a lapdancer".

Kilroy, meanwhile, is the domain of the unglamorous, where balding insomniacs, frumpy former foster children and goitered stammerers gather early to swap trite sentiments like "cheer up it might never happen" and "hope for the best, expect the worst and take what comes", while the show's silky host preens himself in his own reflection, appearing, more often than not, in the mirrored sunglasses of the prostitute and mother he is pretending to listen to, suitably ill-disguised as ever in cheap acrylic bob wig and heavy make-up. (Who is she trying to kid? We'd certainly recognise her if we knew her.) Both shows are cheap, vulgar and the biggest crime of all, dull.

Do not despair. Actually, though they don't advertise it as such, there is quality drama to be found everyday on your television. Intelligent, engrossing, cruel, triumphant, quality drama. (And no I'm not talking about Neighbours or Home And Away. Sorry kids.)

Drama being, as we all know, about conflict, there can be no bigger hotbed of conflict, no more intriguing, eclectic a group of human beings willing to trample over each other in search of success, respect, power, the final word, than on... er... Fifteen-To-One (today, 4pm). Next time you want to prove a point - maybe your football team gets relegated, or your wife divorces you, or you lose your job - contain yourself. Don't lie down in the middle of the road or take someone hostage, no road rage, no dirty protests, don't go all American Beauty on us - instead, fill in an application form to appear on the Channel 4 daytime quiz show Fifteen-To-One?

Fifteen characters, lowly folk, the unemployed, the retired, spinsters, fighting for The Light. It must not dim. Fifteen freaks there were, good and true, each slugging it out for the ultimate prize of... er... can anyone actually remember? I think it's a glass sculpture of some sort. With yer moniker engraved on it. (I hope they'd put your name on it.) Anyway, as I was saying, it's all very dramatic and that. It's kill or be killed, survival of the fittest. Fifteen people are each asked two questions, one of which they MUST get right. If they don't, the light goes out. In Monday's episode, two people said "Goodnight Vienna." Okay they didn't actually die, it's not quite Rollerball, they just sat down, but I'm trying to make it interesting for you. Look, I'm on your side! The next bit is where it does get interesting, though, because - oh how delicious, how brilliant a masterstroke - the contestants are then able to choose whether to answer a question themselves or to offer it to an opponent. Whoever gets it wrong loses a life. (Something one can ill afford to lose, trust me.) Here's where the rivalries start. Hospitality chumminess, the pre-show vol-au-vents, the backstage group bonding, the nervous chatter in the Green Room counts for NOTHING!

Why did Mary choose Chris? And when Chris got it right, why didn't he choose Mary back? Why did he go for Bernard? And what had Vera done to offend everyone?

She didn't stand a chance.

And all the while, the MC smiles benignly as Vera droops.

"Dear William G Stewart, in my hour of need, you were no help. You did not calm me, or soothe me, or comfort me. I'm a lifelong academic. I came on the show because I have a degree in History and another one in Theology. I'm a schoolteacher at a highly regarded private school. I read the broadsheets. I go to the theatre. I speak four languages. And you, you bastard, asked me a question about Stock, Aitken and bloody Waterman!"

And then there was one.

Bernard, a retired sheet metal inspector. But the glory is short-lived.

As the credits fall and the theme music plays, all is quiet. Still. Dark. He won the battle but lost the war. One hundred and fifty one points is an admirable tally. They said he'd have been fine earlier on in the series but at this late stage, it wasn't enough to get on to the finals board. So near yet so far. Oh the comedy. Oh the tragedy. Oh the irony. William G Shakespeare himself couldn't have written it.

fields.headline: Court circular
fields.standfirst: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.trailText: Who's up in front of the judge. This week: Wallace Langham | Wayne Newton
fields.body:
Well, regular readers probably thought it would never happen, but Wallace Langham - troubled star of lingerie-comedy Veronica's Closet and The Larry Sanders Show - has finally reached the end of the litigious road begun last September when he tangled with an off-duty tabloid hack in a Beverly Hills supermarket. The result? A no-contest plea to a charge of battery, after which Langham walked from court a free man. The original incident, you may recall, revolved around the actor's attack on Star reporter John Luciano after (at least in Langham's version of events) the latter insulted his girlfriend's tattoos. What really stoked the fires, however, was Langham's use of a generic anti-gay slur during the affray, a lapse which later caused prosecutors to dub the assault a hate-crime. "If I have to defend myself again, I'll wait for them to throw the first punch", remarked a relieved Langham, who now has to perform 450 hours of community service and give $10,000 to the LA Gay And Lesbian Center. Luciano's attorney Barry Goldberg, however, was less conciliatory, complaining that "[he] has still not taken personal responsibility for what he's done to my client". Watch this civil lawsuit-sized space.

Meanwhile, glutinous crooner Wayne Newton unexpectedly found himself in the midst of a courtroom bunfight in Troy, Michigan late last week, after an 18-year-old hip-hop fan was sentenced to listen to his records in lieu of jail-time. The errant b-boy, one Justin Rushford, had been charged with violating the city's noise-pollution statutes: pitching up in court on Friday, he was then given a choice between 90 days in jail (with a $500 fine attached) or listening to the Vegas lounge lizard for "at least two hours". Having accepted the second option, Rushford was due back in court today with a freshly-purchased CD of the golden-throated Newton....
