The result? A no-contest plea to a charge of battery, after which Langham walked from court a free man. The original incident, you may recall, revolved around the actor's attack on Star reporter John Luciano after (at least in Langham's version of events) the latter insulted his girlfriend's tattoos. What really stoked the fires, however, was Langham's use of a generic anti-gay slur during the affray, a lapse which later caused prosecutors to dub the assault a hate-crime. "If I have to defend myself again, I'll wait for them to throw the first punch", remarked a relieved Langham, who now has to perform 450 hours of community service and give $10,000 to the LA Gay And Lesbian Center. Luciano's attorney Barry Goldberg, however, was less conciliatory, complaining that "[he] has still not taken personal responsibility for what he's done to my client". Watch this civil lawsuit-sized space. Meanwhile, glutinous crooner Wayne Newton unexpectedly found himself in the midst of a courtroom bunfight in Troy, Michigan late last week, after an 18-year-old hip-hop fan was sentenced to listen to his records in lieu of jail-time. The errant b-boy, one Justin Rushford, had been charged with violating the city's noise-pollution statutes: pitching up in court on Friday, he was then given a choice between 90 days in jail (with a $500 fine attached) or listening to the Vegas lounge lizard for "at least two hours". Having accepted the second option, Rushford was due back in court today with a freshly-purchased CD of the golden-throated Newton....

fields.headline: Random views
fields.standfirst: What ballet dancers are watching on television
fields.trailText: What ballet dancers are watching on television.
fields.body:
Mary Wenger: "I don't think there's enough dance on television. BBC2 is very good, but no other channel shows it, and there are a lot of big dance fans out there. I'm an avid watcher of things like Gormenghast and documentaries, and wildlife documentaries - but about animals you're not aware of - not just monkeys and tigers, but strange arctic creatures. But I hate Jeremy Paxman. I think he terrorises people."

Charlotte Davis: "Did you see that Channel Four programme 15? About that girl called Kimberley. It was so depressing I had to turn it off. I couldn't bear watching her with her monstrous father - with the tattoos and everything. I really felt for her, that was a slice of real life."

Michael Renard: "I like music TV a lot, Never Mind The Buzzcocks and Top Of The Pops 2, TFI Friday, that sort of thing. I play the guitar too, so that's why I have an interest. I do like a bit of Stars In Their Eyes and Blind Date no-brain TV. I was thinking of entering the BBC talent competition to be a TV presenter."

Gina Sayles: "I'm not the biggest TV person, but I do have a claim to fame - my brother was on Jim'll Fix It going to the zoo, and he has the medal to prove it! Actually, he found it at a car boot sale, and it's his big chat-up line with women - apart from the fact he's got two kids now. I don't watch any dance on TV, I prefer to see it live - I don't like the camera work. It's best to see a complete stage full of movement, not close ups."

Bonnie Fay: "I watch all the cooking programmes - Delia, Gary Rhodes, Ready Steady Cook, Nigel Slater, Anthony Worral Thompson. That's my absolute favourite thing, cookery. I know it's naff, but I like flopping out in front of the TV when I get home and demanding my boyfriend go out and get the ingredients to the dishes they're cooking and make me my supper. I can't cook very well. It's a myth ballet dancers eat nothing, I eat loads."

 Sian Pattenden spoke to ballet students in Nottingham

fields.headline: Gone to the dogs
fields.trailText: Puppy Love | Airport
fields.body:
Waldemar Januszczak wants to annoy. Why else would he eat dog soup on British television? So I watched Puppy Love (Channel 4) with the same grim resolve I used to assume when I was 18 and my 11-year-old brother took the piss out of my boyfriends. I WILL NOT BE WOUND UP BY THIS.

But Waldemar wins and for the same reason. You can't shut him up. For a whole hour he purports to expose the ugly face of British dog ownership and what he really exposes is the fact that he hates dogs. Or maybe just dog poo. The programme opens with close-ups of dogs' arses as they relieve themselves in the park, and circles back to shit before it closes. Waldemar hunches over the path in a London park scraping poo into a tub to be tested for bacteria. Coprophobic or coprophilic?

So here is the evidence that dog-ownership is a perverted and evil practice. Some breeds of dog are deliberately inbred. Cut to bulldog. Follow with fluffy foolish dogbreeder shrugging off health problems. Score one to Waldemar.

Dog-owners use dogs as "conduits for their repressed emotions" and value them because they can have complete control of the relationship. This from Dr Aric Sigman, consultant psychologist and general all-round morning-TV-style expert.

Spookily Dr Aric later tells us that the widescale castration of pets "coincided with the rise of feminism", possibly because uncastrated dogs "remind humans of what men are really like". It would be nice to think this loonytoon digression was allowed in so that the discerning viewer could take Dr Aric with a pinch of salt.

But I don't.

That many of the points simply contradict each other (evil dog-owners can't relate to people so they get pets; evil dog-owners are cruel to their pets; dogs are unnatural anyway and we might as well eat them) betrays the fact that the programme is driven less by intellect than by a strange disgust: Waldemar points out that the cost of each dog's food would feed a family of three in Angola (of course all non-dog-owners give their spare cash to charity).

Waldemar observes that 100 people a year get toxocariasis, which can be in dog faeces (100 whole people!)

So as a programme designed to provoke, this succeeded but only by allowing logic to be chopped like suey, by dallying misleadingly with "experts" and by tolerating some abuses of trust (Waldemar, allowed into the home of some harmless Shar-Pei breeders, observes that they "live spiritually and geographically in the English Midlands"; the camera invites us to scoff at an elderly woman who has just seen her dog interred, describing her grief in a pet cemetery littered with naff ornaments and sentiment). Making fun of love: it's not funny and it's not clever.

And I think the dogs shone through. In spite of itself, the camera caught something of their gratuitous gaiety, the daft, unquenchable, infectious happiness of dogs. Even if they do lick each other's bottoms. And then your face.

Airport (BBC1) is back, showing us Heathrow and the Basil Fawlty ghastliness of English service industry culture.

The immigration officers in particular specialise in a kind of pointless cruelty:

Spotty long-haired French Canadian student who has been trying to sneak into UK to work illegally: We had a job in Burnmowt.

Sharp-nosed immigration officer: In Bournemouth.

Spotty: Heh heh, Burnmooth, mowth.

Sharpnose: Bournemouth.

Spotty: Heh heh.

This goes on for a painfully long time.

On the other hand if you are Donatella Versace, you get non-stop fawning from your own personal man in a Day-Glo parka. Donatella stalks around followed by a heap of black luggage which could easily contain a dismembered elephant. She cannot board her private jet because her thirteenth bag has gone missing. Is it OK for her to smoke in this area?

Day-Glo man: "Um, I think technically it's not, but I'm not, let's put it this way, I'm not going to say anything."

The drama culminates in Day-Glo man wrapping himself round the wheels of Donatella's jet and clinging there with the bag until they arrive in Milan where he falls to the tarmac, apologising.

Well, not quite, but you get the idea.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: World's Largest Hotel | Seven years In Tibet | The Shanghai Gesture | Matinee
fields.body:
World's Largest Hotel

9pm, Discovery

That'll be the Venetian in Las Vegas: a theme-park mock-up of Venice - Grand Canal, St Mark's Square and all - that incorporates a 3,000-bed hotel, casino, conference centre and holiday resort. This cut-price fly on the wall goes behind the scenes with the kitchen staff, maids and security guards going about their business. In spite of the figures that are hurled at you in every other sentence - 50 tons of food guzzled in one sitting, etc - there is nothing here of much interest. Where's chef from Liverpool's Grand when you need him?

Seven years In Tibet

(Jean-Jacques Annaud, 1997) 10am, 5.30pm, Sky Premier

Around the time the Austrian Von Trapp family was climbing every mountain to escape the Nazis, the Austrian Heinrich Harrer was tackling the Himalayan peak of Nanga Parbat. Harrer, however, was a Nazi, played here by Brad Pitt. But the meat of the tale is in Harrer's time with the young Dalai Lama, which adds humour and humanity to an over-meditative study. The mountains are stupendous.

The Shanghai Gesture

(Joseph von Sternberg, 1941)

3pm, Carlton Cinema

Von Sternberg's final Hollywood flourish is a wicked, wonderful melodrama, set in Shanghai because that's where anything goes. East and West collide in the poisonous postmarital relationship of Sir Guy (Walter Huston) and Mother Gin Sling (Ona Munson); as ever it's the kid - Poppy (Gene Tierney) who suffers, skirting corruption in a casino-pleasure palace. All this and Victor Mature in a fez...

Matinee

(Joe Dante, 1993)

6pm, FilmFour

Supercharged parody of 50s US sci-fi movies, and the state of the nation that watched them. It's actually set in 1962, during the Cuban missile crisis, with Americans either quaking or ready to nuke the Russians - it's the only way to be sure. Enter cigar-chomping cine-showman John Goodman, promoting his new schlock B-movie Mant!, about a creature that's half-man and half-ant, the special effects proving far too realistic for the nervy population of Key West.

webTitle: Don't leave morals to the madmen

fields.headline: Don't leave morals to the madmen
fields.standfirst:
Religious leaders have no role in ordering a just, modern society

Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Last week the government announced that it is to add a clause to its current education bill requiring that schools should promote marriage and "other stable relationships" as ideals, and should encourage pupils to delay engaging in sex until they are older. The proposal is a sop to those, chief among them the churches, who oppose repeal of the notorious section 28 which forbids "promotion of homosexuality" by public bodies.
fields.body:
Last week the government announced that it is to add a clause to its current education bill requiring that schools should promote marriage and "other stable relationships" as ideals, and should encourage pupils to delay engaging in sex until they are older. The proposal is a sop to those, chief among them the churches, who oppose repeal of the notorious section 28 which forbids "promotion of homosexuality" by public bodies.

Why are the churches given a privileged - almost, indeed, an exclusive - position in the social debate about morality, when they are arguably the least competent organisations to have it? If this claim seems paradoxical, it is because we have become used to giving, as if by reflex, a platform to churchmen when moral dilemmas arise. This has come about in an odd way. The churches have always been obsessed with a small range of human activities, mainly those associated with sexuality. It is their vociferous complaining about human turpitude that has somehow made them authorities on moral matters in general.

But it can easily be shown that the churches are either largely irrelevant to genuine questions of morality, or are positively anti-moral. In modern, developed societies, personal autonomy, achievement in earning a living, providing for a family, saving against a rainy day, and being rewarded for success in one's career, are approved and enjoined.

Christian morality says the exact opposite. It tells people to consider the lilies of the field, which neither reap nor spin, and take no thought for the morrow. It tells believers to give all their possessions to the poor, warns that it is easier for a camel to go through a needle's eye than for a well-off person to enter heaven, and preaches complete obedience to a deity. Such a morality is wholly opposed to the norms and practices of contemporary society.

Most people simply ignore the contrast between such views and today's ethos, and the churches keep quiet about it. But if we bothered to examine what a Christian - or indeed any religious - morality demanded, we would be amazed by its diametric opposition to what is regarded as normal and desirable now.

But religious morality is not merely irrelevant: it is anti-moral. The great moral questions of the present age are those about human rights, war, poverty, the vast disparities between rich and poor, the fact that somewhere in the third world a child dies every two-and-a-half seconds because of starvation or remediable disease. The churches' obsessions with pre-marital sex and whether divorced couples can remarry in church appears contemptible in the light of this mountain of human suffering and need. By distracting attention from what really counts, and focusing it on the minor and anyway futile attempt to get people to have sex only when the church permits, harm is done to the cause of good in the world.

Religion can often be immoral, too. Elsewhere in the world, religious fundamentalists and fanatics incarcerate women, mutilate genitals, amputate hands, murder, bomb and terrorise in the name of their faith. It is a mistake to think that our own milk-and-water clerics would never conceive of doing likewise; it is not long in historical terms since Christian priests were burning people at the stake if they did not believe that wine turns to blood when a priest prays over it or - more to the present point - since they were whipping people and slitting their noses and ears for having sex outside marriage, or preaching that masturbation is worse than rape because at least the latter can result in pregnancy.

Because so much religious energy is devoted to controlling sexual behaviour, either by disallowing it (or thoughts or representations of it) other than in strictly limited circumstances, or by preventing the amelioration of its consequences once it has happened, we have the spectacle of the righteous writing letters of complaint about televised nudity, while from the factory next door tons of armaments are exported to regions of the world gripped by poverty and civil war.

With such examples and contrasts, religion has very little to offer moral debate. No doubt the churches are as entitled as any other interest group to have their say on matters that fall within their range of concerns. But asking them to take an especially authoritative line on moral matters is like asking the fox to set rules for fox-hunting.

Churchmen are people with avowedly ancient supernatural beliefs who rely on moral casuistry which is 2,000 years out of date; it is extraordinary that their views should be given precedence over those that could be drawn from the richness of thoughtful, educated, open-minded opinion otherwise available in society

 Dr Anthony Grayling lectures in philosophy at Birkbeck College, London

webTitle: £200,000 electoral pledge draws inquiry on DJ Evans

fields.headline: £200,000 electoral pledge draws inquiry on DJ Evans
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Virgin Radio is to be investigated by the government-appointed radio authority for possible breaches of political impartiality rules after Chris Evans, the DJ, announced on air yesterday that he planned to double his donation to Ken Livingstone's London mayoral campaign to £200,000.
fields.body:
Virgin Radio is to be investigated by the government-appointed radio authority for possible breaches of political impartiality rules after Chris Evans, the DJ, announced on air yesterday that he planned to double his donation to Ken Livingstone's London mayoral campaign to £200,000.

Mr Evans was enraged by a joke about redheads made by Mr Livingstone's official Labour rival, Frank Dobson, after he declared his £100,000 gift at the weekend, and decided to take his revenge by handing over another £100,000.

But a radio authority spokeswoman said tapes of remarks by the former Ginger Media Group magnate on his breakfast show were being studied and that the authority would decide in May whether Virgin had broken its obligation to be fair in the run-up to the mayoral election.

On Monday, Mr Dobson had tried to laugh off the radio presenter's announcement of his original donation by telling reporters: "I am somewhat relieved really because my mum always told me to steer clear of redheads."

The joke backfired in spectacular fashion yesterday when the ginger-haired Mr Evans doubled his contribution, telling listeners: "What Frank Dobson said is very offensive to people with red hair. Kids growing up with red hair could be given a really tough time, especially if they have glasses."

Mr Livingstone, who has set himself a campaign cash target of £500,000, declared himself delighted at Mr Evans's generosity. "At this rate, Frank's gaffes will pay for my entire campaign fund."

A Dobson campaign source said Mr Evans had "more money than sense", declining to comment further.

But if the radio authority finds against Virgin - which sought to distance itself yesterday from Mr Evans's views and donation - it could fine the station or alter the terms of its licence. The largest fine to date has been £50,000.

Mr Dobson's backers at Labour's Millbank headquarters meanwhile faced further gaffe accusations, after a party spokesman commented on the support for Mr Livingstone by readers of Britain's main Irish community paper, the Irish Post. A Labour party spokesman said: "Are your readers all Sinn Fein supporters?"

Norah Casey, Irish Post editor, said yesterday: "He wasn't joking either. It was an outrageous remark and it's not the first time we've had those kind of comments from Millbank".

Father Gerry Kivlehan, of the London Irish Centre, said yesterday that the comment had been "very disappointing and regrettable".

webTitle: MPs berate Blair over science site

fields.headline: MPs berate Blair over science site
fields.trailText: Tony Blair came under attack last night from Labour MPs who accused him of abandoning the party's heartlands after the government decided to site a £500m science park in Oxfordshire, rather than at a leading laboratory in the north-west.
fields.body:
Tony Blair came under attack last night from Labour MPs who accused him of abandoning the party's heartlands after the government decided to site a £500m science park in Oxfordshire, rather than at a leading laboratory in the north-west.

During "robust exchanges" in his Commons office, the prime minister was told of deep dismay in the north-west after the government's decision to place the hi-tech synchrotron project at the Rutherford laboratory in Didcot instead of at the Daresbury laboratory in Cheshire.

Derek Twigg, chairman of Labour's north-west group of MPs, who is also a ministerial aide, said last night: "We left the prime minister in no doubt about the depth of anger in the region. The group were bitterly disappointed they were unable to persuade the prime minister to change the decision. The north-west group of Labour MPs would like to apologise to the staff and supporters of Daresbury for this decision."

The government was forced to site the multi-million pound synchrotron, which is seen as a crucial development in British science, in Oxfordshire after intense pressure from the project's other sponsors. The Wellcome Trust and the French government, which are supporting the project, threatened to pull out if ministers opted for Cheshire.

In a parliamentary answer last night Mr Blair said the scientific case was "marginally in favour" of the Oxfordshire site.

webTitle: Brain test for Pinochet after he collapses

fields.headline: Brain test for Pinochet after he collapses
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: General Augusto Pinochet, whose spritely performance on arrival in Chile cast doubt on medical opinion that he was mentally unfit to stand trial, underwent a brain test yesterday after fainting at his Santiago residence.
fields.body:
General Augusto Pinochet, whose spritely performance on arrival in Chile cast doubt on medical opinion that he was mentally unfit to stand trial, underwent a brain test yesterday after fainting at his Santiago residence.

It is the fourth time that the 84 year-old former dictator has collapsed after suffering a series of small strokes in Britain in September last year.

After spending three hours at the military hospital on Monday morning, doctors urged him to undergo a test to measure the flow of blood to his brain at a local private clinic.

The Las Condes clinic said he underwent a test called "cerebral spets" and was released shortly afterwards.

Gen Pinochet's daughter, Jacqueline, revealed that her father was feeling very tired: "He even fell asleep during the test," she said.

The incident appeared to be a repeat of the occurence reported by four British doctors, whose findings formed the basis of the decision by the home secretary, Jack Straw, to send him back to Chile, after a 16-month fight against extradition to Spain.

The former Chilean dictator first collapsed on September 9 while walking in the garden of his rented home on the Wentworth estate in Surrey.

The report said then: "The clinical diagnosis was of multiple small bilateral cerebral infarcts." They said there were two further incidents on September 20 and October 9 and concluded that there would be progressive damage to the blood vessels in his brain.

The doctors said that Gen Pinochet, who has a pacemaker and suffers from diabetes, would be physically and mentally unfit for trial. He was suffering from a memory deficit, limited ability to understand complex sentences, impaired ability to express himself audibly, and was easy fatigued, they told Mr Straw.

Since his return to Chile on March 3, Gen Pinochet has remained secluded in his heavily guarded suburban Santiago residence. After his latest collapse, state television showed only the former dictator's motorcade speeding into the private clinic.

The downturn in his health came after moves for his possible trial gathered pace. The hero's welcome he received from the military has hardened the resolve of the civilian government to see justice done.

A judge is currently investigating 72 allegations of Gen Pinochet's involvement in murder, kidnapping and torture, in connection with the 3,197 people who disappeared during his 17-year rule.

Yesterday 24 corpses were discovered by government forensic experts in a mass grave in the southern town of Cauquenes. It is the fifth such discovery, and is piling on the pressure for a prosecution.

Two weeks ago, the Chilean government announced that the public prosecutor's office would join in criminal proceedings under way against Gen Pinochet. The decision means that government lawyers will be able to take part in investigations against him and would be allowed to intervene in any trial.

A petition to strip Gen Pinochet of the immunity from prosecution he enjoys as a senator for life has been approved by the investigating judge and will now be examined by Santiago's appeal court.

A decision is expected in a month. The court is also considering televising any criminal trial.

fields.headline: WD 'Bill' Hamilton
fields.standfirst: Appreciation
fields.trailText: To be with the biologist Professor WD "Bill" Hamilton (Obituary, March 9) in the field, particularly in Amazonia, was exhilarating, educational, and usually terrifying.
fields.body:
To be with the biologist Professor WD "Bill" Hamilton (Obituary, March 9) in the field, particularly in Amazonia, was exhilarating, educational, and usually terrifying. To find wasps - with hymenoptera a favoured group - he would thrash wildly at passing vegetation. Any co-walker, sanely situated some 40 yards astern, would suddenly see Bill stop, place a hand where he was being stung, carefully pinch off the insect, examine it closely, recognise the species, and then know where to look for its nearby nest.

Even if the nest was very high in a tree, perhaps resembling a three-foot fir cone, Bill would fashion a club to bring its occupants nearer. He would smite the tree and observe what he called the "bombing".

Clusters of disturbed wasps would drop from the bottom hole, each hanging together in a compact mass, and then separate to search a particular level. With these horizontal groupings each seeking the cause of their disturbance, there was an inevitable query. "Why aren't they searching where we are standing?" "Probably", he answered, "because most of their intruders come from higher up."

Only once did I see Bill run. This was plainly no occasion for dalliance, and I hurried breathlessly by him. "Why are we running, Bill?" "Those were Africans," he replied. Earlier, we had seen a Brazilian about to axe a small tree to acquire honey from its nest of bees. Bill had explained that these were not the traditionally docile kind but the famous killer bees. They had resulted from a laboratory escape, when bees imported from Africa had managed to get out, mix with the local variety, and then travel throughout South America. The poor honey-seeker had been terribly stung.

Bill mixed his computer-based studies of biology back in Oxford with forays in the wilderness. He was the complete field naturalist. There was always a magnifying glass around his neck, and binoculars, a camera, and a rucksack of killing bottles, notebooks, and the like. Everything out there was grist to his mill, to a mind forever curious. "These seeds with wings for aerial dispersal," he once said, "seem often to be purple. So why should that be?"

He plunged his hand down any hole he found. Almost every year, he spent time near Tefé on the Amazon, the spot where HW Bates, the Victorian naturalist, had passed many years - and that was where I last saw Bill in action. To my relief, he had stopped putting an arm down holes. "Are you wiser now?" I asked.

"Yes, I think I have discovered everything that's ever down them!" Earlier, I had noticed three finger-joints were missing from one hand. "Lost down a hole?' I queried. "No, a firework made at school."

His speech was almost inaudible, possibly because he felt others must know what he had to say. His lecture slides of computer printouts were scantily (and silently) explained as his audience would surely know their meaning. An evening with his family was almost Trappist, with everyone apparently knowing what others were suggesting. Bill was an astonishing blend of old-style naturalist, new-style theoretician, and always up there, eccentrically at the sharp point of his science.

fields.headline: KN Singh
fields.standfirst: Indian actor who belied his crooked image
fields.trailText: K N Singh, who has died aged 90, broke the image of the stereotypical villain in popular Indian cinema. Unlike the conventional baddie - with his tough looks, loud and nasty talk, and horrible laugh - he always maintained a poised, cultured and soft exterior.
fields.body:
K N Singh, who has died aged 90, broke the image of the stereotypical villain in popular Indian cinema. Unlike the conventional baddie - with his tough looks, loud and nasty talk, and horrible laugh - he always maintained a poised, cultured and soft exterior.

Singh was born into a family of lawyers from the north Indian town of Dehradun, in the beautiful Doon valley. He was discovered by the actor Prithviraj Kapoor in Calcutta in the 1930s. The film-maker Debaki Bose offered him the role of a doctor in Sunhera Sansar (The Ideal World, 1935) and that successful debut was followed by Raj Kapoor's Barsaat (Rain, 1949) and Awara (The Vagabond, 1951). By the late 1950s, his distinct style and underplayed performance made him one of the highest paid villains in Indian cinema.

Whether it was Guru Dutt's Baazi (A Game Of Chance, 1951), Shakti Samant's Howrah Bridge (1958) or Vijay Anand's Teesri Manzil (Third Storey, 1966), Singh sent shivers down people's spines. In one of his last interviews, he recalled: "Even off-screen I was a bad man. One day on my way back from shooting, I had to deliver an envelope at an address given to me by my friend. I pressed the doorbell and, from the moving curtains, I could see a woman hurrying to open the door. When she saw me standing in front of her, she screamed out in fright and ran inside leaving the door open. Even I fled from the scene."

In a career spanning nearly 60 years, Singh acted in nearly 250 films; his last was Shashi Kapoor's Ajooba (Wonder, 1991). As violence became the hallmark of Bombay cinema in the l990s, he said: "Today's films lack authenticity and are full of bad language."

In the last 10 years of his life, he lost his sight but, unlike many of his cinema contemporaries, he had invested his money wisely and could afford to live comfortably despite his vision and hearing problems.

Singh's wife, Chandravati Singh, died some years ago. He is survived by an adopted son Pushkar Singh, a television serial producer.

fields.headline: John Kay
fields.trailText: John Kay, who has died aged 72, was a lifelong member of the Communist party, yet implausibly attained the rank of chief architect to the Department of Education and Science during Margaret Thatcher's government.
fields.body:
John Kay, who has died aged 72, was a lifelong member of the Communist party, yet implausibly attained the rank of chief architect to the Department of Education and Science during Margaret Thatcher's government.

Born in Reading, he belonged to a generation of British architects who looked upon self-expression as a frivolous distraction from the task of bettering lives by raising technical standards. He attended a progressive private school, Leighton Park, and trained at the Architectural Association.

In 1953, he joined the Building Research Station at Watford, which provided the technical underpinning for new building methods being pioneered in the public sector. Three years later, he moved to the Ministry of Education and, for the rest of his career, improved and co-ordinated design techniques for schools and colleges at a time when Britain led Europe. An expert in natural and artificial light, he was co-author, with the ergonomist Professor Ralph Hopkinson, of The Lighting Of Buildings (1969).

Kay joined the Communist party at school and never saw reason to change his allegiance. An indefatigable organiser, he spent endless hours on leftwing causes connected with design - from a 1950 east-west conference of architectural students, to a campaign to restore union rights at the Royal Institute of British Architects.

With his wife Ann, a fellow architect, Kay built himself a home in south London, and became active in the Clapham Society - helping to shift its focus from pure conservation to wider local issues - and also the William Morris Society. But then for Kay, Morris meant not wallpaper, but a blend of grass-roots politics and design. He is survived by Ann, two sons and a daughter.

 John Davenport Kay, architect, born April 27 1927; died November 16 1999

fields.headline: Irving Smith
fields.standfirst: Wartime fighter pilot famed for leading low-level precision bombing raids
fields.trailText: Irving "Black" Smith, who has died aged 82, played a leading role in Operation Jericho, the Royal Air Force's precision raid against Amiens jail in France on February 18 1944. The Gestapo were holding more than 700 French prisoners, including Louis Vivant, a key resistance figure, in Abbeville. The plan, requested by the resistance, was for the RAF to initiate a breakout of inmates.
fields.body:
Irving "Black" Smith, who has died aged 82, played a leading role in Operation Jericho, the Royal Air Force's precision raid against Amiens jail in France on February 18 1944. The Gestapo were holding more than 700 French prisoners, including Louis Vivant, a key resistance figure, in Abbeville. The plan, requested by the resistance, was for the RAF to initiate a breakout of inmates.

Eighteen Mosquito-VI fighter-bombers, six each from 487, 464 and 21 squadrons, all carrying two 500lb bombs with 11-second delay detonators, were to breach the 20ft-walls surrounding the prison and, three minutes later, smash the inner building. Twelve Typhoon fighters were to escort the force. A 19th Mosquito, from the film production unit, was to record the operation, which called for precision flying and bombing, and great courage.

The weather was appalling. The crews studied a model of the prison for two hours, and took off at 11am from Hunsdon, Hertfordshire, with snow falling. Smith led the first six aircraft from 487 squadron and, just after midday, attacked the surrounding walls from a height of 10ft. Three minutes later, six Mosquitoes, of 464 squadron, attacked the prison buildings through the smoke and debris of the preceding attack. Two Mosquitoes and a Typhoon were lost, but 258 prisoners escaped, including Louis Vivant.

Smith was born at Invercargill, Southland, New Zealand. He was educated at Seddon memorial technical college, Auckland, and on leaving school became an apprentice coach-painter. In late 1938, he applied for a short service commission in the Royal New Zealand Air Force and was accepted in January 1939. In July 1939, he was sent to England to complete his training.

Smith was posted to 151 squadron flying Hurricane fighters in July 1940, and was soon involved in the Battle of Britain. On August 15, he shot down two Messerschmidt Bf-109E fighters and damaged a third. Other victories followed in August and October. In November, 151 squadron, flying Hurricanes and Defiant fighters, was re-deployed on night operations against the Luftwaffe's night blitz on British cities. Smith was promoted to the rank of flight commander, and in March 1941 was awarded a DFC. In July, flying a Defiant, he destroyed a Dornier Do-217 bomber and damaged a Junkers Ju88 off Cromer.

Smith was appointed commanding officer of 151 squadron in February 1942 and acting wing commander in April, when 151 squadron began converting to the potent Mosquito-II night-fighter. On the night of June 24/25, he shot down two German bombers and damaged a third off Yarmouth. He was awarded a bar to his DFC in July, having scored eight aerial kills and four damaged. Having spent more than 2 years flying operationally with 151 squadron, he was rested from operations in March 1943.

Later that year, Smith was posted to No 2 (Bomber) Group HQ at the request of its air officer commanding, the famous Air Vice-Marshal Sir Basil Embry. In February 1944, he was appointed commanding officer of 487 squadron, RNZAF, operating Mosquito-VIs. Six Mosquito squadrons, specialising in low-level precision bombing - often against individual buildings - operated with No 2 Group, 2nd Tactical Air Force. Three squadrons - 487, 21 (British), and 464 (Australian) - formed 140 Wing, commanded by the redoubtable Wing Commander "Pick" Pickard. Then came Operation Jericho.

The following August, Smith led 487 squadron in low-level precision raids on barracks at Poitiers and, some weeks later, on an SS headquarters at Vincey, near Metz. He was subsequently mentioned in dispatches. In October, he was again rested from operations, and served at 13 Officer Training Unit until the end of the war, when he was granted a permanent commission. His later duties included commanding 56 squadron, flying Meteor jets, and staff appointments at HQ Fighter Command and HQ Signals Command.

He retired from the RAF as a group captain in 1966, and took up farming in south Devon. His wife Joan, whom he married in 1942 when she was a WAAF officer, died in 1994. They had two daughters, one of whom died in a car accident, and a son, who is now deputy supreme allied commander, Europe, General Sir Rupert Smith.

fields.headline: Ned Goy
fields.standfirst: Inspiring Cambridge teacher of Serbian and Croatian literature
fields.trailText: The Cambridge scholar and literary critic ED "Ned" Goy, who has died aged 73, was genuinely literary and genuinely critical. Within western Europe, his contribution to the study of Serbian and Croatian literature was second to none.
fields.body:
The Cambridge scholar and literary critic ED "Ned" Goy, who has died aged 73, was genuinely literary and genuinely critical. Within western Europe, his contribution to the study of Serbian and Croatian literature was second to none. While most of his articles on that subject remain uncollected, they are essential reading for students of south Slav culture. His translations from Serbo-Croat spanned contemporary fiction, modern, renaissance and baroque poetry, and folk literature.

Ned was born in Enfield, Middlesex; his father was a silk merchant from a Huguenot background, his mother was the 11th child of a Sunder land miner. She brought up her son alone, moving, when he was five, to the Hampshire village of Clanfield, where he attended the local school and then Churchers College, Petersfield. There he took up Russian, which was then, he recalled, "a great eccentricity". He sat his higher school certificate (now A-levels) after only seven months' study and developed a lifelong love of nature, fishing - and making collages.

Army national service from 1945-1947 took him to Cambridge University to complete the joint services Russian course, and then to Poland and Germany as an interpreter. Back at Cambridge in 1948, he consulted the distinguished Slavonic scholar Elizabeth Hill about which other language to study; she suggested Serbo-Croat. In 1951, Goy graduated with starred first-class honours in Russian and Serbo-Croat. Four years later, he was awarded a PhD for his thesis, Serbian Russophilism And The Infiltration Of Russian Literature And Thought Into Serbia, and was appointed as a lecturer in Slavonic studies, teaching mainly Serbian and Croatian literature at Cambridge until his retirement in 1990.

During the 1960s, when he was asked to tutor in Russian literature, news soon spread among students about his original and exciting tutorials. He considered that his academic colleagues' reaction was less enthusiastic; indeed, he came to believe that his students were being penalised in examinations for the views they had acquired at his tutorials, and so stopped tutoring Russian literature altogether. He became something of a loner in the department of Slavonic studies, admired by undergraduates but sidelined by the establishment. Yet without these tutorials, he would not have written the fine essays on Pushkin and Turgenev, published in his book Excursions (1996).

Goy relished words and communication, whether written or oral. Literature had a direct emotional and aesthetic impact on him. While always painstaking in his research of the historical, social or literary contexts of a work, in his teaching and writing he would always start from the experience of the work itself, applying the Leavisite touchstone of "realisation". What interested him was whether a work came alive in its own right or merely "embodied an idea or ideology in literary terms".

His contributions to Serbian and Croatian literature were deeply appreciated. In 1988, the Serbian PEN centre honoured him, and in 1999 he was nominated for both the Croatian and the Serbian academies of sciences and arts.

In the last three years of his life, Goy embarked on a series of new literary ventures with his wife Jasna Levinger-Goy, whom he married in February 1997. The translations of Mesa Slimovic's novel, The Fortress, and Miroslav Krleza's The Banquet In Blitva are crowning achievements of their co-operation. They had just started translating Milos Crnjanski's A Novel About London, when he collapsed and died a few hours later.

The brilliance of Goy's teaching, his determined independence as a thinker, and his profound personal modesty as a man, made a rare combination in the world of Slavonic studies.

 Edward Dennis 'Ned' Goy, Serb and Croat scholar, born September 22 1926; died March 13 2000

fields.headline: In brief
fields.body:
Ex-Panther is caught
H Rap Brown, an activist linked to the Black Panthers in 60s America, has been arrested in woodland outside the Alabama town of Whitehall, police said. He fled Atlanta last week after being accused of killing a sheriff's deputy.

Now known as Jamil Abdullah Al-Amin, he allegedly shot two sheriff's deputies who came to his Atlanta grocery store to arrest him on charges of receiving stolen property and other crimes.
Reuters, Whitehall, Alabama

Inmate flosses his way out
Prison officials believe an inmate used dental floss or a similar coated string to cut his way out of his cell at a Texas jail earlier this month and kill another inmate.

Antonio Lara, 26, was accused of crawling out from under his cell bars and killing Roland Rios, 41. Lara was serving a 15-year sentence for attempted murder, robbery and aggravated assault. Rios was serving a 10-year term for aggravated robbery and child injury.
AP, Houston

Governor owns up in sex case
A former Japanese governor pleaded guilty yesterday to charges of sexually harassing a woman during a 1999 election campaign. Japan is getting tougher about such behaviour.

"Knock" Yokoyama, a comedian turned politician, had already resigned as Osaka governor after being indicted on suspicion of molesting a campaign worker aged 21. He lost a civil lawsuit and was ordered in December to pay 11 million yen (about £64,000) in compensation, Japan's toughest penalty ever for sexual harassment.
Reuters, Tokyo

Man tried to cut hand loose
Trapped for almost three days in a van as traffic whizzed by only a few feet away, a Californian man got so desperate that he tried to cut off his pinned hand with a pocketknife.

Lee Risler's arm was trapped after his van overturned in a ditch in Downey, near Los Angeles. A firefighter said Mr Risler did more more damage to his arm than the accident had.
AP, Downey, California

webTitle: Paris minister threatens to quit in frustration

fields.headline: Paris minister threatens to quit in frustration
fields.trailText: The capacity of France's Socialist-led government to make the reforms so needed in the public service was cast into further doubt yesterday with news that the finance minister, Christian Sautter, planned to resign after just five months because his plans to modernise the tax system had been blocked.
fields.body:
The capacity of France's Socialist-led government to make the reforms so needed in the public service was cast into further doubt yesterday with news that the finance minister, Christian Sautter, planned to resign after just five months because his plans to modernise the tax system had been blocked.

Le Monde newspaper said Mr Sautter had complained on Monday night that he was "mortified" when his proposed reformswere dropped in the face of ferocious trade union opposition.

The paper said that unnamed sources close to the minister had confirmed he intended to quit. The finance ministry and the prime minister's office declined to comment.

Mr Sautter had announced on Monday that he was cancelling plans to streamline France's cumbersome tax-collection system, which is the responsibility of two bodies - one to assess and one to collect taxes.

fields.headline: No: 1599
fields.standfirst: Cormac Murphy-O'Connor
fields.trailText: Cormac Murphy-O'Connor.
fields.body:
Age: 67.

Appearance: Semi-retired, jolly mid-afternoon gameshow host.

Old job: Bishop of Arundel (a much classier title than Bishop of Brighton, which is where he was really based).

New job: As of today - when he's installed, live on TV, at 11am - the Archbishop of Westminster, leader of the Catholics of England and Wales, replacing the late Cardinal Basil Hume.

A tough assigment. Yes. There are about 4.1m in Britain, and to say that there are differences of opinion within the Church ... well, is the Pope a Catholic?

Is he a liberal or a conservative? Oh, lordy, what a can of worms. Can't we talk about something else?

Dodging the question, are you? Well, it's just he's, in a very real sense, well, both. Or neither. "If by a liberal you mean someone who is open to all new things that come along, then I am not," he says. But "if, by a conservative, you mean someone who is a rigid fundamentalist, then I am not that either".

Meaning? He's conservative on abortion, women's ordination and divorce, but has distanced himself from Cardinal Winning's campaign to keep Section 28.

So what is he? "I am a man of the Church," he says.

Does this handwringing infuriate his flock? No: 2,400 people will cram Westminster Cathedral today (more than it can take) and the Catholic weekly, the Tablet, calls him "everyone's favourite bishop, human, genial, collaborative, imposing".

You mean... Precisely. He's heading for the status of much-loved national institution.

Any other bishoply traits? He dislikes the culture of consumerism and likes ecumenicalism, and Prince Charles wants to be his friend (he was going to attend today, but has to present awards to policemen in Norfolk).

Any unbishoply traits? Well, he used to be a rugby player. And his brother put a rather unpious bet at Ladbroke's on his getting the job.

Odds of him being on Radio 4's Thought for The Day: 4-1 on.

fields.headline: Falling for Madonna
fields.standfirst: After years of hellraising, Madonna is settling down with a nice English bloke to have his baby - and we're all delighted.  Joan Smith  on how the material girl became a maternal icon
fields.trailText: After years of hellraising, Madonna is settling down with a nice English bloke to have his baby - and we're all delighted.  Joan Smith  on how the material girl became a maternal icon.
fields.body:
Phew! Forget blonde ambition, that Gaultier corset and the notorious knickerless photographs. Think instead maternity smocks, woolly bootees and midnight feeds: Madonna is pregnant for the second time. And aren't we all delighted! This time round, she has found herself a nice Englishman, film director Guy Ritchie, and they are madly in love. The singer, it turns out, is "a sweet and simple girl" who is going to be an absolutely wonderful mother.

So the raunchy disco diva who shocked the Vatican with the video for her single Like a Prayer is now a much-loved mum-to-be. But can a hunk and a bump really make such a difference? The fact that Madonna's re-invention as a maternal icon is not as innocent as it seems is confirmed by the contrasting treatment handed out yesterday to another famous mum, the tabloids' choice for the discarded "material girl" title. The unlucky contender is Posh Spice, Victoria Beckham, who was pictured with her husband in yesterday's Daily Mail under the headline "Who do they think they are?" There is no doubt that the Beckhams look increasingly strange. With his new crew cut and a cagoule-type jacket, the footballer looked like a UN volunteer helping a hungry, traumatised refugee and her child to safety in a war zone. In fact, the Beckhams were, as they so often are these days, in the West End of London on a shopping trip.

The paper costed out every item the couple wore, from Victoria's Gucci sunglasses (£130) to Brooklyn's Tommy Hilfiger jacket (£35). Including the couple's jewellery, the total came to £105,852 - enough, as the Mail did not say, to keep half a dozen Bosnian refugees or Afghan asylum seekers in luxury for months. "Could they have been more conspicuous?" the writer demanded. "Someone needs to take this couple in hand before they destroy themselves, each other, their relationship and their careers."

But it is Posh, with her new hair colour - blonde ambition, by an awful coincidence of timing - who really gets it in the neck. It is she who is said to be the force behind their endless publicity-seeking, dragging her unfortunate husband along with her as she seeks out yet more photo opportunities. The tabloids' current estimation of the two couples could be summed up, crudely, as Madonna and Guy good, Posh and Becks bad. And when Victoria is bad, it seems, she is very bad indeed.

It was not always thus. The outpouring of sentimentality which has greeted Madonna's announcement of her pregnancy and the implication that she is really an ordinary girl at heart, are a very recent phenomena. It is not so long since she was portrayed as a sexual predator whose promiscuity had turned her into a lonely recluse, unable to hang on to a boyfriend. Her vulnerability was confirmed by the disclosure that she had even acquired that unenviable accoutrement of contemporary celebrity, a stalker: the inevitable outcome, it was implied, of her frankly sexual stage persona and her foray into soft porn in her Sex book.

Madonna has been, for much of her career, the archetypal bad girl who has to suffer for her transgressions - a history which makes her new, ecstatic mum-to-be image all the more startling. In the second half of the 90s, showbiz columns speculated about her isolation and there were sniggers over the fact that the father of her daughter Lourdes was not a movie star but her personal trainer, Carlos Leon. Andrew Neil, the former Sunday Times editor whose looks would be unduly flattered by the adjective "craggy", affected to have turned on his answering machine in case the desperate singer called him for a date.

"Although the superstar is surrounded by servants and adoring fans," the Mail reported only four years ago, "her biggest problem is loneliness." Yesterday, parroting the new line on Madonna, the same paper announced: "She's a sweet girl and will be an excellent mum say boyfriend's parents." It described Madonna and Ritchie as a wonderful family who have already settled down together in London.

No more sex and drugs and rock'n'roll, then. The Daily Record catalogued the star's love life, reminding readers that she lost her virginity to a schoolfriend in Michigan at the age of 15. Her second lover was a bisexual, the paper said, who later died of Aids. It claimed Madonna left another boyfriend, French disco star Patrick Hernandez, "to chase fame in New York where she picked up men for one-night stands". Then there was her marriage to actor Sean Penn, her fling with Warren Beatty, and the rumours of a lesbian affair with Sandra Bernhard.

But that is all in the past. What the paper was leading up to was its announcement that "Madonna does a Cherie", surely the first time that the singer's name has been coupled with that of the prime minister's wife. At first sight, the link is that both women have become pregnant in their 40s, but there is a much more revealing sub-text. The tabloids were always cool about Mrs Blair, often criticising her clothes or her hair, until the news of her latest pregnancy leaked out in the autumn. Overnight, the tone changed, with picture editors vying to get the first snap of the Blair bump.

Cherie Booth, ambitious barrister and part-time judge, cannot hold a candle to Mrs Blair, glamorous mum-to-be. One is formidable, threatening, intellectual; the other conjures up images of maternal tenderness and vulnerability which stretch back to the Renaissance, with its painterly cult of the Blessed Virgin Mary. A similar process has happened to Madonna, who has been changed by true love from global sex symbol - the incarnation, if you like, of the goddess Kali - into a woman we can all identify with.

It is not so much that Madonna has gone soft, although her most recent photographs provide a dramatic contrast to the strutting, sexually exuberant figure who appeared in her videos. It is that impending maternity has transformed her, as it has Cherie Booth, from the phallic woman who haunts nightmares to the real woman who loves her man and produces babies. Madonna herself has assisted this process by avoiding publicity and generally behaving, as rumours flew over the past few days, as the perfect mother-to-be.

The question all this leaves is why hasn't it worked for Posh? Victoria Beckham has found a man, given birth to a son and generally behaves as if she is besotted with both of them. The key difference is that if Madonna now has it all, she also has the sense to keep quiet about it. Posh, on the other hand, goes out of her way to flaunt it - and still doesn't seem to be satisfied. Mothers are supposed to be altruistic, to put others first, but Victoria Beckham is still shouting, "Look at me!" She has not yet learned that she may be a mum but she isn't Madonna, in either sense of the word.

webTitle: Ex-priests behind the Ugandan sect that perished by fire

fields.headline: Ex-priests behind the Ugandan sect that perished by fire
fields.trailText: Bulldozers yesterday completed the burial in a mass grave of at least 330 members of the religious sect who burned to death in a chapel on their farm in south-western Uganda.
fields.body:
Bulldozers yesterday completed the burial in a mass grave of at least 330 members of the religious sect who burned to death in a chapel on their farm in south-western Uganda.

Nearby, a salvage team was sorting through an undetermined number of human remains discovered in a latrine pit.

Uganda's Roman Catholic bishops confirmed yesterday that sect head Joseph Kibwetere and another leader of the Movement for the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God were priests who had been excommunicated.

Fides, the Vatican's missionary news agency, quoted relatives of victims as saying sect members had been told the Virgin Mary was coming to take them to heaven on the day of the fire.

webTitle: Colombia's power supply cut by rebel bombs

fields.headline: Colombia's power supply cut by rebel bombs
fields.trailText: A wide swath of Colombia - including five states and most of the capital, Bogota - were left without electricity yesterday after leftist rebels carried out a wave of bomb attacks to protest against the privatisation of the country's national power grid.
fields.body:
A wide swath of Colombia - including five states and most of the capital, Bogota - were left without electricity yesterday after leftist rebels carried out a wave of bomb attacks to protest against the privatisation of the country's national power grid.

The blackout was caused by an overload in the power system after guerrillas from the National Liberation Army (ELN) dynamited 11 pylons and two substations in sepa rate attacks. Since early 1999, the ELN has destroyed nearly 300 electricity pylons.

Although previous bombings had caused limited electricity rationing, the latest attacks were especially effective because the rebels targeted key circuits, causing some officials to suspect that employees of the state power transmission company may have collaborated in the bombings.

The 5,000-strong group of rebels are also fighting to be included in the country's slow-moving peace process.
fields.bodyText: A wide swath of Colombia - including five states and most of the capital, Bogota - were left without electricity yesterday after leftist rebels carried out a wave of bomb attacks to protest against the privatisation of the country's national power grid. The blackout was caused by an overload in the power system after guerrillas from the National Liberation Army (ELN) dynamited 11 pylons and two substations in sepa rate attacks. Since early 1999, the ELN has destroyed nearly 300 electricity pylons. Although previous bombings had caused limited electricity rationing, the latest attacks were especially effective because the rebels targeted key circuits, causing some officials to suspect that employees of the state power transmission company may have collaborated in the bombings. The 5,000-strong group of rebels are also fighting to be included in the country's slow-moving peace process.

fields.headline: Outcry as ex-Nazi doctor freed
fields.standfirst: Judge halts the trial of Austrian charged with killing children in experiments
fields.trailText: The trial of a former Nazi doctor accused of experimenting on the brains of his child patients and murdering at least nine of them was postponed indefinitely yesterday after he was declared suffering from dementia.
fields.body:
The trial of a former Nazi doctor accused of experimenting on the brains of his child patients and murdering at least nine of them was postponed indefinitely yesterday after he was declared suffering from dementia.

The relatives of some of the alleged victims of Heinrich Gross, 84, wept outside the court after the decision to delay the case pending further psychiatric tests in six months. Campaigners said it marked the end of attempts lasting more than 50 years to bring him to justice.

The postponement of the trial has come at an embarrassing time for Austria, which is facing isolation within Europe over the participation of the far-right Freedom party in government. It also raised allegations that Dr Gross had played the "Pinochet card" by pleading mental unfitness to avoid prosecution. "This brings shame on Austria and the judicial system which has turned the culprit into a victim," said Walträud Haupl, whose four-year old sister Annemarie entered the hospital with rickets in 1943, was declared an "idiot" like all other patients and died in the care of Dr Gross 15 months later. Her preserved brain is one of the main pieces of evidence in the case.

Dr Gross, who worked at the Am Spiegelgrund children's hospital in Vienna in 1944, is charged with nine counts of being an accomplice to murder. The charges were brought last April after an investigation into claims that he was responsible for the deaths of hundreds of children. It was found he had kept their brains in a private collection, using them for experiments until just a few years ago.

Seven hundred children died at Spiegelgrund, one of 30 Nazi euthanasia institutes where mentally and physically disabled people were detained and killed. Its head, Dr Ernst Illing, was executed for his part immediately after the second world war and another doctor, Marianne Türk, was jailed for 10 years.

Dr Gross managed to escape prosecution until 1950 when he was sentenced to two years in prison for being an accessory to a single case of manslaughter. But the verdict was later overturned by the high court. He joined the Social Democratic party and went on to become one of the country's leading neurologists and its second highest-earning doctor.

The case was reopened after new evidence came to light three years ago, including declassified papers from the East German secret police archives. In February 1998 prosecutors removed 400 brains from Dr Gross's private collection. Experiments carried out by doctors in Innsbruck found that nine of the brains of children aged between 10 days and 14 years old showed traces of poison, remnants of sleeping tablets alleged to have been administered by Dr Gross. In most cases pneumonia was stated as the cause of death.

Even before yesterday the trial had been delayed for months as the judiciary searched for a judge who had not worked with Dr Gross during the more than 60 years he spent as a forensic doctor.

Former child victims who survived Spiegelgrund along with relatives of the dead packed room 203 of Vienna's criminal court to watch as Dr Gross, dressed in a cloth cap and grey suit, shuffled slowly to the witness stand, accompanied by his doctor. His head was bowed as Judge Karlheinz Seewald asked him: "Can you understand me?" Dr Gross answered: "Not very well." The judge raised his voice and repeated the question, to which Gross replied: "a bit", before going on to answer questions such as the names of his parents and to confirm his date of birth, income and widower status.

Reinhard Haller, a doctor who examined Dr Gross twice, in December 1998 and again on Sunday, told the court that his patient was suffering from dementia and his mental and physical health was deteriorating fast. He said Dr Gross had slight brain damage and showed signs of the initial stages of Parkinson's disease. "He's not confused, he knows where he is and he knows why he's here." But because of a reduced attention span and memory lapses, he would have great trouble following the trial for periods of longer than five to 10 minutes.

After a short intermission the judge declared Dr Gross unfit to stand trial, saying: "Dr Gross's mental and physical health has considerably worsened since the last examination. If he is not able to follow the case it must be adjourned." He called for a new examination to be carried out in six months.

The announcement brought gasps and outbursts of laughter from the public gallery. Dr Gross smiled, stood and shook the hand of his lawyer, Nikolaus Lehner.

Outside the court relatives of his alleged victims relayed their shock. "It's a dirty trick," said Adolf Bernard, 62, who spent more than a year in Spiegelgrund. "He was just playing to the court, which he should be able to do well after all his years of experience as a court doctor."

Mr Bernard was six when he entered the hospital. He recalled how Dr Gross had been nicknamed "the scythe", after the grim reaper. "He would put me in my bed out on the balcony, naked in the middle of winter in the hope I'd get pneumonia," said Mr Bernard.

Ms Haupl produced pictures from her handbag of her four-year old sister Annemarie taken by the staff, showing a crying blonde girl with a bloated belly.

"She was starved and poisoned and when she died she weighed less than a one-year-old," she said. "I had hoped that soon I could bury her brain, but goodness knows when that will be possible now."

Alois Kaufmann, who had been due to give evidence at the trial, said: "All we want is that somebody finally admits that he did what he did, simply a moral judgment - we don't benefit if he goes to jail or not."

In 1998 Mr Kaufmann, 66, was given £385 compensation for the 22 months he spent in Spiegelgrund. He had been admitted to the hospital at the age of 10. Even now he wakes up in the night screaming as a result of a recurring nightmare that he is back in the hospital.

"I've been waiting for 55 years for justice," he said. "I had hoped that the decision to have the trial meant that a new and better generation had emerged in Austria, after years of silence, but now I know it is really true that democracy in Austria is as a layer of tissue paper, behind which Nazi hordes still lurk."

Werner Vogt, one of Austria's top surgeons, who has campaigned for years for Dr Gross to be tried and in 1981 lost a libel battle against him, called the decision in what is probably the last trial of a Nazi doctor a farce. "I think Dr Gross is suffering from the Pinochet syndrome," he said.

fields.headline: Seeing red
fields.standfirst: Frank Dobson's attack on Chris Evans's hair colour has enraged gingers.  Martin Kelner  - once known as coppernob - reveals the trichological colour bar
fields.trailText: Blast Frank Dobson for bringing it up again. I am a more or less responsible adult now, with three children and a Marks & Spencer charge card. My mildly - and I think quite acceptably - auburn hair should not be an issue any more.
fields.body:
Blast Frank Dobson for bringing it up again. I am a more or less responsible adult now, with three children and a Marks & Spencer charge card. My mildly - and I think quite acceptably - auburn hair should not be an issue any more.

All that should have died with Ernie Hanson, the octogenarian maths master at the boys' school I attended who used to call me coppernob. In fact, he never called me anything else. He was our form master, and at registration every other boy was called by name. Not me, though. I was always coppernob.

This, as you can imagine, was seized upon by my classmates, which was not pleasant for a 12-year-old. And it meant that I wasted vital time - time that should have been spent worrying about my acne or the size of my penis - investigating hair dyes. And this was in the 1960s, when a school pupil with dyed hair was about as rare as a teacher without a tweed jacket.

This is not a bid for the sympathy vote, you understand. You expect to be picked on at school, but by the other kids, not by the teachers.

Having a go at the ginger kid, though, has always been deemed a harmless and amusing pastime, and remains the last available acceptable prejudice. I mean, would Ernie have picked on me if I were fat, or foreign, or bespectacled? Actually, that's a poor example: that's exactly what teachers did in those days. But 30-odd years on, you might expect Frank Dobson, who needs every blessed vote he can get, right across the trichological spectrum, to show a little more sensitivity.

I can accept that having a go at the ginger kid does become considerably more attractive when the ginger kid is Chris Evans, but Dobbo chose to attack Evans not for rampant megalomania, nor for fawning shamelessly over guests on his TV show, nor even for not being funny, but for the one thing the Warrington wunderkind cannot help - his hair colour.

Some of us, in fact, applaud Evans for the way he has flaunted his gingerness. On those drunken occasions that I have caught his Friday night programme, I have always felt a small glow of satisfaction when the Ginger Productions logo appears. I used to present a radio show in Leeds in the early 80s, on which both my assistants were similarly Titian-haired, and we used to call it the Proud to Be Ginger show - which, come to think of it, may explain our slightly disappointing audience figures.

Prejudice dies hard. One of my staff went on to form a pop group called The Three Gingers, who failed to find the kind of female following they were seeking - until they changed their name to Mutants of the Holocaust, which seems to convey the rather depressing message to those of us of the rust-coloured tendency that hideous mutation is somehow more sexually attractive than ginger hair.

So, bless Chris for somehow managing to be successful, and apparently sexually hyperactive, while remaining defiantly ginger-haired. It is interesting, though, that the hair colour issue is invariably raised when he is being criticised. Remember when he was moaning about the hours he was working on Radio One. I seem to recall the phrase "ginger whinger" featuring prominently in most of the news stories.

Neil Kinnock suffered similar prejudice. There are those who say he lost the 1992 general election because the nation was not ready for a ginger prime minister. But other factors have to be taken into consideration; such as the fact that he is also Welsh, unfeasibly voluble, and did choose to appear at a pre-election rally in Sheffield acting like a geography master at the sixth form disco.

Politics, of course, is often little more than a beauty contest, so I suppose we should not be surprised that ginger politicians are pretty thin on the ground. Most of them, I suspect, fail to get past the selection process. Charles Kennedy, however, has managed to make it to the summit of the Liberal Democrat party despite being slightly chubby as well as ginger (which must have presented his schoolmates with a real dilemma). Robin Cook, our other leading ginger politician, is by common consent a clever and able foreign secretary, and the fact that he has failed to find a firm place in the nation's affections may not be entirely down to his hair colour.

Something we gingers tend to become accustomed to during adolescence is that our hair is invariably found most attractive by women 40 or 50 years older than us. While I could never find anyone from the girls' school prepared to go to the youth club disco with me, I was never short of friends of my mother who loved to run their fingers through my hair and say, "Ooh, hasn't he got lovely hair." This, I suspect, was not a unique experience.

While red hair has, sadly, never been considered the height of sexual attractiveness in males, the opposite is apparently true for female red-heads. I did an internet search on the word "ginger" and the first site was described as follows: "Ginger Lynn motel 35 latino lesbians reluctant teen starlets ..." and so on.

Like Evans and the lovely Ginger Lynn, I plump for the word ginger when describing my hair colour these days. Just as some militant campaigners for gay rights like to use the word "queer" to show they are unashamed in the face of prejudice, I feel that it is time for we gingers, too, to be a little more brash. We're supposed to be a fiery lot anyway, and if even Dobbo - a man with a beard, for goodness sake - is going to have a go at us, perhaps it is time to live up to that reputation.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: • On page 7, March 20, we published an article concerning legal proceedings that have been brought against Robbie Williams. We now understand that the report contained a number of inaccuracies. In fact, Loudon Wainwright III has not sued Robbie Williams at all. Jesus In A Campervan by Robbie Williams contains just one line that was inspired by I Am The Way by Loudon Wainwright III. Williams's publisher has offered Ludlow Music 25% of the copyright in Jesus In A Campervan in recognition of this. It estimates that this is worth approximately £20,000 in publishing income. Ludlow Music is not satisfied with this and wants more, and has therefore issued proceedings.
fields.body:
 On page 7, March 20, we published an article concerning legal proceedings that have been brought against Robbie Williams. We now understand that the report contained a number of inaccuracies. In fact, Loudon Wainwright III has not sued Robbie Williams at all. Jesus In A Campervan by Robbie Williams contains just one line that was inspired by I Am The Way by Loudon Wainwright III. Williams's publisher has offered Ludlow Music 25% of the copyright in Jesus In A Campervan in recognition of this. It estimates that this is worth approximately £20,000 in publishing income. Ludlow Music is not satisfied with this and wants more, and has therefore issued proceedings.

 We credited the wrong photographer with our front page picture yesterday of a detective searching the rubbish bin where the stolen Oscars were found. It was taken by Damian Dovarganes.

 At the end of a report headed Fast-track curb on beggars, page 2, March 20, we quoted Nick Hardwick, the chief executive of the Refugee Council as saying, "In our view it is completely unacceptable to beg with children. We have constantly called for the decision-making process to be speeded up." He then added the following, "We think this can and must be done without compromising the fairness of the decision-making process." We omitted the words "and must" from the printed version. Sorry.

 In our report about the return of the Lindisfarne gospels to the north-east, page 5, March 20, we said they constituted "one of the oldest surviving works in the English language". They are in Latin (c700). An Anglo-Saxon gloss was added about 250 years later in the spaces between the lines of Latin text.

fields.headline: Mother knows best
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: I cannot conceive how the Dobson camp so badly mishandled everything. My mother, for several weeks, now in her dotage, lived in a state of complete turmoil waiting for her expulsion to come through the post. How can they be so very stupid?
fields.body:
I was born in a sprawling, Victorian mansion owned by my grandmother in Nassington Road, Hampstead. We lived in the former servants' quarters in the attic of the house and there was a mixed bunch of tenants on the other floors - writers, artists, poets, emigres or refugees from Hitler's Europe. All of them were card-carrying communists.

So in my childhood I was surrounded by eccentric intellectuals who would gather in front of my mother's fireplace long into the evening and debate the issues of the day, or recite their poetry. One of my earliest memories, sitting quietly in my pyjamas, is of a tousle-haired, dishevelled and red-faced poet called Dylan Thomas reciting a riveting poem he had just completed. He was reading it from the back of a large buff envelope and it was called Fern Hill. He held the room completely spellbound.

During the Russian invasion of Hungary in the 50s there was much discussion with all my parents' friends and our immediate neighbours around the same flickering fire, and most decided to leave the communist party in disgust. My mother had never actually carried the card, but was a strong sympathiser. After all, almost everyone we knew had fought in the Ninth Brigade on the Republican side of the Spanish civil war.

After Hungary, nearly all of them instead decided to lend whatever emotional, financial, and intellectual backing they could to the Socialist party and my mother then paid her dues as a Labour party activist.

She has done so ever since. She is still a member of the Hampstead party, where the resident MP is Glenda Jackson, but she now lives in Camden so her own MP is Frank Dobson. She had a serious clash of loyalties when both these MPs were balloting to become Labour candidate for London's mayor.

Both she and I have had cause to ask for Dobson's help from time to time and he has proved to be an excellent constituency member. As London Labourites we were also invited to a meeting in the Commons with Tony Blair while John Smith was still alive. She said after the meeting: "I really like his cut."

But along the way she also encountered Ken Livingstone. Ken and I had met on a couple of radio chat-shows and, by and large, it was pretty boring radio because we agreed on most issues. We did have a small spat on Clive Anderson's programme about political correctness, but on almost everything else Ken made very good sense.

He was in the political wilderness between the GLC and reaching parliament. But he was still very much a "London face". At the time my magazine, Scallywag, was still running and we held Wednesday lunches in a Camden pub where Ken came twice. Here he met my mother, who had begged us to invite her for that purpose.

Despite the fact that she was now in her late 70s and was a "garden party" Labourite from Hampstead, they got on like a house on fire. Even though my mother probably bored him to death, he was a complete gentleman - pleasant, polite, informative, erudite, and very good company. She became a Ken supporter overnight.

Then, a few weeks ago, she got a missive from the Dobson camp asking her, if there was a mayoral election, who she would support. There was a veiled threat that she was obliged to back the official labour party candidate. Now in her 80s, she panicked.

This Hampstead Labourite (Glenda) with a Camden MP (Dobson), was instinctively rooting for Ken. She called me in a state of real consternation because after a virtual life as a member, she now risked being expelled. She was actually quite terrified of answering the poll.

She was living proof that the mayoral issue was deeply dividing the party. And Tony Blair had seemed to be doing so well. My mother was not so much divided as wrenched. Her loyalties to the Labour party, however, also forbade her to ignore it. She told me after much agitated discussion: "I'm going to hold my nose and dive off the top board. I'm going for Ken, whatever they say or do to me."

She afterwards had many sleepless nights. I imagine this has happened to many dedicated Labourites. My mother is just one small voice which encapsulates the dilemma.
