fields.bodyText: I was born in a sprawling, Victorian mansion owned by my grandmother in Nassington Road, Hampstead. We lived in the former servants' quarters in the attic of the house and there was a mixed bunch of tenants on the other floors - writers, artists, poets, emigres or refugees from Hitler's Europe. All of them were card-carrying communists. So in my childhood I was surrounded by eccentric intellectuals who would gather in front of my mother's fireplace long into the evening and debate the issues of the day, or recite their poetry. One of my earliest memories, sitting quietly in my pyjamas, is of a tousle-haired, dishevelled and red-faced poet called Dylan Thomas reciting a riveting poem he had just completed. He was reading it from the back of a large buff envelope and it was called Fern Hill. He held the room completely spellbound. During the Russian invasion of Hungary in the 50s there was much discussion with all my parents' friends and our immediate neighbours around the same flickering fire, and most decided to leave the communist party in disgust. My mother had never actually carried the card, but was a strong sympathiser. After all, almost everyone we knew had fought in the Ninth Brigade on the Republican side of the Spanish civil war. After Hungary, nearly all of them instead decided to lend whatever emotional, financial, and intellectual backing they could to the Socialist party and my mother then paid her dues as a Labour party activist. She has done so ever since. She is still a member of the Hampstead party, where the resident MP is Glenda Jackson, but she now lives in Camden so her own MP is Frank Dobson. She had a serious clash of loyalties when both these MPs were balloting to become Labour candidate for London's mayor. Both she and I have had cause to ask for Dobson's help from time to time and he has proved to be an excellent constituency member. As London Labourites we were also invited to a meeting in the Commons with Tony Blair while John Smith was still alive. She said after the meeting: "I really like his cut." But along the way she also encountered Ken Livingstone. Ken and I had met on a couple of radio chat-shows and, by and large, it was pretty boring radio because we agreed on most issues. We did have a small spat on Clive Anderson's programme about political correctness, but on almost everything else Ken made very good sense. He was in the political wilderness between the GLC and reaching parliament. But he was still very much a "London face". At the time my magazine, Scallywag, was still running and we held Wednesday lunches in a Camden pub where Ken came twice. Here he met my mother, who had begged us to invite her for that purpose. Despite the fact that she was now in her late 70s and was a "garden party" Labourite from Hampstead, they got on like a house on fire. Even though my mother probably bored him to death, he was a complete gentleman - pleasant, polite, informative, erudite, and very good company. She became a Ken supporter overnight. Then, a few weeks ago, she got a missive from the Dobson camp asking her, if there was a mayoral election, who she would support. There was a veiled threat that she was obliged to back the official labour party candidate. Now in her 80s, she panicked. This Hampstead Labourite (Glenda) with a Camden MP (Dobson), was instinctively rooting for Ken. She called me in a state of real consternation because after a virtual life as a member, she now risked being expelled. She was actually quite terrified of answering the poll. She was living proof that the mayoral issue was deeply dividing the party. And Tony Blair had seemed to be doing so well. My mother was not so much divided as wrenched. Her loyalties to the Labour party, however, also forbade her to ignore it. She told me after much agitated discussion: "I'm going to hold my nose and dive off the top board. I'm going for Ken, whatever they say or do to me." She afterwards had many sleepless nights. I imagine this has happened to many dedicated Labourites. My mother is just one small voice which encapsulates the dilemma. I cannot conceive how the Dobson camp so badly mishandled everything. My mother, for several weeks, now in her dotage, lived in a state of complete turmoil waiting for her expulsion to come through the post. How can they be so very stupid? She has, of course, now been completely vindicated. A vast majority of Londoners of every party have said they will vote for Ken, regardless. And after she has been put through so much stress, so will I.

webTitle: Inflation number crunching is back in fashion at last

fields.headline: Inflation number crunching is back in fashion at last
fields.trailText: Vogue magazine clearly is not required reading down at Drummond Gate, where government number crunchers have finally twigged that women do not wear leggings any more.
fields.body:
Vogue magazine clearly is not required reading down at Drummond Gate, where government number crunchers have finally twigged that women do not wear leggings any more.

The garment which was the 1980s alternative to jeans has been dropped this year from the basket of goods used to measure price pressures in the economy - about 10 years after most women stopped wearing them in public.

As well as replacing leggings with shorts, the office for national statistics has made a number of other changes to retail prices index reflect changing tastes and shopping habits.

Admission fees at bingo halls are out, replaced by charges at tenpin bowling allies. Out go luncheon meat, custard powder and tinned ravioli, while in come broccoli, prepacked salads and takeway pizzas.

For the first time, the retail prices index will attempt to measure prices on the internet. The ONS said it would include books and toys commonly bought over the internet in the basket, but the weighting given to e-commerce is just 0.05% of the index, reflecting the tiny size of the sector.

The ONS said yesterday that underlying inflation had drifted upwards in February to 2.2%, from 2.1% the previous months.

However, it remains well below the target of 2.5% which the government has set for the Bank of England, and economists said the rise was a 'blip' and unlikely to worry Threadneedle Street policymakers.

"Overall, the data make it all the harder for the Bank England to justify another rate hike next month unless the chancellor is especially generous in his budget, which we doubt," said Jeremy Hawkins of Bank of America.

The underlying measure strips out changes in mortgate interest payments which have jumped since the Bank started raising interest rates last Septem ber. As a result, headline inflation has risen sharply over the last four months, from 1.2% in October to 2.3% in February.

Mr Hawkins said it was encouraging that inflation in the services sector had levelled off.

"At 4.2% there will be some relief that inflation in the service sector showed no further pick-up - a 0.1 percent year-on-year rate for goods producing area underlines the very intense competition in this sector," he added.

fields.headline: BASF pays $3.8bn for AHP's Cyanamid
fields.trailText: The consolidation among the world's crop protection companies took another step forward yesterday when German chemicals maker BASF disclosed it was buying American Home Products' Cyanamid business for $3.8bn (£2.42bn).
fields.body:
The consolidation among the world's crop protection companies took another step forward yesterday when German chemicals maker BASF disclosed it was buying American Home Products' Cyanamid business for $3.8bn (£2.42bn).

BASF is understood to have outbid rival German group Bayer as well as DuPont in order to land Cyanamid in a deal which will double the size of its crop protection business.

The acquisition follows last December's announcement that AstraZeneca and Novartis were to merge their crop protection business to form Syngenta - a move about which the European Commission expressed reservations yesterday.

Industry experts say the crop protection companies are being forced to consolidate because of the costs of research and development are outstripping growth in the market. Cyanamid is seen as a good partner for BASF. "From a production point of view the two businesses fit well together. BASF is strong in herbicides and fungicides, AHP in insecticides," said Michael Butscher, an analyst at Merck Fink.

However, there was some concern that BASF may be paying a heavy price for Cyanamid, which will put the German firm into fourth place in the world crop protection industry behind Syngenta, Aventis and Monsanto.

The deal also puts a question mark over the future of AHP, which became primarily a pharmaceuticals company following the sale of Cyanamid.

It has tried on several occasions to merge with other drug manufacturers and yesterday's deal is seen as making it attractive to suitors which would like to establish a presence in the US or to expand existing operations there.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: United sells Express HQ
fields.body:
United sells Express HQ

United News & Media, owner of Express newspapers, yesterday sold Ludgate House, its headquarters on the south bank of the Thames, for £69m.

The landmark building with its imposing views of St Paul's Cathedral has been bought by the property group Minerva. United, run by Labour peer Lord Hollick, has signed a lease for 15 years at £4.87m per annum although Minerva has the right to evict the media group after 10 years.

United moved into the building when it was finished in 1989 and it was promptly nicknamed the grey Lubianka, after the company's former Fleet Street home, known widely as the black Lubianka.

The company is currently planning a merger with Carlton Communications while Granada has also said it might bid for one of the two companies, creating considerable uncertainty.

Freecom hires Coleman

Freecom.net, the ambitious e-commerce enabler for small and medium-sized businesses, has beefed up its management team by hiring Paul Coleman of Carlisle Holdings as its finance director. Mr Coleman's departure from Carlisle comes just months after chairman Peter Fox left. Neither position is being filled at the Channel Islands-registered contract cleaning and property investment company.

Bonanza for Goldman staff

Partners in Wall Street's premier investment bank, Goldman Sachs, are heading for another bonanza this year. First-quarter figures show a 67% rise in profits - well ahead of expectations. Goldman, which went public almost a year ago in a $3.7bn (£2.3bn) offer, earned $887m in the first quarter, up from $532m in the same period last year. Investment banking revenues hit $1.2bn in the first quarter, stock trading earnings shot to a record $2.1bn and bond trading brought in another $1bn. Asset management revenues were 59% higher than last year at $1.2bn. If profits growth continues Goldman's 15,000 employee-partners - who last year picked up an average $580,000 (£360,000) - might see even better earnings in 2000.

EC clears way for BSkyB deal

The European commission said yesterday that it had conditionally cleared BSkyB's acquisition of a 24% stake in KirchGruppe's KirchPay TV. The parties have undertaken to enable digital interactive TV service providers to establish their own technical platform and to compete with Kirch's by giving them access to Kirch's pay-TV services, the commission said.

fields.headline: Accountancy inquiry into Versailles
fields.standfirst:
Profession's role in collapsed trading group under scrutiny

www.versailles.co.uk
fields.trailText: Investigators from the accountancy profession are to scan the books of Versailles, the collapsed trading group at the centre of a serious fraud office inquiry, it was announced yesterday. They will look at the role played by the chartered accountants who worked for the company and at its auditors, Nunn Hayward.
fields.body:
Investigators from the accountancy profession are to scan the books of Versailles, the collapsed trading group at the centre of a serious fraud office inquiry, it was announced yesterday. They will look at the role played by the chartered accountants who worked for the company and at its auditors, Nunn Hayward.

The joint disciplinary scheme will start immediately. Its head, Chris Dickson, former assistant director at the SFO, said it was "difficult to know" how long it would take.

Versailles collapsed after gaps thought to total well over £100m were discovered in its accounts. The group admitted late last year that double counting in its accounts might have inflated the turnover of about £250m by £80m, although it said this would not affect profits.

It is thought likely Mr Dickson will keep in close touch with his former colleagues at the SFO, although the two inquiries are entirely separate. The joint disciplinary scheme is seeking breaches of the professional rules that bind accountants and has no authority to deal with anybody who is not a member of an accountancy body.

None of the six directors, including finance director Frederick Clough, is thought to have been registered as an accountant. But two chartered accountants are believed to have worked in the Versailles accounts department, and they will be interviewed.

The joint scheme will want also to know how Nunn Hayward, the small accountancy firm based in Gerrards Cross, Buckinghamshire, signed off Versailles accounts despite all the irregularities that have since come to light.

A specialist practice, Forensic Accounting, has been hired by the joint disciplinary scheme to help the inquiry.

Forensic will compile a report for the joint scheme, which will then decide on the basis of the report whether to press charges at a professional tribunal, headed by a QC with two accountants. Penalties might extend to expulsion from the profession, although there is a right of appeal.

Even before the inquiry was announced, details have come to light of unorthodox accounting at Versailles.

Its "client services department" kept confidential customer details and separate sets of books which make it difficult to trace back from published profits to actual trade-finance deals.

Furthermore, a home counties-based "fan club" of wealthy individuals came in with Versailles on a number of deals in a complex system of parallel financing that pumped at least £2.5m into the company in the mid-1990s.

Versailles is now in receivership. Its principal bankers, NatWest, Royal Bank of Scotland and Barclays, are owed in total as much as £60m.

fields.headline: Focus
fields.standfirst: Glynwed
fields.trailText: The old economy, dumped out of the Footsie, may be fighting back in the markets but one way to ensure long-term favour is to embrace dot.com values with a vengeance and talk yourself up as a new world company.
fields.body:
The old economy, dumped out of the Footsie, may be fighting back in the markets but one way to ensure long-term favour is to embrace dot.com values with a vengeance and talk yourself up as a new world company.

Step forward Glynwed International. The 700,000 "Good Lifers" who use their Aga and Rayburn cast-iron cookers, collect the kids from prep school in 4x4s and tramp the Chilterns in Barbours and green wellies are to be offered a lifestyle portal.

Last year Glynwed abandoned metal-bashing when it sold its foundries to focus on food service equipment and plastic pipes and spent £250m on acquiring Canada's IPEX pipes business. The impact of this restructuring on last year's results was pre-figured and, sure enough, group pre-tax earnings came in at £71.8m compared with £77.4m a year earlier. But sales in the continuing business rose from £549m to £800m, with trading profit up from £53.6m to £86.7m.

Tony Wilson, chief executive, is promising pay-back this year, with operating margins up to 12% and the return on capital to 15%. Even the bedraggled engineering analysts were impressed, with Glynwed shares up 8.25p to close at 208.25p.

But it's the thought of those AB Aga-owners that excites. The cooker business may account for just 10% of turnover but Glynwed, promising to sell online, has appointed KPMG to seek out media partners for its lifestyle portal: offering fine wines, recipes, exotic hols et al.

Even the pipes business, the lion's share of the group's activities, and the food equipment operation are going online. Wait for www.capperplastics.com hardly a debby domain but offering a 24-hour distribution service to customers.

Mr Wilson is promising "tremendous savings" -but it's the spending patterns of his cooker clients that presage a better future.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.body:
With the Budget taking over the afternoon session in the stock market, and with a rate rise in the US widely predicted, there was only cautious movement for the FTSE 100 yesterday, with the index ending just 6.6 points lower at 6,617.9.

The Techmark index was, however, a big loser again, down 291 points, echoing the continued fall of the Nasdaq.

Baltimore was down £22.51 at £81, Celltech Group shed 128p to £12.74, Psion lost 590p to £48.06, and Freeserve was off 82p at 449p.

Meanwhile, the old economy chugged upwards: Marks & Spencer gained 14p at 248p, with sales of its new designer Autograph range reported to be doing well. Aside from these, however, there was little non- Budget related movement. There was little Budget related movement either.

Gordon Brown's speech brought trading to a standstill and few of his pronouncements moved the market. Dealers pointed out that the equity market could be encouraged by the chancellor's bullish British growth forecasts, which could be taken as an indication that interest rates will not need to be raised any further.

Among the few Budget features, news of a halving in air passenger duty for European flights - to £5 per person provided a modest lift to airline and airport issues, although most were already firmer thanks to a switch back to old economy interest.

BAA rose 16p to 451p, while British Airways , in need of some good news, gained 13p to 326p.

Drink groups were cheered by another freezing of the duty on spirits, with Allied Domecq , now a second liner, improving 43p to 329p.

Pharmaceutical issues benefited from the chancellor's plans to significantly boost its spending on the health service. Glaxo Wellcome rose 74p to £18.60, with SmithKline Beecham up 14p at 848p and AstraZeneca climbing 94p to £26.98.

Brewers were relieved by news of just a penny rise to the duty on beer. Whitbread added 17p to 533p and Scottish & Newcastle gained 12p to 403p.

Despite the 5% above the rate of inflation increase on duty on cigarettes, tobacco shares more than held their own, presumably safe in the knowledge that smokers are unlikely to quit as a result of a few extra pennies on an already expensive habit.

Imperial Tobacco put on 20p at 504p, while Gallaher was up 10p at 278p.

Shares in BAT were off 24p at 299p after news overnight that US tobacco firms Reynolds and Philip Morris lost a key court case in California.

fields.headline: Attack of the blurbmeisters
fields.standfirst: The power of the critic
fields.trailText: For a report on the current state of American film criticism, the showbiz weekly Variety polled four dozen US film-makers - nearly all of whom insisted on remaining anonymous, the pusillanimous lot. "I can't name one critic that I trust," was a typical response.
fields.body:
Last week the showbiz weekly Variety pulled one of its occasional variations on its most notorious headline, the one about Tom Mix westerns going down badly with rural audiences ("Hix Nix Mix Piz"). The latest version is "Pix Nix Crix Shticks" or, "Reviewers get thumbs-down from film-makers." For a report on the current state of American film criticism, the paper polled four dozen US film-makers - nearly all of whom insisted on remaining anonymous, the pusillanimous lot.

"I can't name one critic that I trust," was a typical response. The general feeling was that critics are not as reliable as they were. There are some exceptions: many film-makers favoured the New Yorker's British import Anthony Lane, for general literacy and credibility.

It was felt that real criticism had been supplanted by a surfeit of blurbmeisters, the hacks whose inane effusions always guarantee a quote for the ads. Variety annually prints its own selection of prize blurbs, and although the latest bunch isn't as loopy as the vintage, it has its highlights. Hail to one Patty Spitler on The Bone Collector - "It will make you gasp, sweat and squeal!"; to the astute Jim Svejda of CBS for acclaiming "Milla Jovovich's astonishing Oscar-calibre performance as Joan of Arc"; and for pithy concision, to one Maria Salas - "End of Days rocks!"

Where print critics used to dominate the blurbs, Variety reports, studios are increasingly quoting from internet reviews. There's a widespread perception of internet critics as fly-by-night troublemakers; even Harvey Karten, of the Online Film Critics Society, is quoted as admitting, "The vast majority of internet critics are bad news, semi-literate people." However, Karten promises that the reviews on his website are "maturely written things". Judge for yourself at www.ofcs.org: on a random dip, I found a fair proportion of featherweight stuff, but among the OFCS's list of 89 members are a handful of respected names. But another 89 critics in the world? That's scary.

It's interesting that the American film industry should be worried about standards of criticism at all. In Britain, critics make little or no difference to the state of the industry. In the US, we're told, reviews can still make or break a film, but the fate of most of the films released in Britain has been sealed elsewhere by the time we see them.

But even in the US, crit power may only be a matter of interest to insiders. According to Variety's poll of filmgoers, only 28% felt critics' opinions were important, while 70% felt friends' opinions mattered. A total 61% said they ignored the critics, while 57% felt "critics can't relate to normal audiences". You almost feel like packing up your thesaurus and going home.

Alternatively, why not benefit from the implications of those findings? If a critic's business is no longer to advise people how to spend £7 on a Friday night, then perhaps it should be aiming at something more ambitious: to involve anyone who's interested in a good polemical dialogue about what a film means in the context of the real world. In other words, we should be talking about the big picture, not just the big movie.

A model in this respect is the scholarly Jonathan Rosenbaum, who writes in the Chicago Reader (www.chireader.com/movies). Rosenbaum's weekly reviews are of an enviable length, range from mainstream features to avant-garde shorts, and always extend the scope of the argument. His latest review, of Jim Jarmusch's Ghost Dog, touches on the cultural assumptions we make when we see an Iranian or French art film, and on the globalising implications of English as the dominant internet language.

There's a distinction often made between "critics" and "reviewers" - sometimes snobbishly, sometimes pragmatically on the basis of what critics have space to write. Rosenbaum proves that a reviewer can be a critic and a theorist too. Given the exceptional amount of space he has, maybe we'd all be real critics. The space consideration is something the internet might conceivably solve; then again, we might end up scrolling down screen after screen telling us how Milla Jovovich rocks.

webTitle: It's the visionary enterprise capitalists wot get the pleasure ...

fields.headline: It's the visionary enterprise capitalists wot get the pleasure ...
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown resembled a shore leave sailor in a dockside pub, pockets stuffed with fivers. "Ish only 'cosh I'm sho pruden' I've gorrall thish money to shpen."
fields.body:
Gordon Brown resembled a shore leave sailor in a dockside pub, pockets stuffed with fivers. "Ish only 'cosh I'm sho pruden' I've gorrall thish money to shpen."

"Oo wanz a drink? Hey, you, trible Drambuie for my fren'. Yer see, I'm pruden', thash wha' I am ... "

Well of course he didn't sound like that, but there was some extravagant bragging to go with the giveaways. These included up to £50,000 for schools with more than a thousand pupils to be spent as the head teacher wishes.

Most polling stations are in schools. So we can expect to pop in to vote and see a sign saying: "This fine mahogany trophy cabinet [or possibly the staff room sub to Penthouse] provided through the generosity and prudence of Mr Gordon Brown."

"Prudence" and variations received nine mentions, "boom and bust" only two, but "cautious" made several appearances, as did "locked into fiscal tightening".

They finally merged into a pair of convoluted, buttock-clenching phrases: "we have decided on a prudent and responsible approach which will lock in fiscal tightening"; and my own favourite: "because we have not spent more, and will not spend more, at the expense of being prudent!", a sentence which curls around itself and finally disappears up its own fiscal black hole.

I get the impression that the chancellor finds this kind of talk rather exciting. I expect he secretly combs West End phone boxes looking at the cards: "Gorgeous model locks in fiscal tightening", or "Prudence with optional massage? Oriental lovely of fers personal tax relief." The chancellor has also invented a new phrase, "the civic society", which seems to be code for "creating more jobs so that young men don't go round stealing car radios."

It sounded rather quaint: "Mr G Brown will give a slide lecture next week entitled 'Bygone Kirkcaldy' to the civic society ..."

He sat down to enthusiastic if not overwhelming applause from his own side and a glum silence from the other. At this stage it is William Hague's traditional role to cheer his party up - which he did with a rumbustious attack on everyone.

He quoted Alastair Campbell's first on the record lobby briefing in which, when asked about tax rises, he replied with this crisp analysis: "Yeah, those are the figures, as set out in the last PBR, either the Budget or whatever, the red book, the projections, had they been, yeah, I dunno, whatever."

"It's no consolation," said Mr Hague, to happy laughter from his side, "that the real deputy prime minister is no more eloquent than the official one."

The official one, John Prescott, sat there scowling. He may not loath being attacked in the commons any more than anyone else, but it looks that way.

Mr Hague also referred to Labour's "heartlands".

I am not sure when this became a synonym for "poor." Again our great works of literature will have to be rewritten: "blessed are the heartlands, for they shall have a 50% rise in winter supplement" and "it's the visionary enterprise capitalists who take advantage of the technological revolution wot gets the pleasure, it's the heartlands gets the blame."

Mr Brown watched the Hague speech with what passes for a merry smile on his face and would look like terminal heartburn on anybody else's. But of course even sailors on leave have to face up to reality the morning after. With Mr Brown's budgets, the hangover tends to come after a week or so.

fields.headline: Going for a song
fields.standfirst: Paddy McAloon made Prefab Sprout one of Britain's favourite bands. Now you can buy the albums for just 10p.  Tom Cox asks him how he feels about that
fields.trailText: Paddy McAloon made Prefab Sprout one of Britain's favourite bands. Now you can buy the albums for just 10p. Tom Cox asks him how he feels about that.
fields.body:
The hotel room is supposed to house Paddy McAloon, the singer and songwriter behind Prefab Sprout, but it's Orson Welles - distinguished grey beard, foppish hair, black waistcoat, academician eyewear - who opens the door. Only when he speaks do you spot the McAloon of old: the stubbly motorcycle outlaw from the 1985 LP Steve McQueen, the clean-shaven neo-romantic of 1988's From Langley Park to Memphis.

For someone so anti-image, McAloon makes a pretty good pop chameleon. It's one of many contradictions that make you wonder just where Prefab Sprout fit in. Overproduced smoothies or astute sonic designers? Elvis-obsessed Yankophiles or provincial English idealists? Only McAloon could write a critique of Bruce Springsteen's hot rods-and-chicks worldview as sharp as Cars and Girls, then end the track with a line as ambiguous as, "I guess this world needs its dreamers... May they never wake up." Prefab Sprout are also one of the few bands who could be described as both "bargain-bin" and "critically acclaimed".

These days, if you go to enough second-hand record stores, you can get the entire Sprout back catalogue for under a tenner. Last year I bought a new copy of 1989's masterpiece Protest Songs for 10p. How does McAloon feel about that? "There was a time when I would have been quite upset about it, but you can't really afford to get precious. I'm lucky to be still here getting paid for making music." Perhaps this is the low point in the lifecycle of the Sprout catalogue, and in 20 years it will be collectors' stuff? McAloon seems genuinely pleased at the idea.

Sixteen years after Prefab released their first album, Swoon, McAloon still seems to care about feedback. Perhaps that's because there's been so little of it recently. The band have released just one album in the past decade, 1997's Andromeda Heights; the inactivity forced Paddy's brother Martin and his ex-girlfriend Wendy Smith to take up teaching (though Martin is still with the band). McAloon himself made ends meet by writing songs for Cher and Jimmy Nail. Yet he claims to have been even more prolific in the 90s than he was in the 80s, and to have stockpiled around 150 songs that he would consider people hearing. So why doesn't he just release them?

"When we signed with a major label (CBS) in the mid-80s, my songs suddenly had a monetary value, which made me think about what I should be writing about if each song is worth something, and made me save songs in case I dried up. I made a rod for my own back: a lot of those songs might be past their sell-by date now because they're about subjects that might seem a little tasteless." Two of McAloon's unreleased projects are concept albums about Princess Diana and Michael Jackson.

Despite never wanting to be one, he's always been interested in celebrities: Springsteen, Elvis, even God. "I don't name-drop as much now," he says. "That's a weakness in my earlier style. Those name-drops make the ears prick up, but the effect over a period of time will be different. One day that person's name will have a different kind of resonance for your listener."

It's interesting that McAloon should be concerned about keeping in tune with the times, when Prefab Sprout have always stood just outside them. After getting their first band together in Newcastle in 1977, McAloon and his brother quickly became disenchanted with punk's year-zero mentality. "It suddenly seemed like a lot of music critics and musicians had reinvented themselves as people who didn't have a record collection until the summer of 1976. Secretly, I was always listening to Aja by Steely Dan."

Super-slick but never losing sight of the fact that music should be a tonic for the spirit rather than the ego, Prefab Sprout were the Steely Dan of the 80s. That may explain why they were so desperately uncool in the 90s - and suggests they'll go through some sort of renaissance in the noughties.

What's often forgotten about Prefab Sprout is that they were brave enough to introduce highfalutin ideas, convoluted melodies and cunning ironies into the most audience-friendly pop formula. In the track Faron Young, from Steve McQueen, the name of a country firebrand is just a starting point for McAloon's attempts to pre-empt David Bowie's mutation into a roots-rocker. "I was listening to all this American country music and wondering what people living down the road got out of it. You could say the same thing with rap now: why is it so big in England? It's the strangeness, but it's also real_ It may not be real in your little pocket of the world, but it's glamorous-real, which is what Elvis with echo on his voice must have sounded like to Lennon and McCartney."

McAloon, 42, has had an uneven few years. He got married - to Victoria, whom he met in a Newcastle music shop - and is now a father. He also had to have a metal buckle fitted behind his right eye to prevent his retina disintegrating. But he's working again, recording random documentaries from the radio, chopping them up, writing them down, then introducing an outside voice to read them over his music. "I call it fake poetry, because nobody's intended it to mean anything, yet it's organised so it has a certain emotional pull."

That material isn't likely to feature in Prefab Sprout's forthcoming tour (that's a story in itself - McAloon has made no secret of his dislike of gigging). But McAloon will probably find room for the latest single, Where the Heart Is. That song was actually released in limited numbers three years ago; it seems very like McAloon to be reissuing an old track rather than something new.

Where the Heart Is was originally the theme tune for a TV series, and it seems odd that McAloon hasn't done more soundtrack work: his widescreen, picturesque harmonies could do a lot for the cinema. "I've lost all ambition in that area," he says, "because you're subjugating to someone else's image. I'm thinking in pictures as I'm making it, so I'm pre-empting someone else's job. On the surface of it, it should be great, but if a bloke's singing about Manhattan and making it sound like Manhattan, to have a film of Manhattan to go with it might be overegging the pudding. As John Barry would say, you've got to creep underneath the scene to make a good soundtrack, and I think it's vanity to think that I'm suited to that work." He's being ridiculously modest again, of course, but you can see his point: the only screen that McAloon's ever needed is the one behind those spectacles.

 Where The Heart Is is released on May 8. Prefab Sprout play the Royal Centre, Nottingham (0115-989 5555), on March 30, then tour.

fields.headline: The sins of the fathers
fields.standfirst: Australia and New Zealand are still trying to come to terms with their bloody pasts. In the theatre they actually seem to be getting somewhere.  Michael Billington  reports
fields.trailText: Australia and New Zealand are still trying to come to terms with their bloody pasts. In the theatre they actually seem to be getting somewhere.
fields.body:
The people's party is full of glint-eyed opportunists on cellular phones. Idealism has been replaced by faith in the global market. Business tycooons are being wooed at the expense of core working-class voters.

It sounds like an attack on Blair's Britain by David Hare or Howard Brenton. In fact, it's the key argument of The Great Man, a satire on the Australian Labor Party by David Williamson that is drawing capacity crowds to the Sydney Theatre Company. Thirty years ago Williamson wrote a landmark play, Don's Party, about fading radical hopes after yet another Labor defeat. Now, after long periods of Labor government - the party was in power from 1983 to 1996 - he writes brutally about the compromises of office.

Williamson's play is a stark reminder that the left the world over faces the same problems: in particular, the sacrifice of ideology to economic rationalism. It also proves that Australians like their satire red in tooth and claw.

Williamson's fictional, recently dead hero was a key minister in the reforming Whitlam government of 1972-75. His widow, Fleur, gathers his old mates together to prepare the funeral orations. What we see is the dismantling of a myth, as the hero's private and political failures are revealed, leading to exposure of financial chicanery.

In a sense Williamson subverts his own thesis that the left has lost its political soul - the discovery that the hero created a secret slush fund suggests it never had much of a soul to start with. But Williamson has the gift - which we temporarily seem to have lost - of writing big, popular plays on political subjects. The nearest British equivalent would be Hare and Brenton's Pravda. And Robyn Nevin's production is performed with great gusto, not least by Max Cullen as a pissed painter who declares, "Our 60s didn't happen till the 70s," and by Gary Day as a rogue politician who sees the impending funeral as a heaven-sent photo-opportunity.

But the real issue that haunts the national conscience is that of the aborigines - how to make good the injustices of the past. While I was there the prime minister, John Howard, backtracked on a promised gesture of reconciliation. The widespread feeling was that a great opportunity had been missed.

Australia, however, has an enviable knack of turning social problems into creative opportunities, and it hit me, like a thunderclap, that it is in the arts that the real racial reconciliation is taking place. I caught the last performance by the vibrant Sydney Theatre Company, which has to raise 80% of its income through box office, of a lively, tuneful, generous-spirited musical called The Sunshine Club. Set in the 40s, it showed an aboriginal soldier returning from wartime service and setting up an interracial dance club in defiance of the curfew laws of the time. When the hero falls for a white girl they inevitably come up against parental intransigence and social hostility. But the real point was how much Australia has moved on - in an ironic present-day coda we see a director of mixed parentage auditioning white actors. Art reflects life: the show itself was written and directed by the brightly talented Wesley Enoch, who has an aboriginal father and a mother of Spanish- Danish descent, and who told me he looks forward to the not-too-distant day when 60% of Australians will be of mixed blood.

Assimilation, of course, brings its problems; this is the theme of an outstanding solo show, White Baptist Abba Fan, which Britons will have a chance to see when it comes to the Barbican in July as part of a festival celebrating Australia's centenary of federation. Written and performed by Deborah Cheetham, it has a devastating autobiographical truth. Taken from her mother as a baby by a Salvation Army officer, Cheetham was brought up as an "adopted aboriginal" by a white middle-class family, studied music at Sydney Conservatorium and is now a fast- rising opera singer. Professional gain, however, is accompanied by emotional loss. Meeting her real family, she is first seen by them as "a self-opinionated lesbian snob" and only gradually comes to terms with her racial identity. The hauntingly poignant story is leavened by Cheetham's graceful rendering of arias by Handel, Puccini and Gounod; whether she remains an Abba fan I'm not quite sure.

Another work on the forcible removal of aboriginal children from their parents, Jane Harrison's Stolen, directed by Wesley Enoch, comes to London's Tricycle theatre in July. But it would be wrong to suggest the per vasive note is one of guilt or recrimination. Sheer creative joy was the theme of an exhibition of modern aboriginal art, Beyond the Pale, that I saw at the Adelaide festival. This is a show that would cause a sensation in London or New York.

At the same venue, the Art Gallery of South Australia, I also caught a remarkable performance, Ochre and Dust, by two elderly aboriginal storytellers. Seated on top of a huge sandstone mound, the women kept us enthralled for 80 minutes with their stories of their battles with former PM Malcolm Fraser over the rights to Ayers Rock. They described the concern they shared with urban whites over dissolute grandchildren: "Down here," they claimed, "they're sniffing glue; up there they're sniffing petrol." At the same time, they lamented the harsh mandatory sentencing meted out to aboriginal delinquents. Out of the texture of their lives they created a piece of narrative theatre that Peter Brook might have envied.

fields.headline: The best corporate scene
fields.standfirst: The Insider
fields.trailText: The Insider
fields.body:
In the offices of Kentucky tobacco corporation Brown And Williamson, former research scientist Jeffrey Wigand (Russell Crowe) has been summoned back to meet with Chief Executive Thomas Sandefur (Michael Gambon).

With a crew of lawyers hovering around him, Sandefur beams malignantly.

"So, you had a chance to play golf?"

Wigand shifts in his seat; before he can reply, Sandefur has turned to his legal team, still wearing the same wolfish smile.

"Jeffrey's a premier golfer."

He turns back to Wigand.

"What, two handicap?"

"Seven."

Sandefur returns to his lawyers.

"And he goes out there and he has five strokes on it. He's got more concentration than any man I've ever met. It's spooky the way he can concentrate."

Wigand scowls.

"I'd rather play than talk about it. What do you want to see me about? I don't like being back here."

Sandefur keeps grinning.

"Now, Jeffrey says exactly what's on his mind. Most people consider what they're saying. Social skills. Jeffrey just charges right ahead."

He gazes at his former employee, eyes narrowed.

"I hope you understand the nature of our confidentiality agreement_You know, I came up through sales. And one of the reasons I was a great salesman was that I never made a promise I couldn't keep. I never broke a promise - and if I did, I'd accept the consequences."

Wigand stares back.

"Is that a threat?"

See also: Network, Office Space, RoboCop, Rollerball

Don't see also: Holy Man

Pointless trivia: Russell Crowe has smoked since the age of 10.

fields.headline: Work to rule
fields.standfirst: 'Best value' is a new regime designed to ensure  quality in public services. Peter Hetherington on  ministers' campaign to make local authorities more  accountable
fields.trailText: 'Best value' is a new regime designed to ensure quality in public services. Peter Hetherington on ministers' campaign to make local authorities more accountable.
fields.body:
Never before has local government faced such an array of new regulations designed to bring poorly performing councils to heel. Officially, it begins with the introduction of a consumerist "best value" regime in 10 days' time, underpinned by a raft of centrally-determined performance indicators to improve the quality of services.

Everything from the condition of roads, the average time taken to remove fly-tips, the amount of household waste recycled, to the percentage of pavements cleared of dog fouling - even the number of public toilets provided by a council - will come under regular review alongside more weightier matters like fire, police, housing, social services and education.

But for council personnel and human resources directors, whose professional organisation, Socpo, begins its annual conference in Brighton today, that's just the start. The men and women representing some of the country's biggest employers - for local government employs 2.1m in England and Wales alone - know that if services fall below set standards, the government will step in. While the threat may be distant, the prospect of regular visits from an army of new inspectors who will monitor performance isn't.

Like schools, and social services departments, local councils will now face regular inspections from a special new, 400-strong unit in the audit commission, established at a cost of £40m under Newham council's former chief executive, Wendy Thomson.

For Terry Gorman, president-elect of Socpo and Nottinghamshire county council's assistant chief executive, best value represents more of a challenge than a threat. With 24,000 Notts employees under his wing, the county council, serving 700,000 people, has been preparing for best value for some time. It even has a best value board to monitor standards, which includes people from outside county hall including a banker and a former director of Boots.

Like other councils, Notts has set in train an elaborate system of public consultation to underpin best value, with a 1,000-strong "people's panel" - which is regularly consulted - and another panel of 500 key stakeholders in the county.

Like other senior town and county hall officials, Terry Gorman says it's the biggest challenge he's faced in 30 years in local government. While not decrying the new regime - "most of it makes sense" - he has a few fears that the inspection and auditing process which every council will soon face could prove overbearing and inflexible, with authorities serving the regime more than the public. "If we spend our time just ticking boxes, it will be self-defeating and it could be that we lose touch with what we are about - serving the people."

Perhaps with an eye on the Ofsted regime in education, he fears that councils could become creatures of accountancy, driven by the bottom line. While market testing services is a key to the new system, he cautions that councils can never compete with the private sector on a straight cost basis. "Services should not be undertaken according to a cost-driven, bottom-line basis".

The other fear is that, in spite of protestations to the contrary, best value could prove as tiresome as the compulsory competitive tendering regime it replaces. CCT, first introduced in 1980 by a Thatcher government instinctively hostile to councils, initially covered contracting services and was extended to manual services, such as refuse collection, and school meals, in 1988 and to white collar services in 1991. Intriguingly, the senior DETR civil servant responsible for CCT is also in charge of best value.

However, Matthew Warburton, head of strategy at the Local Government Association, cautions that the big difference with best value is the philosophy of continuous improvement. "The idea is that authorities will be judged by their ability to do things better and not by their ability to jump through a series of hoops."

Nevertheless, there are those who fear that with so many performance indicators, which will have to be met (in DETR-speak) by councils annually reviewing "why they are providing services and who is best placed to deliver them", there's a danger of best value becoming, in effect, "son of CCT". Results of the continuous review process will have to be published and distributed widely so as to give electors a chance to respond.

As the local government minister, Hilary Armstrong, explained at the launch of the performance indicators: "Responsive, customer-focused services, delivered to high standards, are at the heart of the modern society we wish to create. We need imaginative councils prepared to challenge the status quo if we are to achieve these goals. We also need to create a climate in which councils involve local people in decisions about service levels and delivery, and inform them about progress to date."

And if they don't? As the bulky performance indicator booklet, prepared by the DETR and the audit commission explains, the government "will have powers to intervene in cases of serious failure" of local services. That could mean asking a neighbouring authority or a private contractor to take over, say, street cleaning or refuse collection.

Will it happen and, more pointedly, will the new inspection regime replicate Ofsted in education? In other words, if a "failing" local education authority, or school, faces a takeover, can a council expect the same treatment? "Always remember," said one senior council official, "Wendy Thomson is no Chris Woodhead".

In other words, as a former town hall chief executive herself, she at least has local government on her side. That should be a reassurance to Socpo as it enters its 25th year.

fields.headline: Brown's NHS billions
fields.standfirst: Even with debt, improved care of the elderly, extra beds and inflation making further claims, the chancellor's  NHS settlement looks healthy
fields.trailText: Even with debt, improved care of the elderly, extra beds and inflation making further claims, the chancellor's NHS settlement looks healthy
fields.body:
Chastened by their experience two years ago, when they lived to regret describing the government's cumulative £21bn increase for the health service as "beyond our wildest dreams", NHS leaders will be wary of going overboard in welcoming the four-year spending commitment of 6.1% a year above inflation.

There will also be reservations about how ministers intend to allocate the extra money. This is unlikely to become clear until July, on publication of the conclusions of the prime minister and Alan Milburn, the health secretary, following promised consultations with health experts, NHS staff and patients. It is, however, possible to predict with some certainty where much of the money will go - at least in the short term.

The first and inescapable challenge for Labour is to meet its commitment to cut hospital waiting lists in England by 100,000 by the next general election. After this winter's flu crisis, ministers are 60,000 adrift of the target.

Hospitals have to make rapid progress over the coming seven months if the government is to be in a position to call an election in spring 2001 with the target achieved.

This is likely to mean sending many NHS patients to the private sector for their operations. In a marked softening of party policy on this, Tony Blair said recently: "If money is available and there is no NHS facility available, I have absolutely nothing against using the independent sector."

A second early call on the money will be to clear the debts of many NHS trusts and health authorities. Finance managers have forecast an annual overspend of £200m by the end of this month and the long term, historic debt position is perhaps £500m. Ken Livingstone, the London mayoral candidate, said yesterday some of the capital's most famous hospitals were in effect bankrupt.

Changes in accounting conventions have made it much more difficult either to disguise or to carry over debts, so there will be real tension between finance managers and their colleagues in charge of services over what should get priority.

A third slice of the money, and a hefty one, is likely to go on care of older people. Ministers had been putting off a decision on the recommendations of the royal commission on long term care, published a year ago, but will now have no excuse of financial uncertainty.

The commission called for all "personal" care to be made free at an estimated cost of £1.1bn a year - 22% of next year's NHS spending rise - but ministers have balked at such a bill.

Recent reports have indicated that the government is contemplating declaring free all "nursing" care, wherever it is delivered. While this would be cheaper than the commission's plan, and could be much cheaper depending on how nursing is defined, it would be hard to escape funding it from the NHS budget as opposed to social services. The annual cost would be unlikely to be much less than £600m.

One other definite expenditure heading can be identified - beds, and the staff to service the patients in them.

Following a review of bed numbers in the health and social care sectors, ministers are already committed to a small increase of 4,000 beds in England by 2003. Beyond that, though, there could be a further rise of anything between 6,000 and 53,000 beds, depending on which development plan is adopted.

The chancellor referred yesterday to recuiting "up to 10,000" more nurses, but many of these extra beds will not need fully qualified staff as they will provide what Mr Milburn calls "intermediate" care - very much like the old convalescent homes - for elderly patients no longer needing an acute hospital bed but not yet ready to go home.

After all the above, there will not be as much room for extra spending as first appears - certainly in the coming year. The annual real-terms increases of 6.1% have to be seen in a context in which, it is widely agreed, NHS inflation is at least 1% higher than the general rate, allowing 0.5% each for the ageing population and advances in drugs and medical technology.

Drug costs have risen so much in the past 12 months that the government had to find an extra £104m just before Christmas to bail out the local primary care groups in their first year of operation.

Even so, the additional £2bn promised for 2000-01 looks good against the £600m which the NHS Confederation, representing trusts and heath authorities, had said would be needed "to keep the NHS show on the road". Another £250m on top, it said, would bring the NHS into line with average European levels of critical care provision.

Last night, the confederation said its members could look forward to substantial progress and turn their attention "from crisis management to delivering modernisation".

The inevitable rider, as Gordon Brown made plain, is that the price for the funds will be acceptance of "more reform". For organisations like the British Medical Association, not so long ago implicated by Mr Blair as a force of conservatism, that will mean swallowing hard on further innovations like NHS Direct, the nurse-led telephone advice line, and walk-in clinics that bypass the GP.

Although the BMA is welcoming the spending programme as "a substantial step in putting the NHS on a sound long term funding basis", the Blair/Milburn master plan might not be so much to their liking.

Drug costs have risen so much in the past 12 months that the government had to find an extra £104m just before Christmas to bail out the local primary care groups in their first year of operation. Even so, the additional £2bn promised for 2000-01 looks good against the £600m which the NHS Confederation, representing trusts and heath authorities, had said would be needed "to keep the NHS show on the road". Another £250m on top, it said, would bring the NHS into line with average European levels of critical care provision. Last night, the confederation said its members could look forward to substantial progress and turn their attention "from crisis management to delivering modernisation". The inevitable rider, as Gordon Brown made plain, is that the price for the funds will be acceptance of "more reform". For organisations like the British Medical Association, not so long ago implicated by Mr Blair as a force of conservatism, that will mean swallowing hard on further innovations like NHS Direct, the nurse-led telephone advice line, and walk-in clinics that bypass the GP. Although the BMA is welcoming the spending programme as "a substantial step in putting the NHS on a sound long term funding basis", the Blair/Milburn master plan might not be so much to their liking.

fields.headline: Tide turns in troubled islands
fields.trailText: Mike Selvey Had anyone mused that a Test match against Zimbabwe perhaps held the key to the resurrection or otherwise of Caribbean cricket, he would have been carted off to the funny farm forthwith.
fields.body:
Down on their uppers they may have been but, when the odds are stacked against them and pride kicks in like a drug, there is still no more compelling sight in cricket than West Indian bowlers in their own region forcing victory when none seemed possible.

The events of Monday at Queen's Park Oval, when the old campaigners Curtly Ambrose and Courtney Walsh and the next generation Franklyn Rose and Reon King kept their discipline and reduced Zimbabwe to gibbering inadequates when history had fleetingly beckoned, may yet be seen as a watershed in the fortunes of Caribbean cricket. If ever there had been a day that needed seizing it was this one.

Had anyone in their glory years, equipped with the foresight equivalent of the Hubble telescope, sat in a Trinidad rum shop and mused that a Test match against Zimbabwe perhaps held the key to the resurrection or otherwise of Caribbean cricket, he would have been carted off to the funny farm forthwith.

But that is what Monday's win may prove to be. For a decade now the complacency that has prevailed in the administration of the game across the region, based on previous successes, has extracted its dues. Recent years have shown that, far from being the norm, the players who graced the successful West Indies sides were exceptions. There was no infrastructure to ensure that the heritage was carried forward. With no inter-island television coverage of Test matches, children sought new heroes and, via giant satellite dishes, they arrived from the United States in the form of freakish basket-ball players.

Thus the price was paid. Many had seen it coming - listen, if you get the chance, to Dave Rudder's magnificent anthem Rally Round The West Indies - but they were powerless to stop it.

A generation has been lost and the domestic game has all but collapsed, suffering from insidious pitches and the high cost of transporting and accommodating sides throughout the Caribbean, all of it culminating in a disastrous year that until this match had seen 10 of the previous 12 matches lost.

It was and is unthinkable in a region that has no West Indies football side, no Caribbean athletics or basket-ball team and where it has been cricket that has lent a corporate identity.

But has the tide turned? The fact that a 37-year-old fast bowler and another just a year younger are still dragging their limbs to the crease in the cause in Trinidad is telling enough. And the batting, without Brian Lara, remains woeful.

They need the Prince of Port of Spain back. Only a couple of years ago, however, Richie Richardson mentioned that his sports shop in Antigua was starting to sell cricket bats again and fewer Air Jordan basketball boots. The implication was that, if they could just hang in, then the dark days might just come to an end.

Late last year, in Sri Lanka, England's Under-19s came across their West Indian equivalents and were trounced. Small it may be but it is a start and the game will be better for it. For, while we may smile and reflect on the wheel of sporting life, we know not just that cricket needs West Indies but that, as much as ever, West Indies still needs cricket.

webTitle: Farewell to the magic of Marshall

fields.headline: Farewell to the magic of Marshall
fields.standfirst: Yesterday the world of cricket paid tribute to the greatest West Indian fast bowler
fields.trailText: Yesterday the world of cricket paid tribute to Malcolm Marshall, the greatest West Indian fast bowler.
fields.body:
They came in dark, funereal clothes to pay tribute to the great cricketer, though the spring sunshine shone so brightly on Southampton's daffodils yesterday afternoon that they might have worn flannels instead.

The sharpness in the air would not have helped the ball swing but Malcolm Marshall would still have bowled brilliantly. And yesterday he did, in the warm memories of all who attended the memorial service for this wonderful player who died in November, aged just 41.

Prayers were led by the Rev Wesley Hall; the Hampshire captain Robin Smith gave a reading and Mark Nicholas, the captain during the second phase of Marshall's county career, gave an address that was at once sad, humorous and anecdotal, a reprise of the one he gave at the fast bowler's funeral in Barbados.

Most of the Hampshire team were there. So were, from an earlier vintage, David Gower and Chris Smith. So was Chris Tavare, who played for neither West Indies nor Hampshire but wanted to come along anyway.

There were countless other old players there too, including Marshall's great friend Monte Lynch, his famously large, round eyes blurred by a stubborn tear. A memorial service is difficult. It feels like the removal of a bandage from a still-fresh wound.

There has never been a greater fast bowler. In some mythical match against the Rest of the Galaxy he would probably share the new ball with Dennis Lillee, and a coin would be tossed to determine who took the first over; Ray Lindwall would mooch about and hope there might be some batsmen left for him.

With his skidding pace, rapid arm-action and ability to swing the ball both ways, and late, Marshall took 376 wickets in 81 Tests at an average of 20.95, the lowest in the modern age. In all first-class cricket he took 1,651 wickets at 19.10. He also scored more than 11,000 runs, with seven hundreds. For Hampshire, he took more than 800 wickets and, along with Mike Procter, is considered the most successful of overseas signings.

Yesterday Nicholas recalled a cricketer who "excelled without arrogance". He remembered his great humour, his liking for brandy and, when he first played for Hampshire in 1979, the way he gripped the radiator at Derby to get over the cold. He recalled how he would turn his collar up and swagger in homage to his hero, Garfield Sobers.

But Nicholas was wrong to say Marshall played for Hampshire because he wanted to follow his namesake Roy. As Pat Symes explained in his most readable book on "Maca", he followed Hampshire because he was intrigued by the name of Trevor Jesty, the 1970s all-rounder. Strange but true.

Marshall had been ill with colon cancer long before it was diagnosed last May. Until then he had attributed his discomfort to ulcers or indigestion.

He underwent emergency surgery and then chemotherapy in Birmingham. But it was too late and he returned home to spend his final weeks in Barbados. At his bedside at the end was Connie, his girlfriend of 13 years, whom he married in October, and their son Mali.

Gordon Greenidge, his old Barbados, Hampshire and West Indies colleague, said: "He died at 5.30, which was somehow appropriate. It is the time local cricket matches finish in Barbados.

"It was as though the stumps were pulled. It was a gracious exit from the world, a peaceful serenity. I would think that is the way I would want to go as well."

webTitle: Wednesday sack Wilson and turn to Shreeves

fields.headline: Wednesday sack Wilson and turn to Shreeves
fields.standfirst:
Frank Keating on how a laboured plot finally throttled Wilson
Danny Wilson factfile
fields.trailText: Sheffield Wednesday yesterday sacked their manager Danny Wilson. The seemingly hopeless task of preserving Wednesday's top-flight status has been handed to the much-travelled Peter Shreeves.
fields.body:
With timing that bordered on the bizarre, Sheffield Wednesday yesterday sacked their manager Danny Wilson.

With only eight weeks of the season to run and Wednesday stranded in the relegation zone, Wilson's contract with the Yorkshire club was terminated, giving him the dubious distinction of being the first Premiership manager to be sacked this season.

Wednesday's chairman Howard Culley, who replaced Dave Richards four weeks ago, said that the decision had been taken after the 1-0 defeat at the Premiership's bottom side Watford on Saturday. "The thought process is that we can still avoid relegation and we thought a change on the coaching side might improve our chances," he said.

The seemingly hopeless task of preserving Wednesday's top-flight status has been handed to the much-travelled Peter Shreeves, one-time assistant manager to Ron Atkinson at Hillsborough.

Out of work since leaving a coaching job with Nottingham Forest last year, Shreeves has only nine games in which to bridge the seven-point gap that separates Wednesday from Derby County, in the lowest place of safety in the Premiership table.

Although Wilson swiftly reached a financial settlement with Wednesday in lieu of a contract that had more than two years to run, he was described as being "extremely distressed" by John Barnwell, the chief executive of the League Managers' Association.

Shreeves will hold the managerial reins until the summer, when the Wednesday board of directors will make a permanent appointment.

He will be a serious contender if he steers Wednesday to safety but, if he is unable to prevent what many already regard as the inevitable, the list of candidates is likely to be headed by the former Wimbledon manager Joe Kinnear.

Another man certain to come under consideration is the former Wednesday manager Howard Wilkinson, the Football Association's technical director.

"I have a job and a contract with the FA," said Wilkinson. "Things are about as low as they have been for two or three decades at Wednesday. I'm shocked by Danny's sacking - but not surprised. They must formulate a long-term strategy and stick to it; there will be no quick fixes."

Despite Wilson overseeing the club's worst start to the season, there was never any likelihood of a managerial switch until Culley's installation as chairman. Richards insisted that, while he was in control, Wilson, who succeeded Atkinson in the summer of 1998 after giving Barnsley their first experience of the top flight, would not be sacked under any circumstances. But, unfortunately for the manager, the chairman went first, resigning to take up the post of chairman of the Premier League.

Wednesday have spent the entire season marooned in the Premiership's bottom three and, once Wilson's recent assertion that his team would remain unbeaten in the remainder of the season had been undone at Vicarage Road, there was only one likely outcome.

fields.headline: Barnsley scramble up to second
fields.trailText: Barnsley 1 - 0 Fulham
fields.body:
The lure of a place in the Premiership, and the television millions that go with it, is bringing repeated attacks of the jitters among the First Division's motley band of promotion candidates.

Barnsley salvaged a victory at Oakwell last night to displace Manchester City in the second automatic promotion spot, thanks to a goal four minutes before the interval by Neil Shipperley. But there was little to admire in their display as Fulham, much the more orderly side, were desperately unlucky not to get at least a point.

Dave Bassett, a proven master at making the best of limited material, now faces an appealing run-in against a succession of lowly sides but that did not blind him to the poverty of the performance.

"The game should have gone after the TV watershed," he said. "We were apprehensive and we didn't play but at least we got the points."

Barnsley's opening forays hardly smacked of a side stricken by promotion anxiety and Fulham, who began the night four points off a play-off place, began to imagine that remedying their season might not be beyond them.

They almost sneaked the lead midway through the half when Barry Hayles stole behind John Curtis on to Steve Finnan's pass but dragged his shot across goal.

As the interval neared, Fulham's optimism abounded. Finnan might have scored when he seized on Chris Barker's error but Kevin Miller saved his low shot comfortably. Sean Davis also went close.

In Fulham's goal Maik Taylor, a few testing centres apart, had been unemployed but Barnsley roused themselves to take the lead three minutes before the interval.

Fulham must have thought their luck had held when Terry Phelan, under pressure from Shipperley at the far post, came perilously close to turning a left-wing cross from Darren Barnard into his own net.

But their marking was slack at the resulting corner, Craig Hignett helped on Barnard's ball at the near post and, from the same spot where he had been thwarted seconds earlier, Shipperley slid in his 10th goal of the season: there is an art in standing still.

Barnard was fortunate to be only booked for a wild challenge on Goldbaek which caused the Fulham defender to be replaced by Wayne Collins at the interval. Collins almost turned in a Fulham equaliser at the near post after Hayles had torn past Barker on the right and then Hayles, whose pace offered Fulham their likeliest outlet, suffered for loose control as he failed to prey upon Miller's poor clearance.

With Hignett, so often Barnsley's inspiration, relatively subdued, the Tykes hardly mustered a threat. If they do go up, they will do so less well equipped than they were two years ago and, barring miracles, can anticipate immediate relegation with another hefty Sky TV payment to help them on their way.

Goals from Steve Claridge, a penalty, and Shaun Derry gave Portsmouth the points against West Bromwich, who had Matt Carbon sent off after he received two yellow cards.

webTitle: Boom and bust is at an end, says Brown

fields.headline: Boom and bust is at an end, says Brown
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown claimed to have eradicated boom-bust by forecasting a robust outlook for economic growth accompanied by low inflation and sound public finances.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown claimed to have eradicated boom-bust by forecasting a robust outlook for economic growth accompanied by low inflation and sound public finances.

Confirming widespread expectations in the City, he jacked up the growth prediction for this year to a range of 2.75%-3.25%, well above the 2.5% rate the Treasury regards as sustainable in the long run without putting upward pressure on inflation.

This compared to November's pre-Budget report forecast of 2.5%-3%.

The boost mainly reflects higher than expected consumer spending levels but is also due to upward revisions to investment and government spending.

However, the strength of sterling is seen as taking its toll, with exports detracting from rather than adding to overall gross domestic product growth in 2000.

The headroom for above-trend growth this year is created by inflation being below the government's 2.5% target for the last 11 months.

But with precious little spare capacity in the economy the Treasury reckons the economy needs to slow down soon to keep the rate of price increases in check.

It has pencilled in output growth of between 2.25% and 2.75% during both of the next two years.

The Treasury attributes the slowdown in growth to the pre-emptive 1% point increase in interest rates seen since last September. "Within a credible policy framework such moves are likely to have a significant impact, and a marked slowing in household spending growth is expected from the second half of 2000," it says.

Along with the International Monetary Fund and other independent forecasters, the Treasury says the main risk to its forecast is that growth will prove too strong, leading to overheating in the economy.

"In particular, there is a strong risk of more rapid growth in domestic demand, at least in the near term," the Treasury says.

In particular, the Treasury flags up its concern about the danger of another house price boom leading to runaway consumer spending.

While expecting house price inflation and transactions to ease later this year and during the period to 2001 - partly due to higher interest rates - the Treasury nevertheless says that past housing cycles have tended to overshoot.

"While the new macroeconomic framework provides a more credible guard against speculative behaviour, policy will need to remain alert to the risks," says the Treasury.

However, the risks are not all seen as being in one direction.

The threat of an uncontrolled consumer boom is balanced to some extent by the danger of a global stock market crash and a sharper than expected slowing in American and world growth.

"This would have direct implications for UK stock prices, export demand and sterling. Moreover, it would pose the risk of a sudden deterioration in private sector balance sheets, prompting a much sharper deceleration in domestic spending."

The strong pound is also seen as posing a downside risk to growth, via a flood of cheap imports and waning exports.

However, the treasury flatly rejects suggestions that the Bank of England should attempt to target both inflation and the exchange rate to help ailing manufacturing industry.

Such a course of action would "lead back to the policies that caused economic instability in the past".

The damaging impact of the currency's overvaluation is seen in the current account projections - which show a deficit of some £20.5bn in 2000, rising to £21bn in 2001 before beginning to fall to £19.75 during 2002.

In the pre-Budget report, the equivalent figures were £10.25bn, £11.5bn and £10.75bn.

Despite net tax cuts of around £1.2bn and increases in public spending worth some £4bn, the public finances are predicted to be healthier than in last year's Budget.

This reflects both unexpectedly strong growth, which has boosted tax receipts and reduced social security spending, reduced debt servicing costs due to cheaper long term borrowing, and structural factors, which mean that the tax take per unit of gross domestic product is higher than the Treasury believed. For example, the introduction of self-assessment has yielded far more income than expected over and beyond the impact of the economic cycle.

According to the Treasury, the public finances comfortably meet both the chancellor's tough rules for borrowing and debt - that he should only borrow to invest and keep debt as a proportion of gross domestic product below 40%.

The current budget is projected to be in surplus by a massive £17bn in the year 1999-2000, £14bn next year, £16bn in 2001-02 and £13bn in 2002-2003.

The debt to output ratio, meanwhile, falls from 37.1% in 1999-2000 to 35.1% next year, 33.6% in 2001-2002 and 32.7% in 2002-2003. Treasury sources stressed the fiscal stance was continuing to support monetary policy by not overstimulating the economy at a time when there is already upward pressure on inflation.

If there had been no Budget this year the fiscal stance would have tightened by around 1.6% of output because of the money sucked out of the economy by the higher than expected tax take and unplanned reductions in spending on unemployment and debt interest.

The net tax cuts announced yesterday and the increases in spending on crucial areas merely offset part of that fiscal tightening, not all of it.

Overall, therefore, the fiscal stance is still tighter than anticipated in last year's Budget by 1.1% of output, falling to 0.6% of output in 2001-2002.

Although the current budget is projected to remain in surplus, net borrowing - which includes investment spending such as new hospitals and schools - is predicted to rise towards the end of the forecast horizon, reaching £11bn in the year 2003-2004.

Despite believing the the economy's long-term growth rate has risen to 2.5%, the Treasury is continuing to forecast public finances on the cautious assumption that it remains at 2.25%.
