Moreover, it would pose the risk of a sudden deterioration in private sector balance sheets, prompting a much sharper deceleration in domestic spending." The strong pound is also seen as posing a downside risk to growth, via a flood of cheap imports and waning exports. However, the treasury flatly rejects suggestions that the Bank of England should attempt to target both inflation and the exchange rate to help ailing manufacturing industry. Such a course of action would "lead back to the policies that caused economic instability in the past". The damaging impact of the currency's overvaluation is seen in the current account projections - which show a deficit of some £20.5bn in 2000, rising to £21bn in 2001 before beginning to fall to £19.75 during 2002. In the pre-Budget report, the equivalent figures were £10.25bn, £11.5bn and £10.75bn. Despite net tax cuts of around £1.2bn and increases in public spending worth some £4bn, the public finances are predicted to be healthier than in last year's Budget. This reflects both unexpectedly strong growth, which has boosted tax receipts and reduced social security spending, reduced debt servicing costs due to cheaper long term borrowing, and structural factors, which mean that the tax take per unit of gross domestic product is higher than the Treasury believed. For example, the introduction of self-assessment has yielded far more income than expected over and beyond the impact of the economic cycle. According to the Treasury, the public finances comfortably meet both the chancellor's tough rules for borrowing and debt - that he should only borrow to invest and keep debt as a proportion of gross domestic product below 40%. The current budget is projected to be in surplus by a massive £17bn in the year 1999-2000, £14bn next year, £16bn in 2001-02 and £13bn in 2002-2003. The debt to output ratio, meanwhile, falls from 37.1% in 1999-2000 to 35.1% next year, 33.6% in 2001-2002 and 32.7% in 2002-2003. Treasury sources stressed the fiscal stance was continuing to support monetary policy by not overstimulating the economy at a time when there is already upward pressure on inflation. If there had been no Budget this year the fiscal stance would have tightened by around 1.6% of output because of the money sucked out of the economy by the higher than expected tax take and unplanned reductions in spending on unemployment and debt interest. The net tax cuts announced yesterday and the increases in spending on crucial areas merely offset part of that fiscal tightening, not all of it. Overall, therefore, the fiscal stance is still tighter than anticipated in last year's Budget by 1.1% of output, falling to 0.6% of output in 2001-2002. Although the current budget is projected to remain in surplus, net borrowing - which includes investment spending such as new hospitals and schools - is predicted to rise towards the end of the forecast horizon, reaching £11bn in the year 2003-2004. Despite believing the the economy's long-term growth rate has risen to 2.5%, the Treasury is continuing to forecast public finances on the cautious assumption that it remains at 2.25%.

fields.headline: Laboured plot finally throttles Wilson
fields.standfirst:
Wednesday sack Wilson and turn to Shreeves
Danny Wilson factfile
fields.trailText: With only nine games and eight weeks left in the season, Danny Wilson's is the most bizarre of sackings, even for English football.
fields.body:
So Joe Ashton and the gang of four MPs finally got their man. By all accounts, Ashton yesterday was looking more smilingly smug and vindicated than he has all year. Although it was unseemly for lifelong socialists - brotherhood of man and all that - to wish a fellow toiler out of work, it might have been better all round, certainly for Danny Wilson and Sheffield Wednesday, had the young manager packed his bags in outraged umbrage as soon as the MP plotters unsheathed their daggers.

Back in midwinter the meddlers' double-cross would have been palpable and everybody's Decent Dan would have sailed into another job on the sympathy vote alone - and his predecessor would have had time to right the ship without the frenzied desperation of imminent relegation in his face. With only nine games and eight weeks left in the season, it is the most bizarre of sackings, even for English football.

In September Wednesday were thrashed 8-0 by Alan Shearer's Newcastle. Wilson survived that. November is the traditional month for uneasy managers of crummy teams to look over their shoulders and fear the worst. Wilson survived it.

His honourable reaction to the MPs' calls for his head won him another chairman's vote of confidence, round which his players rallied and, with seven points out of a possible nine, Wilson was named manager of the month for January. But in February, when his friend and ally Dave Richards stood down as chairman, Wilson again must have covered his back.

He seemed to have survived again - but, with the most faithful of supporters by now calling urgently for the lifeboats and pulling away at a lick, Wilson must have realised that an abject performance in the relegation six-pointer against Watford on Saturday would put the kibosh on any more survival. And an abject show it was. In spite of his being quoted yesterday as being "utterly distressed", Wilson must have been braced for the phone call.

Perhaps he had survived so many obvious crises that the winds around Hillsborough smelled no differently to Wilson. I remember good Roy Sproson once telling me about that.

Roy was another, just like Wilson and Wednesday, who had returned as manager to the club, in his case Port Vale, for which he had been a long-serving and stalwart player. Said Sproson: "A manager can smell the end of his time. The place reeks with an imminent sacking. The stench gets everywhere.

"It can be a long time till they actually say, 'You're bloody fired'. Before that it's all innuendo and muttering - 'things aren't going too well, are they?' But you know they are all after your blood. They can smell it - and so can you - and, if the truth was told, you've already had your bag packed for weeks."

On Saturday at Vicarage Road five Wednesday survivors played from the XI that had appeared when the clubs had last met at Watford - in the FA Cup in January 1998. Wilson had spent his allocation on those new players. There was no more in the kitty and the club is £12m in debt. Watford won 1-0.

"Half the Wednesday players didn't seem too bothered. Well, mercenaries don't really bother who actually wins wars as long as they do all right," said a friend who was there.

Ashton said much the same yesterday: "Danny couldn't handle the big players. We had a lot of foreigners. Players know a manager. They can spot him inside six matches. They know the good ones who can do it and the ones who can't, and it finished up with the players just playing how they liked - with no fight, no guts, no bottle."

Ashton was not, to be fair, gloating - but vindicated, sure. Had Wednesday's turnaround yesterday come three months ago, one wonders where they would be now. Yet the MP's assassination attempt still sticks in the craw.

One lifelong Wednesday fanatic, and senior politician by far, Lord Hattersley, has shown himself more noble than Brutus in that sidestreet near the Capitol. I phoned him yesterday. Said the wise Owl: "I have never uttered a word about Wednesday through all this, and I don't intend to start. I am prepared to launch attacks on the monarchy, the prime minister or the editor of the Guardian - all in the same breath if you want me to - but I don't intend to pronounce one word on my beloved Wednesday."

fields.headline: Danny Wilson
fields.trailText: 1960
fields.body:
1960

Born in Wigan on New Year's Day.

1977

Joins Bury on a free transfer from Wigan.

1980

Moves to Chesterfield for £100,000.

1983

Brian Clough pays £50,000 to take Wilson to Nottingham Forest. Makes only 10 appearances for Forest and is loaned to Scunthorpe. Eventually leaves the City Ground for Brighton.

1987

Joins Luton for £150,000.

1988

Collects League Cup winners' medal as Luton beat Arsenal 3-2 at Wembley.

1989

Luton beaten 3-1 by Nottingham Forest in League Cup final.

1990

Moves to Sheffield Wednesday for £200,000 and makes 137 appearances in all competitions for the Owls.

1993

Costs Barnsley £200,000 in July.

1995

Leads the Tykes to sixth position in the First Division in his first full season as player-manager at Oakwell.

Sheffield Wednesday's first approach for their former player fails in May when Wilson signs a new contract at Barnsley. The Owls were seeking a successor to Trevor Francis.

1997

Takes Barnsley into the top flight for the first time in the club's 110-year history. They finish as runners-up in the First Division to Bolton.

1998

Barnsley reach quarter-finals of the FA Cup after beating Manchester United 3-2 in a thrilling replay at Oakwell. But they are knocked out of the last eight by Newcastle and despite a brave struggle, are relegated.

After four years of managing Barnsley, Wilson accepts offer to replace Ron Atkinson as Sheffield Wednesday boss and leads Owls to 12th place finish in 1998-99 Premiership season, 11 points clear of the relegation zone.

1999

September 19: beaten 8-0 by Newcastle United, with Alan Shearer scoring five goals. Dave Richards defiantly stands by his beleaguered manager, saying he would not be sacked.

October 2: Wednesday finally bring an end to the worst league start in their history - almost trebling their goals tally for the season in the process with a 5-1 home win over Wimbledon.

2000

January: A group of four Sheffield MPs hold a meeting with investment company Charterhouse, who hold a 36% stake in the club, during which it emerges the politicians want Wilson sacked because of Wednesday's woeful form.

Wilson rides the storm which leads to the MPs turning on then chairman Dave Richards, but he, too, fends off the criticism.

February: Richards stands down after nine years in charge at Hillsborough, due to his impending appointment as chairman of the FA Premier League, although he retains his place on the board. Solicitor Howard Culley steps up from director to chairman, although does not give Wilson the same strong backing he received from Richards.

March 21: 72 hours after Wednesday lose 1-0 in a crunch relegation clash with bottom side Watford, Wilson is sacked, 21 months into a four-year contract.

fields.headline: Walsall leave Vale in fear
fields.trailText: Walsall moved to within a point of escaping from the First Division relegation zone with a 2-1 victory at Port Vale, who now look destined for the drop.
fields.body:
Walsall moved to within a point of escaping from the First Division relegation zone with a 2-1 victory at Port Vale, who now look destined for the drop.

Pedro Matias opened the scoring for the visitors in the 12th minute and Graham Fenton, who had earlier hit a post, added a second in the fourth minute of first-half stoppage time. Michael Cummins, making his home debut, gave Port Vale hope with a goal on the hour but Walsall held on to increase their survival hopes.

The Second Division leaders Preston slipped to a 1-0 defeat at Notts County, who boosted their play-off hopes courtesy of Matthew Redmile's fourth-minute goal. Of the other promotion contenders, only Gillingham and Wigan fully capitalised, with victories at Bournemouth and Wycombe respectively.

Rotherham moved back to the top of the Third Division with victory at Leyton Orient. They replaced Swansea who could only draw 1-1 at home to Shrewsbury.

fields.headline: Museum pieces
fields.standfirst:
Roots
Ronnie Scott's, London
***
fields.trailText: When the classic-jazz archaeology movement got going in the 80s, droves of dewy teenagers started practising swing-sax licks. The upswing produced a lot of hopefuls who have been and gone, and a good many big talents who are cherishing and transforming the music too. But what you mostly don't get, is the authentic, in-your-face, idiosyncratic live sound of jazz musicians who matured in a time and place a very long way away, and who really do sound different to all their younger disciples.
fields.body:
When the classic-jazz archaeology movement got going in the 80s, droves of dewy teenagers started practising swing-sax licks. The upswing produced a lot of hopefuls who have been and gone, and a good many big talents who are cherishing and transforming the music too. But what you mostly don't get, is the authentic, in-your-face, idiosyncratic live sound of jazz musicians who matured in a time and place a very long way away, and who really do sound different to all their younger disciples.

That's the enduring appeal of the Roots band, that rugged four-sax ensemble of beefy swingers who have devoted themselves for most of the past decade to preserving as authentic-sounding a version of jazz saxophone history as is technically and humanly possible today. And even though Monday night's opening performance on their current Ronnie Scott's season had the former Max Roach tenorist Odean Pope substituted for Chico Freeman (the player who usually represents the Coltrane legacy) and Britain's Peter King deputising for altoist Arthur Blythe, the full force of the band's imposing presence asserted.

The Roots repertory spans 30s swing up to pre-free John Coltrane. They played the big band classic Lester Leaps In; the urbane veteran Benny Golson's slippery phrasing and gurgly, dolorous sound paid appropriate tribute to Lester Young's utterly personal signature not by mimicking it, but by unfurling his own.

On an original dedicated to the clamour of a Saturday night in Harlem, the whole band took on the dark, gospelly fervour of a Charles Mingus group, with pianist Kirk Lightsey's piano ringing through like a firebell. Nathan Davis, a broad-beamed man with a sax sound like stampeding cattle and an oblique manner of phrasing, raised the roof on this feature, the climax a wail of manic warbles and trills.

Peter King, the member of the line-up with the closest hook to Charlie Parker's methods, hurled in several headlong alto solos with the aplomb of a permanent member rather than a late substitute. The lazily muscular purr of the horns when playing an ensemble part behind a soloist makes Roots sound a much bigger outfit than it is. Not history in the making, but history pretty close to the way it was made.

 Until Saturday. Box office: 0171-439 0747.

webTitle: Tim Radford's top 10 books on science

fields.headline: Tim Radford's top 10 books on science
fields.trailText: "Strictly speaking, there are no science books. There are books about how the universe began, or how life began, or how humanity began, or why people die, fall in love, remember and forget. The authors use science to address the questions, not fairy tales. The results are just as thrilling. Here are 10 new and less new favourites"
fields.body:
"Strictly speaking, there are no science books. There are books about how the universe began, or how life began, or how humanity began, or why people die, fall in love, remember and forget. The authors use science to address the questions, not fairy tales. The results are just as thrilling. Here are 10 new and less new favourites"

1. Seeing and Believing by Richard Panek
When Galileo put a tube with two lenses in it and looked upwards, the spectacle was awesome. So were the consequences - it was the making of modern science. This little book's an eye-opener, too.

2. The Blind Watchmaker by Richard Dawkins
How evolution works - by someone who knows how to make words work. This book looked like a classic on its first printing in 1986 and it's just come out again in a pert new Penguin jacket.

3. Just Six Numbers by Martin Rees
We're on this planet because of a few old-fashioned values: the cosmic number omega, epsilon the the number that defines the alchemy of the stars, and so on. Gawp at the dizzying improbability of existence, except in a finely tuned universe.

4. Genome: the Autobiography of a Species in 23 Chapters by Matt Ridley
The latest rather than the greatest book on genetics, but in a fast moving field, up-to-date is what matters. A good read, and a good guide to people as packets of DNA.

5. The Language Instinct by Steven Pinker
Language - fecund, inventive, prodigal and rule-ridden - arrives suddenly and is mastered by children of three or four. How does this happen? A cracker by a connoisseur of headlines such as "Drunk gets six months in violin case".

6. The Fifth Miracle: The Search for the Origin of Life by Paul Davies
A cosmic physicist contemplates the meaning of life: did it have to happen? Is there something about this universe that makes it inevitable? How did it begin, and where? Is it happening anywhere else?

7. Life: An Unauthorised Biography by Richard Fortey
Palaeontologists read stories in stones. And what a story: two billion years from slime to Sloane Ranger. Whenever anyone says "What shall I buy?" this is the first book I think of.

8. Guns, Germs and Steel by Jared Diamond
Life is a playing field, but not a level one. One of the great biologists takes a look at why some peoples have it all and some get the sticky end of the lollipop. Liberals will be relieved to know that it's nothing to do with inherent tribal talent.

9. The Diversity of Life by Edward O Wilson
Not so much how evolution works, but what it works towards: a fantastic tapestry of creation, beyond numbering, but alas not beyond extinguishing, which is why this book may be the most important of all.

10. The Oxford Companion To The Year by Bonnie Blackburn and Leofranc Holford-Strevens
A salute to millennial contemplation: this is a day-book that covers all calendars and chronologies, feasts and fast days and other attempts to reckon time. You could spend a whole year enjoying it.

fields.headline: Tricks of the trade
fields.standfirst:
15. How I got my dream job
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: 15. How I got my dream job.
fields.body:
Rachel Fox, 45 managing director

I got my current job through networking, rather than by applying for an advertised job. In my previous job, as a marketing director, I initiated a marketing discussion group which caught the imaginations of senior directors, and I used my contact with them to my advantage. I started mixing with them socially as well as professionally, met their friends and started asking for help. Soon they were passing invitations to parties and conferences they couldn't attend, and I met more people. At one lunch I sat next to a board member of a huge international company who was the linchpin in getting the job I have now. As long as you behave appropriately, dress well and are not afraid of initiating conversation with important people you can network your way to the top.

Alison Parker, 38 chief executive

I've always wanted to be chief executive for a charity and have achieved that aim at the Children's Foundation. I got there by carefully planning the stepping-stones. I used to work as a development manager in the chemical industry and knew I needed more experience if I was going to fulfil my ambition. I took a job as an area manager as my next move, to learn how to manage people. Then I took a cut in salary and went to a job in fundraising to get the experience that would give me credibility at director level. It's very tempting to take the next job that comes along with more money and benefits, but if you really want to achieve something you have to make sacrifices.

Chrissie Morris, 28 account manager

I set my heart on moving up the chain at work, where I was a secretary in a small public relations firm. My boss was loath for me to move on because she said I didn't have enough experience. I decided to sell myself as an investment. I wrote a list of all the relevant skills I had accumulated and pushed home the point that my potential was going to waste, rather like resources that weren't being used efficiently by a company. I asked her how much the salary was, volunteered to work initially for less and told her how much money and time she would save by promoting within the company. I got other people behind me and eventually she was convinced I was right for the job.

Martin Morgan, 24 account manager

I've just got a new job event organising, which I've always wanted to do. I got an interview after seeing the job advertised and had to prepare a five-minute presentation at two days notice. I bought books on interview techniques and mirrored the interviewers' body language, stayed as calm as I could and spoke slowly because I have a tendency to gabble when nervous. I ran through the presentation with a couple of patient friends. Although nervous, I looked on the process as a learning curve and tried not to get too desperate about it.

When I applied for my current job I had a holiday booked, so rang the personnel department to tell them. The message didn't get through and I missed the interviews. I contacted one of the panel and asked if they had made a decision. They hadn't and saw me next day. I was myself, warts and all. I made the occasional joke and accepted a cup of tea. I had to be myself because my personality is a strong part of my work.

In my previous job, as a marketing director, I initiated a marketing discussion group which caught the imaginations of senior directors, and I used my contact with them to my advantage. webTitle: Oil firms and banks to set up net exchange

fields.headline: Oil firms and banks to set up net exchange
fields.standfirst:
Money Unlimited
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Some of the biggest names in energy and finance plan to establish an internet-based market for oil trading which could threaten brokers and compete with the International Petroleum Exchange (IPE).
fields.body:
Some of the biggest names in energy and finance plan to establish an internet-based market for oil trading which could threaten brokers and compete with the International Petroleum Exchange (IPE).

The venture, which includes BP Amoco, Goldman Sachs, Deutsche Bank, Royal Dutch Shell, Totalfina Elf, Société Générale and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, will specialise in trading over-the-counter energy, metals and other products. This fast-growing sector is worth about $1.8 trillion (£1.1 trillion) annually.

The new IntercontinentalExchange will be based in the US and open for trading later this year. It is the biggest initiative yet to use the worldwide web in the energy sector.

Chris Moorhouse, chief executive of BP's oil trading arm said: "This is an innovative commitment by significant market players to a progressive independent exchange, which will enhance the transparency and liquidity in the market."

The major oil companies play down the potential threat to existing markets pointing out it involves OTC trades rather than regulated futures contracts used on the IPE and New York Mercantile Exchange.

But industry experts said longer-term business could move away to a new market. One trader said: "If the market becomes mature enough, liquid enough and enough players take an active part, it could take a good stake from the futures market."

The IPE admitted it might become a threat but said details were too sketchy. "It might be a threat, it might be an opportunity. We note the development with interest and look forward to learning more about it," said a spokeswoman.

IntercontinentalExchange will be headed by Jeffrey Sprecher, the former president of Continental Power Exchange, which developed the system to be used in the new venture.

The exchange should be more efficient and transparent and also reduce the cost of doing business now done by telephone and later backed up by paper work. The seven founding partners will put up an unspecified amount of money to provide initial liquidity for the market which will have no formal membership or signing on fees.

Mr Sprecher said: "I believe that, just as financial products have quickly and efficiently moved on to electronic trading platforms, so too will commodity products. Energy and metals are a natural start, but not an end to this venture."

fields.headline: Lastminute frenzy falls flat
fields.standfirst:
Money Unlimited
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Shares in Lastminute.com slumped below their issue price yesterday amid concerns about the loss-making retailer's heady valuation.
fields.body:
Shares in Lastminute.com slumped below their issue price yesterday amid concerns about the loss-making retailer's heady valuation.

Lastminute shares fell 62.5p to 320p, 157.5p below last Tuesday's closing price when the shares were floated. The company, which in the last quarter generated turnover of £409,000 and made an operating loss of £6m, is now valued at £481m, compared to a high of £845m on its first day.

The latest slide coincided with the first day of unconditional dealing, when many private investors who had bought shares in the hope of a quick profit were able to trade them. Instead they were nursing a paper loss. The issue was 40 times oversubscribed and small investors were only issued with 35 shares each at 380p. Even before dealing fees are taken into account those who sold at yesterday's close price lost £21 on a £133 investment.

The end of Lastminute's short honeymoon with investors coincided with a heavy sell-off of technology stocks in London and on the US Nasdaq market. Last night the FTSE's Techmark 100 index closed off 291.8 points at 4585.74.

Advisers to Lastminute yesterday denied it had been over-hyped and over-valued. They emphasised the potential long-term benefits.

One adviser compared Lastminute's performance with that of telecoms groups Colt and Orange and internet companies Freeserve and QXL. All four floated at a premium then slipped below the issue price. They now trade significantly above the float price.

The early performance of Lastminute shares is likely embarrass broker Morgan Stanley, which employed star US internet analyst Mary Meeker to co-author research on the company. Lastminute's founders, Brent Hoberman and Martha Lane Fox, appointed the US investment bank largely because it had floated only one internet business that fell below its issue price.

Morgan Stanley is understood to have supported the share price by buying shares.

fields.headline: Interface to interface
fields.standfirst: An employment tribunal lawyer writes
fields.trailText: Susie was sacked for being a lousy schmoozer. Her job was one of those sales-marketing-publicity-telephone-lunch sort of jobs with a specification full of bewildering management jargon about co-ordinational abilities and persuasive interfacing. Although everyone agreed she was bright and diligent and well-organised, her interfacing was apparently not very persuasive.
fields.body:
Susie was sacked for being a lousy schmoozer. Her job was one of those sales-marketing-publicity-telephone-lunch sort of jobs with a person specification full of bewildering management jargon about co-ordinational abilities and persuasive interfacing.

Susie's problem was that, although everyone agreed she was bright and diligent and well-organised, her interfacing was apparently not very persuasive, as reflected in a low rate of customer orders.

Although all of my sympathies are secretly with Susie, I am in fact representing her bosses. They all cheerily and somewhat forcefully interface with me about why the dismissal was fair. I have to interface with them back that maybe it wasn't fair because they didn't interface with Susie about what was wrong with her interfacing. At this stage the interfacing rather breaks down and the bosses become openly sulky.

Nonetheless they authorise me to make Susie's counsel a modest offer to settle the case, which is on no account to be raised, oh no.

So I go off to interface with Susie's counsel. He's a bit young and has that rather defenceless, head-runs-into-neck-with-no-distinguishing-anatomical-features-in-between effect popularised by Beaker from the Muppets.

Me: OK, I can offer you X pounds but that's it.

Beaker: She'll take 2X.

Me: I can't offer you 2X. I can only offer you _X.

Beaker: How about 1.5X?

Me: I can't offer you that either. All they're willing to offer is X. Take it or leave it.

Beaker: That's not negotiating! You can't just offer a figure and stick to it!

He's turning red and his adam's apple is dancing up and down alarmingly. I begin to wonder whether they failed to mention to Beaker when he learned negotiation skills at Bar School that there's no rule that you have to agree on a figure halfway between your respective starting figures.

I suggest in what I like to think of as a soothing kind of voice that Beaker goes and asks Susie what she thinks about the offer. He perks up and toddles off; he clearly remembers this bit of the process. Thankfully Susie says yes to X because I doubt anyone ever told Beaker what to do next when a negotiation breaks down.

But who am I to talk? In the evening, we have a book launch for a law book I and various other people in chambers have written (Note: If anyone should ever ask you to contribute to a law book, run away very fast). This is a top opportunity to interface with lots of solicitors, eg: Solicitor: Hello, congratulations on the book.

Me (strange growl): Oh, I hardly wrote any of it anyway and the bits I did write are probably wrong...er...

(Long pause whilst we both gaze at our wineglasses)

At this stage the solicitor seems almost violently persuaded to interface with someone on the other side of the room and I am left interfacing moodily with some cheap Chardonnay.

fields.headline: Rooms with a dingy view
fields.standfirst:
Mike Nelson
Matt's Gallery, London
*****
fields.trailText: Matt's Gallery is a famous venue for installation art perched on a gravy-coloured canal off the Mile End Road, London. Currently the neighbouring park is being torn up to make a superpark with trees soaring on a bridge over the road. To get there you have to negotiate a wasteland of wire and dug-up paths that turns out to perfectly anticipate the art of Mike Nelson.
fields.body:
Matt's Gallery is a famous venue for installation art perched on a gravy-coloured canal off the Mile End Road, London. Currently the neighbouring park is being torn up to make a superpark with trees soaring on a bridge over the road. To get there you have to negotiate a wasteland of wire and dug-up paths that turns out to perfectly anticipate the art of Mike Nelson.

You cross the threshold into what appears to be a normal, civilised antechamber, with a visitors' book, but someone tells you this is not a real room; it is a false room. It feels real enough, so you ignore them, and push through a door into a dim space, perhaps a mini-cab office, with a caller's window plastered with Islamic posters. There is another door at the end of the room and this leads into a room with an American eagle and a White House souvenir bath towel. Through the next door there's a white corridor, a mirror, choices: the workshop full of tyres? The place with the slot machine? The door with the strange noises beyond?

A mild terror creeps up when you realise you're alone and lost, in a warren of rooms that all suggest very powerfully the character of their recently departed occupant. These are rooms that could all exist in the world outside, rooms that may be evil: a claustrophobic decaying flat with nothing but a mattress and a lighter on a piece of silver foil; a room with a page from a book about Aleister Crowley pinned to the wall.

Nelson's architectural installations are ambitious spatial constructs that make you feel you are inside a story that is never quite explained. In the past he has created spatial equivalents for the horror stories of HP Lovecraft and the science fiction of Stanislav Lem. He doesn't evoke a precise literary example this time, but he compares the rooms within rooms, the tangle of fictions, to a story by Borges.

I thought of Edgar Allan Poe's palace of Prince Prospero, which leads its occupants through a suite of coloured chambers, each provoking a different exquisite mood, or the House of Usher, which encloses and torments its occupants. Mike Nelson shares Poe's vision of architecture as a pulsing, breathing presence. There is a political point to Nelson's work: horri ble, derelict buildings sustain horrible, derelict lives. The space he has created at Matt's is a wonderful creation, a place for the washed up. He calls it The Coral Reef.

 Until March 26. 0181-983 1771.

fields.headline: Paternity suits you, sir
fields.standfirst:
Cherie Booth thinks the Finnish prime minister is a shining example of fatherhood because he took a week off when his baby was born. Will her husband do the same - and promote the idea of more time off for men? Sarah Boseley reports
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Cherie Booth thinks the Finnish prime minister is a shining example of fatherhood because he took a week off when his baby was born. Will her husband do the same - and promote the idea of more time off for men?
fields.body:
Paavo Lipponen is a man for our times. So says Cherie Booth, applauding the prime minister of Finland for handing the top job over to his finance minister and taking a week off last month after the birth of his second daughter.

Lipponen took parental leave for both births, Booth pointed out. "I, for one, am promoting the widespread adoption of his fine example," she said. "It is time that men started to challenge the assumptions in the workplace that the nurturing of children has nothing to do with them. Our children need their male role models as well as their female ones."

All eyes are now on Tony Blair. Will he let Gordon Brown take over while he immerses himself in the family after the birth of his fourth child in May?

"What Tony Blair does when this baby is born will be a very powerful signal to other men about what real men do," said Mary Newburn of the National Childbirth Trust. "If he is not seen to take time off that will be quite damaging because it is difficult for men to prioritise their families and it is crucial that they should be able to be involved in sharing responsibility and caring for their children."

While signals and role models are all-important to cultural change, they do little to help the cash-strapped average working father because the parental leave provisions that the UK has finally brought in, now that we are signed up to the social chapter of the EU, give men the right to time off but only without pay. The new provisions apply equally to men and women, who can add the unpaid leave to maternity leave (18 weeks of which is paid). There are no retrospective rights. Parents - including adoptive parents - are entitled to take a total of 13 weeks off unpaid during the first five years of life of any baby born or adopted after 15 December last year.

This brings us into line with the rest of the continent, but many European countries have already gone further and introduced an element of pay. In Italy, a mother or father gets 30% of earnings for up to six months leave. German men can have up to three years off at 600DM (£190)a month on a mean-tested basis. Belgium subsidises career breaks at £250 a month for up to five years.

The Nordic countries are already so far ahead that Britain is unlikely ever to catch up. Swedish parents each have a right to a year's paid leave and 78% of men take it. Norwegians get full wages for 42 weeks which can be shared, although fathers have a ring-fenced four weeks to themselves. Finland and Denmark also have generous arrangements, although Lipponen's gesture was partly intended to boost the male take-up, which is only about 2%.

In the UK, there is a further, crucial, hitch. Only men and women who have been employed for a year can take parental leave; workers on contract have no such entitlement. In fact, unless the prime minister's contract says so, he probably isn't entitled to leave either.

There has already been a shift in male perceptions of their roles in childcare to judge by attendance levels in the delivery room. According to the Maternity Alliance, more than 90% share the experience of childbirth, and employers rarely object now. However, men take the time from holiday entitlement, usually spending a few days at home afterwards. The government does not expect more than 2% of men to take up paternity leave - but 35% of women will. The change in the law is not a great advance.

To make a real difference, Cherie Booth should lean on her husband to take a week off every year until their child is five. But Tony Blair is not the unconventional Paavo Lipponen: the 58-year-old Finnish PM courted disapproval in his own country by living with his 32-year-old partner - both were divorced and had children already - and marrying only when a baby was on the way. She is Paivi Hertzberg, a history teacher.

By taking paternity leave, Lipponen sent an important message to his fellow countryment: no one, not even a prime minister, is indispensable at work. That may not be a position Tony Blair will want to endorse.

Bonding with baby: Do men need or want time off?

John Humphrys, broadcaster and expectant father

"I'm not having any. I can't see the point. I'm not the one having the baby. If I were, then I'd want maternity leave, but I'm not. I'm freelance anyway, but even if I were able to take it I doubt that I would."

John Brown, John Brown Publishing

"We give parental leave to everybody, but in my experience - personal and as an employer - a lot of people want an excuse to come back to work quickly. I think it's right to take a few days, but, especially with the first child, you come back to the office for some peace and quiet. Of course, men should have some time off."

Allon Reich, head of film, Miramax Films UK. Two children, aged two and four

"I took roughly two weeks when my children were born and there was no sense of it being frowned upon, in fact the Weinstein brothers [his employers] sent me a hamper from Harrods when my latest was born. I had a paternity leave clause written into my contract at Miramax."

John Griffiths, managing director of the billion-dollar Intershop. Three children aged ten, eight, five

"I didn't take paternity leave. I couldn't afford to. We were all on crazy working hours then and taking more than your standard two weeks a year would have been frowned upon. If I had a fourth child, I would take leave. It is more socially acceptable now. Besides, it is my company and I can do what I like."

Rowley Leigh, chef at Kensington Place, London. Two children, aged fourteen, eleven and two

"Most men do try to take a week off but it's always at the wrong time: the baby's always early or late. Most men take it as holiday; we don't give leave and I don't think it should be statutory. I took a week for my youngest, but I had a lot of staff to cover for me. In this job, it's not easy."

Andrew Robertson, chief executive, Abbot Mead Vickers advertising agency. Three children, aged eleven, eight, seven

"I took paternity leave each time - not longer than a week, but more than a few days. We encourage it for women and men and it is certainly not to be frowned upon. We generally find men will not take their full entitlement, but most will take some sort of leave."

To make a real difference, Cherie Booth should lean on her husband to take a week off every year until their child is five. But Tony Blair is not the unconventional Paavo Lipponen: the 58-year-old Finnish PM courted disapproval in his own country by living with his 32-year-old partner - both were divorced and had children already - and marrying only when a baby was on the way. She is Paivi Hertzberg, a history teacher. By taking paternity leave, Lipponen sent an important message to his fellow countryment: no one, not even a prime minister, is indispensable at work. That may not be a position Tony Blair will want to endorse. Bonding with baby: Do men need or want time off? John Humphrys, broadcaster and expectant father "I'm not having any. I can't see the point. I'm not the one having the baby. If I were, then I'd want maternity leave, but I'm not. I'm freelance anyway, but even if I were able to take it I doubt that I would." John Brown, John Brown Publishing "We give parental leave to everybody, but in my experience - personal and as an employer - a lot of people want an excuse to come back to work quickly. I think it's right to take a few days, but, especially with the first child, you come back to the office for some peace and quiet. Of course, men should have some time off." Allon Reich, head of film, Miramax Films UK. Two children, aged two and four "I took roughly two weeks when my children were born and there was no sense of it being frowned upon, in fact the Weinstein brothers [his employers] sent me a hamper from Harrods when my latest was born. I had a paternity leave clause written into my contract at Miramax." John Griffiths, managing director of the billion-dollar Intershop. Three children aged ten, eight, five "I didn't take paternity leave. I couldn't afford to. We were all on crazy working hours then and taking more than your standard two weeks a year would have been frowned upon. If I had a fourth child, I would take leave. It is more socially acceptable now. Besides, it is my company and I can do what I like." Rowley Leigh, chef at Kensington Place, London. Two children, aged fourteen, eleven and two "Most men do try to take a week off but it's always at the wrong time: the baby's always early or late. Most men take it as holiday; we don't give leave and I don't think it should be statutory. I took a week for my youngest, but I had a lot of staff to cover for me. In this job, it's not easy." Andrew Robertson, chief executive, Abbot Mead Vickers advertising agency. Three children, aged eleven, eight, seven "I took paternity leave each time - not longer than a week, but more than a few days. We encourage it for women and men and it is certainly not to be frowned upon. We generally find men will not take their full entitlement, but most will take some sort of leave."

webTitle: Abuse and graffiti at BMW dealer's

fields.headline: Abuse and graffiti at BMW dealer's
fields.standfirst: Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Robert Sherry at Clark's dealership has been left in no doubt about the strength of anti-BMW feeling among Rover's workforce, thanks to his showroom's prime location 50 yards from the Longbridge plant in the West Midlands.
fields.body:
Robert Sherry at Clark's dealership has been left in no doubt about the strength of anti-BMW feeling among Rover's workforce, thanks to his showroom's prime location 50 yards from the Longbridge plant in the West Midlands.

Last week he arrived to find "scum" in red spraypaint on the BMW signs outside his showroom, which offers BMW motorcycles and Rover cars for sale.

Mr Sherry, 28, the dealer principal, said: "You can understand how people feel. There's a lot of anti-German feeling. We've also had abusive phone calls, people hurling abuse at us across the forecourt and even people driving past shouting.

"What can you do? We've still got a business to run at the end of the day. I don't approve of vandalism, but you can understand that feelings are riding high. We've got the whole of the West Midlands economy on the line here, so I can completely understand where they're coming from.

"It's good to see everyone rallying together to try to put public pressure on to get this decision reversed, but I think it's going to get worse before it gets better.

"The staff are taking it in their stride, but we're being extremely vigilant. We haven't had any windows smashed - not yet, anyway - but there's a big march planned for April 1, and I'm worried about what will happen then. I can just see them trashing our signs on the television news. I just hope people have the sense to realise that our future is tied up with theirs.

"There have been a few cancelled Rover sales but no effect on BMW sales yet. We sell about 1,000 Rovers a year through our three showrooms, so Rover is a very big part of our business. If that side goes down, then the rest of the company will probably end up in the same predicament.

"My job is on the line as much as anybody else's around here. People say I can always get another franchise, but there'll be no one left to buy cars."

fields.headline: Law Society's deputy quits
fields.standfirst: Resignation follows reports that staff were bullied
fields.trailText: The Law Society's vice-president, Kamlesh Bahl, who was suspended last week after she was branded a bully at work by an independent inquiry, resigned from her post yesterday.
fields.body:
The Law Society's vice-president, Kamlesh Bahl, who was suspended last week after she was branded a bully at work by an independent inquiry, resigned from her post yesterday.

Ms Bahl decided to quit just in time to stop copies of the damning inquiry report going out to all 80,000 solicitor members of the society in England and Wales.

She had been in line to become the society's first woman and ethnic minority president in July, when five members of staff, including four of the most senior officials, lodged complaints of harassment.

The inquiry panel, headed by a retired law lord, Lord Griffiths, found her treatment of staff "at times demeaning and humiliating and at other times offensively aggressive." The society's 75-member council voted overwhelmingly to suspend her.

A special general meeting is due on April 19 to decide if she should be expelled from the council. The council has yet to decide whether this meeting will go ahead.

The resignation means the report will not now be sent out to all the society's members.

In the wake of the damning report, Ms Bahl filed a claim for sex and race discrimination against the society - a charge described by officials as outrageous - refused to resign and went on television to put her case.

But yesterday she said she had decided to resign because the Law Society had given her no opportunity to put her side and had decided in her absence to suspend her as vice-president. She believed she had been treated unfairly and would not get just treatment.

She said the stress of the investigation had been compounded by the death last week of her sister-in-law.

She added: "I believe this matter has gone on long enough. I believe the price I have had to pay for trying to reform the Law Society has been to be labelled a bully. I went in with a mandate for reform and this is what has happened. I have been fighting single-handedly against a massive establishment that doesn't want me to be there. I believe I have been treated unfairly throughout this whole episode - it has been a witch hunt. It has put me under the most enormous stress".

She said she was subjected to "ritual public humiliation" when the report came out and again last Thursday when she was suspended. "The Griffiths report at worst is me shouting at people or telling them off in front of others. Compare that with the treatment I've had."

A leaked copy of the report showed Lord Griffiths's inquiry had found Ms Bahl had driven staff to tears, publicly humiliated them, subjected them to "verbal onslaughts" and "introduced an atmosphere of fear and confusion in the line of command."

Allegations of bullying were also made against her in her former post as chairman of the Equal Opportunities Commission, according to union sources. MSF, the union representing Law Society staff, said the resignation was an "appropriate response" given the findings of the inquiry.

Peter Skyte, a regional officer, said: "This landmark case should demonstrate that people found to have bullied employees will pay a high price."

fields.headline: Desk therapist
fields.standfirst:
We showed psychologist Donna Dawson the desk of comedian Nina Wadia
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: We showed psychologist Donna Dawson the desk of comedian Nina Wadia.
fields.body:
The person who works at this desk is fast-moving and extrovert. Technology is consigned to the upper shelf to make space for creative work; the keyboard indicates that the work involves music. The boxes on the right are stacked in a precarious arrangement which suggests originality, a sense of daring and mischief. The flowers and photograph reveal a sentimental, affectionate person, their yellow and dark pink colours suggesting that this affection can be physical, even slightly aggressive, though her head will usually rule her heart.

The yellow reveals an idealistic, imaginative person who is young-at-heart (the space invader gun and the cartoon-bird mousemat). It also reveals a person who has high expectations, and who is able to think clearly. She may not have time to organise things (the trays full of paperwork mixed with photographs) and is slightly scatty. The pen crossed over the notepad suggests a person who works fast - she'd rather be somewhere else.

This is an original thinker with a real zest for life and a great sense of humour; however, the humour is always balanced by hard work. Is this the desk of Victoria Wood?

Did our expert get it right?
Nina Wadia responds: "It's spot on - especially her comments about the way the boxes are stacked because I do like balancing things. I'm a Sagittarian and it reminds me of reading astrologer Linda Goodman's stuff."

 Nina Wadia stars in Perfect World on BBC2 on Friday BBC2 at 9.30pm.

webTitle: Time to stock up on old-style shares

fields.headline: Time to stock up on old-style shares
fields.standfirst:
Market forces
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: After the hype, the reality. Lastminute.com and World Online, two of Europe's highest profile and most recent internet flotations, yesterday offered a reminder that not every dot.com investment guarantees an instant profit.
fields.body:
After the hype, the reality. Lastminute.com and World Online, two of Europe's highest profile and most recent internet flotations, yesterday offered a reminder that not every dot.com investment guarantees an instant profit.

Both floated last week amid much fanfare, both ended yesterday below their issue prices.

Heavy selling across the technology and internet sectors on New York's Nasdaq and the European exchange's has not helped the performance of their shares and almost every rival stock has taken a beating. FTSE 100 newcomers Baltimore, Freeserve and Psion all encountered heavy selling early yesterday.

But analysts believe more fundamental changes are occurring. Just a few weeks ago Lastminute and World Online would have expected to be trading way above their issue prices but the market for internet stocks is evolving fast and there are now fewer certainties than ever.

A shift in supply and demand is also taking place. When Freeserve floated last July the scarcity of listed UK internet stocks fuelled much of the buying. Although more money is pouring into the sector than ever before, investors now have a wider choice of investments.

"Not all internet companies are the same," said one leading internet analyst yesterday. "At the moment good and bad are being accorded similar ratings. It looks like a shake-out is happening."

Hence World Online's problem. Though well branded by a strong management team many analysts believe it has spread itself too thin. It has a presence in most of the key European markets but does not dominate in any of them. Analysts say fund managers now have the choice and are better served by investing in domestic market leaders. Why would German investors buy into World Online when they can apply for shares in T-Online, the market leading internet service provider soon to be spun out of Deutsche Telekom.

An article in Barron's, the respected US finance journal, has added to concerns that many internet companies may not survive.

This week's issue examines the impending cash crunch for weaker net companies. "Dozens of internet companies are likely to implode this year as they burn through their cash," it says, naming Amazon and eToys on a list of firms its predicts could run out of cash within 12 month.

Many analysts agree. "A majority of internet companies (we estimate up to 75%) will never make money and will eventually disappear, either through consolidation or business failure," says Merrill Lynch analyst Henry Blodget.

A retreat to bombed-out old economy stocks, where many believe the potential for upside is great, seems attractive.

fields.headline: Help for the frontier-free industry
fields.trailText: The government yesterday moved to plug the shortage of highly skilled IT workers in Britain by announcing a relaxation on work restrictions constraining firms from hiring foreigners.
fields.body:
The government yesterday moved to plug the shortage of highly skilled IT workers in Britain by announcing a relaxation on work restrictions constraining firms from hiring foreigners.

The chancellor said incentives were needed to help Britain catch up with America in e-commerce as swiftly as possible.

"We are determined to lead in e-commerce and the internet," Mr Brown said. "We are introducing new rules for work permits in areas of highly skilled information technology where there is a global shortage."

He did not do into detail about how the work permit laws would be changed, but his move was welcomed by technology firms and industry.

Robbie Vann-Adibe, co-founder of US web services firm Viant, said: "We have stressed the need for this pretty strongly in our discussions with the government. We haven't said it prevents us from doing business here but if they are really serious about making the UK a leader in the e-commerce space you need to do this."

Viant, worth $1.7bn (£1.1bn) on the Nasdaq market, set up its British arm last year and currently employs about 30 staff locally. "It means that importing that help from operations overseas allows the knowledge transfer to local staff," Mr Vann-Adibe said.

India has a large pool of skilled and cheap IT professionals. However, cumber some and bureaucratic laws have much it difficult to recruit staff from there. Firms have also looked at Eastern European countries from where to source IT staff.

The government's decision to review the rules comes after months of consultation with British technology firms, recruitment houses and industry bodies who were demanding that it be made easier to hire.

The move follows last month's decision by the German government to allow thousands of IT staff into the country on long term visas.

Philip Collins, a PricewaterhouseCoopers partner specialising in internet firms, said the government's decision had partly been forced by the lack of economic or political boundaries in e-commerce.

"This just reflects the way the economy has had to adjust in the same way that businesses have had to adjust to the internet," he said. "Restrictions are coming off business and transactions costs are becoming cheaper so that means the rest of economy has to change to match that."

The number of work permit applications has grown 60% to 80,000 in the past five years. However, it is estimated by the National Computer Centre that up to 100,000 vacancies exist in the IT sector. In Europe, there the numbers are forecast to be higher around 500,000 growing to possibly 1.2m in the next few years.

Britain's universities are said to not be generating the number of employees in this field to meet such an appetite.

fields.headline: Tenderness and rage
fields.standfirst:
BBC Symphony Orchestra/ Jiri Belohlavek
Royal Festival Hall, London
****
fields.trailText: A whiff of political vehemence - intentional or not - hung over Jiri Belohlavek's concert with the BBC Symphony. The featured composers were all Austrian, and the culminating work, Zemlinsky's setting of Psalm 13 served as a reminder of the horror of events in Austria's past which find deep resonance in its troubling present.
fields.body:
A whiff of political vehemence - intentional or not - hung over Jiri Belohlavek's concert with the BBC Symphony. The featured composers were all Austrian, and the culminating work, Zemlinsky's setting of Psalm 13 served as a reminder of the horror of events in Austria's past which find deep resonance in its troubling present.

Zemlinsky, who was Jewish, wrote the work in 1935, two years after Hitler came to power, three years before the Austrians welcomed the Nazis and Zemlinsky fled to a neglected future and an unhappy death in New York. It's a writing-on-the-wall piece, forcing home the quiet realisation that with the Freedom party now embroiled in Austria's government, the metaphorical inscription is back in place.

Stylistically it's at a tangent from the rest of Zemlinsky's output. He abandons his usual post-Romantic succulence for something both uncompromising and retrospective. The overlapping choral writing peers back through Brahms (who abandoned Hamburg for cosmopolitan Vienna in 1863) to Haydn. The traditional Jewish melody that forms the opening choral interjection ("O Lord, how long wilt thou hide thy face from me?") is accompanied by relentless timpani figurations that suggest Brahms's Requiem.

The piece is heavy with a sense of cultural traditions under threat. Its final section is less a blaze of glory than a shriek of rage. It was counterposed with another of his Psalm settings, No 23, written in 1910, when Zemlinsky was basking in Vienna's Jugendstil glory days. It draws heavily on Mahler (Zemlinsky's great hero) and is in some respects an optimistic rerun of Das Lied von der Erde, using a comparable musical language to depict the "green pastures" and "still waters" in which both the psalmist and Zemlinsky find contentment. The Czech conductor Jiri Belohlavek approaches both works with glowing commitment, proud, perhaps, of Zemlinsky's association with Prague, where he lived in the 20s.

The golden age of Austrian humaneness was represented in the concert by Mozart and Haydn. Alfred Brendel was the soloist in Mozart's D Minor Piano Concerto, No 20. The work has often been described as a trial run for Don Giovanni - and Brendel's playing seemed to seduce the turbulent orchestra into lustrous quiescence. Belohlavek, meanwhile, is outstanding in Haydn, whose 96th Symphony ebbed and flowed with tender warmth.

webTitle: The Man with the Absurdly Large Penis

fields.headline: The Man with the Absurdly Large Penis
fields.standfirst:
**
Young Vic, London
fields.trailText: Size really does matter in Rob Young's monologue about a man from south London who is suffering from Proteus syndrome. John Dixon is ordinary in every way - in his desires, his needs, his everyday concerns. But his penis is 102cm long, contains almost three litres of blood and comprises 50% of his body weight.
fields.body:
Size really does matter in Rob Young's monologue about a man from south London who is suffering from Proteus syndrome. John Dixon is ordinary in every way - in his desires, his needs, his everyday concerns. But his penis is 102cm long, contains almost three litres of blood and comprises 50% of his body weight. The stirring of an erection starves his brain of oxygen, causing near-fatal blackouts. For John the orgasm is not a little death but the big one.

In the circumstances, John is not a man to rub up the wrong way. He censors every aspect of his life to avoid erotic stimulation but cannot censor his need for love. Reading the small ads in Loot is a wild thrill for John. Then he meets Ruth, a tart with a heart from Stockwell, who takes one look at what's in John's shopping trolley and whisks him off to Hastings, where John gets that floating feeling that means it must be love.

It is hard to write about this hour-long show without resorting to the puerile because it takes itself so seriously, failing to acknowledge that there might be something even remotely funny in John's predicament. The real wonder is that a piece of writing so absurdly small should have made it on to the stage in the first place.

But Simon Vincenzi's clever production, with its fleet of glowing red Zeppelin-style organs hanging from the ceiling, its aching lighting and strange, unsettling soundtrack, gives the evening an extra dimension and a weightiness that the piece otherwise lacks.

There is a marvellous performance too from Laurence Harvey, who stands immobile like a beached whale for the whole performance and whose understated, deadpan delivery conveys all the bemused pain of a very ordinary man in an extraordinary situation.

 Till April 1. Box office: 0171-928 6363.
fields.bodyText: Size really does matter in Rob Young's monologue about a man from south London who is suffering from Proteus syndrome. John Dixon is ordinary in every way - in his desires, his needs, his everyday concerns. But his penis is 102cm long, contains almost three litres of blood and comprises 50% of his body weight. The stirring of an erection starves his brain of oxygen, causing near-fatal blackouts. For John the orgasm is not a little death but the big one. In the circumstances, John is not a man to rub up the wrong way. He censors every aspect of his life to avoid erotic stimulation but cannot censor his need for love. Reading the small ads in Loot is a wild thrill for John. Then he meets Ruth, a tart with a heart from Stockwell, who takes one look at what's in John's shopping trolley and whisks him off to Hastings, where John gets that floating feeling that means it must be love. It is hard to write about this hour-long show without resorting to the puerile because it takes itself so seriously, failing to acknowledge that there might be something even remotely funny in John's predicament. The real wonder is that a piece of writing so absurdly small should have made it on to the stage in the first place. But Simon Vincenzi's clever production, with its fleet of glowing red Zeppelin-style organs hanging from the ceiling, its aching lighting and strange, unsettling soundtrack, gives the evening an extra dimension and a weightiness that the piece otherwise lacks. There is a marvellous performance too from Laurence Harvey, who stands immobile like a beached whale for the whole performance and whose understated, deadpan delivery conveys all the bemused pain of a very ordinary man in an extraordinary situation.  Till April 1.
